DOC.TEXT: H. Josef Hebert covers environmental issues for The Associated Press.

DOC.HEAD: Report: Government Hasn't Fixed Most Weapons Plant Hazards
DOC.TEXT: Even the safety and health hazards at the top of 1986 fix-up lists for the government's nuclear weapons plants hadn't been fixed at the beginning of 1990, says a report to Congress. As of January, the government and its contractors had taken care of just 41 percent of the highest priority problems in the weapons complex, and overall had resolved just 34 percent of the health and safety problems identified since 1986, the General Accounting Office said. ``It is shocking that nuclear hazards requiring immediate attention got no attention at all,'' said Sen. Howard Metzenbaum, D-Ohio, who released the report Wednesday with Rep. George Miller, D-Calif. ``Our work raises questions about the (Energy Department's) commitment to resolving its problems in a timely manner,'' said the report by the GAO, Congress' investigative arm. The department refused to comment on the report before officials got a chance to review it. However, the report's authors got their data from the department's computers and discussed the data with DOE officials. ``It would seem to us unlikely that it would reveal anything we weren't already aware of,'' DOE spokesman Robert Griffin said. ``Certainly Admiral Watkins (Secretary James D. Watkins) is aware of the magnitude of the environmental problems faced by the department.'' According to the report, the Energy Department has logged 113 radiation and other problems that posed ``a clear and present danger to workers or the public.'' There were 36 such problems at the Rocky Flats plant in Colorado, of which 23 were resolved; 33 at Savannah River, S.C., of which one was resolved; 30 at the Y-12 Plant in Tennessee, of which 12 were resolved; 14 at the Lawrence Livermore Laboratory in California, of which 10 were resolved. When all types of safety and health problems were added up, the Hanford Nuclear Reservation in Washington state had the largest total, 294, of which 89 had been taken care of. Rocky Flats' total was 262, with 142 problems resolved; and the Feed Material Production Center at Fernald, Ohio, was ranked third with 186 problems, 46 of which were resolved. Data on environmental hazards showed Fernald had more problems than any other plant _ 68 in all. Among the other major plants, Savannah River and Lawrence Livermore were second with 65 environmental problems; Los Alamos, N.M., and Idaho Lab each had 59; Hanford and Y-12 each had 58; Pantex in Amarillo, Texas, had 56; and Portsmouth, Ohio, had 55. At 31 Energy Department-owned nuclear weapons plants and research laboratories, 1,277 environmental problems were logged, including 44 radioactive contamination problems, the report said. ``All of these problems are considered by DOE to be unresolved,'' it said. The department told the GAO none of those 1,277 problems pose an immediate health threat. However, 192 of those problems involve ``a high risk for a threat to health,'' and Fernald had 31 problems in that category _ more than any other plant. The government has acknowledged the environmental problems at the plants, but the report criticized the slow pace at which it has drawn up plans to fix the problems. Nine plants don't have such plans, and where the plans have been completed they were, on average, six months late. ``We know the problems are complex but that is no excuse for DOE's failure even to come with plans to clean up the hundreds of nuclear hazards,'' Metzenbaum said in a statement.

DOC.HEAD: On the Light Side
DOC.TEXT: Sculptor Art Shirer vows his creation ``Shrine to Life'' will remain on display until it rots. Shirer said he will be able to tell the moment his installation of 442 eggs hanging by threads from the ceiling of the Contract Design Center needs to come down. ``We're just gonna have to do an evening sniff test,'' he said. Shirer also has a show of more permanent stone and metal sculptures on display nearby.

The best pitches at Dodger Stadium don't always start on the mound. Up in the stands, peanut vendor Roger Owens can fire bags of goobers to fans up to 30 rows away. Closer to the target, he can make behind-the-back and under-the-leg tosses. Then there's the split-nut shot. Two double bags of peanuts, thrown simultaneously, separate in flight and head toward two targets. And when one hand gives, the other takes. Owens sells an average of 700 bags of peanuts per game at Dodger Stadium _ at a buck each. His all-time record was at Texas Stadium during a Dallas Cowboys game in 1976, when he sold 2,400 single bags. Two years ago, Owens sold 6,000 bags during three days at the Southeast Regionals of the NCAA basketball tournament. The 47-year-old Owens, who pitched baseballs for the Manual Arts High School team years ago, began his career with the Dodgers in 1958 as a soda vendor. He was promoted to peanuts that same season. In search of a sales pitch, he looked to his strong arm and gift of gab. By 1977, he was invited to the presidential inauguration of peanut farmer Jimmy Carter. Owens is writing a biography titled ``The Peanut Man.'' ``It'll show that no matter what job you take, if you do the best you can, you can go to the top,'' Owens said. ``Even with this menial peanut-vending job, I've been able to take it to the top and turn it into a career.''

``Easy listening'' music can do more to put people on edge than silence can, researchers say. Music fans eager to relax should simply reach for the type of music they already enjoy, the researchers said. ``Some people don't relax to certain types of music because they don't like it,'' said Valerie Stratton, a Penn State University assistant professor of psychology. ``The subject might even become more tense than without music,'' said Annette Zalanowski, an assistant professor of music. The pair exposed dozens of people to a variety of music and polled them on how relaxed they felt during each piece. Atonal music from 20th century composers and non-Western music billed as relaxing fared the worst, Stratton said. Rock 'n' roll wasn't used because lyrics could skew a person's true response to the music, she said. Music from India was panned because the 84 college-age people tested were unaccustomed to it, the researchers said. ``No single type of music was most effective in aiding relaxation, and no significant differences were found between soothing and stimulating music,'' the researchers said.

DOC.HEAD: German Industry Seeks U.S. Investment in East Germany, Eastern Europe
DOC.TEXT: West German industry is urging U.S. companies to join in a more-the-merrier spirit and invest in East Germany and elsewhere in Eastern Europe. ``There are vast opportunities for Western business,'' Ludolf von Wartenberg, president of the Federation of German Industries (BDI), said Wednesday in a speech to the American Institute for Contemporary German Studies. Von Wartenberg said West German subsidiaries of American companies, like Ford, General Moters and IBM, are actively looking for investment opportunities like major West German and other West European-owned firms. But he said he came to the United States in part to encourage U.S. companies without a foothold in Europe to join in. ``Japan is very interested,'' he said, noting that it has set up an office in Berlin and is looking to move into East Germany. Von Wartenberg acknowledged that West German companies have a competitive advantage, but said he expected 30 percent of firms in East Germany eventually would be foreign-owned, the same percentage as in West Germany. ``Enormous investments are necessary in infrastructure, above all telecommunications, where the current standards are deplorable, but also roads, railroads, the vast area of financial and consulting services, and to some extent tourism.'' East German industry will have to undergo a drastic transformation because it is so inefficient and polluting, he said. Many plants will have to be rebuilt from the ground up, and the workforce will have to become much more productive.
DOC.HEAD: New Chairman Calls Kennedy Center `Bankrupt'
DOC.TEXT: The John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts is $15 million in debt and needs $30 million worth of renovation, says its new chairman. ``That's a $45 million nut. It's bankrupt,'' James D. Wolfensohn said in an interview published in today's editions of The Washington Post. Wolfensohn said White House Chief of Staff John Sununu promised him that the administration would support the Kennedy Center. ``If they don't come through with the money, I think I'll probably quietly withdraw,'' he said. Wolfensohn said the center has lost money because its programming lacks focus and its board does not provide fund-raising support.
DOC.HEAD: MIT, Other Universities Oppose Pentagon Policy Barring Gays
DOC.TEXT: Several universities are telling the Pentagon a military policy barring homosexuals from service is generating pressure to oust ROTC from their campuses. ``The contradiction between the university's principle of non-discrimination against individuals on the basis of sexual orientation, and the presence of an ROTC that does discriminate, cannot exist on the campuses indefinitely,'' John M. Deutch, provost of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology said in a letter to Defense Secretary Dick Cheney. ``Many universities will withdraw from the ROTC program,'' Deutch wrote. The Department of Defense has declined to comment on the campus challenges on grounds the homosexual ban is being challenged in court. The department has limited responses to a written statement outlining its grounds for barring homosexuals _ that homosexuality is incompatible with military service because of the close quarters in which people of the same sex must live and because of the security risk posed by the possibility of a homosexual officer being blackmailed. Top administrators, faculty groups and students from MIT, the University of Wisconsin, University of Minnesota, Northwestern University and others have actively campaigned against the Reserve Officer Training Corps policy. No ROTC program has been removed from a campus as a result of the opposition.
DOC.HEAD: GM Expediting Electric Car Production, Smith Says
DOC.TEXT: General Motors Corp. is pushing development of an electrically powered car in recognition of consumer demand for a cleaner environment, says GM Chairman Roger B. Smith. The nation's largest automaker intends to be the first to mass-market the vehicle, Smith said in a speech Wednesday to the National Press Club. GM unveiled a prototype vehicle, the Impact, in January. He refused to say when or where the car would be built or to reveal technical information about the vehicle, saying he did not want to tip off competitors. In the 1970s, GM announced it would produce a 1985-model electric car, but it dropped that project long before production. Smith said the goal is to manufacture a car that would match today's safety and performance standards without the air pollution of an internal combustion engine. Generation of the electricity, of course, would create other pollution if fossil fuels were used in the power plant. ``We have set an aggressive schedule for ourselves in order to pull along the technological developments that we still need,'' Smith said. Still needed is a better battery, and Smith said that may require joint development by automakers, utilities, battery manufacturers and the federal government. Though obstacles remain, ``when we look at the strict clean-air legislation that's now being proposed for many areas of the country, we're convinced that the Impact has a bright future.''

Jailhouse Journalist Says His Fame is Keeping Him Behind Bars
LaserPhoto WX8
DOC.TEXT: In the harsh world of the Louisiana State Penitentiary, Wilbert Rideau can do pretty much what he wants _ except get out. In prison for murdering a woman by slitting her throat and stabbing her in the heart, he has become a prize-winning journalist in his 29 years behind bars. But his high profile has led authorities to keep him locked up, says Rideau, who claims he'd be a free man if he had spent his time making license plates instead. ``I've tried to make amends the best I could in the only ways available to me. I've done things that counted over the last 29 years,'' Rideau said in a telephone interview Wednesday. ``That was the only violent act of my life, done when I was a wild teen-ager. If I could change it, I would.'' On Wednesday, the Louisiana Pardon Board recommended _ for the fourth time in six years _ that Rideau be set free. Gov. Buddy Roemer said he is inclined to reject the unanimous recommendation to commute Rideau's life sentence. Rideau is serving time for the 1961 murder of bank teller Julia Ferguson during a robbery in the southwest Louisiana town of Lake Charles. Then 19, he got away with $14,279 stuffed in a suitcase. Wielding his pistol, he forced two tellers and the branch manager into a car. He drove them to a deserted road and shot all three. When Mrs. Ferguson begged for her life, Rideau killed her. The two others survived. Rideau, 48, who fancies designer jeans and cowboy boots as his prison gear, has been called a model inmate by prison officials. The editor of the prison magazine, The Angolite, he also gives lectures to youth groups and gets out to go on national speaking tours on prison reform. Over the years, Rideau, who works out of the magazine office, has had a literary agent and written free-lance articles for up to four figures for publications such as Penthouse. Rideau has won the Robert F. Kennedy Journalism Award, the American Bar Association's Silver Gavel Award and the George Polk Award for special interest reporting. The Polk award came on two articles in The Angolite, ``Prison: a Sexual Jungle,'' dealing with homosexual rape, and ``The Other Side of Murder,'' which told of the aftermath of a killing. The Angolite, which has carried stories on inmate suicides, prison riots, prisoner rights, executions, prison sports and special events, was featured in The New York Times Sunday Magazine and has been praised in Time magazine, The Washington Post and Columbia Journalism Review. Rideau has appeared on national TV, including ABC's ``Nightline,'' on which he was on a five-man panel with former Chief Justice Warren E. Burger in a discussion of prison reform. DOC.HEAD: Stocks Up In Tokyo
DOC.TEXT: The Nikkei Stock Average closed at 29,945.41, up 696.35 points, or 2.38 percent on the Tokyo Stock Exchange Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: Text of Kidnapper's Statement on American Hostage Release
DOC.TEXT: This is the full text of the statement issued by kidnappers of three American educators in Beirut as translated from Arabic into English by The Associated Press: ``The Organization of Islamic Jihad for the Liberation of Palestine persists in the struggle to accomplish its sacred objectives. ``In order to achieve the aims for which the hostages have been held, and since the issue of the hostages has been set at a positive course toward the useful solution for all sides, and after the consensus among people with foresight and those concerned in this crisis that convincing and meaningful formulas should be reached, the organization of Islamic Jihad for the Liberation of Palestine announces the following: ``First: In compliance with the desire and insistence of Islamic leaders, and in response to the emphatic behest of the officials of the Islamic Republic of Iran to initiate a goodwill gesture to begin closing this case, and without forgetting the constant Syrian efforts in this sphere, we have decided to move the hostages affair forward by releasing an American hostage within 48 hours on the basis of reciprocal move to accomplish what is required to accelarate the happy ending. ``Second: We want the humanitarian move to be balanced between both sides. This is a condition to move forward. Otherwise there is no meaning for a one-sided movement. We have responded to the behests, hoping to reach a solution as proposed and on the basis of the verbal message that will be conveyed to President Bush. We are ready to reciprocate or escalate. The other side has to choose. ``Third: The arrangements for the release should be accomplished by the arrival of John Kelly in Damascus to coordinate some final steps to guarantee success within 48 hours. ``Peace upon those who serve justice for the sake of justice, ``The organization of Islamic Jihad for the Liberation of Palestine.''

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Supreme Court OKs Judicial Power to Order Higher Taxes
With PM-Scotus Rdp
DOC.TEXT: A Supreme Court ruling allowing judges to order schools to raise taxes for desegregation wouldn't have come about if lawmakers and the public had met their responsibility, says the head of Kansas City's schools. The high court ruled 9-0 Wednesday that judges cannot directly impose a tax increase, as U.S. District Judge Russell Clark did in the Kansas City case in 1987. But in a 5-4 vote it upheld a federal appeals court decision that Clark could instead order the school board to raise taxes. Julia Hill, newly elected school board president, said the issue wouldn't have even been before the court if voters hadn't turned down school tax increases time and again. ``I would have loved for the previous tax levies to pass when they were presented to the public _ sometimes three times,'' she said at a news conference. ``When democracy fails, sometimes people have to pay. And democracy failed here in Kansas City, and it also failed at the state level. ``All of this could have been alleviated by changing some boundary lines 20 years ago. But nobody did anything, so we're at a state now where we're under a federal court order.'' Before 1954, Missouri law required schools to be racially segregated. In the following 35 years, the percentage of black students in Kansas City's school district rose from 22.5 percent to about 75 percent. Black parents sued in 1977 over the decline of what had become predominantly black schools, alleging black students were being denied equal educational opportunities. Clark ruled in 1987 that the schools ``have literally rotted,'' and ordered state and district officials to upgrade them. He ordered the state to pay three-fourths of the remedial costs and the school district the rest. District voters had rejected six proposals since 1970 to raise taxes for education. Clark had nearly doubled the local property tax from $2.05 to $4 per $100 of assessed valuation to help finance the improvements. The increase raised about $30 million. Civil rights forces praised the Supreme Court decision. ``It's a powerful reaffirmation that state laws may not impede the vindication of constitutional rights, the rights of school children,'' said Paul Holtzman of the Washington-based Lawyers' Committee for Civil Rights Under Law.

DOC.HEAD: State to Demolish 34 Buildings on Seedy Times Square
DOC.TEXT: The peep shows and X-rated theaters of Times Square will give way to four new office towers now that the state has won the right to demolish 34 buildings in a long-delayed, $2.5 billion renewal project. State and city officials hope that replacing the sex shops and other run-down buildings will revitalze the area and rout the prostitutes, drug pushers and muggers that give Times Square its seedy reputation. State Supreme Court Justice Stanley J. Parness signed an order Wednesday giving the state Urban Development Corp. title to the 34 properties. The project, first approved in 1984, is the nation's largest urban redevelopment project. ``After seven years, after 48 lawsuits, we are finally taking possession of the property,'' said state Director of Economic Development Vincent Tese. ``We now own it.'' The tenants will be moved out and demolition could begin as early as summer, he said. Critics charge that the towers are too big, the tax abatements granted to builders too large and the real estate market too soft to warrant the new office space. But backers say the project will create 16,000 construction jobs and 20,000 permanent jobs when the towers are completed in four years. The buildings will be glitzed up with neon signs, lights and mirrors to preserve the area's character. The developers also plan to renovate the dilapidated Times Square subway station and nine theaters. The idea is to discourage drug dealers, muggers, con artists and prostitutes in an area where 2,246 felonies were reported on 42nd Street between Broadway and Eighth Avenue in 1988. ``This is a milestone for the economy of New York,'' Gov. Mario Cuomo said. ``It will make 42nd Street a safe, productive part of the city's entertainment district.'' The project's developers, Prudential Insurance Co. and Park Tower Realty, have put up $241 million to compensate the landowners. Gary Rosenberg, lawyer for the Durst Organization, which filed three lawsuits against the project, said his organization had 30 days to decide whether to appeal the condemnation order. In the last year, Durst acquired 70-year leaseholds for eight theaters. Despite the threat of condemnation, it is renovating the theaters and has spent more than $3 million so far to repair roofs and facades. A hotel and merchandise mart are also on the drawing board. Tese said Wednesday's decision also should spur action on those plans.

DOC.HEAD: RETRANSMITTING
Sex of Embryos Revealed by New Technique Before Pregnancy Begins
DOC.TEXT: Women who sought to have baby girls have been impregnated with female embryos selected from a test tube, scientists reported today. The results, obtained by way of a new embryo-screening procedure designed to prevent genetic diseases, are the first reported pregnancies using embryos tested to reveal gender, researchers said in the British journal Nature. Two of three pregnant women expect twins this summer, study co-author Alan Handyside said in a telephone interview. The third expects one child, he said. The laboratory test identified the sex of the microscopic embryos only three days after fertilization, he said. The women were at risk of transmitting serious genetic diseases to a male child, Handyside said. The test also could be used without a medical justification to select the sex of a child. But Handyside said he would consider that unethical. Further research might provide a way to screen out embryos that would develop serious genetic diseases, thereby removing the prospect of abortions in those cases, researchers said. The work was reported by Handyside and colleagues at the Royal Postgraduate Medical School at Hammsmith Hospital in London. Lab techniques have been used before to determine a baby's sex. In 1986, a New Orleans fertility institute announced the birth of a boy whose sex had been selected during ``in vitro'' fertilization, which is done in the laboratory. That case involved selecting sperm to produce a boy. But sperm selection has not proved reliable, said Dr. Maria Bustillo of the Genetics and IVF Institute in Fairfax, Va. And it does not hold the promise of diagnosing genetic diseases before an embryo is implanted, as embryo analysis does, she said Wednesday. It is not clear how many couples would choose the embryo analysis, which requires in vitro fertilization, rather than conceiving naturally and then considering an abortion after undergoing a standard genetic analysis of the fetus, she said. But it may be possible someday to allow a woman to conceive naturally and then flush out the embryo for analysis, she said, then reimplant it if desired. Some 200 genetic diseases that typically affect only boys have been identified, including the most severe form of muscular dystrophy, hemophilia and a form of mental retardation, Handyside said. The embryo analysis involves collecting eggs from a woman, fertilizing them in a test tube and letting them grow to eight-cell embryos. A single cell is removed from each embryo to see if it contains a bit of genetic material that indicates the presence of a Y chromosome, which would mean the embryo is destined to become a boy. The three pregnant women were each given two embryos to increase the chance of pregnancy, Handyside said. For families that risk passing on serious genetic disease to males, the embryo procedure should be less emotionally trying than an abortion, said pediatrician and ethicist Dr. Kathleen Nolan at the Hastings Center in Briarcliff Manor, N.Y. She and ethicist Arthur Caplan at the University of Minnesota said the technique is probably too cumbersome and costly to make it widely popular for choosing a baby's sex without any medical reason. But they said thorny issues could arise if researchers find an easier way to analyze genetic traits of an embryo and learn to predict a variety of diseases and personal traits. Many people would oppose using embryo analysis to pick a child's hair color or sex for no medical reason, just as many would support use of the technique if the embryo were certain to develop a serious disease, Nolan said. But between those two extremes lies ``a huge gray zone'' in terms of how to decide an embryo ``isn't good enough'' for implantation, she said. ``Some might consider it socially very undesirable for a woman to take a 50 percent chance of having a child who is going to be obese ... since those children are likely to get into more medical problems and cost the society,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Nikkei Soars, Dollar Dives
DOC.TEXT: Prices on the Tokyo Stock Exchange soared Thursday, while the dollar closed sharply lower against the yen. The 225-issue Nikkei Stock Average, which rose 787.46 points on Wednesday, added another 696.35 points, or 2.38 percent, to end the day at 29,945.41. The dollar closed at 157.75 yen, down 2.12 yen from Wednesday's close of 159.87 yen. The currency opened at 158.35 yen and ranged between 157.60 yen and 158.50 yen. Traders attributed the Nikkei index's surge largely to the yen's strength against the dollar. ``Inspired by the yen's recovery, market players started buying issues to which they have been paying little attention,'' said a trader with Yamaichi Securities Co., speaking on condition of anonymity. He said the market appears to have entered a rising phase after a series of plunges earlier this year. Currency dealers said the dollar's slide followed its downswing in New York Wednesday, despite a report of a sharp improvement in the U.S. merchandise trade figures for February. ``Japanese investors had bought the dollar earlier expecting the improvement in the U.S. trade deficit, and they started selling the dollar before the figure actually came out yesterday,'' said Minori Takeuchi, a dealer with Chemical Bank in Tokyo. The trade deficit narrowed to $6.49 billion in February, its lowest level in six years, from a revised $9.32 billion in January, largely because of a sharp drop in oil imports. Past improvements in the trade deficit have usually helped the dollar, but some analysts suggested that the latest improvement may not last. ``Many market players are still doubtful that the decrease in the U.S. deficit will continue,'' Ms. Takeuchi said. She said investors are trying to test the dollar's bottom, and added, ``The dollar will slide as low as 157 yen.'' The price of the benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bond was quoted at 86.26 points, up from Wednesday's close of 86.14. That dropped the yield to 7.31 percent from 7.335 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Ammo in Economic Arsenals of Lithuania, Soviet Union
With PM-Lithuania, Bjt
DOC.TEXT:
Here's a look at what is at stake economically for Lithuania and the Soviet Union if the Baltic republic is isolated:
IN THE SOVIET ECONOMIC ARSENAL _ Lithuania receives all of its oil, gas and diesel fuel from the Soviet Union, paying subsidized prices. At world market prices, Lithuania would run a deficit of $700 million for oil alone. _ It also receives all of its metals, cotton, tractors and automobiles from the Soviet Union. _ It receives 58 percent of its sugar from Cuba, via the Soviet Union. _ It receives 37 percent of its concentrated fertilizer from the Soviet Union. Cotton, 100 percent. _ It received 400,000 tons of grain from the Soviets in 1989. _ It has only four to five days' supply of newsprint, and the Soviets could cut off the supply, thus shutting down its newspapers.
IN LITHUANIA'S ECONOMIC ARSENAL _ The republic sends to the Soviet Union 1.5 percent of the nation's total production, including household electrical meters (100 percent); television set components (70 percent); and tractor components (30 percent). _ It produces much more meat (530,000 metric tons in 1987), eggs (1.2 million metric tons in 1987), milk (3.1 million metric tons in 1987) and other dairy products than it consumes, so it could cut off the rest of the Soviet Union from its surplus. _ Textile products are shipped to factories in the Soviet Union, including one plant in Leningrad that employs 18,000 workers. _ The shutdown of the pipeline to the Mazeikiai refinery also means a curtailment of supplies to the republics of Estonia, Latvia and Byelorussia. A shutdown of a natural gas pipeline would interrupt the flow of gas to Kaliningrad, part of the Russian republic west of Lithuania. _ Lithuania could demand world prices for exporting Soviet products through its Baltic ports, including Klaipeda.

DOC.HEAD: One of Three Hemophiliac Brothers Gets AIDS
DOC.TEXT: Robert Ray, one of three AIDS-exposed hemophiliac brothers who won a court battle to go to school only to be burned out of their home by an arsonist, has developed the disease, his mother says. The Ray family learned about two months ago that 12-year-old Robert had AIDS, his mother, Louise Ray, said Wednesday. The body was taken out of school to study at home, she said. ``It was our decision because of his mood swings. One minute he's fine, the next he may be crying. It's embarrassing enough. But then to be crying in front of your friends. And it's something uncontrollable,'' she said. Robert, who had been the healthiest of the three boys, is the first to progress to the disease. Ricky, 13, and Randy, 11, also are infected with the AIDS virus. Doctors say all three were exposed to the virus through tainted blood products used to treat their hemophilia before screening began in 1985. Four years ago, the boys were barred from school in Arcadia and then in Bay Minette, Ala., but in 1987 they were reinstated in Arcadia by a federal judge. Many parents kept their children home in protest. At the end of the first week of class, the Rays' house burned down, an unsolved arson. The family moved to Sarasota, where the boys and their virus-free sister enrolled without incident. Robert ``still swims in the pool, rides his bike,'' his mother said. ``He's doing as well as can be expected. With AIDS you don't know what to expect.''

DOC.HEAD: Police Call Eye Injury Bogus
DOC.TEXT: A woman has been charged with using eye shadow to fake a black eye to obtain a protection order against her estranged husband. Mary Gael MacPhail, 43, of Ligonier Township was arraigned on charges of fabricating evidence and criminal solicitation. Authorities said Mrs. MacPhail coerced her housekeeper into applying the makeup. The housekeeper, Janice Claypool, also told investigators she used makeup to darken bruises on Mrs. MacPhail's arms and legs. Mrs. MacPhail also was charged with forging her husband's signature on five prescriptions. Mrs. MacPhail and her husband, Dr. John MacPhail, an orthopedic surgeon, are getting divorced.

DOC.HEAD: Eight More Sheriff's Officers Snared in Investigation
DOC.TEXT: Eight more sheriff's officers have been suspended in an internal investigation into skimming of drug money in the department's narcotics bureau, bringing to 27 the number relieved of duty. The seven deputies and one sergeant suspended Wednesday were summoned to City Hall in suburban Santa Fe Springs, relieved of their weapons and badges and questioned, the department said. They were suspended with pay. They joined 18 other officers from the narcotics bureau and another officer outside the unit who have been suspended in the 18-month-old probe. Sheriff Sherman Block declined to elaborate on why the eight were suspended, but the inquiry has focused on allegations officers skimmed money seized from suspected drug dealers. Ten deputies suspended earlier and one of their wives were indicted on charges of stealing more than $1.4 million and using it to buy cars, homes and stocks. ``Although we are saddened by the necessity for this action, the more than 11,000 honest and hard working men and women of the Sheriff's Department will continue, as they have, to do their jobs within integrity,'' said Sheriff Block, who is up for re-election this year. About two years ago the narcotics bureau had 120 deputies and sergeants. Current numbers were not released. The inquiry has hurt at least a dozen drug prosecutions. Most recently, a convicted dealer serving a five-year sentence was freed from prison in December after the judge learned sheriff's investigators may have falsified evidence. Prosecutors said deputies may have lied about the circumstances that led to a search of Trosper Parie's apartment and discovery of more than 11 pounds of cocaine.

DOC.HEAD: Mexico Warns U.S. Of Possible Cut In Anti-Drug Cooperation
DOC.TEXT: Mexico says it could curtail joint anti-drug operations with the United States if it confirms reports that bounty hunters kidnapped a Mexican doctor to face charges in the murder of a U.S. drug agent. The government said Attorney General Enrique Alvarez del Castillo delivered the warning to U.S. Attorney General Richard Thornburgh on Wednesday. Dr. Humberto Alvarez Machain, a suspect in the 1985 torture-slaying of U.S. drug agent Enrique ``Kiki'' Camarena, was arrested April 3 in El Paso, Texas. He had reportedly been kidnapped at his Guadalajara office the previous day. Some news reports have said Alvarez Machain was kidnapped by bounty hunters seeking a $100,000 reward offered by the U.S. Drug Enforcement Adminstration. The agency has refused to comment on how he arrived in the United States. Other reports say Mexican federal police took Alvarez Machain to the United States. The Mexican attorney general's office denies this and the government said Tuesday it had asked the U.S. State Department to explain how he was apprehended. Another investigation has been opened by Mexico's Congress, where lawmakers are complaining of an affront to their country's sovereignty. Alvarez del Castillo and Thornburgh met Wednesday during a regional drug enforcement conference. ``The Mexican attorney general told the U.S. official that it is the exclusive province of Mexican authorities to fight narcotics trafficking in all its forms within its own territory,'' the government said in a statement. ``If it is proved that the suspect was kidnapped and illegally taken to the United States by authorities of that country, it endangers the bilateral cooperation in the fight against drug trafficking, which until now have been excellent,'' the statement said. Thornburgh says he has ordered an investigation into the case. The Los Angeles Times on Wednesday quoted unnamed Mexican sources as saying Alvarez Machain's abduction was arranged by agents in the Los Angeles DEA office without the knowledge of their superiors in Washington. Alvarez Machain, 42, is one of 19 Mexicans indicted by a federal grand jury in Los Angeles on charges of kidnapping, torturing and killing Camarena, a DEA special agent. He was arraigned earlier this month and pleaded innocent. U.S. prosecutors allege that Camarena was abducted by drug traffickers and tortured by Mexican officials about DEA activities in Mexico and charges against suspected participants in the abduction and murder have strained U.S.-Mexican relations. U.S. law enforcement officials say Mexico failed to respond to their requests to extradite several defendants. Mexican officials say the United States had never requested the extradition of anyone. A Jan. 31 indictment returned in Los Angeles contained the latest charges in the case. Besides Alvarez Machain, it named Manuel Ibarra Herrera, former director of the Mexican Federal Judicial Police, and Miguel Aldana Ibarra, former head of the Mexican office of Interpol, the international law enforcement agency. Alvarez Machain's lawyer, Robert Steinberg, says his client was kidnapped but that he would not raise the abduction as a legal issue because prior rulings in similar cases said, in effect, ``too bad, but they're here.'' Steinberg said Alvarez Machain was taken from his Guadalajara office on April 2 by five men who identified themselves as Mexican federal police and told the gynecologist he was under arrest for performing illegal abortions. He said that the next day the group placed Alvarez Machain on a plane to El Paso, where he was arrested by a DEA agent. They say fingerprints on a syringe used to drug Camarena were traced to Alvarez Machain, who allegedly revived the DEA agent when he lost consciousness after being beaten. Alvarez Machain is to face trial in Los Angeles on May 1 along with four other defendants in the case.

DOC.HEAD: Current Quotations
DOC.TEXT: ``If you look up history, this kind of coincidence happens many times. I don't think it is really statistically significant.'' _ Seismologist Hiroo Kanamori of the California Institute of Technology on a barrage of earthquakes during a two-day period this week in California, Indiana and Asia.

``What I sent to those congressmen is as filthy as anything I've ever seen.'' _ The Rev. Donald Wildmon, director of the Tupelo, Miss.-based American Family Association, which is blanketing Congress with envelopes it says contain pictures of homosexual acts from a taxpayer-funded art exhibit in an effort to kill funding for the National Endowment for the Arts.

``It is hard to imagine why the people of Lithuania ... are being punished. What was their crime?'' _ Lithuania's president, Vytautas Landsbergis, after the Soviet Union cut off crude oil in a drive to make the Baltic state abandon its independence drive.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Down In Tokyo, Stocks Surge
DOC.TEXT: The dollar took a nosedive against the Japanese yen today, contributing to a surge on the Tokyo Stock Exchange's chief index as market players actively bought issues. The dollar closed at 157.75 yen, down 2.12 yen from Wednesday's close at 159.87 yen. The currency opened at 158.35 yen and ranged between 157.60 yen and 158.50 yen. The amount of decline in the dollar today was the largest since Aug. 1, when it lost 2.45 yen overnight to 136.65 yen. Dealers said the dollar's slide in Tokyo followed its overnight downswing in New York, despite a report Wednesday of a sharp improvement in the U.S. merchandise trade figures for February. ``Japanese investors had bought the dollar earlier based on their expectation that the U.S. trade deficit would largely improve, and then they dumped the currency when the figure actually came out,'' said Mitsuhiko Kinugasa, a dealer with Daiwa Bank. He said the market did not react to Wednesday's U.S. trade report because it had already taken into account the expected decline in the trade deficit. ``In an attempt to take profits, many market players sold the dollar regardless of the figure,'' he said. The U.S. Commerce Department said the nation's trade deficit narrowed in February to a six-month low of $6.49 billion from a revised $9.32 billion deficit the previous month. ``The dollar's decline after the 158.50 yen line is not because of position adjustments,'' he said. He said life insurance firms selling dollars were in part trying to get enough money for the May U.S. bond auction. On the stock exchange, the 225-issue Nikkei Stock Average, which rose 787.46 points Wednesday, posted another 696.35 points, or 2.38 percent, ending the day at 29,945.41 in heavy trading. Volume traded on the first section was estimated at 1 billion shares, up from Wednesday's 450 million. Traders attributed the index's surge largely to the yen's sharp recovery. ``Market players now believe that they have gotten over with all the negative elements as the yen and bond prices started recovering,'' said Yoshio Shimoyama, a senior trader with Nikko Securities Co. The price of the benchmark 10-year Japanese government bonds was changing hands at 86.38 points as of 4 p.m., up from Wednesday's 86.14-point close. Their yield was quoted at 7.285 percent, down from 7.335 percent the previous day. Shimoyama said the market is recovering by itself after a series of plunges. The market has lost 8,970.46 points, or 23.1 percent, from its yearend record-high close at 38,915.87. ``Because the index has lost so much, and also from our past experiences, we believe the market had bottomed out,'' he said, but added that some uncertainties remain. A trader with Yamaichi Securities Co., speaking on condition of anonymity, said, ``Inspired by the yen's recovery, market players started buying issues to which they had been paying little attention.'' Traders actively bought shipbuilding, steel and bank issues.

DOC.HEAD: Mexico Warns U.S. Of Possible Cut In Anti-Drug Cooperation
DOC.NOTE: Eds: RETRANSMITTING a0464 to CORRECT spelling in slug.

DOC.HEAD: Dismembered Daughter Had Terrorized Her Family
DOC.TEXT: A woman who police say was killed and then carved up and boiled by her father was mentally ill and had made life miserable for her family, her sister says. Angela DeChurch, 32, of Atco, N.J., said Wednesday her 38-year-old sister, Carol DiGregorio, had attacked every member of the family during episodes of paranoid schizophrenia and had ``tortured'' her father and ``treated him terrible.'' John DiGregorio, 60, was charged with murder and abuse of corpse in the slaying. Police said he told them he hit his elder daughter with a tire iron four or five times as she attacked him with a knife in their Bensalem kitchen Sunday. He then cut off her extremities, boiled parts of her body in three large pots and put her head in the refrigerator's lettuce crisper, police said. Mrs. DeChurch said her father came to her home Monday and told him what he had done. Her husband called police. DiGregorio ``was a wreck,'' she said. ``He couldn't live with himself. He came to me because he knew we would make a call.'' In Mrs. DeChurch's eyes, her father committed no crime. ``He loved my sister probably more than any father could love his daughter,'' she told the Philadelphia Daily News. ``She has attacked me in the past. She has attacked my mother. She hated herself and she hated him.'' Neighbors said that the victim constantly screamed at DiGregorio and that the father had tried hard to keep her home and out of a mental institution, where she had been previously committed. They said they admired his devotion to his daughter. Ana Rodriguez said DiGregorio on Friday told her his elder daughter was ``doing bad'' and he feared she would have to go back to a mental institution. Another neighbor, Bill Oakley, said he could tell from Ms. DiGregorio's clothes and makeup that her mental condition had deteriorated. Her lipstick was off the side of her mouth, like a clown's, and dress went from conservative to leather miniskirts, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Israeli Air Raid South of Beirut
DOC.TEXT: Israeli warplanes blasted unidentified targets in the seaside village of Naameh south of Beirut today, a local radio station reported. Voice of the People, mouthpiece of the Lebanese Communist Party, said the raid was carried out at 10:45 a.m. against unidentified ``targets in the Naameh hills.'' The broadcast, which interrupted regular programming to flash the report, did not disclose further details. Police could not immediately confirm the report. The Naameh hills house bases for several Palestinian guerrilla factions as well as bases for Druse warlord Walid Jumblatt's Progressive Socialist Party. The raid, if confirmed, will be the 10th Israeli air attack into Lebanon this year. Israeli helicopter gunships carried out the Jewish state's ninth air attack into Lebanon this year on April 4, blasting an office of the Palestinian Communist Party in the southern refugee camp of Rashidiyeh. Seven people were wounded. By police count, 10 people were killed and 29 wounded in the nine air attacks.

DOC.HEAD: Anti-Abortion Legislator Will Contest Election
DOC.TEXT: The chief abortion foe in the Illinois House, narrowly defeated in a primary re-election bid by an abortion-rights candidate after 14 years in office, says she will sue to be declared the winner. The state Board of Elections on April 9 pronounced Rosemary Mulligan, a paralegal from Des Plaines, the winner over Rep. Penny Pullen by a vote of 7,431 to 7,400 _ the same count reported on election night March 20. But Pullen said a recount of 56 of the 112 precincts in her suburban district showed her winning by 17 votes. ``We will be asking the court to correct the figures and declare me the winner,'' she said in Wednesday's Chicago Tribune. Pullen's attorney, former Chicago Election Commissioner Michael Lavelle, said he would file the lawsuit in Circuit Court this week. Both candidates in the closely watched election had received financial backing from groups on either side of the abortion issue.

DOC.HEAD: Observer: Cease-Fire Talks On Edge Of Breakdown
DOC.TEXT: Cease-fire talks involving the Contra rebels, the Sandinista government and the incoming administration are on the verge of a breakdown, according to a source close to the negotiations. The parties were optimistically described as being near agreement on Tuesday, but on Wednesday became bogged down in disputes. The talks dragged on nine hours with no success reported. Suspicion remains high after nine years of civil war. The Contras said Wednesday they were willing to negotiate an immedaite cease-fire. But they said they would not disarm until the Sandinista-controlled army is under the control of Violeta Barrios de Chamorro's civilian government, which takes over from President Daniel Ortega next Wednesday. The Sandinistas have warned that a failure by the Contras to disarm could endanger a peaceful transfer of power. An observer from the Organization of American States said late Wednesday that the talks were ``very delicate and on the edge of breaking down.'' The observer spoke on condition of anonymity and gave no further details. Chief Contra negotiator Oscar Sovalbarro said earlier that the rebels want to ``avoid the continued shedding of blood,'' but expressed distrust for the Sandinista's main objective _ to see the rebels disarmed before inauguration day. He said there were 15,000 rebels in the Nicaraguan countryside; most estimates put the number at 9,000. The fighters recently began infiltrating back into Nicaragua from border camps in Honduras, their base in waging war against the Sandinistas with U.S. support. Suspicion on both sides remains high, and the Sandinista Party newspaper Barricada accused the Contras of playing ``a double game of promises of demobilization and threats to the contrary.'' ``They are all working toward the same tactical objective: gaining time so the demobilization does not start before April 25, while at the same time ... recently infiltrated troops occupy advantageous military positions in the mountainous zones,'' it said in an editorial Wednesday. Barricada demanded Mrs. Chamorro's coalition, the United National Opposition, abide by its promise to ``respect the integrity and professionalism'' of the army in exchange for officers giving up leadership positions in any political party. Sandinista Party officials now control the force. On Wednesday evening, about 200 people demanding the immediate dismantling of the Contras surrounded the Organization of American States building, where the talks were being held. ``We're not leaving ... until they sign to demobilize,'' said a young woman who gave only her first name, Carla. The group threatened representatives of the Contras and Mrs. Chamorro's advisers, said Antonio Lacayo, head of Mrs. Chamorro's transition team. No police were present. Ortega called on the negotiators ``to contribute patriotically to reach an accord that sets the exact date for the demobilization and disarming of the Contras.'' The Contras' stance increases the chance that Mrs. Chamorro, who defeated Ortega in Feb. 25 elections, could face a threat of protest strikes and other actions by Sandinista-dominated labor groups. At a news conference, the Contras said they wanted to clarify a series of contradictory statements issued since their arrival Tuesday morning from the Honduran capital of Tegucigalpa. ``We want to be clear that the resistance maintains its position: As long as the destiny of the Sandinista army is not known, which cadres are going to control the army of Nicaragua, we cannot take the next step,'' Aristides Sanchez said. The three parties concluded a rough draft of a 12-point document dealing with the cease-fire and five security zones in which the Contras are to gather before turning in their weapons. ``We have had promises from the president-elect that the necessary reforms will be made, reforms that can bring the reconciliation of the Nicaraguan people,'' Sanchez said.

DOC.HEAD: Guam Says Roe vs. Wade Doesn't Apply
DOC.TEXT: Gov. Joseph Ada's chief counsel contends in court papers that the 1973 U.S. Supreme Court decision guaranteeing the right to an abortion does not apply to this U.S. territory. The memorandum argued that Roe vs. Wade and Webster v. Reproductive Health Services, the July decision giving states more authority to restrict abortion without overturning the earier ruling, are not in force in Guam because it is a territory. Ada signed the nation's most restrictive anti-abortion measure into law last month. Enforcement remains on hold pending a hearing in federal court May 8 on a challenge brought by a woman who wants an abortion. Katherine Maraman, the governor's legal counsel, and attorney Monessa Lujan argued that many of the Constitution's due process and equal-protection provisions do not fully apply to Guam in recognition of its traditions. The new law, if upheld by the court, would make it a felony for doctors to perform abortions and a misdemeanor for women to have abortions, except in cases where the pregnancy would endanger the mother's life. The measure also makes it a misdemeanor to solicit women to have an abortion.

DOC.HEAD: Cold in Northeast, Rain in Midwest
DOC.TEXT: Freezing cold lingered in the Northeast and rain drenched parts of the Midwest today. Much of the rest of the nation enjoyed fair weather. A low of 29 was reported today in Albany, N.Y., and 30 in Portland, Maine. Rain fell in Iowa, Kansas and Alaska. A surge of cold brought overnight freeze warnings to the Atlantic states and dipped into northern Florida. Fog hovered over Tampa Bay and Jacksonville, Fla., and New Orleans. Today's forecast calls for showers in Washington, Oregon and Wyoming, rain in Iowa and thunderstorms in Texas. Storms swept the Southwest on Wednesday. A flash flood watch was posted for Wednesday night over western Texas. Rain and storms were scattered Wednesday evening from Oklahoma to New Mexico and Colorado, Arizona, Nevada, Utah, Wyoming, Montana, Idaho and Florida. Overnight freeze warnings were posted across Delaware, Pennsylvania, New Jersey, West Virginia, Virginia and North Carolina.
