DOC.HEAD: Study: Many Refuse to Change Sunning Habits After Skin Cancer
DOC.TEXT: A study of more than 1,000 people who had skin-cancer surgery found that nearly half continued to stay in the sun in the belief that cancer ``was not enough of a problem to give up a tan.'' Still, a leading dermatologist sees the sun setting on sunbathing. ``I'm encouraged in the way attitudes are changing,'' said Dr. Howard K. Koh, chairman of the American Academy of Dermatology committee coordinating its annual effort to encourage skin cancer prevention and detection. ``I think the message is out that the deep tan is unhealthy.'' The study found 44 percent had not changed their habits concerning outdoor activities one year after removal of their cancers, despite a doctor's repeated counseling. Thirty-eight percent said they still weren't using sunscreens, despite their doctors' advice, said the study, published in the April issue of the American Medical Association's Archives of Dermatology. Though giving up sunbathing was the most common behavior among subjects after surgery, 24 percent admitted they were still suntanning a year later. ``The attitude of these non-compliant individuals, who were usually women, was that skin cancer was not enough of a problem to give up a tan,'' said the study's author, Dr. June K. Robinson, a dermatologist at Northwestern University Medical School in Chicago. The patients who disregarded their doctor's advice said a tan ``made them feel good, and that the sunscreens have an objectionable sticky feeling,'' wrote Ms. Robinson. All subjects underwent surgery between 1983 and 1987. They were counseled before and after by Ms. Robinson and a nurse, who told them they could reduce their risk for subsequent cancers by reducing sun exposure, wearing protective clothing and using sunscreens. The study focused on non-melanoma skin cancer because its known cause is the built-up effect of sun exposure over several years, Koh said. Though rarely fatal, non-melanoma skin cancer will strike an estimated 600,000 Americans this year, the American Cancer Society says. In contrast, melanoma skin cancer is expected to strike 27,600 Americans in 1990 and kill 5,300. Its cause is less certain but is believed to be partly intermittent harsh sun exposure, particularly during adolescence, Koh said. Skin cancer is the most common form of cancer in the United States, with the number of cases of malignant melanoma doubling each decade, according to the American Academy of Pediatrics. Ms. Robinson wrote that of the 1,042 patients who answered anonymous questionnaires, 56 percent said they had changed their outdoor activities.

DOC.BYLINE: China Will Not Tolerate Pro-Democracy Ship ^By JIM ABRAMS
DOC.TEXT: China said today it ``cannot tolerate'' support for a radio ship that plans to transmit pro-democracy messages into the country, and did not rule out the use of force to stop the broadcasts. ``The activities of this ship are aimed at subverting the people's government and are against the norms of international relations,'' Foreign Ministry spokeswoman Li Jinhua told a news conference. ``Therefore we cannot tolerate the support of that ship.'' The 1,200-ton ``Goddess of Democracy'' left France on March 17 for international waters off the Chinese coast, where it plans to broadcast music, news and pro-democracy reports to the mainland. The converted trawler's mission is sponsored by a coalition of groups headed by the French magazine Actuel and with the cooperation of the Federation for a Democratic China, a Paris-based Chinese dissident organization. China has formally protested to the French government about the boat, and sponsors have charged that the ship has been under ``constant surveillance and intimidation by the Chinese authorities'' since it left port. Actuel on Monday said its editorial offices in Paris were broken into over the weekend with documents and computer disks related to the ship stolen. A reporter for the magazine said the disks were returned on Wednesday in a non-stamped envelope carried to the magazine's offices by a postman. The ``Goddess of Democracy'' is named after the statue erected by pro-democracy students in Tiananmen Square last spring before Chinese troops crushed the movement for a freer China, killing hundreds of people. Li refused to answer several questions on whether China would resort to force to stop the broadcasts, saying only that she had ``nothing to offer'' on that question. She said the radio ship ``is a tool of the reactionary organization Front for Democracy in China (Federation for a Democratic China) ... We are resolutely opposed to the provision of support or facilities to it by any state, region, organization or individual. Chinese authorities have protested the mission to France as ``gross interference'' in China's internal affairs. The French government says it is not involved in the project. The ship, which is equipped with one television and two radio studios, is now in the Indian Ocean headed for Singapore. It plans to begin broadcasting into the mainland by the end of April. Sponsors say the ship suffered 10 days of administrative hassles in the port of Djibouti on the Horn of Africa.

DOC.HEAD: Air Traffic Control Center Short on Chairs: Union
DOC.TEXT: Some controllers at the Chicago Air Route Traffic Control Center are sitting on garbage cans and crates these days because of a backlog of orders for chair parts, union officials said. The broken chairs threaten the efficiency of the controllers, who need good chairs to have a clear view of radar screens, said Jim Poole, chairman of the National Air Traffic Control Association chapter at the center, 40 miles west of Chicago. Union and Federal Aviation Administration officials said the lack of chairs _ ordinary office chairs designed for good posture _ posed no danger to traffic safety at the center, one of the nation's busiest with about 400 controllers. So many chairs are broken two controllers had to make do with an overturned garbage can and a wooden box on a recent shift, Poole said this week. FAA spokesman Mort Edelstein said there is a nationwide problem with broken chairs. ``The agency has had difficulty getting replacement parts,'' he said. ``They have to go to Oklahoma City for the parts, and there's a backlog of orders.''

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Skids, Gold Rises
DOC.TEXT: The dollar was lower against all key currencies in European trading this morning, after taking a dive on the Tokyo market. Gold was higher. The dollar closed in Tokyo at 157.75 yen, down 2.12 yen from Wednesday's close. Later in London, the dollar traded at 156.85 yen. The drop in Tokyo was the sharpest since Aug. 1, 1989, when the dollar fell 2.45 yen overnight. Dealers said the dollar began falling in New York Wednesday despite a report of a sharp improvement in the U.S. merchandise trade figures for February. ``Japanese investors had bought the dollar earlier based on their expectation that the U.S. trade deficit would largely improve, and then they dumped the currency when the figure actually came out,'' said Mitsuhiko Kinugasa, a dealer with Daiwa Bank in Tokyo. He said the market did not react to Wednesday's U.S. trade report because it had already taken into account the expected decline in the trade deficit. ``In an attempt to take profits, many market players sold the dollar regardless of the figure,'' he said. Other dollar rates at midmorning compared with late Wednesday: _1.6713 West German marks, down from 1.6720 _1.4790 Swiss francs, down from 1.4876 _5.6200 French francs, down from 5.6315 _1.8835 Dutch guilders, down from 1.8855 _1,228.00 Italian lire, down from 1,230.50 _1.1608 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1640 The British pound was quoted at $1.6440, compared with $1.6347 late Wednesday. Gold dealers in London fixed a recommended price of $376.60 per troy ounce this morning, up from $375.00 per ounce late Wednesday. In Zurich, the bid price was $376.50 up from $375.50 late Wednesday. In Hong Kong, gold rose $1.93 to close at $377.80 an ounce. Silver traded in London at a bid price of $5.11 a troy ounce, unchanged from late Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: Attackers Massacre 50 Peasants in Peruvian Jungle
DOC.TEXT: Three hundred masked men dressed in civilian clothes rounded up residents of a remote jungle village and shot to death about 50 elderly people and children, area officials said. The massacre occurred one week ago in Sonomoro, according to officials 12 miles north in Concepcion. They said Wednesday that they did not learn of it until five survivors arrived on foot to report it. Villagers said they did not know who the attackers were, and that the gunmen did not say anything during the slaughter. The killers could have been members of the Maoist-inspired Shining Path guerrilla group, said officials in Concepcion, about 120 miles east of Lima, the capital. Both the rebels and government security forces have been accused of similar massacres in the past. The survivors said the attackers, carrying automatic rifles and grenades, rounded up villagers and shot to death about 50 of them in the village square after separating them by age. They said the killers then burned homes and a school and left on foot. The villagers asked Concepcion officials for police protection and for money to bury the victims. Also Wednesday, police in Peru's main coca-growing region said Shining Path rebels ambushed an army convoy and killed seven soldiers. An undetermined number of soldiers were wounded in the Tuesday attack, near the town of Campanilla, 400 miles north of Lima, police said. There was no report of rebel casualties. Campanilla is in the upper Huallaga valley, where most of Peru's coca, the raw material used to make cocaine, is grown. Peru is the world's leading supplier of coca. Shining Path rebels control much of the valley and police say they allow drug traffickers to operate in the region in exchange for arms and money. The Shining Path has been fighting Peru's elected governments since 1980. The government says more than 18,000 people have died in the violence. Most of the victims have been civilians.

DOC.HEAD: Cuban Exile Pleads Innocent in Bombing of Chilean Envoy
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS top 3 grafs to CORRECT that car bombing was 14 years ago, insert year of bombing.
DOC.TEXT: A Cuban exile is denying federal charges that he took part 14 years ago in the car-bomb assassination of former Chilean ambassador Orlando Letelier. In a three-minute court proceeding Wednesday, Jose Dionisio Suarez Esquivel pleaded innocent through his lawyer to five felony charges, including murdering a foreign official. FBI agents arrested Suarez on April 11 in St. Petersburg, Fla. He had been a fugitive since his indictment in 1978 with seven other people in the 1976 bomb blast that killed Letelier as he was driving along Washington's Embassy Row. A woman aide also was fatally injured. A former Chilean diplomat, Jose Miguel Barros, testified in a Chilean court last year that Letelier's assassination was ordered by Chilean army Gen. Juan Manuel Contreras Sepulveda, who headed the Chilean National Intelligence Agency. Contreras is one of three men sought in the case and U.S. Attorney Jay Stephens said he has not given up hope of having them brought to justice. The recently replaced military government of Chile refused to extradite Contreras and another Chilean intelligence official. A third man, an associate of Suarez, is a fugitive. ``We are currently considering a number of avenues with respect to the remaining three fugitives,'' Stephens said in a statement. Suarez is being held without bond at an undisclosed location. A plea of innocent was entered for him by his lawyer, Edward Sussman, before U.S. Magistrate Deborah Robinson. Suarez's next court appearance will be in two or three weeks. Investigators believe that Suarez, reportedly a member of an anti-Castro group, was drawn into the murder by officials of Chile. Letelier had been ambassador to the United States from 1970 to 1973 under the Marxist government of Salvador Allende. His killing strained U.S. relations with the dictatorship of Augusto Pinochet. According to the indictment, Suarez provided explosives and a remote-controlled detonating device and helped assemble the bomb used in the assassination. Michael Townley, a U.S. citizen who worked for the Chilean intelligence agency and served a prison term in the case, said Suarez detonated the bomb. FBI officials said Suarez, 51, a naturalized U.S. citizen, had been living in the St. Petersburg area for the past five years and the arrest was the result of information developed a few days before his capture.

DOC.HEAD: Attorney General Orders Settlers Out of Christian Quarter
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with quotes, background, details. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Attorney General Yosef Harish today ordered police to remove 150 Jewish settlers from a building complex in the Christian quarter of Jerusalem's Old City. The Jews' occupation of a 72-room building complex in the Christian area on April 11 set off a week of angry protests by Christian clerics and Palestinians, both Christian and Moslem. About 30 police and border guards were stationed outside the four 100-year-old buildings owned by the Greek Orthodox Church just after the order was issued. Asked if the settlers would be ejected today, Police spokesman Uzi Sandori said: ``It's almost certain but not sure.'' Ben Elon, one settler, said the group had not yet received Harish's eviction order. Asked if they would comply with the order, Elon said: ``We will honor all legal decisions.'' Harish's order said the settlers have not proved the right to occupy the complex. He said he took the action to prevent further deterioration of relations between the Christian and Jewish communities in Jerusalem. If the Jews are removed from the building, it would be the first time settlers have been dislodged since April 1982 when Israeli soldiers evacuated 3,000 settlers from Yamit in the Sinai Peninsula, ceded to Egypt under its peace treaty with Israel. Abdul Wahab Daroushe, an Arab member of Israel's Parliament, visited the Jerusalem site and told the settlers the Jews should leave. ``I don't think there are any lack of apartments for these people to live in. They are a provocation here,'' he said. The Jews' move into the Christian quarter upset a tradition in which religious communities in the Old City live in separate and jealously guarded neighborhoods. The settlement also has political implications since the Old City is part of the area captured from Jordan in the 1967 Middle East war. Israel annexed the area to its capital, but most countries, including the United States, do not recognize Israel's claim to sovereignty. The settlement led to court action by the Greek Orthodox Church to dislodge the settlers. The church maintained a former tenant acted illegally when he sold his rights to live in the building, leading to establishment of the Jewish settlement. The settlers argued they had a legal contract from a Panamanian company to sublet.

DOC.HEAD: Program For New Weapons Put On Indefinite Hold
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration, responding to a lessening of tensions in Europe, is indefinitely postponing the production of new short-range nuclear missiles that were to be deployed in West Germany, U.S. officials said today. The 88 new launchers, 36 of which were to be controlled by the United States and the others by West Germany, Britain and the Netherlands, were designed for targeting on East Germany. The tentative U.S. goal was to begin deploying them in 1995 to replace the current mixture of nuclear-armed and conventional Lance missiles. But East Germany is rapidly moving out of the Soviet sphere and preparing for union with West Germany. It is no longer perceived as a threat to the North Atlantic Treaty Organization countries. The current arsenal of Lances will remain in West Germany, however. Those with nuclear warheads have a range of about 75 miles, and the non-nuclear weapons are designed to hit targets within 45 miles. The new launchers were intended to have a greater range of about 280 miles, just below the level of intermediate-range nuclear missiles that were banned in a U.S.-Soviet treaty in 1987. ``The present system is a viable deterrent through the year 2,000, even though the Army would have liked to start deployment of new Lances in 1995,'' a U.S. official said. The current Lances recently were touched up with new fuel for their rockets, the replacement of worn-out components and other maintenance.

DOC.HEAD: Maples Says She Dropped From Sight To Protect Friends
DOC.TEXT: Marla Maples says she went into hiding amid the publicity about her reported romance with Donald Trump in part out of concern for her friends' privacy. ``I didn't want to bring any more havoc into my friend's lives,'' Maples said in an interview with ABC newswoman Diane Sawyer. ``I had to always think about where I was going and what effect it could have on the people I was visiting.'' Sawyer showed a brief clip of the taped interview this morning on the WABC-TV program ``Live With Regis and Kathie Lee.'' The interview was to be broadcast tonight on ABC's ``Primetime Live.'' Allegations of the actress-model's purported affair with Trump first surfaced in February. After she was thrust into the spotlight, Maples said, ``I knew I had to get away. I knew I needed to turn off the television, not read newspapers, just not be affected by words. I needed to get back to what's real.'' Sawyer said Maples avoided talking about specifics in her relationship with Trump, about which she may have to testify in litigation between the developer and his wife, Ivana.

DOC.HEAD: Report: FTC Investigating On-Screen Advertising Bans
DOC.TEXT: Two Hollywood studios that banned on-screen advertisements at theaters showing their movies have come under investigation by the Federal Trade Commission, according to published reports. Fred Haynes, chief of the FTC antitrust division's motion picture section, revealed the probe of Walt Disney Studios and Warner Bros. at a recent board meeting of the National Association of Theater Owners in Washington, the Los Angeles Times reported today. The FTC would neither confirm nor deny the existence of the investigation first reported Wednesday in the entertainment trade paper Daily Variety, the Times said. Justice Department spokesman Joe Krovinsky said Wednesday that officials there were aware of the FTC probe because the agencies check with each other to avoid duplicating efforts. Officials with Disney and Warner said the studios had not been contacted by the FTC and they would not comment on the reports, the Times said. Disney and Warner have said many moviegoers dislike the commercials and the studios feared the bad feelings could extend to their feature films. Some theater owners have said the policy infringes on their right to offset costs by showing commercials before movies. The FTC enforces laws governing restraint of trade, which is the restriction or prevention of business competition. Both Disney and Warner have said they will allow theaters' existing advertising contracts to expire before they impose the bans.

DOC.HEAD: Elderly Minister Arrested in Death of Ill Daughter
DOC.TEXT: An 81-year-old retired minister was charged with first-degree murder and armed criminal action in the clubbing death of his ailing daughter. The Rev. Gerald E. Maggart struck 49-year-old Beverly Maggart with a hammer Tuesday night as she lay in a bed in her apartment, authorities said. She lived within a short walk of her parents. Maggart, the retired pastor of Country Club Congregational Church, was charged Wednesday and released on $25,000 bond. His wife, Elizabeth Maggart, said he acted out of kindness, not malice. She said their daughter suffered from a brain tumor, seizures and bad reactions to medication, though her problems were not terminal. ``The poor girl was going through so much,'' Mrs. Maggart said. ``They just loved each other to death.'' Police said Maggart decided to kill his daughter on Sunday. He allegedly walked to her apartment Tuesday and killed her about 11 p.m. He called police Wednesday morning after talking to his wife. John M. Morris, chief counsel for the criminal division of the state attorney general's office, said he does not recall any previous mercy killing cases in Missouri. The state has no provision for mercy killing, he said, adding, ``Murder is murder.'' Beverly Maggart worked as a secretary at the University of Missouri-Kansas City from the mid-1970s until she became physically unable to work last September.

DOC.HEAD: WASHN: other maintenance.
DOC.TEXT: All the new Lances were supposed to be nuclear-armed. Their potential deployment had stirred opposition among West German groups eager to promote disarmament and concerned that deploying new weapons on their territory could make West Germany a more inviting target in the event of a war. As East-West tensions eased, support for the missiles declined in the West German government and among several of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization allies. Still, the Reagan and Bush administrations resisted efforts led by West Germany for negotiations to eliminate both NATO and Warsaw Pact short-range missiles until a treaty to cut back troops, tanks and other weapons in Europe is concluded. The accord is still not finished. But, the officials said, the Bush administration has decided not to have the Army Missile Command solicit proposals from munitions makers for manufacturing new Lance missiles. ``The project has been put on indefinite hold,'' said a U.S. official, who spoke on condition of anonymity. He said the current Lance arsenal would serve as a deterrent through the rest of the century.

DOC.HEAD: Income Growth Slowed in New England for Second Straight Year
DOC.TEXT: Per capita personal income growth slowed in New England for the second straight year in l989 and failed to match the national average in the Plains, Southwest and Far West states, the government said today. ``New England had a second consecutive year of decelerating per capita income growth in 1989,'' the Commerce Department said in its semi-annual report. ``Per capita income in New England grew 6.6 percent in 1989, down from 8.3 percent in 1988 and 8.6 percent in 1987.'' Despite the slowdown, New England's per capita income of $21,509 topped all other regions of the country, according to the survey by the department's Bureau of Economic Analysis. By contrast, per capita incomes grew 5.5 percent to $16,231 in the Plains, 5.6 percent to $19,153 in the Far West and 6.1 percent to $15,231 in the Southwest, the department said. It reported the national growth rate was 6.5 percent and the average per capita personal income was $17,567. The Mideast posted the highest growth rate, up 7.1 percent. It was followed by the Great Lakes region, up 7.0 percent; and the Southeast and Rocky Mountain states, both up 6.7 percent. It was the third consecutive year of accelerating growth in the Rocky Mountains. But despite the pickup, it still was 13 percent below the U.S. average of $17,567. Per capita personal income is the annual total personal income of residents divided by the resident population. States with the highest incomes were Connecticut, with an average $24,604; New Jersey, $23,764; Massachusetts, $22,196; Alaska, $21,173, and Maryland, $21,020. At the lowest end were Mississippi with an average $11,835; West Virginia, $12,529; Arkansas, $12,984; Utah, $13,027, and Louisiana, $13,041. New England posted ``well-above-average growth earlier in the 1980s,'' the department said. The deceleration last year was caused by the smallest earnings increases in manufacturing and private service-type industries since 1975 and the first construction earnings decline since 1975.

DOC.HEAD: New York City to Ring Up New Area Code
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 3 graf to CORRECT that New York probably would not be the first city in the nation with three area codes, as spokesman says the change is not expected until 1993 and Los Angeles change set in 1992.
DOC.TEXT: Area code 212's number is up. And that means New York could have three area codes in a few years. With the proliferation of faxes and computers using phone lines, New York Telephone expects to run out of numbers for that area code in Manhattan and the Bronx in 1993, company spokesman Peter Muller said. Muller said the company's ``best guess'' is that it will add an area code that year. New York Telephone has reserved 917 for future use. The state Public Service Commission voted Wednesday to begin looking at the issue and to solicit comments. One option would be to assign the new area code to cellular and pager numbers, said commission spokesman Edward Collins. No area in the country has a special area code for portable phones and beepers, he said. The five boroughs that make up New York City used to have one area code: 212. In 1985 the numbers in that area code were used up, and the 718 area code was created for Brooklyn, Staten Island and Queens. New York and Los Angeles are the nation's only two cities with two area codes. Los Angeles County is getting a third area code in 1992 that Pacific Bell says will include parts of the city.

DOC.HEAD: Gap Between Federal Income Taxes Owed and Paid About $100 Billion
DOC.TEXT: The gap between federal income taxes owed and paid is about $100 billion a year and growing, and Internal Revenue Service enforcement efforts are likely to cut it by only about one-fourth, Congress was told today. IRS Commissioner Fred T. Goldberg Jr. said the tax gap was as much as $96.8 billion in 1988 and predicted it will rise to $127 billion in 1992. The figure includes only the federal income taxes owed on legal income. The total gap, including taxes on illegal earnings, and Social Security and estate taxes, has been estimated unofficially at $200 billion a year or more. The tax gap does not include about $87 billion of accounts receivable, which are taxes assessed by the IRS but still unpaid over several years. ``A $100 billion shortfall is certainly a cause for concern _ particularly in today's world of sizable deficits,'' Goldberg told the House Ways and Means oversight subcommittee. He noted, however, that last year the IRS collected over $1 trillion, all but $25 billion of it paid through self-assessment by the taxpayers. ``The plain fact is that voluntary compliance has been and remains the backbone of our tax system,'' Goldberg said. Although tougher enforcement efforts are essential, he added, ``we cannot lose sight of the fact that a 1 percent swing in voluntary compliance will increase _ or decrease _ revenues each year by more than $5 billion.'' His prescription for the problem: simplified tax laws, a modernized computer system and better quality assistance to taxpayers. ``Taxpayers are willing to pay what they owe; they cannot abide complexity, uncertainty, administrative burdens and hassles with the IRS that may take months or years to resolve,'' Goldberg said. Since the IRS began tracking the tax gap, voluntary compliance by individual taxpayers has remained fairly constanty: as high as 83 percent in 1973, 82.7 percent in 1988 and a forecast of 83.6 percent in 1992. Corporate compliance, estimated at 86.6 percent in 1973, has risen to 88.1 percent. In 1987, the lastest year for which complete figures are available, 25.8 percent of the tax gap was attributed to informal supplies (such as roadside vendors and home-repair workers) underreporting income; large corporations were next at 17.8 percent. Individuals who did not bother to file a return accounted for 7.6 percent of the gap. Failure to report capital gains was responsible for 7.1 percent. Miscellaneous business income, including rent and partnership income, accounted for 6.7 percent. The IRS found that 99 percent of wages, interest and dividends was reported. The remainder accounted for 4.6 percent of the gap. Goldberg estimated that $505 billion of income taxes were due in 1987 and that $411 billion was paid voluntarily, leaving a gross tax gap of $94 billion. IRS enforcement efforts, including audits and collection initiatives, brought in $22 billion, leaving a net gap of $72 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Jogger A Year After Attack: Promoted To VP And May Testify At Trial
DOC.TEXT: The Central Park jogger who was gang-raped and beaten into a coma a year ago today has been promoted to a vice president at her investment banking firm, Salomon Brothers Inc. The promotion was confirmed today by Lisa Borowitz, a Salomon spokeswoman. It was made in January, when the firm announces all its corporate moves. The 29-year-old jogger, whose name has never been made public, returned to work at Salomon Brothers in November after undergoing rehabilitation at a Connecticut hospital. She was assigned to a position advising large corporations on investments. Doctors have called her recovery from severe brain damage remarkable. When she was found in the park April 20, 1989, after being attacked the previous evening, she had lost most of her blood and was near death. The woman may be called to testify against her alleged assailants, even though she has no memory of the attack. New York Newsday, quoting unidentified court sources, reported there is a ``strong possibility'' prosecutors will call her to the witness stand to discuss her life before the attack and her recovery. She has said she wants to testify. No date has been set for the first trial, which will involve three of the six teen-agers charged. Authorities said she was attacked while jogging during the late evening, as she often did, by a gang of ``wilding'' youths who beat and raped her and left her. Two suspects remain in jail because they could not make bail: Raymond Santana, 15, and Kharey Wise, 17. The other four suspects, Kevin Richardson, 15; Steven Lopez, 16; Antron McCray, 16; and Yusef Salaam, 16, are out on bail. Salaam, Santana and McCray are to be tried first.

DOC.HEAD: Swiss Say Three U.N.-Accredited Soviet Diplomats Were Spying
DOC.TEXT: Three Soviet diplomats accredited with the United Nations have been uncovered as spies attempting to obtain restricted technology, Swiss authorities said today. The three were trying to collect confidential ``scientific-technological information,'' according to the office of the Federal Prosecutor at Bern. They were accredited with the U.N. office in Geneva. One was stopped last month on a parking lot in Geneva before he was to receive documents from an informant, the office said. He has since left Switzerland, it added. The government demanded last week that he be recalled. The two others returned home earlier as part of a regular rotation, the office said. All three were barred from re-entering Swiss territory. A spokesman of the office, Roland Hauenstein, declined to give their names or elaborate on their assignments. He also refused to say what happened to the informant. Hauenstein said the case showed again that Eastern intelligence agents are focusing on efforts to obtain Western technological and scientific know-how. Last year, a member of the Soviet trade mission in Bern was expelled for similar activities. The Geneva newspaper Tribune de Geneve said about 1,200 Soviet officials in Geneva and 120 in Bern and Zurich have diplomatic status. It said about 30 percent were believed to be intelligence agents.

DOC.HEAD: Package Bomb Explodes at Expo '92 Headquarters
DOC.TEXT: A package bomb believed sent by Basque separatists exploded today at the headquarters of Expo '92, the Seville World's Fair, injuring one woman, officials said. A spokesman at Seville's General Hospital said the left hand of secretary Carmen de Felipe was mangled when she opened a book sent inside the package. Surgeons were operating in an attempt to save her hand, he said. The explosion, at around noon, was the first attack directly related to the exposition, scheduled to open April 12, 1992, in commemoration of Christopher Columbus' first voyage to the New World. At the time of the explosion, Expo '92 Commissioner Manuel Olivencia was meeting with officials of the French-based International Expositions Office. None of the participants in the meeting was injured. No group immediately took reponsibility for the blast. Police said the package bore the hallmarks of ETA, the Basque separatist group that has been attacking official Spanish targets in its independence campaign for the three-province Basque region. On April 2, police at a roadblock outside Seville arrested a French national whose car contained more than 660 pounds of explosives. The man, Henri Parot, said he belonged to a roving French commando group of ETA. He said the organization had planned car bomb attacks against government buildings in the southern Spanish city. ETA, which stands for homeland and liberty in the Basque language, has claimed the lives of more than 600 people since 1968.

DOC.HEAD: Opposition-Led Government Takes Office
LaserPhoto KAT2
DOC.TEXT: Nepal's first independent government in almost three decades took office today, less than two weeks after the king lifted a ban on political parties. King Birendra swore in Nepali Congress Party President Krishna Prasad Bhattarai, a former political prisoner, as prime minister and leader of an interim coalition government until elections promised for within a year. After taking the oath of office at the royal palace in central Katmandu, Bhattarai swore in nine ministers at the government secretariat. One member of the 11-minister Cabinet was to arrive in the capital later, Bhattarai said. Four ministers including Bhattarai belong to the Nepali Congress, three to the United Left Front, two are Birendra's nominees and two are independents. ``The responsibility weighs very heavy on my shoulders,'' Bhattarai said after the swearing-in ceremony. Hundreds of people packed the conference hall where the ministers took their oaths in a private ceremony. Bhattarai said his government's first priority will be to ``try to lessen the economic difficulties of the people and make life easier and less expensive than what it is today.'' Nepal is one of the world's poorest countries. Its 17 million people have an average annual income of 150 dollars a year, and 75 percent of them are illiterate. Nepali Congress leader Ganesh Man Singh, who declined Birendra's proposal to become prime minister because of poor health, said economic reforms were important but ``cannot be achieved in a day and people should not have unwarranted aspirations.'' The swearing-in capped the pro-democracy movement that started Feb. 18 with a series of marches and strikes that spawned a popular groundswell in this remote Himalayan monarchy where political activity had been forbidden since 1961. On April 6, police opened fire on 200,000 demonstrators marching on Birendra's palace, killing 200, according to witnesses. The government claims no more than 10 died. Two days later the king yielded to the mass movement led by the Nepali Congress and the United Left Front, and lifted a 29-year ban on political parties. On April 16, Birendra dissolved the partyless legislature and announced the resignation of his government's prime minister, Lokendra Bahadur Chand. Those had been the main conditions of the Nepali Congress and the United Left Front for joining a palace-proposed interim government. The ministers' oath called for allegiance to Nepal's present constitution which gives near-absolute powers to the king. But Bhattarai has said a proposed constitutional reforms commission would draft a new constitution reducing the king's powers and possibly make Nepal a constitutional monarchy. The new government has also promised to hold multiparty elections within a year. The Nepali Congress formed the country's first democratically elected government in 1959, but it lasted only 20 months before Birendra's father, King Mahendra, dismissed it, accusing it of corruption and poor administration. Bhattarai was Parliament speaker in the 1959-60 government. He was jailed for nine years immediately after Mahendra dissolved that government and spent five more years in jail at different times for political agitation.

DOC.HEAD: Black Youths Slain Hours After De Klerk Orders Probe
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 4 grafs to UPDATE with four black youths slain. Pickup 3rd graf pvs, `In other...'
DOC.TEXT: Officers killed four blacks today, just hours after President F.W. de Klerk ordered an investigation into the police shooting of 11 unarmed blacks who were protesting high rents. Police said officers shot and killed four youths and wounded another at the Rammulotsi black township near Viljoenskroon in the Orange Free State. Police opened fire during a demonstration, but officials declined to give any details. Earlier, De Klerk appointed a judicial commission to investigate the March 26 police action in the black township of Sebokeng. The African National Congress had pulled out of peace talks with the government over the killings. Judge Richard Goldstone will head the inquiry, the government said. In other developments, police said five more people died in black factional fighting in Natal province, including a black police officer who was stabbed. They said a 14-year-old boy and a 9-year-old girl were burned to death in ``necklace'' killings. Blazing tires were put around their necks. Police said a police barracks in the black township of Soweto outside Johannesburg was attacked Wednesday with grenades, but there were no injuries. The government also announced that military reservists would be required to do 60 days duty a year instead of 30 days because of growing unrest. De Klerk made the decision to appoint a judicial commission to look into the police action in Sebokeng, which is outside Johannesburg, after meeting late Wednesday with his Cabinet. Judge Richard Goldstone will head the inquiry. ANC leader Walter Sisulu welcomed de Klerk's decision, saying police actions must be investigated. ``A judicial commission is important in our situation because it is able more or less to sift through things _ not depend on opinions,'' he said. Police said they were forced to open fire when protesters threatened officers blocking the march. Defense Minister Magnus Malan said military service for army reservists had to be increased to 60 days because of unrest in Natal and other parts of the country. ``This situation, as well as the potential for unrest elsewhere in the country, make an extension of the service period ... unavoidable as a temporary measure,'' he said in a statement. Malan challenged the ANC to drop its support for armed resistance to the white government. He said all responsible groups had to help end the wave of unrest that has claimed more than 500 lives this year. ``No peace process can in reality take place if violence continues or when violence is held out as an option,'' he said. ``Revolutionary intimidation and mobilization of people is taking place on a wide scale and is connected with the ANC's links to the continuation of the armed struggle.'' De Klerk earlier this week demanded the ANC formally renounce its armed struggle. The ANC has refused to renounce violence, even though its guerrilla forces are virtually inactive. De Klerk legalized the ANC and freed Nelson Mandela in February to try and clear the way for talks on ending white-minority rule and sharing power with the country's black majority. Much of the violence sweeping South Africa has involved rival black political factions. The worst bloodshed has been in Natal, where hundreds have died in black faction fights.

DOC.HEAD: Contras Agree to Cease Fire and Disband
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 14 grafs to CLARIFY that two separate cease-fires; CORRECTS cease-fire time; ADDS detail on disarming; Pickup 15th, `The government...' ^By FILADELFO ALEMAN
DOC.TEXT: The Sandinista government and the U.S.-backed rebels signed a cease-fire agreement early today that calls on the Contras to begin laying down their arms next week and to disband by June 10. The cease-fire, which began at noon today, will be verified by U.N. forces and Nicaraguan Cardinal Miguel Obando y Bravo. The document was signed by Nicaragua's minister of defense, Gen. Humberto Ortega, rebel commanders Oscar Sovalbarro and Aquilino Ruiz Robleto, and representatives of President-elect Violeta Barrios de Chamorro. ``With this accord we conclude the peace process started with the elections,'' said Antonio Lacayo, chief of the Chamorro transition team. The Yatama Miskito Indian group fighting alongside the Contras on the Atlantic coast reached a separate but similar disarmament agreement that establishes a cease-fire in the eastern half of the country at midnight today. The accords appeared to end a tense standoff among the Sandinista government, Chamorro's incoming administration and the Contras that had threatened to derail the transfer of power in Nicaragua. The signing came after lengthy negotiations, including an all-night session that ended this morning. The talks began on Tuesday. The agreement says the rebel forces should begin disarming on Wednesday, the day the Chamorro government is inaugurated. Demobilization of the Contra forces is to be completed by June 10 at the latest. The leftist Sandinistas had demanded that the Contras disarm before they handed power to the new civilian government. But Gen. Ortega said today that it was more important that peace be reached ``as soon as possible.'' ``We all made an effort so that it (the dismantling) would have been on the 25th,'' but ``technical hurdles'' made that impossible, Gen. Ortega said. He said the delay was ``nothing if we compare it to the tragedy and suffering that we have had during these years of war.'' The accord says the Contras' weapons will be surrendered ``in a voluntary form'' in the presence of U.N. forces and Obando y Bravo. It also establishes security zones for the rebels inside Nicaragua so they can begin regrouping immediately in preparation for demobilization and disarmament. During the decade-long war between the Contras and the Sandinista government, many of the Contras were based in Honduras. Under the accord signed today, Sandinista forces are to start withdrawing immmediately from the five security zones and complete the withdrawal by Saturday. The Sandinista forces are required to stay at least 12 miles from the zones and are prohibited from conducting flights over the zones. The government has guaranteed the safety of the rebels and their families and said it will respect their civil liberties. The agreement calls for Roman Catholic monitors to provide transportation for the rebels and their families to the security zones and give them humanitarian aid. The Contras had said on Wednesday they were willing to negotiate an immediate cease-fire but would not disarm until the Sandinista-controlled army was brought under the control of the new civilian government. Sandinista President Daniel Ortega had warned that if the Contras failed to disarm, the peaceful transfer of power could be endangered. There are at least 9,000 rebels in the Nicaraguan countryside. The fighters recently began returning to Nicaragua from border camps in Honduras. The talks began on Tuesday, lasted for six hours and then resumed again on Wednesday afternoon, lasting until about 5:30 this morning. The negotiations were the first involving the opposition coalition backing Chamorro, known as UNO, the Contras and the Sandinistas since Mrs. Chamorro's 14-party coalition defeated the Sandinistas in Feb. 25 elections. Mrs. Chamorro will take office for six years and her administration is counting on a peaceful Nicaragua to deliver on her key campaign promise of reviving the economy. Ortega and Mrs. Chamorro had called on the Contras to disband. However, as soon as UNO won the elections, most of the Contras slipped across the border into Nicaragua, leaving behind in Honduras only the wounded, the crippled and a few old guns. That reduced the effectiveness of a UNO-Contra accord of March 23 under which Contra forces in Honduras were to disarm. The accord set no firm date. Washington backed the Contras in their nine-year war with the Sandinistas that cost 57,000 lives but supported Mrs. Chamorro's call for their dissolution. Fighting between the Contras and Sandinista forces had slowed to a virtual standstill in recent months, with only sporadic fighting.

DOC.HEAD: Attorney General Describes Spokesman's Role in Gray Story
DOC.TEXT: Attorney General Dick Thornburgh today confirmed that his chief spokesman had declined to steer a CBS reporter off a story about a criminal investigation involving Rep. William H. Gray III, D-Pa. Thornburgh, who ordered an intensive criminal investigation of unauthorized disclosures about the case, said in a statement that press secretary David Runkel was following his standing instructions by declining to wave CBS reporter Rita Braver off the story. Thornburgh said Runkel did not violate any department rules because he had not intended to confirm the story by refusing to deny information Ms. Braver had obtained from other sources. Several days after CBS reported that Gray was a subject of the probe, the Justice Department issued a statement that the congressman was not a target of the investigation. The department said at the time that Gray was cooperating with the investigation of alleged financial irregularities in his congressional office. Thornburgh said that Runkel, in refusing to deny that a probe of Gray was underway, was ``following my standing instruction that no one in the department mislead the media.'' ``Unfortunately, there are circumstances where a statement of the kind likely made here by Mr. Runkel may be used by a reporter as confirmation of a story,'' the attorney general said. The attorney general, who was attending a hemispheric drug enforcement conference in Mexico, issued the statement in response to a story in today's editions of The New York Times that Runkel had played a role in confirming the story reported by Ms. Braver last spring. Justice Department spokesman Daniel Eramian, who read the attorney general's statement to reporters, refused to comment on The Times' account that Runkel had failed a lie detector test during the leak investigation conducted by federal prosecutors and the FBI. Thornburgh said that ``a refusal to deny or wave a reporter off a story with which he is confronted by the reporter does not, in my view, constitute misconduct.' ``A real distinction must be made, I believe, between an unsolicited and affirmative unauthorized disclosure and such a `confirmation' by one responsible for dealing with the media.'' The CBS story produced a storm of indignation from Democrats on Capitol Hill because it broke as Gray was seeking election as House majority whip. Democrats charged the leaks from the Justice Department were politically inspired. Thornburgh ordered the Justice Department to conduct a criminal investigation, in which more than 100 people were questioned and asked to make sworn statements. Runkel has refused to say if he was among those who took lie detector tests but has confirmed that he had given testimony before a federal grand jury that investigated the matter. In December, Thornburgh reported to Congress that the investigation ``has not produced sufficient evidence to enable me to ascertain that any present employee of the Department of Justice was responsible for the disclosure.'' The attorney general, responding to pressure from Democratic lawmakers, agreed recently to turn over the report of the investigation to the Justice Department's Office of Professional Responsibility. That unit conducts investigations of misconduct by Justice Department employees and can recommend to the attorney general that disciplinary action be taken against individuals. Eramian said ``the OPR review has been completed and the attorney general has received that office's advice.'' He declined to say what OPR had advised.

DOC.HEAD: Bush, Mitterrand Meet on Lithuanian Crisis, Future of NATO
DOC.NOTE: EDs: INSERTS 13th graf, bgng, Heading into ... with Bush declining comment on Lithuania; SUBS 12th graf pvs, After flying ... to CORRECT name of estate owner
DOC.TEXT: President Bush met with French President Francois Mitterrand at a Florida Keys resort today to discuss the future of NATO and how to respond to Soviet pressure on the breakaway republic of Lithuania. ``We're still trying to get verification of the exact situation there,'' White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said of the developing Lithuanian crisis as Bush flew to the Florida Keys for his meeting with Mitterrand. The Kremlin sharply curtailed supplies of natural gas to Lithuania today, hours after it halted the flow of crude oil to the republic for refusing to scrap laws promoting independence, Lithuanian officials said. ``President Bush has begun a series of consultations with our allies on appropriate responses,'' Fitzwater said. ``He telephoned German Chancellor (Helmut) Kohl yesterday on this matter. He will discuss it with President Mitterrand this afternoon and we will be in touch with all of the allies either directly or through diplomatic channels in the next few days.'' Asked if joint NATO or Western action was being considered, Fitzwater said, ``I wouldn't put it in that category. I think it's more a consultation about what individual countries might do, what their approach might be.'' ``We're still trying to get dialogue. Trying to get both sides to use whatever maneuvering room they have,'' said Fitzwater. The spokesman also said the U.S. government had received a message from Syria Wednesday saying it appears an American hostage would be released as the Islamic Jihad for the Liberation of Palestine said earlier. ``We have statements of imminent release from Islamic Jihad and from Syria. But there's no way for us to know conclusively that it's going to happen,'' Fitzwater said. He said the State Department has dispatched a reception team to Wiesbaden, West Germany, but cautioned that the reception team has been sent there before on rumors of a hostage release that never happened. ``Our position is that we want the unconditional release of all hostages. We will not deal or negotiate for hostage release but we're hopeful this could be real,'' Fitzwater said. Today's meeting of Bush and Mitterrand is the seventh time the two leaders have met since Bush became president 15 months ago. After flying across the Atlantic in a Concorde jet, the French leader joined Bush at the exclusive Ocean Reef Club. The two leaders went to the private waterfront estate of Ohio businessman and friend Richard Farmer to begin eight hours of talks. Heading into the meeting, Bush waved off reporters questions about Lithuania, saying ``We'll answer all questions later.'' The president said earlier he hoped the session with Mitterrand will ``narrow any differences that might exist'' between France and the United States on the post-Cold War role of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, the West's political and military alliance. ``There have been reports that there was a little drift and a little separation'' between the two allies on the future of NATO, Bush said in an interview Monday. ``The best way to find that out is simply to sit and talk.'' Fitzwater said that in addition to NATO and German unification, Bush and Mitterrand will discuss the May 30 U.S.-Soviet summit as well as the president's recent talks with Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze. Bush, who met last week with Canadian Prime Minister Brian Mulroney in Toronto and British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher in Bermuda, said, ``I've tried hard as president to stay in close touch with our alliance leaders, and (these) talks, given the rapidity of change in Eastern Europe, seemed very timely.'' France has enjoyed a special, independent status within NATO ever since the late Charles de Gaulle pulled French forces out of the alliance's integrated military structure in 1966. De Gaulle was unwilling to cede control of French forces to NATO's supreme commander _ an American general. Now, as the two Germanys head toward unification, Bush and the entire NATO alliance have insisted that the new Germany must be a full member of NATO, including its military arm. The Soviet Union has dropped its insistence that Germany be neutralized, but has suggested overlapping NATO and Warsaw Pact membership. Mitterrand planned to fly back to Paris aboard the supersonic jet tonight after eight hours of private meetings, a news conference and dinner with his American host. For Bush, it was the prelude to an outdoorsy Earth Day weekend that he will spend fishing in the Everglades off Islamorada, Fla., after side trips to Republican fundraisers in Birmingham, Ala., and Orlando, Fla., on Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Denver Mayor Orders Probe Into Coroner's Office After Autopsies Disputed
DOC.TEXT: Mayor Federico Pena has ordered an investigation into the Denver coroner's office following questions about its handling of the deaths of two small children. Pena on Wednesday asked the Denver Department of Health and Hospitals to conduct a thorough review. He said he specifically wants an analysis of the working relationship between the coroner's office, the district attorney's office, the police department and other city agencies. Attorneys and medical experts have questioned the competence of a pathologist, Dr. Robert Deters, who was temporarily hired by the coroner's office during a staff shortage. The offices of the Colorado public defender and the Denver district attorney separately have requested second opinions on Deters' rulings in the deaths of two children. The district attorney is questioning the case of 16-month-old Salvador Rodriguez of Denver, who was hospitalized Jan. 17 and died three days later. Several doctors at the hospital said he showed signs of having been hit on the ear, but Deters ruled that the child had died of complications resulting from an ear infection. In another case, involving a 2-month-old boy allegedly starved to death by his mother, the public defender's office accused the coroner's office of withholding autopsy reports and failing to perform required tests. Questions also have been raised about Deters' findings in other cases. Deters on Wednesday said his work had remained top-quality despite a caseload of more than 500 autopsies in 16 months. ``I worked hard, I put in some long hours and I devoted whatever time was required to the job thoroughly,'' he said. John Fairman, manager of the Denver health department, said the coroner's office turned to Deters, head of the pathology department at McKee Medical Center in Loveland, for a few months' help after its full-time pathologist resigned and the part-time pathologist was transferred. But the contract period grew to 10 months, during which time Deters performed 390 autopsies for Denver, plus others for McKee and for counties in northern Colorado and Wyoming. Deters says he has worked as much as 80 hours a week during the past 10 months, with few days off. He was paid $234,000 for the autopsies performed for Denver. At a news conference at Denver General Hospital Wednesday, Deters initially declined to discuss the cases in which his rulings have been challenged because of possible litigation. But he later stood by his decision in the Rodriguez case. Also at the news conference, officials with the Denver Department of Health and Hospitals, the coroner's office and McKee defended Deters' work. ``He stepped forward voluntarily and has worked extremely hard to provide competent, high-quality work,'' said Dr. Ben Galloway, acting director of forensic pathology at the Denver coroner's office. Denver this month hired a new full-time pathologist, which is expected to ease the crisis in the coroner's office. Fairman said Deters remains on contract, but can now reduce his workload.

DOC.HEAD: Census Response Still Lagging

DOC.TEXT: The 1990 census could cost an extra $100 million or more, Census Director Barbara E. Bryant said today as she urged Americans who have not returned their forms to do so. It could cost the bureau an extra $10 million to count each 1 percent of citizens who don't mail back their forms, she told the House census subcommittee. Currently the response rate is 7 percent below plan. Asked if the total shortfall would be close to $100 million, Bryant said, ``it could be more than that.'' Some 4.8 million census forms have been returned by the post office as undeliverable. Detailed plans exist to send workers out to count people on their doorsteps. ``We plan to follow up on every housing unit for which a questionnaire was not returned and we have the workforce to do it,'' she said. The census is not over, Bryant emphasized, calling on Americans to mail back their forms. Workers will begin visitimg homes next week, but the bureau is always happy to get mailed-back forms, she said. Currently, 63 percent of households have mailed back their census forme, she said. The bureau had hoped for a 70 percent mail response. Census workers have been hand-delivering forms to many of the missed blocks and buildings, a process that has delayed response in many areas. Thus, the bureau continues to urge people to fill out the forms and send them back although the count officially took place on April 1. The updated figures show Wisconsin as the most responsive state, with 74.5 percent of households having sent back their forms. Alaska is trailing at 47.1 percent. Among major cities, Columbus, Ohio was leading with a 71.9 percent response rate. Other major cities with high return rates included Indianapolis, 68.6 percent; Minneapolis-St. Paul, 66.2 percent; El Paso, 64.9 percent; Kansas City, 64.4 percent and Seattle, 64.2 percent. Boston was last at 45.4 percent and New Orleans was also low at 47 percent. Other major city response rates include Atlanta, 60 percent; Baltimore, 60.9; Chicago, 52.0; Cleveland, 50.8; Dallas, 58; Denver, 59.3; Detroit, 55.3; Houston, 55.6; Also Los Angeles, 58.3 percent; Memphis, 60.2; Milwaukee, 59.8; New York, 51.3; Philadelphia, 54.7; San Diego, 60.8; and San Francisco, 61.7. DOC.HEAD: Storm Hit Bangladesh, 8 Killed, 200 Injured
DOC.TEXT: A summer storm whipped across Bangladesh, killing eight people and injuring 200, news reports and officials said Thursday. The storm, with winds of 60 to 90 mph, hit six eastern and northern districts Wednesday. It blew down houses and toppled trees, said a district official at Jamalpur, 90 miles northwest of Dhaka. He spoke on condition of anonymity. Bangladesh, one of the poorest countries in the world, is often buffeted by natural disasters. Floods, cyclones and storms kill hundreds of people every year. At least 166 people were killed and another 1,600 injured in storms that battered the country in late March and early April.

DOC.HEAD: Government Files Rebellion Charges Against Aquino Opponent
DOC.TEXT: The government Thursday filed rebellion and murder charges against one of President Corazon Aquino's sharpest critics for allegedly helping mutineers in last December's coup bid, officials said. Judge Tirso Salazar's spokeswoman said the court ordered the arrest of Homobono Adaza, former member of the Philippine Assembly, and five other people for their alleged involvement in the Dec. 1-9 bid to oust Mrs. Aquino. Adaza's lawyer, Armando Marcelo, said he was told about the charges but was unaware of any arrest warrant. He said he did not know the whereabouts of his client. Others charged were fugitive Brig. Gen. Jose Zumel, key leader of the December assault; Edgardo Abenina, Jr. son of another rebel officer; and three businessmen _ Medardo Pestano, Crismel Verano and Joaquin Venus. Venus is the former presidential assistant of the late Ferdinand Marcos. Adaza is the third prominent civilian to have been charged in connection with the December coup attempt. It was the sixth and most serious attempt to overthrow Mrs. Aquino since she took power in 1986. Others charged include Sen. Juan Ponce Enrile, who was arrested in February but released on bail, and Rodolfo Aguinaldo, former governor of Cagayan province who remains at large. At least 113 people were killed and more than 600 injured in the fighting in December. Adaza was formerly an Aquino supporter and a strident critic of Marcos, who ruled for 20 years. He helped direct Mrs. Aquino's 1986 election campaign against Marcos but later broke with her because of personal and philosophic differences.

DOC.HEAD: Two Wounded in Quake, Aftershocks Continue
DOC.TEXT: A series of aftershocks hit an area of western China on Thursday following a strong quake two days earlier, and regional officials said two people were hurt. On Tuesday, a quake measuring 6.4 on the Richter scale hit West Wuqia in the Xinjiang Uygur Autonomous Region. A woman at the Xinjiang Seismology Bureau said frequent aftershocks measuring up to 4 on the Richter scale were still being felt in the mountainous region. The official, who did not give her name, said two people were injured, but she did not have details. Zhu Lingren, the bureau's deputy director, said Wednesday the big quake's epicenter was in an unpopulated mountain range 37 to 43 miles southwest of Wuqia and less than 60 miles from the Soviet border. The Richter scale gauges the energy released by an earthquake as measured by ground motion recorded on a seismograph. A quake measuring 6.4 could cause severe damage in a populated area. Foreigners have been barred this month from the area where the quakes hit because of ethnic unrest. Local sources said troops were dispatched to Kashgar and two other cities April 6 to quell rioting by Xinjiang's Turkic-speaking Moslems.

DOC.HEAD: Heavy Rains in Rio Kill Up To Seven; McCartney Concert Postponed
DOC.TEXT: Heavy rains in Rio killed up to seven people, news reports said Thursday. The downpour caused chaos throughout the city and forced the postponement of a long-awaited show by Paul McCartney. News media reported four people died late Wednesday when two homes collapsed. Three others were electrocuted when they leanedon light posts as they waded through flooded streets, according to news reports. Police and Civil Defense officials told The Associated Press they could not confirm the number of deaths. The rain caused massive traffic jams throughout Rio as cars stalled in flooded streets. Traffic was backed up for hours on the 10-mile-long bridge that connects Rio to the neighboring city of Niteroi on the other side of the Guanabara Bay. Promotors of McCartney's two scheduled shows at the Maracana soccer stadium announced the first concert, scheduled Thursday night, would be pushed back a day as rain forced workers to halt construction of the stage.

DOC.HEAD: Kilauea Volcano Lava Destroys Another Home
DOC.TEXT: Lava from Kilauea Volcano torched another Hawaii Island home today, the 82nd destroyed during its current eruption, and continued moving toward other dwellings in its path, authorities said. A house in Kalapana Gardens Subdivision was ignited about 3:30 a.m. today, less than 12 hours after another home a short distance away burned down, said Bruce Butts of the Hawaii County Civil Defense Agency. The flow was moving toward another home that was about 350 feet away, Butts said. The lava was coming from the north and was following the path of another flow that destroyed two homes April 4. In all, the volcano has destroyed six homes in the Kalapana area this month. There are about 120 homes in and around Kalapana Gardens Subdivision. Residents in 26 homes remain on 24-hour evacuation alert. Twenty-five homes were evacuated Sunday. Damage from the lava has totaled more than $20 million since the volcano started erupting in January 1983.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Appoints Ministers of Health, Aviation
DOC.TEXT: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev has appointed two new ministers to head the departments of health and civil aviation, the Tass news agency said. Igor Denisov was named to replace Yevgeny Chazov as minister of health. Boris Panyukov was appointed minister of civil aviation, taking over from Alexander Volkov, the news agency said Wednesday. The two former ministers were relieved of their duties by Gorbachev last month. Denisov takes over the health ministry at a time when the department is under frequent attack for poor equipment and training, shortages of medicine, and personnel that often seems uncaring and lazy. The 49-year-old surgeon has been working in the health ministry since 1987. He was first deputy minister in charge of personnel training, health planning, economics and foreign relations in the field of medicine, Tass said. Panykov, 60, has been involved in Soviet civil aviation since 1962 and held the title of first deputy minister before being tapped by Gorbachev for the top job, the news agency said. The two appointees face confirmation hearings by the Supreme Soviet legislature. No date for the hearings was announced.

DOC.HEAD: Vandalized Rembrandt Going Back on Display
DOC.TEXT: Rembrandt's ``Night Watch'' masterpiece will go back on display May 1, less than one month after being sprayed with sulfuric acid by a man believed to be mentally disturbed, officials said Thursday. No extra security will be introduced to protect the painting, despite the fact the April 6 attack was the third against the Rembrandt this century, said Det de Beus, spokeswoman for the Rijksmuseum. The huge 1642 painting will be returned to its customary center-stage spot in the main gallery in the Rijksmuseum, the nation's largest treasure trove of art. A protective veneer layer prevented any damage to the work of art, according to Ms. De Beus. ``The painting can withstand an attack as it is,'' she told The Associated Press, adding: ``It's not as if it is attacked every day. The last one was 15 years ago.'' In 1975, a Dutch schoolmaster claiming to be on a divine mission slashed the painting with a knife. He was sent to a psychiatric hospital, where he committed suicide. During World War I, a jobless shoemaker slashed the canvas to protest his inability to find work. In the latest attack, a 31-year-old Dutchman squirted sulfuric acid onto the canvas. He is undergoing psychiatric treatment. The acid ate away at the veneer layer, leaving several dozen white streaks over a one-square-yard area of the canvas. The painting measures 12-by-14.5 feet. ``But the paint layer was not harmed at all,'' said Ms. De Beus, adding that restorers were able to begin refinishing the painting last week without having to retouch the paintwork. Working in a dust-free room in the museum, the restorers will apply the second and final veneer coat Friday. It is expected to dry by May 1. The protective veneer layer was put on the painting during the lengthy restoration that followed the 1975 attack. ``Night Watch,'' a group portrait of 17th-century Dutch militiamen, draws far more museum viewers than any other painting in the Netherlands. The priceless painting, renowned for Rembrandt's mastery of light and dark, is not insured in line with Dutch government policy. Two guards are stationed by the ``Night Watch'' during museum hours. One of them sprayed a neutralizing agent over the painting after the acid attack. A knee-high steel barrier keeps viewers approximately two yards away from the painting.

DOC.HEAD: Former Political Prisoner Becomes Nepalese Prime Minister
DOC.TEXT: Krishna Prasad Bhattarai, a leader of the pro-democracy movement who spent 14 years in jail, on Thursday became prime minister of Nepal's first independent government in almost three decades. King Birendra administered Bhattarai's oath of office at the royal palace, embarking on a new political course for the Himalayan monarchy where Birendra once wielded absolute power. After the ceremony at Narayan-heti palace, Bhattarai drove to the government secretariat where he swore in nine ministers. His 10th minister missed the ceremony because of a flight delay, the prime minister said. ``The responsibility weighs very heavy on my shoulders,'' Bhattarai said after the swearing-in ceremony, which was attended by government officials and hundreds of supporters. Bhattarai, president of the Nepali Congress party, now heads a coalition interim government composed of democrats, communists, royalists and independents. Four ministers, including Bhattarai, belong to the Nepali Congress. Three are members of the seven-party United Left Front; two are Birendra's nominees; and two are independents. Bhattarai said his government would like to lessen the economical difficulties of the people and ``make life easier and less expensive than what it is today.'' Nepal has a per capital annual income of $150 and is one of the world's poorest countries. Seventy-five percent of its 17 million people are illiterate. The palace ceremony was closed to the public and press. Hundreds of people packed the secretariat conference hall, the size of a hockey field, where the ministers were sworn in. The pro-democracy movement, led by Nepali Congress and the United Left Front, started Feb. 18 with a series of demonstrations and strikes in this remote mountain kingdom where political protest was forbidden. On April 8, Birendra bowed to protesters' demands and lifted a 29-year-old ban on political parties. The surprising announcement followed an April 6 crackdown on demonstrators that witnesses called a massacre. Authorities said 10 people were killed and 107 injured that day throughout the country. Witnesses said 200 died in Katmandu alone when police fired on marchers. On April 16, Birendra dissolved the non-partisan National Assembly and announced the resignation of the government, meeting major opposition demands. The two Cabinet members nominated by Birendra are Achyut Raj Regmi, a minister in the former Cabinet and a former Nepali Congress member; and Keshar Jung Rayamajhi, a former Nepal Communist Party member. The ministers' oath called for allegiance to Nepal's present constitution, which gives near-absolute powers to the king. But Bhattarai has said a new constitution will be drafted to reduce the king's powers. The new government has promised to hold multiparty elections within a year. The Nepali Congress formed the country's first democratically elected government in 1959. It lasted only 20 months before Birendra's father, King Mahendra, dismissed it, accusing it of corruption and poor administration. Mahendra introduced a new constitution and ruled the country through the National Assembly and the submissive government. Bhattarai was the Parliament speaker in the 1959-60 government. He was jailed for nine years immediately after Mahendra dissolved that government and spent a total of five more years in jail at different times for political agitation.

DOC.HEAD: Religious Strife Deaths Jump 83 Percent
DOC.TEXT: Deaths linked to religious tensions in India jumped 750 percent in 1989, according to figures released Thursday. Home Minister Mufti Mohammed Sayeed said 491 of the 607 deaths occurred in Bihar state, the scene of bloody clashes between Hindus and Moslems. Sayeed's figures did not include killings in the northwestern state of Punjab, where Sikh militants are fighting for a separate homeland. At least 1,821 people died in separatist violence there in 1989. More than 600 have died this year. It also did not include bloodshed in Kashmir, where Moslem militants are trying to secede from India. More than 270 people have died in separatist violence in Jammu-Kashmir state this year. Sayeed told Parliament that in 1988, 80 people died in ``communal violence.'' That is the term used by Indian officials and news media to describe ethnic, religious or caste-related clashes. In 1987, the total was 331. The majority of India's communal violence occurs between Hindus and Moslems. India's 880 million people are 82 percent Hindu, while 12 percent are Moslems. The most recent clash occurred in the western state of Gujarat. More than 30 people were killed in riots that broke out this month in the state after a Hindu boy who was in love with a Moslem girl was stabbed to death. Not all of the violence involves Hindus and Moslems. In the state of Assam, members of the Bodo tribe, who worship spirits believed to inhabit rocks and trees, have been agitating for a separate homeland. Last week, attacks by suspected Bodo militants left 25 dead. So far this year, 43 people have died in such violence. Clashes in central India between security forces and Naxalites, a band with roots in Maoist Marxism, have left 93 dead so far this year, Sayeed said.

DOC.HEAD: Authorities: No Arrests at 2 Live Crew Concert
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 5th graf, `Register's office...', with 2 grafs to UPDATE with group spokeswoman confirming that group did not eliminate adult lyrics, had lawyer, bail money readied. Picks up 6th graf pvs, `Police spokeswoman...'. Skyywalker cq in final graf.
DOC.TEXT: The rap group 2 Live Crew performed before hundreds of fans early today without incident despite threats by a prosecutor to have the musicians arrested on obscenity charges. The band began its 90-minute concert shortly after midnight, opening with a song called ``Martinez Rap,'' about Republican Gov. Bob Martinez's campaign against explicit lyrics. The nightclub Central City was filled to its 1,500-person capacity at $12.50 a ticket for the one-night stand. ``Just business as usual. Arrests? Not by this department,'' said a duty officer at Gainesville police headquarters who asked not to be named. ``This whole thing, we understand, was being publicized by the state attorney's office.'' State attorney Len Register had called some of 2 Live Crew's sexually explicit songs ``the most filthy thing I've ever encountered.'' He threatened to have the band arrested if they played uncensored versions of songs such as ``Me So Horny,'' and ``Move Somethin,'' which has lyrics referring to sadomasochistic sex and violence against women. Debbie Bennett, spokeswoman for the group in Miami, said it played its usual concert, including adult lyrics. She said the group had an attorney on standby and bail money available if Register had followed up on his threat. Register's office said this morning that he was in meetings, and that he was not immediately available for comment on why his threat was not carried out. Police spokeswoman Sadie Darnell said before the concert that police received no special orders from the state attorney's office. ``I don't feel this issue is over,'' though, she said this morning. No Alachua County sheriff's officers were sent to the nightclub either, clerk Lashaun Butler said. Local officials in some Florida counties have banned some 2 Live Crew albums, especially one called ``As Nasty As They Wanna Be.'' State legislatures in several states also have begun considering mandatory record labeling acts because of the group's material. The Miami-based group is led by Luther ``Luke Skyywalker'' Campbell. Members are David ``Mr. Mixx'' Hobbs, Chris ``Fresh Ice Kid'' Won Wong and Mark ``Brother Marquis'' Ross.

DOC.HEAD: Lithuanians Say Natural Gas Supplies Sharply Curtailed
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 5th pvs, `The flow...' with 4 grafs to UPDATE with Gorbachev tries to persuade Latvia and Estonia to stay in fold. Pickup 6th, `A fourth...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto OSL1
DOC.TEXT: The Kremlin sharply curtailed supplies of natural gas to Lithuania today, hours after it halted the flow of crude oil to the republic for refusing to scrap laws promoting independence, Lithuanian officials said. Lithuanian President Vytautas Landsbergis said Moscow's economic embargo was tantamount to it recognizing his Baltic republic's independence. A Soviet energy official, however, said the Lithuanians got what they deserved for defying President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, who on Friday threatened to cut off supplies unless they rescinded their independence-oriented laws. A Lithuanian government spokesman appealed over Vilnius Radio today for fuel conservation, ``and maybe we will not be intimidated by these sanctions.'' As the events in Lithuania unfolded, Gorbachev met in the Kremlin today with leaders of Latvia and Estonia and offered concessions and made threats in an effort to keep them in the Soviet Union, participants said. Gorbachev offered both republics ``special status'' in the Soviet Union if they drop their attempts to follow Lithuania into independence, said Raymond Lochmelis of the Latvian Popular Front and other officials present. The Soviet leader also proposed a loose confederative system instead of a union tightly controlled by the center. He also reportedly threatened to end the talks unless Estonia rescinded its claim that it is an occupied independent state and Latvia canceled its plan to declare independence on May 3. The flow of natural gas to Lithuania was shut off in three pipelines _ two from Latvia and one from Minsk in Byelorussia _ reducing supplies to Lithuania by more than 80 percent, Lithuanian lawmakers said. A fourth pipeline from Slonim in Byelorussia that supplies Lithuania continued to provide 3.5 million cubic meters of gas to the republic, guaranteeing ``a normal supply of gas for residents and communal domestic use in the Lithuanian S.S.R.,'' parliamentary officials quoted the Byelorussian gas concern's telegram as saying. That leaves Lithuania with only 16 percent of the gas it needs per day. Lithuania uses an average of 18 million cubic meters daily for industrial and domestic use. Lithuanian officials estimate the republic has enough oil to last six weeks to three months. Juozas Martusevicius, a Lithuanian electrical official, said Moscow officials guaranteed that enough natural gas would be supplied to keep Lithuania's Elektrenai power plant functioning. The plant also serves customers in the neighboring Russian republic territory of Kaliningrad. Lithuania's sole nuclear power station, in Ignalina, is shut down for repairs. Lithuania is entirely dependent on Moscow for oil and gas, and the embargo was the toughest action Gorbachev has taken in his effort to force the republic of 3.8 million people to rescind its March 11 declaration of independence. Soviet Foreign Ministry spokesman Vadim Perfiliev said today that Moscow ``might have some other restrictions'' to impose on Lithuania, but he refused to elaborate. Late Wednesday night, the oil to Lithuania's only refinery stopped flowing through a pipeline feeding the plant from the Russian city of Polotsk, according to Bronius Vainoras, director of the facility. Vainoras told the British Broadcasting Corp. that the refinery will have to close if supplies are not restored. Half of the refinery was working but at a reduced capacity, he said. Landsbergis, speaking after Lithuania's parliament had refused a Kremlin ultimatum and instead offered to negotiate, said Gorbachev's move represented ``economic coercion and economic warfare against a neighboring country.'' ``Truly, this is recognition of the independence of Lithuania,'' he said. ``It is hard to imagine why the people of Lithuania, irrespective of nationality and creed, are being punished. What was their crime?'' In Moscow, Deputy Oil Minister Lev Dmitrievich Churilov said his department cut off the oil _ mostly Siberian crude _ after receiving a decree from the Soviet Council of Ministers ordering the shutdown ``until further special notice.'' Lithuania's Mazhiekiai refinery processes about 12 million tons of petroleum products a year. Lithuania uses about a quarter of the output, journalists quoted Lithuanian government officials as saying.
