Neighboring Baltic states Latvia and Estonia _ themselves moving along a slower path toward independence _ won't be hurt by the cutoff to Lithuania, Churilov said. Lithuania's supplies will now go to the republics of Byelorussia, the Ukraine and Russia, as well as Eastern Europe, he said. Noting that he was expressing his personal opinion, Churilov told The Associated Press that the cutoff might teach the Lithuanians a lesson. ``Maybe this measure can make them think a little,'' he said. ``They should not respond to appeals from the president and government with ultimatums.'' Lithuanian officials met today to discuss the cuts in energy supplies, said spokesman Ceslovas Jursenas, with the priority being given to the power industry, bakeries and the food industry. He said that in the areas of fuel and power, Lithuanians would be put on ``a starvation diet.'' ``Where we can give up the use of gas, petrol, any heating or lighting, let us do this, and then we will be able to survive longer and, maybe, we will not be intimidated by these sanctions,'' Jursenas said in his appeal. Sales of gasoline in Lithuania tripled this week as motorists reacted to Gorbachev's threat with panic-buying, said Lithuanian Energy Minister Leonas Asmantas. Lithuanian Prime Minister Kazimiera Prunskiene was in Norway today, seeking oil to help offset the embargo. Norwegian Prime Minister Jan P. Syse said his country has not promised oil supplies to Lithuania. ``We don't expect the world to give us any concrete goods at the moment ... all we are after is moral support,'' Mrs. Prunskiene said. ``We believe Lithuania will survive without natural gas but life will be reduced, cut off from normal possibilities.'' The White House said today that President Bush was consulting with U.S. allies on ``appropriate responses'' to the Lithuanian crisis. Prior to the cutoff, Secretary of State James A. Baker III said action against Lithuania could destroy commercial relations between the Soviet Union and the United States. ``It's very difficult to see some of the commercial aspects of our relationship surviving the use of force or coercion'' he said. Gorbachev has declared unconstitutional Lithuania's moves to curtail the spring draft into the Soviet army, give residents Lithuanian identity cards and seize the property of the Communist Party on Lithuanian territory. Lithuania was forcibly annexed by the Soviet Union in 1940 along with the fellow Baltic states of Latvia and Estonia.

DOC.HEAD: Official Says Trade Deficit Could Worsen
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Tops with 8 new grafs with committee testimony, picks up 5th graf pvs, While this forecast.
DOC.TEXT: A top Bush administration official said today that the U.S. trade deficit could worsen this year and warned that Japan's closed markets pose ``important risks for the world economy.'' Treasury Undersecretary David Mulford said that there is more at stake than reducing America's huge trade imbalance. He said growing protectionist threats could imperil world prosperity. ``If we are going to preserve the global trading system, we are going to have to insist that Japan and others who share the benefits do their part,'' Mulford said. ``Clearly, Japan has not done its part.'' Mulford's comments were part of the administration's continuing campaign to pressure Japan to open its markets further for foreign trade. Many have grown concerned that a big decline in the value of the yen in recent months threatens to worsen the $49 billion trade deficit between the two nations. A weaker yen would make Japanese products less expensive in this country while making American goods more costly in Japan. ``The depreciation of the yen and Japan's relatively closed markets are not sustainable over time as their continuation would pose important risks for the world economy,'' Mulford said in testimony before a Senate Banking subcommittee. Mulford said that any further improvement in America's broadest measure of trade, the current account, was likely to be ``very modest and the possibility of deterioration in the current account cannot be excluded.'' Mulford's comments echoed the outlook in a new adminisration assessemnt prepared by the Treasury Department which said further improvement in the trade balance this year would be ``modest at best.'' While this forecast is in line with the view of many private economists, it poses a threat to the optimistic economic assumptions underlying President Bush's 1991 budget. A widening of the trade deficit would worsen the slump in manufacturing as companies found it harder to sell their products overseas. Further weakness in manufacturing could seriously depress overall economic growth. The broadest measure of U.S. trade, the current account, posted a deficit of $105.9 billion in 1989. It had posted an all-time high of $143.7 billion in 1987. The current account measures both trade in merchandise and services, a category that primarily reflects investment flows between countries. So far this year, the merchandise portion of the trade deficit has been on a roller coaster, surging to $9.32 billion in January, only to drop to $6.49 billion in February as oil imports retreated from a record high set the month before. Many private economists look for America's oil dependence to deepen in coming months as domestic production slumps further. Another negative factor on the trade front is the recent strength of the U.S. dollar, especially against the Japanese yen. A stronger dollar makes U.S. goods less competitive on overseas markets and makes foreign imports cheaper for American consumers. The United States has often joined with other leading industrial countries in coordinated efforts to keep currency rates in line as a way at attacking trade imbalances. The Group of Seven nations _ the United States, Japan, West Germany, Britain, France, Canada and Italy _ last met in Paris earlier this month. They promised then to continue their coordination efforts but rejected petitions by Japanese officials for stronger action to bolster the sagging yen. In the trade assessment, the administration declared that ``the yen's weakness is a matter of concern, with undesirable consequences for the global adjustment process.'' Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady gave a similar view in congressional testimony but did not offer any specific actions the administration was willing to take. The U.S. trade deficit with Japan widened to $3.12 billion in February from $2.86 billion in January. The administration's trade report said the dramatic political changes occurring in Eastern Europe had the potential of easing global trade imbalances. The report said the unification of West and East Germany should help lower West Germany's large trade surpluses because the united country would have more demand for imported products. However, it said, the prime beneficiaries of this development were likely to be other countries in Europe, not the United States. On another point, the report said Taiwan and South Korea had made progress in liberalizing their currency exchange-rate policies but that both nations need to make further progress. The two countries had been cited in previous reports for manipulating their currencies in order to bolster their export sales, particularly with the United States, their primary foreign market.

DOC.HEAD: State Department Warns Americans on Travel in Philippines
DOC.TEXT: The State Department has advised Americans not to travel to eight areas of the Philippines because of continued crime and danger from insurgents, according to the U.S. Embassy. The latest travel advisory was issued April 9 and will be in effect for a year, an embassy official said. At least eight Americans have been killed in Communist insurgency-related incidents here in the last four years. Americans should avoid Kalinga-Apayao province, Isabela province and the Cagayan Valley region on the main island of Luzon. Samar island and Masbate province in the central Philippines also should be avoided. The other areas on the advisory are Lanao del Sur, Sulu province, and Basilan island in the southern Mindanao island group. It said travel to most tourist destinations and urban areas in the Philippines is generally considered safe but that Americans should stay away from entertainment districts at night because of high crime. ``Only national highways and paved roads should be used. Except for major urban areas, road travel at night should be avoided,'' it added. Americans should check with the U.S. Embassy or with local officials before leaving the capital, the warning said. It noted that while there were no warnings against travel to the six U.S.-run military installations in the Philippines, Americans should take precautions because of threats against military personnel and facilities. In March, Communist rebels kill an American rancher in Masbate province for refusing to pay ``revolutionary taxes'' to the insurgents. An American geologist, his Filipino wife and his father-in-law were killed in an ambush by guerrillas last February in Bohol province. In September last year, Communist guerrillas killed two American civilian employees at a U.S. Air Force post. A year ago, Communist assassins gunned down a U.S. Army colonel on his way to work in suburban Quezon City. In October 1987, insurgents shot to death three Americans in attacks outside Clark Air Base. The Communist New People's Army is widely believed to be operating in most of the country's 75 provinces. It is the armed wing of the outlawed Communist Party of the Philippines, which has been fighting a 21-year-old insurgency. Moslem rebels have also been waging a largely dormant war for self-rule in Mindanao for the past 18 years. Several pirate groups and kidnapping syndicates also operate in the region.

DOC.HEAD: Seal That Strayed 100 Miles up River Shot Dead
DOC.TEXT: A California sea lion that wandered 100 miles up the San Joaquin River was shot to death, authorities said. The 214-pound seal named Judge was found beached Sunday on the river bank west of Modesto. Two days later, it was found dead with a gunshot wound, said Warden Hugh Rutherford of the state Department of Fish and Game. ``I got a call about a seal in the river. I said `A seal? A seal, as in Sam-Edward-Adam-Lincoln?' Who ever heard of a seal in the San Joaquin River?'' Rutherford asked. Rutherford said Judge apparently got lost while in the San Francisco Bay. Authorities haven't determined who shot the seal, but if caught the person could face a year in jail and a $20,000 fine. Judge was raised at the California Marine Mammal Center in Sausalito and tagged before being released into the wild, Rutherford said.

DOC.HEAD: Honduran President Says Democratic Progress Linked to Aid
DOC.TEXT: The United States risks erosions of Central America's recent democratic progress if it fails to fulfill aid commitments to Honduras and its neighbors, Honduran president Rafael Callejas said Thursday. Callejas said he encountered ``a lot of good will'' in discussions with administration and congressional officials this week on U.S. plans to provide $80 million in economic aid to his country in the 1991 fiscal year. But he also was realistic about the political unpopularity of foreign aid in the United States and the increased competition for aid dollars from emerging democracies in Eastern Europe. ``We understand the difficulties in the United States and the new perspectives in Eastern Europe,'' Callejas said at a news conference. ``Without economic support, the Central American region will again have social unrest, and its consequences ... will be a weakening of the democratic system.'' U.S. aid is the only source of short-term financing for the country's balance of payment needs, he said. He added: ``The environment for government is not easy,'' citing a decade of economic reversal in his country he said would take two decades to overcome. But Callejas said a $247 million international loan to pay off past-due debts to international financial institutions will help Honduras begin an economic turnaround by the end of next month. Since he was sworn in on Jan. 27, the 46-year-old, U.S.-educated president has launched sweeping economic reforms, including raising taxes and cutting his government's budget to reduce the deficit. Increasing the region's political stability will help warm the climate for international investment, Callejas said, specifically mentioning development of the tourism and agricultural sectors. In the long run, ``the vital element is not foreign aid but trade,'' he said. During his visit, he sought to open talks about possible future opening of U.S. markets to his country's sugar, coffee, textiles and footwear, said Callejas. He conceded those goods are ``politically subject to very intense dialogue'' because of protectionist sentiments in the United States and said no opening was likely in the next two years. ``Achieving perfection is very complex,'' he said. ``We're looking for a political will demonstration that trade for Central America will be opened.'' On other subjects, Callejas said: _He welcomed news of a truce in Nicaragua between the Sandinista government and the U.S.-backed Contra rebels. ``This implies that there is a guaranteed transition of the presidency in Nicaragua and a willingness to dialogue in the search for solutions,'' he said. _An informal congressional delegation from Honduras is visiting Cuba, but there is no intent to formalize diplomatic relations. ``It is the only Hispanic nation (in the hemisphere) that is not democratic. There is a requirement that they change their political attitudes,'' he said. _It is too soon to talk about economic integration for Central America, until peace is achieved in El Salvador and the new Nicaraguan government can be solidified. But an economic summit in June or July that will include Belize and Panama will be a forum for discussion of such issues, he said.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: Retransmitting a0579 to remove extraneous material in editor's note
DOC.HEAD: Members who used a0682, BC-Drug Assets-List transmitted April 17 under a Washington dateline, are asked to use the following story.
DOC.TEXT: The Associated Press, using information provided by the Justice Department, erroneously reported April 17 that the First Bank of Philadelphia was among 173 banks ordered to produce records of accounts that prosecutors say contained money made by Colombian drug dealers. The Justice Department, in a memo correcting its original list, said the Philadelphia bank covered by the court order is the First Pennsylvania Bank.

DOC.HEAD: Sikhs Bomb Bus in Punjab; 15 People Killed
DOC.TEXT: A bomb set by Sikh separatists exploded in a fast-moving bus in Punjab state, killing at least 15 passengers and injuring 44, police said. Nine people were in critical condition. In other incidents of violence in the state, seven people were shot and killed by the militants, Press Trust of India news agency reported. At least eight militants were killed. Police official Brijender Singh said the bomb exploded in a state-owned bus near Bharoli village, about 60 miles northeast of Amritsar. The Sikh holy city of Amritsar is a main center of the Sikh separatist movement. The bus was on a 180-mile run from the Punjab town of Moga to Jammu, in Jammu-Kashmir state. Singh, the police chief in the area where the bombing occurred, said the vehicle was traveling at 50 mph when the bomb went off. It exploded in the rear of the bus, starting a fire. The dead were identifed as 10 men, three women and two children. Thirteen victims were Hindus, India's religious majority. The other two were Sikhs. PTI said Sikh militants had shot and killed seven people across the state since Wednesday. Four militants were killed during armed encounters with police. Four others died in a Sikh gang war, PTI said. On Sunday, five people were killed when a bomb hidden in a tractor exploded outside a Hindu temple in Ludhiana, 70 miles southeast of Amritsar. Police blamed the Ludhiana bombing on Sikh militants. The extremists have killed 631 people so far this year in Punjab, the only Indian state where Sikhs form a slight majority over Hindus. Nationwide, Sikhs account for 2 percent of the population, while 82 percent of the 880 million Indians are Hindus. Militants in the Sikh community seek a separate nation to guard against what they call cultural and political discrimination by Hindus.

DOC.HEAD: New Missile Program Put On Hold
DOC.TEXT: By BARRY SCHWEID=

With East-West tensions in decline, the Bush administration is postponing indefinitely the development of new short-range nuclear missiles that were to be based in West Germany, U.S. officials said Thursday. The 88 new launchers, 36 of which were to be controlled by the United States and the others by West Germany, Britain and the Netherlands, were designed for targeting on East Germany. They would have been capable of launching about 1,600 missiles. The tentative U.S. goal had been to begin deploying the missiles in 1995 to replace the current mixture of nuclear-armed and conventional Lance missiles with an all-nuclear force and an expanded range. But East Germany is rapidly moving out of the Soviet orbit and preparing for union with West Germany. It is no longer perceived as a threat to the North Atlantic Treaty Organization countries. The current arsenal of Lances will remain in West Germany. About 700 carry nuclear warheads and have a range of about 75 miles. The 900 or so non-nuclear missiles in the arsenal are designed to hit targets within 45 miles. The new launchers were intended to have a range of about 280 miles, just below the level of intermediate-range nuclear missiles that were banned in a U.S.-Soviet treaty in 1987. Sen. Sam Nunn, D-Ga. and chairman of the Armed Services Committee, called the decision sensible and in line with what he had advocated the move for some time. In a speech, Nunn also called for sharp reductions in U.S. forces in Europe beyond the 225,000 level proposed by the Bush administration and tentatively approved by the Soviet Union, which would cut back to 195,000 troops beyond its border. ``We should start planning on a residual force in Europe on the order of 75,000 to 100,000 troops within five years,'' Nunn said. He also suggested cutting the Navy's 14 carrier battle groups to 10 to 12. Congress appropriated $32 million last year to develop the new Lance missiles. The Pentagon has requested $112 million for this year. Overall, the program would have cost more than $1 billion, Dunbar Lockwood of the private Arms Control Association estimated. Pete Williams, the Pentagon spokesman, said the future of the Lance was a decision for the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. He said, however, that the Army Missiles Command had put a hold on plans to issue a formal request for contractors' proposals for building the new weapons. ``The Army has delayed the release of the final request for proposals on the follow-on to Lance,'' he said. Another U.S. official told The Associated Press that ``the present system is a viable deterrent through the year 2000, even though the Army would have liked to start deployment of new Lances in 1995.'' The current Lances recently were touched up with new fuel for their rockets, the replacement of worn-out components and other maintenance. All the new Lances were supposed to be nuclear-armed. Their potential deployment had stirred opposition among West German groups eager to promote disarmament and concerned that deploying new weapons on their territory could make West Germany a more inviting target in the event of a war. As East-West tensions have eased, support for the missiles has declined in the West German government and among several of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization allies. Still, the Reagan and Bush administrations resisted efforts led by West Germany for negotiations to eliminate both NATO and Warsaw Pact short-range missiles until a treaty to cut back troops, tanks and other weapons in Europe is concluded. The accord is still not finished. But, the officials said, the Bush administration has decided not to have the Army Missile Command solicit proposals from munitions makers for manufacturing new Lance missiles. ``The project has been put on indefinite hold,'' said a U.S. official, who spoke on condition of anonymity. He said the current Lance arsenal would serve as a deterrent through the rest of the century.

DOC.HEAD: Senate Panel Votes to Spend More on Organic Farming Research
DOC.TEXT: The Senate Agriculture Committee voted Thursday to increase spending for research on organic farming nearly tenfold. Conventional farming methods promoted by the federal government over the last several decades have involved a growing use of chemical fertilizers, pesticides and herbicides, which environmentalists and many farmers are beginning to consider detrimental. The committee voted to increase the $4.5 million being spent this year on organic farming to $40 million annually. It also authorized $10 million a year to train thousands of extension agents in non-chemical farming methods. The authorization is the first major step the government has taken to get farming out of the chemical business. The legislation, approved on voice vote, also would establish a groundwater office in the Agriculture Department to determine the extent of damage to drinking water caused by agriculture chemicals and how to correct it. The proposals were among the provisions of the committee's agricultural research section, or title, of its 1990 farm bill. Another provision requires USDA to study the effects of climate change on food crops and forests. ``Many scientists believe that a four degree rise in average temperature could halve the world's production of rice _ the staff of life for 70 percent of the world's population,'' said Sen. Patrick Leahy, D-Vt., chairman of the committee. Federal agriculture officials would be required to integrate global warming concerns into plant and forestry research planning and decision-making and to establish an office of climate change if the legislation is adopted. Both the Senate and House agriculture committees have been working since January on the 1990 farm bill, which will set policy for virtually all federal agriculture programs during the next five years. The panels are in different stages of completion on the various parts of the legislation, which they hope to have before the full Congress by summer. The Senate's section on research would authorize an unprecedented $400 million over the life of the bill for research grants to companies, institutions and individuals studying plants, animals, nutrition and health, natural resources and the environment, new products and marketing and trade. The bill also creates partnerships among researchers, state and local governments, private businesses and the federal government for developing and selling industrial products made from farm and forest crops. Progress is being made, for example, in using corn and wheat to make biodegradable plastic bags and diapers. Soybeans are being experimented with in the manufacture of lubricants and printing ink; sunflowers in fuel and red dye; meadowfoam in cosmetics; and milkweed in pillow stuffing and backpacking equipment.

DOC.HEAD: Married to the Mob?
DOC.TEXT: Reputed mobster John Gotti's son is reportedly getting married Saturday, and the lucky woman is in the mob version of the federal witness protection program _ no one is willing to identify her. ``We keep everything confidential,'' said Maria DeCandia, who runs Hidden Assets, a lingerie store where the son, John A. Gotti, is known to shop. ``I have nothing to say. No dice,'' said the pastor of Our Lady of Grace Roman Catholic Church. ``I don't know anything about a wedding. Didn't hear about a wedding. Shows how stupid we are. We don't even know about a wedding,'' said the groom's uncle, Pete Gotti. These comments were harvested by the Daily News, which quoted sources as saying that a reception for 200 people was planned at the Helmsley Palace Hotel. But few other details were forthcoming about the nuptials. The elder Gotti himself answered queries with a cold stare as he entered his favorite haunt, the Bergin Hunt and Fish Club. Others in Gotti's Queens neighborhood said they were in the dark. ``Of course we've heard about it,'' said Nancy, a manicurist who works next door to the Bergin. ``But we have no idea who she is. Nobody knows. It's the question of the day.'' ``We just heard about it. He's really a very nice boy. Who's the girl? Have you heard?'' said Gotti's next-door neighbor, Jack Stillman. Law enforcement officials have alleged that the younger Gotti joined the mob last year. He is 26 and is said to be president of a Brooklyn trucking company; he has been arrested several times in bar fights. His father, known as the Dapper Don, is reputedly head of the Gambino organization, which authorities say is the nation's most powerful crime family.

DOC.HEAD: Radical Students Fight Police on Anniversary of Uprising
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of radical students clashed with riot police Thursday during nationwide protests marking the 30th anniversary of an uprising that toppled the country's first authoritarian government. ``Crush the pro-American fascist regime!'' yelled students as they hurled rocks and firebombs at riot troops in Seoul. News reports said at least 30,000 radicals and dissidents protested in at least six cities. Police reported 25,000 students rallied at 76 colleges and universities and about 10,000 of the protesters were violent. About 50 arrests were reported in Seoul. No injuries were reported, but dozens of police and protesters were hit by rocks or glass as firebombs exploded. In addition to Seoul, violent clashes erupted at schools in the central provincial cities of Taejon and Kongju, and in the eastern cities of Chunchon, Kongneung and Wonju, according to Yonhap, the South Korean news agency. Thousands of riot police were deployed to protect government buildings, train stations and downtown areas. Thursday was the 30th anniversary of the student-led uprising that ended the 12-year authoritarian rule of President Syngman Rhee. Radicals, who have lost support due to their violent tactics, said the anniversary would mark the beginning of fresh anti-government and anti-U.S. protests. They also were protesting the merger in January of the ruling party and two opposition parties into a huge conservative governing party. ``Destroy the merger!'' yelled some 1,000 radical students wielding metal pipes and hurling firebombs and rocks at Seoul's Hankuk University of Foreign Studies. ``Down with (President) Roh Tae-woo!'' As night fell, bands of 50 to 100 students ran through downtown areas jabbing their fists in the air and shouting anti-government slogans. The protests backed up traffic on one of Seoul's main bridges and sent shopkeepers and pedestrians racing for cover to escape acrid gas. The 1960 uprising is generally regarded as the beginning of Korean democracy, and the anniversary is celebrated by both radicals and government officials. ``The April 19 uprising was part of a movement to protect free democracy by youths and students who rose against government oppression,'' Prime Minister Kang Young-hoon said at a ceremony marking the anniversary. ``The precious sacrifice of those slain brought a victory for civil rights as well as a historic turning point for developing a free democracy,'' he said. Police with black paint moved onto Chungang University early Thursday and removed traces of a U.S. flag painted on a campus road. Students have painted U.S. flags on campus roads to let pedestrians trample on them and stimulate anti-U.S. feeling. Officials warned that burning or defaming American flags ``could damage the traditional friendly relationship'' with the United States. Dissidents say the presence of the 43,000 U.S. troops in South Korea prevents reunification of North and South Korea. The radicals are a small but vocal minority in South Korea.

DOC.HEAD: Census Counts On Despite Slow Public Response
DOC.TEXT: The Census Bureau remains determined to count Americans, but the bureau director said Thursday that lagging public response means it will take more people and money to do it. ``We plan to follow up on every housing unit for which a questionnaire was not returned and we have the workforce to do it,'' bureau Director Barbara E. Bryant told the House Census subcommittee. ``The only thing that has changed is that our workload of personal-visit followup will be larger than originally planned.'' To date, 63 percent of households have returned the forms; the bureau had hoped for a 70 percent return by this time. Bryant said it would take an extra 5,300 workers and cost an additional $10 million to count each percentage point below the 70 percent level. ``A 63 percent mail response is by no means a disaster,'' she said. Rep. Tom Sawyer, D-Ohio, said he was ``deeply troubled'' by the low level of participation so far. Public confidence, he said, may be shaken by reports of millions of forms that could not be delivered for various reasons. ``We have had some operational problems and our mail-response came in lower than expected. ... We remain convinced we will have an accurate census,'' Bryant said. Rep. Thomas Ridge, R-Pa., said the bureau does have problems, but ``it's not a crisis, it's not a disaster.'' ``You cannot conclude that we will not have an accurate census,'' Ridge said. ``What you can conclude is that it will cost a lot more money.'' Bryant said the low response rate could boost the cost by $70 million. The bureau has already taken a $60 million cut in general government budget trimming. Asked if her agency would be asking for about $100 million in added money, she declined to be specific. ``It could be more than that,'' she said. The overall cost of the 1990 national head count, spread over 10 years, is expected to total about $2.5 billion. Asked about problems in large buildings and whole towns and ZIP codes being missed, Bryant said about 5 million forms were mailed late because addresses were added for new developments and for places not included earlier. In late summer, there will be a followup to reach people who were missed, and local governments will check the counts for accuracy, she said. About 4.8 million forms were returned to the bureau as undeliverable, a rate Bryant said was well below that of the 1980 census. She said that occurred in many cases because some people get their mail in post office boxes while the census uses street addresses. The street addresses are needed to design political districts. About 1.8 million of the returned forms have been delivered by hand. Of the remaining 3 million, she said most will turn out to be vacant homes and apartments. All locations will be visited. People who have not received forms, she said, should call the bureau at 1-800-999-1990. The bureau will begin sending out about 330,000 workers April 26 to visit homes where people did not respond, Bryant said.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Appoints Trustee to Run Eastern
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 10 grafs to UPDATE with Eastern saying it will not appeal. Picks up 12th graf pvs, `Miami-based Eastern...'. SUBS 16th graf pvs, `Earlier, Bakes...', to restore first reference to airline president. A longer verson moved on the business wire.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY5
DOC.TEXT: Eastern Airlines said today it would not appeal a federal bankruptcy judge's appointment of a trustee to take control of the airline, a move that ousts boss Frank Lorenzo from that role. ``Although we did not feel a trustee is warranted, we are gratified Judge Burton Lifland has indicated the airline will be reorganized and not broken into pieces,'' said spokesman Bob Hunter in Miami. Lifland late Wednesday granted the request of Eastern's unsecured creditors, who sought a trustee because of frustration over the carrier's mounting losses and its plans to cut payments to creditors sharply. ``The flying public's interest must at all times be taken into account,'' Lifland told a packed courtroom, adding later, ``It's time to change the captain of Eastern's crew.'' The head of Eastern's Machinists, while welcoming the move, said today the action would not mean a quick end to his union's year-old strike. ``It will not happen immediately,'' Eastern Machinists president Charles Bryan told a news conference in Miami. ``Obviously we have no interest in going back and sacrificing, working very hard and bringing it out of bankruptcy, only to still have Frank Lorenzo own all the common stock.'' The judge appointed as trustee Martin Shugrue, a pilot and airline executive who formerly worked for Lorenzo, chairman of Eastern parent Texas Air Corp. Shugrue, a former president of Continental Airlines, resigned last year under pressure from Lorenzo. Texas Air also is the parent of Continental. Lorenzo left the courtroom without comment before the decision. Hunter said today that the company welcomed Shugrue's arrival. ``There are no changes, it's business as usual,'' Hunter said. ``His appointment does send a very clear message of Judge Lifland's confidence in the company's future _ he said he would appoint a trustee to operate the airline, not to liquidate it.'' Miami-based Eastern has been in Chapter 11 bankruptcy reorganization since March 1989, after a strike by its pilots, Machinists and flight attendants crippled its operations. The unions had sought a trustee from the start, claiming that Lorenzo was bleeding Eastern by transferring its assets to non-union Continental and Texas Air, and they had heaped practically all their hostility on him alone. Dick Nellis, a representative of Eastern's pilots union, said he was ``overjoyed'' at the ruling but added: ``It is really very sad that it has taken so long for the system to recognize why the real Eastern employees left the property in the first place.'' ``Literally, there have been thousands of careers that have been shattered and billions of dollars of Eastern Airlines assets wasted,'' he said. Earlier, Eastern President Phil Bakes testified that appointment of a trustee would prompt employees to quit, hurt business further and heighten the chance Eastern eventually would have to be liquidated. E.J. Breen, a spokesman for the pilots union in Miami, said the appointment of Shugrue would give Eastern another chance to succeed. The appointment of a trustee in a bankruptcy case is rare, legal experts observed. Lifland said naming a trustee ``is an extraordinary remedy,'' but he cited Eastern's staggering losses of more than $1.2 billion since the bankruptcy filing, which he said had ``wiped out the parent's equity.'' The judge also noted numerous instances where the company had projected overly optimistic results and then cut the amount it proposed to repay creditors in successive reorganization plans. The unsecured creditors, who are owed $980 million, had repeatedly emphasized that they did not seek a liquidation of the airline. Instead, they asked for a trustee to operate Eastern and perhaps seek a buyer for it. Lifland also said during the four-day hearing, which began Friday, that if a trustee were appointed it would be someone to operate rather than liquidate the airline. In closing statements, Eastern's court-appointed bankruptcy examiner used strong language to describe the carrier's losses and Lorenzo's management style, although he did not formally take a position on the trustee request. Examiner David I. Shapiro told the court that other companies in Chapter 11 had never been allowed to continue operating with such big losses and with such a total lack of confidence from creditors. ``Can Mr. Lorenzo now be allowed to wipe out the creditors' interest? Can anyone blame the creditors for being outraged?'' he said. ``Mr. Lorenzo only starts negotiating at the very last minute. ... He's just a tough guy to make a deal with.'' Because of Lorenzo's style, Shapiro added, it would be easier to sell Eastern under a trustee than under current management.

DOC.HEAD: East German Leader Predicts Economic Merger in Eight Weeks
DOC.TEXT: East Germany's prime minister on Thursday said the Germanys may merge their economies within eight weeks, but he demanded that West Germany pay a bigger price for unification. Lothar de Maiziere also said East Germany would defend the military interests of the Soviet Union but still would pursue the quick path to unification that Moscow opposes. De Maiziere, in his first speech to the freely elected Parliament, said a final plan for a single Germany could be in place before Parliament breaks for the summer. ``In the next eight to 10 weeks we will lay the foundations for the economic, monetary and social union so that this union can enter into force before the summer break,'' he said. He said East Germany must be an equal partner in the talks and that the nations ``must agree on conditions that ensure East Germans do not get the feeling of being second-class German citizens.'' While a single currency and shared social and economic institutions could be in place, long negotiations are expected on the process of fully unifying the governments and creating a single nation. The process is not expected to be completed until next year. De Maiziere reiterated that most East German marks, which are virtually worthless, must be traded at a 1-1 rate to the powerful West German mark when a single currency is created. But the vice president of the West German central bank, Helmut Schlesinger, was quoted as saying a 1-1 exchange could lead to higher inflation in West Germany. De Maiziere said he was concerned there was less willingness to help among West Germans fearful that inflation and higher taxes may be the price for bailing out the collapsing East German economy. ``We are not demanding sacrifices from you,'' he said. ``What we expect is togetherness and solidarity. The division of Germany can only be lifted by sharing.'' De Maiziere, chosen as prime minister last week, also said most of the remaining sections of the Berlin Wall would be torn down to symbolize the end of 40 years of oppression. He said one piece would stand as a ``historical monument.'' The wall and East Germany's other border controls were opened in November during the pro-democracy revolt that toppled the former hard-line Communist regime. He also said he expected the Germanys would field a single team in the 1992 Olympics. De Maiziere, in a wide-ranging speech, also sought to ease Soviet objections to quick unification. He said East Germany, now a member of the Warsaw Pact, would protect the interests of the Soviet-led alliance when it negotiates unification. He avoided direct reference to NATO. Last week, his coalition government said a unified Germany could be part of the Western military alliance until a new European security system is formed. The Soviet Union opposes NATO membership for a united Germany. But West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl says the merged country must remain part of the alliance. The West German television network ZDF said Wednesday that a letter from Soviet officials to de Maiziere outlined Moscow's opposition to quick unification because it would lead to rapid integration into NATO. De Maiziere favors a form of unification in which the West German constitution would become the constitution of East Germany. Some German politicans in both states favor a slower pace that would require a new constitution to be written.

DOC.HEAD: Teachers Strike Continues; Legislature Deadlocked
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 12 grafs to UPDATE with senator saying compromise being sought in caucus, picking up 11th graf pvs, `Many of...'.
DOC.TEXT: A teachers strike that has closed hundreds of schools since Monday entered its fourth day today with Oklahoma's Senate struggling to forge a compromise to end a deadlock on education spending. Organizers said they expected their largest demonstration of the week at the Capitol this afternoon, in part because teachers from Oklahoma City, the state's second-largest school district, and Lawton, the third-largest, are joining the strike for the day. At least 12,000 teachers, parents and students picketed at the Capitol on Wednesday. Elsewhere, students staged walkouts at their open schools. Teachers are demanding more pay and higher school spending. Their 31,000-member union, the Oklahoma Education Association, says Oklahoma teachers rank 48th in pay among the states, making $22,000 a year, compared with the national average of $29,648. ``We've waited long enough,'' was the message on stickers worn by many of the teachers, referring to an 8-month-old special session and the failure of the Legislature to enact a $230 million school reform and tax bill. The bill stalled in the Senatthers have been met in part, officials said Thursday. AM-CDC-Drug Goals. Eds: For release 6 p.m. EDT.
DOC.HEAD: CDC-CERVICAL CANCER: ATLANTA _ Deaths from cervical cancer have dropped 11 percent in seven years, but the death rates for black women are still twice as high as those for white women. AM-CDC-Cervical Cancer. Eds: For release 6 p.m. EDT.

SHERIFF'S ARMORY: HOLYOKE, Mass. _ A sheriff who drew national attention when he seized a National Guard armory after running out of room at the county jail quietly declared victory Thursday and began moving his overflow prisoners into a temporary jail fixed up by the state in a closed armory here. AM-Sheriff's Armory.

KENNEDY-PALM BEACH: PALM BEACH, Fla. _ It's the Kennedy clan versus conservationists in the dispute over a waterfront mansion. Some officials want to designate the $3 million estate as a historical landmark, but the Kennedys want to keep control of the estate that once served as a winter White House. AM-Kennedy-Palm Beach.

DENVER CORONER: DENVER _ Mayor Federico Pena has ordered a thorough examination of the Denver coroner's office after a contract pathologist's rulings were questioned in two child-abuse cases. AM-Denver Coroner.

OKLAHOMA SCHOOLS: OKLAHOMA CITY _ The president of the National Education Association speaks to a large gathering of Oklahoma school teachers who are protesting the Legislature's failure to enact a big school reform measure. AM-Oklahoma Schools.

GOTTI WEDDING: NEW YORK _ Reputed mobster John Gotti's son is reportedly getting married Saturday, and the lucky woman is in the mob version of the federal witness protection program _ no one is willing to identify her. AM-Gotti Wedding. Sent as a0595.
DOC.TEXT: The AP

DOC.HEAD: Studio Bidding Leads to Record Price for Screenplay
DOC.TEXT: A film script about a private eye who joins forces with a former football star to solve a murder sold for a record $1.75 million. ``The Last Boy Scout'' could have fetched $2 million, but 28-year-old screenwriter Shane Black said he preferred to sign with the David Geffen Co., an independent producer he worked with previously. It's become almost routine to ask $1 million for prized screenplays in recent months. But industry executives said Tuesday's sale price far exceeded previous highs. Black, who wrote ``Lethal Weapon,'' declined to comment on his latest sale. Geffen, who produced ``Beetlejuice,'' said he wanted the script because, ``I can see a movie in it. It's not maybe a movie. It's definitely a movie, and those aren't easy to find.'' A bidding war has broken out during the past year for ``spec scripts,'' screenplays written without having been commissioned by a producer or studio. The boom, fed in part by a push by 20th Century Fox, Walt Disney Co. and Columbia Pictures to expand their slates, ended the $300,000 benchmark price for top scripts barely a year ago. Black's script apparently attracted the studios because it is action-oriented and crafted well enough to lure a prominent director and actors, and it promises to launch sequels. Fox opened the bidding at $850,000 on Monday, the Los Angeles Times reported Thursday. Universal Pictures dropped out when the price topped $1 million, while Warner Bros. and a partnership between Tri-Star and Carolco Pictures continued in pursuit. The partnership had bid $2 million by late Tuesday before Black chose Geffen, the Times said. Some studio executives say script auctioning has become too costly. ``To get $1 million, it used to have to be a damned good script. Now, you practically pay that for the idea alone and wind up with a lot of rewrites,'' said David Hoberman, head of Disney's Touchstone unit, which has stayed out of the auctions. Others like the change. ``I don't know of anything that generates the excitement of the chase after a big script,'' said John Goldwyn, executive vice president of worldwide production at MGM-UA Communications Co. Screenwriters increasingly are auctioning their work as the studios turn away from the development process, in which executives pay writers to write and rewrite ideas discussed in advance. About 83 percent of Hollywood scripts sold last year were made by the development process, down from 91 percent in 1986, according to partially complete figures from the Writers Guild of America West.

DOC.HEAD: Report: Dinkins Saves in Bank with Links to South Africa
DOC.TEXT: Mayor David N. Dinkins, long active in the anti-apartheid movement, has substantial savings accounts at a bank that does business with South Africa, New York Newsday reported Thursday. The 1989 tax return filed jointly by the mayor and his wife, Joyce, shows $7,284 in interest from four separate accounts at Manufacturer's Hanover Trust Co., the newspaper said. Manufacturer's Hanover not only has renewed loans to South Africa, but is one of two U.S. banks on the committee of creditors that renegotiates South Africa's foreign debt. Dinkins, the city's first black mayor, has strongly supported laws forbidding the city from depositing money in banks that do business with South Africa. Apparently the mayor was unaware of Manufacturer's South African ties, Newsday said. Albert Scardino, Dinkins' spokesman, said the mayor was planning to move the accounts by the end of the week for financial as well as political reasons.

DOC.HEAD: Two Liberal Republics Hold Crucial Free Elections
DOC.TEXT: Yugoslavia's two most liberal republics hold elections Sunday whose results could jeopardize the country's fragile federation. In Croatia, more than 30 parties are vying for parliamentary seats in the republic's first multiparty elections in 50 years. In Slovenia, a center-right coalition advocating independence hopes to consolidate power by winning the republic's presidency. It already won legislative elections. The coalition's candidate, Jose Pucznik, faces a tough battle against Milan Kucan. Kucan is a popular reform Communist who won 44.5 percent of the vote in the first round. Pucnik got 26.6 percent in that vote. In Croatia, surveys suggest the Party for Democratic Change _ the reformed Communist party _ is in the lead for the legislature. But nearly a third of the voters are undecided, according to the polls. If pro-independence forces win in both elections, it could exacerbate the tension with Serbia that threatens to pull apart the country. Yugoslavia is a loose federation of six republics and two autonomous regions, simmering with ethnic and ideological tensions. Slovenia and Croatia, already pushing for closer ties with the West, would move further away from the hard-line Communist leadership of Serbia. It is the largest of Yugoslavia's republics and the only one besides Montenegro still following a one-party system. Croatia and Slovenia have liberal judiciaries and media, and their Communist parties no longer consider their supremacy guaranteed. In hard-line Serbia, there is a strong Communist influence in the press, judiciary and all other aspects of life. Last week, the Communist-dominated Yugoslav military, which has forged close ties with Serbian leader Slobodan Milosevic, warned it would prevent anti-Communist parties in Slovenia and Croatia from assuming power. Franjo Tudjman, leader of the conservative Croatian Democratic Union, which wants radical reshaping of Yugoslavia, dismissed the statement as ``irrational and insane.'' Polls show Tudjman's party in second place behind the reformed Communists. Under Tudjman's formula, Yugoslavia's republics would be independent states that would establish relations only if common interests were involved. The reform Communists are more cautious. They say the federation model is fine for now, but if it fails to reflect the republics' needs in the future Yugoslavia should become a confederation without central rule. The 66-year-old Tudjman once was the Yugoslav army's youngest general but later spent almost five years in jail for ``counterrevolutionary activities.'' His bid for power is fueling the fierce rivalry that has existed between Serbia and Croatia since Yugoslavia was created in 1918. Serbia's Communists brand Tudjman a fascist and a secessionist. They have orchestrated several rallies of Croatia's 450,000 Serb minority, which is haunted by memories of mass extermination in the Croatian puppet state set up by Nazi Germany. The Serbs in Croatia seek autonomy from the republic, but all Croatian parties oppose it. Tudjman is predicting victory, but his two main rivals are also optimistic and appear unwilling to consider establishing a coalition with him if no party wins a majority. Mika Tripalo, a senior member of the Coalition for National Accord, says Tudjman is ``too extreme'' to win. The Coalition embraces five traditional Croatian parties emerging for the first time since World War II, and almost a dozen other movements. It has broad support. Tripalo wants some change in Yugoslavia's complex multi-regional system. For instance, he said, Croatia cannot continue to spend vast sums on poorer regions such as Serbia's strife-torn province of Kosovo. But the Coalition, like the reformed Communists, stops short of advocating Croatian independence. Both seek greater autonomy for the republics and a leaner federal government strictly limited to conducting foreign and defense policies. Ivica Racan, the Party of Democratic Change leader who over the past six months has steered Croatia to a multiparty democracy, virtually rules out coalition with Tudjman. Many voters are skeptical any party has the answer in a key area _ the economy. All want to privatize property nationalized by the Communists and introduce a market economy. None says exactly how. ``All their economic programs are vague, consisting mainly of wishful thinking about the possibilities of huge infusions of foreign capital after the vote,'' said economist Tomica Sohinger. ``Everybody seems to think that Westerners have nothing better to do with their money than to give it to us,'' he added.

DOC.HEAD: Senators Bless Bugs Bunny and Friends as Anti-Drug Warriors
DOC.TEXT: Hollywood's plan to send Bugs Bunny and his friends into the fight against drugs won applause from Congress on Thursday but also a request for more than just the cartoon special set to air on national television Saturday. ``I hope this doesn't devolve into a mere self-promotion activity in which we finally hear from Hollywood and this is the last shot,'' said Rep. John Conyers, D-Mich. ``Showing this once or twice isn't really going to change anybody's mind who's going to use drugs,'' he said. Members of the Senate Judiciary Committee watched a sample of the 30-minute special, ``Cartoon All-Stars to the Rescue'' and applauded the effort to reach youngsters. ``The most powerful weapon that we know in politics is the cartoon and we hope that the cartoon will be the most powerful tool to educate our children,'' said committee Chairman Joseph R. Biden Jr. The program tells of Michael, a 14-year-old drug abuser who is saved with help from Bugs Bunny, the Chipmunks, Daffy Duck, Garfield, Huey, Dewey and Louie, Kermit, Gonzo, Miss Piggy, Slimer, the Smurfs, the Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles' Michaelangelo and Winnie the Pooh. He is also saved from Smoke, a sinister, drug-pushing apparition whose voice was provided by actor George C. Scott. The Academy of Television Arts and Sciences presentation, funded by Ronald McDonald Children's Charities and McDonald's restaurant, is set to air at 10:30 a.m. Saturday EDT and PDT, 9:30 a.m. CDT and 8:30 MDT. According to latest plans, the cartoon will be aired on ABC, CBS, FOX, NBC and numerous independent stations and cable outlets. Roy Disney, vice chairman of the Walt Disney Co. and head of its animation department, was executive producer of the program. In the program, Michael lives in a pleasant, middle-class setting where stuffed bears come to life and the Chipmunks sing and dance while urging Michael to ``say no.'' Asked about long-range plans, Disney Studios President Richard Frank said the studios have been working so hard ``to get this particular special out that we really haven't had time to sit down and plan other ones.'' Actually, only 15 minutes of the production were shown to the lawmakers and some of the music as well as all of the sound effects were missing. ``What you're going to see is minus those embellishments,'' Disney explained. ``I know what I'm going to be doing Saturday morning,'' Biden said after the screening. ``I want to hear the music.''

DOC.HEAD: Park Visitors Will Be Asked to Recycle
DOC.TEXT: Visitors to four of the country's most popular national parks will be asked to recycle glass, plastic and aluminum trash in a program sponsored by two chemical companies and the Interior Department. Recycling will start next month at Great Smoky Mountains National Park in North Carolina and Tennessee, the first site of the recycling education program launched by Dow Chemical Co., Huntsman Chemical Corp. and the department. Acadia in Maine and Grand Canyon in Arizona will be added by June, with plans to expand the program to California's Yosemite by fall. Officials said they hoped eventually to add paper to the list of recycled materials. ``It is time to recognize that recycling is a standard of good citizenship,'' Frank Popoff, chief executive officer of Dow, said at an open-air news conference near the Lincoln Memorial. Bill Snodgrass, recycling project manager with Dow, said the first four parks were chosen for their volume of visitors _ a combined total of 18 million to 20 million a year. ``It's our best chance to reach the public,'' he said. ``We think Americans are willing to recycle. When we see people in a national park, we think their environmental mood has to be fantastic.'' Park visitors will find special plastic bins in which to deposit aluminum, glass and plastic trash. Popoff said it's hoped that local entrepreneurs will start businesses to collect the materials, haul them to nearby separation centers and sell them to recyclers. Where possible, he said, Dow will arrange to have the recycled plastics converted and returned to the parks in the form of picnic tables, park benches, sign posts, guard rails, car stops and other products. Snodgrass said the program will cost the companies $500,000 per park this year, but the costs will decrease after the first start-up year. He said about 2 million pounds of recyclable waste should be recovered in the program's first year. Interior Secretary Manuel Lujan said recycling has not been feasible in the past because of inadequate collection systems. ``This is an experiment,'' he said of the Dow-Huntsman project. ``We think it will work. We think it's the answer.'' Both Dow, of Midland, Mich., and Huntsman, of Salt Lake City, have in-house recycling programs that company officials said save millions of dollars a year. Popoff said Dow's recycling practices reduce the company's wastes by 88 million pounds a year and saved $30 million in 1988.

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: Actress-model Lauren Hutton, the gapped-tooth star of such films as ``American Gigolo,'' filed suit against fellow actress and friend Beverly D'Angelo for alleging breaking her leg in a car accident. ``It's not like she ran over her on purpose. It was just an accident, but we wanted to protect the statute (of limitations),'' Hutton attorney Richard Bisetti said Thursday. Such suits must be filed within a year of an accident. The Superior Court suit filed earlier this month against Miss D'Angelo and Budget Rent A Car seeks an unspecified amount for medical expenses, loss of earnings and pain and suffering. On Aug. 20, Miss D'Angelo was behind the wheel of a rented car that backed into Miss Hutton, 46, who was waiting to get inside, Bisetti said. ``She was in a cast for almost eight months and they (doctors) are still concerned about her leg,'' he said. Bisetti said Miss D'Angelo and Budget Rent A Car were supposed to be served with the suit by Friday. Budget owner Arnold Graham wasn't in the office early Thursday, a receptionist said.

A state agency has offered Bob Hope $20 million for 5,700 acres of his mountain property to spare the rugged canyon country from development, an official said. Hope has not acted on the proposal by the Santa Monica Mountains Conservancy, said Executive Director Joseph T. Edmiston. ``I am optimistic,'' he said Wednesday. ``I think it would be the most important acquisition that has been made, certainly in the last 20 years or so, in the whole Santa Monica Mountains zone.'' Hope has been criticized by environmentalists for moving to sell his vast holdings in Los Angeles and Ventura counties to developers. The proposed agreement would transfer most of Hope's mountain land to the state and federal governments. The area would serve as part of a migratory wildlife corridor for animal populations in the Santa Monica and Santa Susana mountains. The 86-year-old comedian has endured negative publicity in recent months over his sale of mountain lands to prospective developers and his refusal to consider giving or selling the land to park agencies. Hope's publicist Frank Lieberman said the entertainer had no comment regarding the proposed sale.

2 Live Crew members were as nasty as they wanted to be early Thursday as they performed in a nightclub despite threats of arrests on obscenity charges. The nightclub Central City was packed to its 1,500-person capacity when the group opened with a song called ``Martinez Rap,'' about Republican Gov. Bob Martinez's campaign against the group's graphic lyrics. The band, whose album ``As Nasty As They Wanna Be'' has been banned in several Florida counties, began its performance at midnight and concluded about 1:30 a.m. ``Arrests? Not by this department,'' said a duty officer at Gainesville police headquarters who spoke on condition of anonymity. ``This whole thing, we understand, was being publicized by the state attorney's office.'' State attorney Len Register had called some of 2 Live Crew's sexually explicit songs ``the most filthy thing I've ever encountered.'' He threatened to have the band arrested if they played uncensored versions of songs such as ``Me So Horny,'' and ``Move Somethin,'' which has lyrics referring to sadomasochistic sex and violence against women. Register's office said Thursday he was in meetings and would not be available for comment. Debbie Bennett, spokeswoman for the group in Miami, said it played its usual concert. The group had an attorney on hand and bail money available if Register had followed up on his threat, she said. The Miami-based group is led by Luther ``Luke Skyywalker'' Campbell. Members are David ``Mr. Mixx'' Hobbs, Chris ``Fresh Ice Kid'' Won Wong and Mark ``Brother Marquis'' Ross.

A group purportedly acting in the name of religion says it set fire to the office of gospel singer Sandi Patti because she put herself ``on the pedestal of God.'' Police said they have never heard of the ``Equal Religious Coalition'' but they're taking a claim of responsibility for the fire seriously. An unidentified woman professing to be part of the group said Tuesday's fire was set in the singer's office ``in objection to Mrs. Patti's blatancy to continue to put herself on the pedestal of God.'' The woman made the claim to the Anderson Herald Bulletin, the newspaper reported Thursday. It said the woman phoned Wednesday and read a statement. ``We are not taking any information too lightly or too seriously,'' Patti said. ``We are waiting to see how this fits into the whole scheme of things.'' The newspaper notified police, and Chief Ron Rheam said he reviewed the message and is considering it. No one was injured when flames destroyed the Helvering Booking and Management office, operated by Patti's husband, John Helvering. The office handles mail distribution of Patti's records, tapes and T-shirts.

Betsey Fowler, wife of Mutual of Omaha's Wild Kingdom co-star Jim Fowler, has painted a series of works to help fight the extinction of the African elephant. Mrs. Fowler said she adopted the plight of the animals after living among a herd with her family during her husband's research in Kenya. Mutual of Omaha Fund Management, the investment affiliate of the insurance company, sponsored Wednesday's reception for Mrs. Fowler and her husband, a naturalist and conservationist, in honor of the 20th anniversary of Earth Day. Mrs. Fowler formed the Fowler Wildlife Association in New York and is selling prints of her work for up to $125 each, with part of the proceeds going to fight the slaughter of elephants. ``For my children and my grandchildren, I am committed to doing all that I can to save this most powerful species from man's destruction and greed,'' she said. The money will help Richard Leakey, director of Kenya's Department of Wildlife, curb the poaching of elephants for their tusks, she said. About 2,000 elephants are killed each week, and about 85 percent of Kenya's elephants have been killed since 1973, she said, citing Leakey's statistics.

DOC.HEAD: Planned to Leave, but Kidnappers Moved First
DOC.TEXT: Alann Steen, a journalism teacher who once faced down a grizzly bear in Alaska, worried about his safety in wartorn Beirut and had planned to leave. Kidnappers acted first. On Jan. 24, 1987, Steen and three other teachers, two Americans and an Indian with resident alien status in the United States, were abducted by gunmen masquerading as police. Steen, 50, had been in the Lebanese capital since 1983, when he surprised friends by taking a job at Beirut University College. ``When he said he was leaving for Lebanon, we were very surprised that he would make that decision, and people here tried very hard to dissuade him,'' said John Sutthoff, a fellow professor when Steen was at California's Chico State University. During a visit to California in October 1985, Steen told the weekly Arcata Union he moved to Beirut over the objections of his second wife, who filed for divorce after a visit. His third wife, Virginia Rose Steen, heads the Fine Arts Department at Beirut University College and witnessed his kidnapping. They were married in July 1986. Howard Seemann, a former colleague at Humboldt State University in Arcata, said Steen indicated in a 1986 letter he would be spending only one more year in Beirut because it had become too dangerous. Seemann said Steen was nervous walking Beirut's streets because his fair complexion made him easy to identify as a Westerner. He moved back to the campus from a downtown apartment, where he kept a pistol under his pillow and an automatic rifle in his closet, Seeman said. Steen was an editor at the Arcata Union before becoming a journalism teacher, off and on, between 1970 and 1981 at Humboldt State University and at Chico State in 1981-83. He also wrote free-lance articles. In ``Grizzly in No-Man's Land,'' a feature in the magazine ``Outdoor Life'' in February 1979, Steen wrote about an encounter with a bear during a solo backpacking and kayaking trip in Alaska. Steen was born in Boston April 22, 1939. He served with the Marines in the Far East during the Vietnam War, according to Humboldt State personnel records, but his daughter Becky said he never saw combat. He graduated from Humboldt State in 1969 with a journalism major and later received a master's degree in English and journalism from that school. Seemann described Steen as ``the good American, the opposite of the ugly American ... very relaxed, patient and pleasant.''

DOC.HEAD: `He Loved the People, the Campus'
DOC.TEXT: Robert Polhill visited Beirut on business trips for an accounting firm and fell in love with the country, his mother recalled. He returned as an assistant professor of business studies at Beirut University College. On Jan. 24, 1987, he and three other academics were kidnapped by gunmen posing as policemen. Polhill, 55, had lived in Lebanon for four years with his second wife, Ferial, who is Lebanese. His mother, Ruth Polhill, a retired high school librarian who resides in Fishkill, N.Y., said her son visited Lebanon on one of his first business trips for a New York City accounting firm. ``It was very beautiful,'' she recalled. ``He loved the people. He loved the campus.'' Polhill, a diabetic who requires daily medication, attended Cornell University and graduated from New York University in 1961, after which he began work as a New York accountant. He was described as a photography buff, an avid New York Giants fan and a committed educator. ``We are a family that's been touched by teaching,'' said Polhill's aunt, Lois Bird of East Rochester, N.Y. Polhill had two children from a previous marriage _ Steven, of New York City and Brian, a student at the State University of New York at Binghamton. His mother said he told her he was not fearful living on the Beirut campus. ``Now that's what he tells his mother,'' she said. ``He had all the confidence he's be safe on the Beirut campus.'' Said son Brian: ``We knew it (kidnapping) was a possibility, but it wasn't something he put a big accent on. He was extremely careful. He kept a low profile.''

DOC.HEAD: Math Professor Taught Three Years in Beirut
DOC.TEXT: Jesse Jonathan ``Jon'' Turner, one of four Beirut University College staff members taken hostage Jan. 24, 1987, stayed in Lebanon to help the college's students get the education they needed, his former wife says. Ina Clare Turner of Moscow, Idaho, said that feeling of responsibility was common among faculty members at the college. ``They all loved BUC as much as Jon does,'' she said. ``Very assuredly I would say they were all there because they wanted to be there.'' Turner, 42, an associate professor of mathematics and computer science at the Beirut campus, was abducted with three other academics, two Americans and an Indian, by men posing as police assigned to protect the college staff. ``He was told the campus was secure,'' said Turner's mother, Estelle Ronnenburg of Boise, Idaho. ``The Lebanese police guarded it, along with student police. The college was fenced all the way around.''' Mrs. Ronneburg said her son, who married a Lebanese woman, had integrated well with the people in Beirut. ``He had many friends over there and came to be highly thought of,'' she said. Turner graduated from Boise High School and received an undergraduate degree in psychology from Boise State University in 1970 and three graduate degrees from the University of Idaho _ master's degrees in philosophy and mathematics, and a doctorate in mathematics. Mrs. Ronneburg said he moved to Beirut from Hawaii in 1983. During the 18 months she spent in Beirut, Ina Clare Turner said, fighting outside the closed campus forced the couple and other faculty members to seek refuge in a basement shelter. The stays would last from four hours to three days and the shelter, a radio-television classroom in better times, was furnished with foam mattresses. ``When we went down there we would take bottles of water, oranges to eat and books to read. Whenever we heard there was trouble, we would go down to the shelter and wait it out,'' she said. Turner's second wife, Badr, gave birth to a daughter, Joanne, on July 24, 1987, five months after he was kidnapped.

DOC.HEAD: White House Dispatches Hostage Reception Team
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Subs pvs graf 2 with 3 new grafs to include kidnappers saying release postponed.
DOC.TEXT: The White House said today it had dispatched a hostage reception team to Wiesbaden, West Germany after hearing ``statements of imminent release'' of an American hostage in Lebanon. But pro-Iranian kidnappers in Beirut said they have postponed the release because the United States failed to meet their demand to send a senior State Department official to Syria. The handwritten statement was accompanied by an instant picture of Robert Polhill, one of three U.S. educators held by the group since Jan. 24, 1987. Presidential spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said the release statements came from both the Islamic Jihad for the Liberation of Palestine, which is holding several American hostages, and from Syria. ``We're hopeful this could be real,'' Fitzwater said as the president flew to Florida for a meeting with French President Francois Mitterrand. Fitzwater said the State Department had dispatched a reception team to Wiesbaden, ``where they have the medical facilities to receive any hostage that might be released.'' ``We have statements of imminent release from Islamic Jihad and from Syria,'' Fitzwater told reporters. But, he cautioned, ``there's no way for us to know conclusively that it's going to happen.'' He said the hostage reception team has been sent there before on rumors of a hostage release that never happened. The Islamic Jihad for the Liberation of Palestine said on Wednesday it would release one hostage this week. It did not identify the hostage, but the statement was accompanied by an instant photograph of Jesse Turner of Boise, Idaho. The group also holds Alann Steen and Robert Polhill. Fitzwater said the Syrian government sent word through diplomatic channels Wednesday that it appears a hostage would be released. ``It is a little more significant that we have a statement from the Syrian government, but it by no means makes it a certainty,'' he said. At the State Department, spokeswoman Margaret D. Tutwiler said the message from Syria was the first official word to the U.S. government that a hostage may be released. She also ruled out any ``deals'' and said the United States had had no contact with Iran, directly or indirectly, about the captive Americans. Ms. Tutwiler said Edward Djerejian, the U.S. ambassador Damascus, had returned to his post in Syria after attending a meeting of U.S. diplomats in Bonn, West Germany. She said Assistant Secretary of State John Kelly, who also attended, did not plan to goto Syria, as demanded by the Islamic Jihad. Eight Americans are among the Western hostages held in Lebanon by pro-Iranian groups. The longest-held is Terry Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press, kidnapped March 16, 1985. Turner, Steen and Polhill were taken from the campus of Beirut University College in Beirut on Jan. 24, 1987. Asked if the administration was concerned that sending Kelly to Damascus might be viewed as negotiating with terrorists, Fitzwater said, ``we certainly don't want any question about negotiations to be raised by his going.'' ``Our position is that we want the unconditional release of all hostages. We will not deal or negotiate for hostage release but we're hopeful this could be real,'' Fitzwater said.

DOC.HEAD: Woman on Trial Gives Birth in Court
DOC.TEXT: Childbirth can be a trial, and it can even happen at a trial. Jacqueline Jamerson, 24, had her son minutes Wednesday after she walked out of District Judge John Ballard's courtroom complaining of labor pains. She was taken to an adjacent courtroom where she gave birth with the help of a fire department ambulance crew. A jury had been picked to hear drug charges against Ms. Jamerson when defense attorney Michael Walker told the judge his client was experiencing ``discomfort.'' The defendant's friend Ester Johnson said Ms. Jamerson complained of being uncomfortable, but assumed it was because she had been sitting on a wooden chair for three days of jury selection. ``I told her she might be going into labor, but she said it was only a few pains,'' Ms. Johnson said. ``She handled this pretty well.'' Ms. Johnson, however, said she almost panicked watching the delivery. ``That baby was a real screamer.'' Mother and son were listed in good condition at the LSU Medical Center. Jurors were told Thursday to go home for the weekend. Jamerson, her former boyfriend Gerald ``Itty-Bitty'' Kennedy, 30, are charged with possessing about 2 pounds of cocaine. Jamerson's attorneys said they will ask for a mistrial.

DOC.HEAD: $50,000 Prize Set Up for Top Lincoln Scholarship
DOC.TEXT: A $50,000 annual Abraham Lincoln Prize has been established to stimulate scholarship into Lincoln's presidency and the Civil War era, sponsors of the award announced Thursday. The prize, said by its sponsors to be by far the largest ever offered in the field of American history, will be awarded annually to a scholarly work _ deemed to be the finest of the year _ dealing with Lincoln, Civil War soldiers or related subjects. The award will be administered by Gettysburg College and will be presented at its Pennsylvania campus each year on Lincoln's birthday, beginning on Feb. 12, 1991. Funds for the award were donated by New York financiers Lewis E. Lehrman and Richard Gilder Jr. Lehrman, a former unsuccessful Republican candidate for governor, is a managing director of the investment banking firm of Morgan, Stanley & Co. Gilder is president of Gilder, Gagnon & Co., a Wall Street stock brokerage. The announcement of the founding of the award was made in a ceremony at the National Portrait Gallery in a hall used by Lincoln 125 years ago to celebrate his second inaugural. A portrait of Lincoln hangs around the corner from where the announcement was made. Gabor S. Boritt, professor of civil war studies at Gettysburg College, said founders anticipate the Lincoln Prize will usually be awarded to the author of a work of history, generally a book. But he said an important article or essay or even works of fiction, poetry, the theatre, the arts or film might be considered, ``provided they show high fidelity to history.'' The jurors for the 1990 Lincoln Prize will be Robert V. Bruce, professor emeritus of history at Boston University; James M. McPherson, professor of history at Princeton University and winner of the Pulitzer Prize for his 1988 Civil War history, ``Battle Cry of Freedom''; and Tom Wicker, a columnist for The New York Times whose 1984 novel, ``Unto This Hour,'' dealt with the Civil War battle of Second Manassas.

DOC.HEAD: Cervical Cancer Deaths Falling, But Blacks Still at Greatest Risk
DOC.NOTE: Eds: For release 6 p.m. EDT, time set by source.
DOC.TEXT: Cervical cancer deaths have dropped 11 percent in seven years, but the death rates for black women remain more than twice as high as those for white women, federal cancer specialists reported Thursday. The racial disparity is ``substantial and persistent,'' the Centers for Disease Control reported, though black women may have surpassed white women in getting cervical cancer screening. U.S. deaths from cervical cancer dropped from 5,537 in 1980 to 4,951 in 1987, the latest year for which detailed analysis is available, the Atlanta-based agency said. ``That's primarily from the increased use of screening,'' said CDC cancer researcher Eddas Bennett. Virtually all cervical cancer deaths are preventable with early detection _ chiefly through Pap test screening _ and treatment when necessary, the CDC said. Overall, annual cervical cancer death rates declined from 4.2 deaths per 100,000 women in 1980, to 3.4 in 1987. But while the rate among black women fell from 10.1 per 100,000 in 1980 to 7.6 in 1987, it remains more than twice the white rate, which dropped from 3.6 to 2.9. The CDC attributed the racial disparity in death rates to generally lower socio-economic status among blacks, as well as a higher incidence rate of cervical cancer, regardless of outcome. Preliminary CDC reports indicate that black women actually are more likely than whites to undergo cancer-screening Pap smears. ``A higher proportion of black women ... report having been screened,'' the CDC said, citing an unpublished study whose details are not yet publicly available. Lower screening rates for black women in previous years may be contributing now to higher death rates in older black women, Bennett said. ``Previously, black women were screened less frequently than white women, and it takes some years for it to catch up,'' she said. But ``for younger black women who were screened more frequently than their white counterparts, disparities in follow-up and treatment may have contributed to excess cervical cancer mortality,'' the CDC said. ``If you're screened, it often comes down to a question of whether you actually received the appropriate follow-up,'' Bennett said.

DOC.HEAD: Solidarity Begins Second Congress
DOC.TEXT: The Solidarity trade union under the gavel of chairman Lech Walesa launched its second national congress Thursday, celebrating its past triumphs while facing deep questions about its future. In an emotional opening speech, Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki invoked the memory of the union's long, painful struggle to survive after the shock of martial law in 1981. ``Solidarity is alive. Poland is alive, free and independent,'' proclaimed the prime minister, interrupted by cheers from the 487 delegates. Walesa looked more to the future. ``Solidarity has had great achievements, but expectations are even higher and we have to live up to them,'' he told the congress before turning control of the meeting over to a 10-member presidium. The scheduled six-day meeting takes place in the same Olivia sports hall where the union met for 18 stormy days in September and October 1981. Communist authorities declared military rule to crush Solidarity only two months later, forcing the union into an eight-year battle to regain legal status and worker rights. The union finally triumphed at talks one year ago, leading to the swift toppling of Communist rule after elections in June. Within months, Communist monopolies were broken in the five other East bloc countries. Solidarity now faces new difficulties. The union has managed to regain only 2.2 million of the 10 million members it had in 1981. Opinion polls show confidence in Solidarity dropping as the public undergoes economic hardships associated with the strict austerity program pursued by Mazowiecki's Solidarity-created government. Economic restructuring is forcing plant closures and raising joblessness among the industrial workers who are the backbone of Solidarity's support. Walesa, meanwhile, has criticized the pace of political reforms, saying Mazowiecki's team is not moving quickly enough to dislodge Communists from power in state-owned enterprises and government ministries. Before a backdrop upon which the red union ``Solidarnosc'' logo was silk-screened, Walesa stood alone on the dais Thursday morning and pounded his gavel three times to bring the congress to order. Delegates and hundreds of international guests and observers applauded, with some union members raising their arms in the traditional Solidarity V-for-victory sign. A symbolic procession of workers _ including black-uniformed miners in tall feathered caps and shipyard workers in blue worksuits and yellow hardhats _ took up positions on the side of the hall. After leading the singing of the national anthem, Walesa announced that the congress had ended the underground and provisional phase of the union's activity.
