He asked for a moment of silence ``for the people who died that we might live a dignified life.'' During the congress, the union will elect new leaders and accept a program for the future. Walesa appeared all but certain to win another term as chairman, but rumors circulated that he would be challenged. At least one Solidarity region, Upper Silesia, is on record as proposing alternative candidates. A draft prepared for the congress urges Solidarity to concentrate more on traditional union issues, while not resigning entirely from being a broad-based political movement. One option to be discussed is creation of a separate Solidarity political party. The congress' first day was mainly given over to ceremony, procedural details and speeches from invited guests such as Mazowiecki. The prime minister, whose economic policies are likely to come under harsh criticism at the congress, stressed his roots in Solidarity in an emotional speech to the congress. ``I am one of you. I remain one of you,'' he said. ``I want to remain faithful to this.'' While acknowledging the ``difficult, painful problems that have appeared _ unemployment, hard living conditions,'' Mazowiecki called attention to signs of success for his economic policies, including ``smothering of inflation (and) more goods in stores.'' He said entirely free local elections scheduled across Poland on May 27 will have a profound effect in increasing democracy in Poland. Today, he concluded: ``We can say we have won this fight against totalitarianism and we shall will this fight for democracy.'' As Mazowiecki stepped away from the podium, half the hall stood to applaud. The other half remained seated until a smiling Walesa went over to vigorously shake the prime minister's hand.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Safety Investigators Want More Access To Cruise Ships
DOC.TEXT: The nation's chief accident investigator asked on Thursday for more power to examine mishaps on cruise ships that sail under foreign flags but work out of U.S. ports and carry mostly Americans. Complaining that international owners have thwarted efforts at investigating offshore accidents involving foreign-flag cruise ships, National Transportation Safety Board Chairman James L. Kolstad encouraged Congress to expand the powers of U.S. authorities. ``Had the Scandinavian Star been carrying hundreds of U.S. passengers off the Florida coast instead of Europeans in the North Sea, neither the National Transportation Safety Board nor the U.S. Coast Guard would have been able to investigate this accident without the owner's permission,'' Kolstad said. Kolstad was referring to the shipboard fire a more than a week ago in the North Sea in which more than 160 people died. The NTSB had investigated a major fire aboard the same ship two years ago in the Gulf of Mexico and ``identified some of the very problem areas survivors have reported this past week,'' he told the House merchant marine subcommittee. Kolstad pointed to another thwarted effort at an offshore investigation: the February 1989 collision between the Celebration, owned by Miami-based Carnival Cruise Lines and operating under Liberian registry, and a Cuban bulk carrier. Not only cruise ships, but also cargo ships operate under so-called ``flags of convenience'' such as those of Panama or Liberia, allowing them to avoid higher taxes and wages. The ``flag state'' rules govern the ship on the high seas, while ``port state'' rules govern it within the port state's territory. But Kolstad and members of Congress say the burgeoning cruise industry has exploited the law of the seas. Critics say the businesses are American in everything except flag, and many ships go on short excursions known as ``cruises to nowhere'' to escape onshore gambling laws. Unions are using the same argument to push for putting the crews of these ships under jurisdiction of U.S. labor law. Opponents say that U.S. efforts to extend regulation would violate long-established international law and would drive cruise operators to base their ships in the Bahamas and offer cheap fly-and-cruise packages. Kolstad argued that the international mechanism for addressing safety issues and accident investigations is too slow and cumbersome. The United States is host nation to more than 80 percent of the world's large passenger vessels, some now capable of carrying 2,600 passengers. Coast Guard Rear Admiral Joel D. Sipes disputed Kolstad's assertions about the lack of international cooperation and said his agency prefers working within international agreements. ``That is the experience that NTSB has had that we have not,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Kidnappers Say Release of U.S. Hostage Postponed
DOC.TEXT: Pro-Iranian kidnappers said Thursday they postponed indefinitely the release of an American hostage because the United States refused to send a senior State Department official to Syria. The announcement came in an Arabic-language statement delivered by Islamic Jihad for the Liberation of Palestine. It was delivered to the independent Beirut newspaper an-Nahar and a Western news agency. The handwritten statement was accompanied by an instant picture of Robert Polhill, one of U.S. educators held by the group since Jan. 24, 1987. The kidnappers on Wednesday said John Kelly, U.S. assistant secretary of state for Near Eastern affairs, should fly to Damascus ``to coordinate some final steps to guarantee success within 48 hours.'' They said a hostage would be freed within that time frame. The White House refused to dispatch Kelly. Doing so would either have engaged the United States in negotiations over the hostages or given that appearance, a senior U.S. official explained Wednesday night. The group's statement Thursday reiterated the demand that Kelly be sent to Damascus. ``As for the release of the American hostage, arrangements had been under way on the basis that they would be concluded and finalized,'' the statement said. ``But Kelly's failure to respond has so far frustrated the release, which made us postpone this operation until the picture is cleared,'' it added. The kidnappers said Wednesday they were freeing one of the three Americans in response to requests from Iran and Syria, whose leaders have encouraged an end to the hostage crisis. The group implied that some sort of exchange was involved. On Thursday morning, White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said the United States had dispatched a hostage reception team to West Germany after hearing ``statements of imminent release'' of an American hostage. The group did not say which of the three would be freed, only that the release would occur within 48 hours _ or by Friday evening. That statement was accompanied by an instant photograph of Jesse Turner of Boise, Idaho _ the first photo of him alone since three months after his abduction. The group also holds Alann Steen. Steen, Polhill and Turner were abducted from the campus of Beirut University College on Jan. 24, 1987. Turner, 42, taught mathematics and computer science at Beirut University. Polhill, 55, of New York, was a lecturer in accounting. Steen, a journalism professor born in Arcata, Calif., and a former resident of Boston, turns 51 Sunday. Eight Americans are among the Western hostages held in Lebanon by pro-Iranian groups. The longest-held is 42-year-old Terry Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press. He was kidnapped March 16, 1985.

DOC.HEAD: Police Find Body Entombed in Concrete
DOC.TEXT: A body encased in concrete was discovered Thursday by police using sledgehammers after a woman told them she could no longer live with the secret of the man's death, authorities said. Elaine LaDolce told police the man had died Nov. 7 after her boyfriend, Paul Garland, gave him a bath in scalding water, said Police Capt. Gabriel DiBernardo. The victim, in his mid-30s, shared the house with Garland and LaDolce in this city 10 miles north of Buffalo, authorities said. His name was withheld until relatives were notified. Police said they were trying to find the 40-year-old Garland for question him. Authorities had not decided what, if any, charges to file. The police captain said Garland had threatened to kill LaDolce if she told anyone about the death, but she went to police late Wednesday after fighting with him and deciding she ``could no longer live with the terrible secret.'' She told detectives Garland had complained about the man's smell and ordered him into the bathtub while he boiled water on the kitchen stove, DiBernardo said. LaDolce said she did not see what happened in the bathroom, but heard the man's screams after Garland took in the scalding water, DiBernardo said. The screams stopped and Garland emerged from the bathroom saying ``something was wrong, that his friend wasn't breathing,'' the detective said. Garland dressed the body and dragged it downstairs, LaDolce told police. He allegedly tried to dig a grave in the basement but couldn't break through the floor, so he built a wooden vault around the body and encased the whole thing in concrete, DiBernardo said. It took detectives four hours to break through the concrete, he said.

DOC.HEAD: House Budget Committee Plan Would Slash Defense Spending
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 4 grafs to UPDATE with committee action. Picks up 3rd graf pvs `We believe ...' SUBS 21st graf pvs `Why couldn't ...' with 4 grafs to UPDATE with Schuette vote, quotes. Picks up 22nd graf pvs `The Democratic ...'
DOC.TEXT: The Democratic-controlled House Budget Committee on Thursday approved a plan to slash President Bush's defense spending proposal and shift billions of dollars to domestic programs. The $1.24 trillion budget for fiscal 1991 was approved on a 21-14 party-line vote. Debate in the full House was scheduled for next week. House Majority Leader Richard Gephardt, D-Mo., said there was ``good common sense'' behind the Democratic version of the fiscal 1991 budget. He described it as ``a sharp departure from the status quo.'' Republicans portrayed the plan as an embodiment of the same old liberal Democratic priorities, with irresponsible defense cuts and loose reins on domestic spending. But they expressed little concern, calling the committee action just an early step in the long budget process. ``We believe the sooner we get this exercise over the sooner ... we can actually begin writing the bill'' in bipartisan talks involving the president, said Rep. Bill Frenzel of Minnesota, senior Republican on the committee. At the White House, spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said the president had ``no plans for a summit at this time'' on the budget. The Democratic budget envisions $295 billion in military spending next year, about $1 billion less than in the current year and $8 billion less than requested by Bush. Three-fourths of the defense savings would be shifted immediately into domestic accounts that include Medicaid, food stamps, education, AIDS and anti-drug abuse programs. Liberals on the committee failed Thursday in their attempt to cut defense spending even further next year. However, they said they were satisfied with the long-term blueprint in the budget for squeezing the Pentagon by 25 percent over the next five years. The Democratic budget is structured to force the Pentagon to abandon procurement of expensive weapons systems. Although it avoids specifics, the B-2 stealth bomber is an obvious target. The long-term focus also would help Congress avert troop cutbacks before the November election. The Senate Budget Committee was scheduled to begin its budget-drafting next week. Its chairman, Sen. James Sasser, D-Tenn., has suggested military spending be cut even more deeply next year than it would under the House plan. Senate Armed Services Committee Chairman Sam Nunn, D-Ga., has balked at that suggestion. ``The Democratic (defense cut) proposal in the House is higher than mine would be but it is within the range of responsibility,'' Nunn said Thursday. He said he would submit his own figures late this week or early next week. He proposed Thursday that U.S. troop strength in Europe should be cut well below the 225,000 baseline proposed by Bush. ``We should start planning on a residual force in Europe on the order of 75,000 to 100,000 troops within five years,'' he said in a speech. In the House committee Thursday, Democrats describe their fiscal blueprint as a turning point. ``It recognizes the realities of a changing world in which our leadership will be tested not by the threat of nuclear war but by the challenge of reversing a legacy of debt and unmet needs within our society,'' said budget committee chairman Leon Panetta, D-Calif. ``The defense number is the fulcrum of the budget,'' said Rep. Charles Schumer, D-N.Y. Republicans, he said, wanted to maintain it ``to fight the last war. The new war we must fight is the economic war.'' But Republicans and some Democrats criticized the plan for adding new domestic spending when federal deficits are still in the $100 billion a year range. ``If you liked the Dukakis economic program, you'll love this budget,'' said Rep. Hal Rogers, R-Ky. ``The defense number ... is scary,'' said Rep. Jim McCrery, R-La. Why couldn't the ``peace dividend'' from defense cuts be translated into ``a deficit reduction dividend or a tax reduction dividend?'' asked Rep. Bill Schuette, R-Mich. Schuette also voted against Bush's budget when it was defeated in committee when offered as a substitute to the Democratic plan. The Democratic budget envisions $13.9 billion in new taxes next year, the same amount requested by Bush in his budget. The plan does not specify where those revenues might be found, and like Bush the word ``taxes'' is avoided. The taxes help the plan achieve its goal of reducing the federal deficit by about $36 billion next year. The government's red ink would be reduced to about $64 billion as figured under the Gramm-Rudman budget law. Those figures include the surplus in the Social Security trust fund as part of the government's revenue stream. But Panetta said that even if that influx wasn't counted, his committee's plan would balance the budget by fiscal 1995. Sen. Pete V. Domenici of New Mexico, senior Republican on the Senate Budget Committee, called Thursday for a bipartisan budget summit to develop a major, long-term plan to restore fiscal balance. Panetta sought to put the onus on the Bush. ``It would be in the best interest of the country if the president and the Congress worked together to resolve their differences and develop a strong deficit reduction package,'' he said. ``In the absence of that kind of cooperation, however, the budget committee must proceed with the budget process.''

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Syrian Soldiers Put Down Street Battles Between Rival Moslems
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 16 grafs to UPDATE with kidnappers' new statement, tightens; Picks up 27th graf, `Islamic Jihad ...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto BEI1
DOC.TEXT: Syrian soldiers tamed street battles between rival Shiite militiamen Thursday after four hours of fighting left four people dead and 10 wounded, police said. The Syrians apparently were dispatched to prevent clashes from hindering the promised release of an American hostage held by a pro-Iranian group. Later in the day, however, the group announced the release had been postponed. The group, Islamic Jihad for the Liberation of Palestine, released a statement saying that the release of one of three American educators had been delayed by the United States' refusal to send a senior State Department official to Syria. The three Americans were seized Jan. 24, 1987. Also Thursday, Israeli warplanes twice raided a tunnel complex used by Syrian-backed Palestinian guerrillas near a seaside village south of Beirut. Two people were wounded. The raids were launched three days after guerrillas in southern Lebanon fired Katyusha rockets into northern Israel. They exploded in a field and caused no casualties. The Syrian soldiers moved into the capital's western and southern zones to separate gunmen of the Iranian-backed Hezbollah, or Party of God, and the Syrian-backed Amal militia. About 12,500 Syrian troops are stationed in Beirut's Moslem sector as a peacekeeping force. The fighting had raised fears that it could jeopardize the hostage's release. Most of the 18 Westerners missing in Lebanon, including eight Americans, are believed held by groups linked to Hezbollah in the southern slums, a Shiite stronghold. ``Tension resulting from intra-Shiite clashes could block efforts to release a hostage,'' a police spokesman said, speaking on condition of anonymity. ``The Syrian command is obviously keen on facilitating a hostage release.'' The appearance of Syrian patrols armed with automatic weapons, machine guns and rocket-propelled grenades ended four hours of clashes between the rival factions. For more than two years the two groups have fought sporadically for control of Lebanon's 1.2 million Shiites, the country's largest sect. The fighting flared after Islamic Jihad for the Liberation of Palestine issued its statement Wednesday saying that it would release a hostage within 48 hours. The kidnappers said the release would be in response to requests from Iran and Syria, whose leaders have sought to end the hostage crisis. Hostages freed in Beirut are usually taken by the Syrians to Damascus, where they are handed to representatives of their governments. The kidnappers' statement Wednesday did not name the hostage to be released. It was accompanied by a photograph of captive Jesse Turner, 42, of Boise, Idaho. Turner, a professor of mathematics and computer science, was kidnapped with three colleagues from the U.S.-affiliated Beirut University College campus Jan. 24, 1987. One of the educators, Nithileshwar Singh, was freed Oct. 3, 1988. The group also still holds journalism professor Alann Steen of Boston, who turns 51 Sunday, and Robert Polhill, 55, an accounting lecturer from New York. The hostage held the longest in Lebanon is Terry Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press. He was seized March 16, 1985. Islamic Jihad for the Liberation of Palestine threatened March 15 to kill its three hostages unless the United States met unspecified demands. It also threatened to attack airlines flying Soviet Jewish emigrants to Israel. The group previously offered to trade the professors for 400 Arab inmates held in Israel. The Israelis rejected the swap. The last American hostage released in Lebanon was David Jacobsen, former director of the American University Hospital in Beirut. He was kidnapped May 28, 1985, by another pro-Iranian Shiite group, Islamic Jihad, or Islamic Holy War. He was freed Nov. 2, 1986, under a clandestine arms-for-hostages deal between Washington and Tehran. Singh is an Indian citizen who was a U.S. resident. In addition to the eight Americans, four Britons, two Swiss, two West Germans, an Irishman and an Italian are missing in Lebanon.

DOC.HEAD: Math, Science Education Needs More Money, Senate Told
DOC.TEXT: Scientists and teachers complained before a Senate panel Thursday that a bill created to boost math and science achievement fails to put enough money behind the ambitious goals. ``The money is minuscule compared to the problem,'' Charles Hollister, marine geologist and vice president of an oceanographic center in Woods Hole, Mass., told the Senate Labor and Human Resources Committee. ``None of us really can get too excited about cranking up our enthusiasm for something that's so small.'' The bill, the Excellence in Mathematics, Science and Engineering Education Act, recently was introduced by Sens. Edward Kennedy, D-Mass., and Claiborne Pell, D-R.I., to help reach the national education goal of making America No. 1 in math and science by the year 2000. About $125 million would be pumped in increments of a few million dollars into wide-ranging programs designed to tackle a variety of problems in the disciplines, as well as provide incentives to minorities and women. Hollister explained it takes as much as $30,000 a year to train a graduate student _ ``just for stipend alone.'' When the research costs are added in, ``it's between $250,000 to $500,000, just for one doctoral student. ``My sense of the bill is (that) the blueprint is pretty good. I was alarmed at the low numbers. I don't think you could possibly have an impact with $2 million to $3 million with today's money, especially with the goal being what it is,'' he said, estimating the appropriation should be ``closer to $1 billion.'' Shirley Malcom of the American Association for the Advancement of Science agreed that ``the size of the authorization is not on a scale with the size of the problem.'' ``Even if we assume that programs can be devised that have higher leverage over state, local and private funds as well as the voluntary efforts of thousands, the level of support currently proposed is not in keeping with the scale of the problem,'' said Ms. Malcom. Hans Andersen, president of the National Science Teachers Association, said the bill should double to about $10 million the amount slated to assess student achievement in each of the programs.

DOC.HEAD: State Department Criticizes Shamir Government
DOC.TEXT: The State Department called on Israelis on Thursday to choose a government ``capable of saying yes'' to U.S. proposals for negotiations with Palestinian Arabs. ``It's our view that progress at this point depends on the emergence of a government that is capable of making decisions and willing to move forward on peace,'' spokeswoman Margaret D. Tutwiler said. The statement reflected barely concealed resentment that Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir had not pushed through a formula by Secretary of State James A. Baker III for negotiations. Israel has been in the throes of trying to form a new government to replace the ruling coalition, headed by Shamir, that fell apart over the Baker plan. Shamir objected to provisions for participation in the negotiations by Palestinians expelled from the West Bank or having had homes there. ``The U.S. has worked very hard to move the peace process forward,'' Ms. Tutwiler said, reading from a prepared statement. ``We have made important progress by getting to the point where Palestinians from the territories were prepared to engage in a dialogue with Israel about elections.'' The U.S. official added: ``What is needed now to get to such a dialogue is for an Israeli government to emerge that is capable of saying yes to the proposals put forward by Secretary Baker.'' Jerusalem said the statement, portions of which were given to Israeli reporters on Wednesday, was improper. Foreign Ministry spokesman Yosef Amihud said U.S.-Israeli relations were ``characterized by a long tradition of non-interference in internal political processes.'' ``The process of forming a new government is currently under way in Israel. It is therefore to be expected that another country, be it as friendly as it may be, will not interfere,'' he added. Shamir, who remains prime minister in a caretaker government, was asked by reporters in Jerusalem if he would accept the Baker formula. ``It is self-understood that I cannot say this,'' he said. Meanwhile, Senate Republican Leader Bob Dole said Thursday that a Senate resolution recognizing Jerusalem as Israel's capital has damaged Middle East peace efforts and is an example of increasingly hasty actions by the chamber on sensitive matters. ``These kinds of resolutions, hastily prepared and even more hastily passed, are nonsense _ dangerous nonsense, and we ought to do something about it,'' said Dole, who was one of 84 sponsors of the measure that was approved in March. The State Department, meanwhile, took another slap at the continuing settlement of Jews on the West Bank and in Gaza. Ms. Tutwiler said it was ``disappointing that a leadership that was not prepared to go forward on peace would be prepared to take steps on settlements, which in our view make it more difficult to develop a meaningful peace process.'' At the same time, the State Department praised a ruling by an Israeli Court ordering the ouster of Jews who had moved into a building complex in the Christian quarter of Jerusalem. ``We are pleased that the court has so promptly made its decision,'' Ms. Tutwiler said. ``We believe it would be in the best interest of reducing tensions for this matter to be concluded as quickly as possible.'' However, the State Department declined to follow the lead of the Carter administration and declare settlements on land held by the Arabs from 1948 to 1967 to be illegal. U.S. policy calls on Israel to withdraw from the West Bank and from Gaza as part of an overall settlement that would involve Arab recognition of the Jewish state.

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Nunn Defense
Poll Says Americans Favor Deeper Troop Cuts in Europe
DOC.TEXT: Two-thirds of Americans favor withdrawing far more U.S. troops from Europe than proposed by President Bush, according to a poll released Thursday. Told that Bush in February proposed cutting U.S. and Soviet forces in Central Europe to 195,000 soldiers, 52 percent said they believed each side should go down to 100,000. Thirty-two percent favored stopping at Bush's proposed level, but 14 percent said both sides should cut to zero. Two percent were undecided. The survey of 1,000 adults was conducted between Feb. 19 and March 2 by Market Strategies Inc., a polling group that works for Republican political candidates, in collaboration with Americans Talk Security, a bipartisan research group. The poll's margin of error was 3.2 percent. The United States currently has 305,000 troops in Europe; the Soviets have about 600,000. In a Senate floor speech Thursday, Sen. Sam Nunn, D-Ga., chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee, said the Bush administration should begin planning for a residual force in Europe of between 75,000 and 100,000 troops within five years. The survey also said Americans see a receding Soviet military threat. Sixteen percent said the Soviets pose no threat at all to the United States; 49 percent cited a minor threat, and 33 percent said the Soviets are still a serious threat. Two years ago, 53 percent of those polled said the Soviets posed a serious threat.

DOC.HEAD: Elizabeth Taylor, Hospitalized With Pneumonia, in Stable Condition
DOC.TEXT: Actress Elizabeth Taylor, hospitalized with pneumonia, was listed as stable Thursday at St. John's Hospital and Health Center, her publicist said. ``She's stable. She's OK. We have nothing else,'' said Lisa Del Favaro, a Taylor spokeswoman with Chen Sam and Associates public relations in New York City. Inquiries to the hospital were referred to Chen Sam. Miss Taylor, 58, hospitalized with a sinus infection April 9 at Daniel Freeman Marina Hospital, was transferred to St. John's on Monday because of a persistent fever and pneumonia. ``She is currently being treated intravenously with antibiotics and will remain hospitalized,'' Dr. Patricia Murray, an infectious disease specialist treating Miss Taylor, said in a statement Tuesday. Miss Taylor said in the statement: ``I have been advised by my physician to remain hospitalized and I expect to make a full recovery.'' The actress had a nearly fatal bout of pneumonia in 1961, the year she won an Oscar for ``Butterfield 8.'' Doctors performed a tracheotomy _ inserting an air tube in her windpipe at the neck _ to help her breathe. Miss Taylor's health problems started with a fall from a horse when she was 13 and filming the movie ``National Velvet.'' She has had back problems ever since. In 1983, she acknowledged a 35-year addiction to sleeping pills and pain killers prescribed for a wide range of health problems. Miss Taylor has been treated for alcohol and drug abuse at the Betty Ford Clinic in Rancho Mirage.

DOC.HEAD: Teenagers Arrested in Connection with Tire Fire
DOC.TEXT: Police arrested five teen-agers and charged them with starting a fire at a tire dump that burned for 17 days, spewing toxic smoke into the air and forcing 600 people from their homes, officials said Thursday. The teen-agers, ranging in age from 15 to 17, were arrested Thursday and late Wednesday, police said. The Young Offenders Act prohibits disclosing the identitities of those charged. The arrests were made after tips from the public, police in Ontario said on condition of anonymity. Investigators had said arson was the cause of the fire at Tyre King Recycling. The dump is in Hagersville, 12 miles north of Lake Erie and 60 miles north of Erie, Ohio. The fire, fed by 14 million tires, broke out early Feb. 12, forcing the evacuation of hundreds living in a two-mile radius around the blaze. The Environment Ministry declared Tyre King, Ontario's largest tire dump, an illegal waste site in December 1985. The fire was initially described as a major environmental disaster, and officials had feared the oily runoff created by the melted tires might have contaminated drinking water in local wells. But experts said recently that damage from both the oil and smoke was less than had been expected.

DOC.HEAD: Coroner Reverses Self, Says Man Was Beaten to Death by Police
DOC.TEXT: The Orleans Parish coroner on Thursday changed his explanation of a police killer's death and agreed with private pathologists who said the black man was beaten to death by police. ``After careful and extensive investigation ... into the death of Adolph Archie, it is my decision that the classification of the death is homicide, police intervention,'' Dr. Frank Minyard wrote in a brief statement. At a news conference March 23, the day Archie died, Minyard said an autopsy indicated that he had suffocated on his own blood after ripping a tracheal tube from his throat while waiting for a CAT scan. But pathologists hired by Archie's family said their autopsies found little blood in Archie's lungs and a great deal of evidence that he had been beaten to death. He had a cracked skull, a crushed larynx, a shattered face and had been hit too many times to count, said attorney Mary Howell. An autopsy also was performed for the FBI, but U.S. Attorney John Volz has said results cannot be released while the investigation was going on. Police Superintendent Warren Woodfork could not be reached for comment. ``Superintendent Woodfork is not in his office, and we have no comment at this time,'' said police Sgt. Robert Young. The Southern Christian Leadership Conference and another civil rights group, the Grass Roots Organization for Women, have called for Minyard's resignation. According to officials for the groups, police have told them confidentially that four police officers beat Archie. Police said Archie punched a guard who surprised him breaking into a car at the Louisiana Superdome on March 22, stole his gun and then ran into rush-hour traffic. Officer Earl Hauck II, directing traffic downtown, was shot after he cornered Archie near an office building loading dock, police said. Archie was pulled out from under a car minutes later, officers said. An officer headed toward Charity Hospital with Archie, but Woodfork said officials decided to take him first to a police station because he might be in danger from Hauck's fellow officers, who had gathered at the hospital. Archie was held for 45 minutes at the station where Hauck had worked, then taken to the hospital, where he died about 13 hours later. Minyard said April 4 that his staff's autopsy was as thorough as possible in two hours, and added that he believed police reports that Archie had fallen in a struggle after he lunged for an officer's gun. ``Every day I work with homicide. And if I don't believe them ... the whole system breaks down,'' he said then. ``I have to believe what they tell me.''

DOC.HEAD: Thornburgh Says His Spokesman Was Source Of Leak
DOC.TEXT: Attorney General Dick Thornburgh said Thursday that his chief spokesman unintentionally confirmed to a reporter that there was a criminal investigation involving Rep. William H. Gray III. Thornburgh said press secretary David Runkel was ``following my standing instruction'' not to mislead the media when he did not steer CBS reporter Rita Braver off the story last spring. The attorney general, who launched a criminal investigation of the unauthorized disclosure of the investigation, said Runkel's failure to deny information Ms. Braver had obtained from other sources was not misconduct. ``A refusal to deny or wave a reporter off a story with which he is confronted by the reporter does not, in my view, constitute misconduct,'' Thornburgh said in a statement. ``Unfortunately there are circumstances where a statement of the kind likely made here by Mr. Runkel may be used by a reporter as confirmation of a story,'' Thornburgh said. ``A real distinction must be made, I believe, between an unsolicited and affirmative unauthorized disclosure and such a `confirmation' by one responsible for dealing with the media,'' Thornburgh said. The CBS story, aired while Gray, D-Pa., was seeking election as House majority whip, produced a storm of indignation from Democrats in Congress who accused the Justice Department of a politically inspired leak. The Justice Department took pains a few days later to correct the impression left by the CBS story that Gray was under investigation. In an unusual statement, Thornburgh's office said the Pennsylvania Democrat was not a target of the investigation. The attorney general, who is in Mexico attending a drug enforcement conference, issued the statement in response to a story published Thursday in the New York Times, which also said that Runkel failed a lie detector test during the leak investigation. Department spokesman Daniel Eramian, who read the statement to reporters, refused to comment on the Times account of the lie detector test. But Runkel, who was traveling with Thornburgh and unavailable for comment, has previously refused to say whether he was one of the 10 people who took polygraph tests during the leak investigation. Runkel has acknowledged that he testified before a grand jury about the case. Under routine investigative procedures, a subject who fails a polygraph test is summoned for questioning before a grand jury. Thornburgh has been an outspoken opponent of unauthorized leaks about pending criminal investigations, making it a hallmark of his tenure as attorney general. The attorney general has repeatedly cited the Gray leak as an egregious example. Eleven FBI agents who conducted the leak investigation took sworn statements from 109 people. In a letter to Congress in December, Thornburgh reported that investigation ``has not produced sufficient evidence to enable me to ascertain that any present employee of the Department of Justice was responsible for the disclosure.'' ``I have determined that no termination of employment or other disciplinary action is justified in this matter at this time,'' the attorney general had said in his letter to Congress.

DOC.HEAD: Government Won't Block Oil Sales to Lithuania
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS one graf to show that Lithuanian delegation flew to Moscow and went on to Norway via a Soviet carrier. No pickup
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Lithuania, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Norway said Thursday that Lithuania is free to buy its oil, but it urged Moscow to lift an energy embargo against the Baltic republic before outside supplies are needed. A Lithuanian delegation led by Prime Minister Kazimiera Prunskiene sought support from Norwegian leaders, but there were no immediate contracts or offers of government aid, said Foreign Minister Kjell Magne Bondevik. ``Norway has not used, and will not use, oil as a foreign policy tool,'' Bondevik said, adding that it was up to the oil companies to decide whether to sell to Lithuania. The Oslo trip, planned weeks ago, coincided with the decision by Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev to close the tap of crude oil and restrict natural gas supplies to Lithuania for refusing to scrap pro-independence laws. ``We were expecting this,'' Mrs. Prunskiene said when told by reporters of the cutback on natural gas. ``We believe Lithuania will survive without natural gas, but life will be reduced, cut off from normal possibilities.'' Norway pumps 1.5 million barrels a day from North Sea fields, making it the second-largest exporter outside the OPEC oil cartel. It also exports natural gas, but it has no way to deliver it to Lithuania. Bondevik said he summoned Soviet Ambassador Alexandre Teterine to express Norway's opposition to the use of economic pressure to thwart Lithuania's independence drive. He said Norway favored flexibility by both Moscow and Lithuania and urged negotiations without pressure or preconditions, before the conflict threatened East-West relations. In the talks with Mrs. Prunskiene, ``we made it clear that the Lithuanians are free to contact the suppliers of petroleum,'' he said. ``We will not step in, much less hinder this.'' The state oil company Statoil has said it was willing to sell oil to Lithuania at market prices for hard currency, but Lithuania has little hard currency. A second potential supplier is Norsk Hydro company, which is 51 percent state-owned. Mrs. Prunskiene said she hoped to meet with directors of both companies Friday. She said she did not expect to secure future supplies during the three-day visit, but to establish contacts that might lead to later contracts. She said Lithuania also would need credit. She acknowledged that the Soviet navy could easily blockade Lithuania's harbors but said: ``It would be an unthinkable thing if the Soviet Union stops oil delivery from other sources.'' After meeting Bondevik, Teterine said Moscow ``would handle the question if it arises'' of Norway supplying Lithuania. But he noted recent legal reforms allowing the Baltic republics to deal with their own economic affairs. ``Perhaps it is up to the leadership of each republic to decide on how they will get petroleum supplies and sell their products,'' he said. Mrs. Prunskiene said the energy squeeze would not force the republic to withdraw its March 11 declaration of independence. ``There is no question of retreating from our position,'' she said. The fate of Lithuania will ``to a high degree define the future of Western Europe.'' Her visit put Prime Minister Jan P. Syse's government in the awkward position of being in front of its NATO allies in responding to the Lithuanian crisis. Syse has been under pressure from opponents on the left and right to come to Lithuania's aid, even at the risk of rousing Moscow's ire. The Lithuanians came to Norway at the invitation of the three parties in the ruling coalition to discuss political ideology, not aid. Syse insisted he met the delegation in his role as Conservative Party chairman rather than head of government. The Lithuanian delegation flew from the republic's capital to Moscow on the Soviet carrier Aeroflot, then transferred to another Aeroflot flight for a flight to Copenhagen, Denmark. In Copenhagen they then boarded a Scandinavian Airlines System airplane and flew on to Oslo.

DOC.HEAD: First Anti-Collision System Being Installed On Commercial Fleet
DOC.TEXT: A new jetliner full of passengers flew intentionally too close to a small plane on Thursday in a demonstration of the first collision-avoidance system to be approved for a commercial airliner fleet. In a change that the airline industry says will cost it nearly $1 billion, airlines must install the Traffic Alert and Collision Avoidance System (TCAS II) in all their large jets before the end of 1993. ``Climb! Climb! Climb!'' said an emphatic male voice generated by the TCAS II built into the first of 100 USAir jetliners to be equipped this year. A small screen in the cockpit showed a red dot, indicating that another plane was dangerously close. With a series of maneuvers between the small plane and the Boeing 737-400 carrying industry and government officials and several reporters and photographers, pilots demonstrated the TCAS II system. Congress has ordered that one-fifth of each carrier's airliners must have the TCAS II units installed before the end of this year at a cost of about $125,000 each. The bill for the whole U.S. fleet is expected to exceed $450 million. Airlines put the cost at closer to $1 billion, figuring in labor and lost profits during installation which takes about five days. Smaller passenger planes are required to have a less sophisticated version, TCAS I, which emits traffic warnings when other planes come too near, but does not tell the pilot what to do. Time after time, the small plane came on a collision course with the USAir jet. Each time, the TCAS screen showed the location of the intruding aircraft and a voice from a speaker in the cockpit ceiling gave quick, precise instructions to the pilot, beginning with, ``Traffic!'' and ending with, ``Clear of conflict'' as passengers watched the small plane whiz by within a few hundred feet of the airliner. If two TCAS computers meet in the sky, they communicate with each other, and one pilot is told to ``climb'' and the other to ``descend,'' said Ace Card, Bendix-King program manager for TCAS. An even more sophisticated third generation of the system, TCAS III, is being developed to give pilots horizontal instructions, as well. Honeywell has been testing such a system on an FAA airliner, but it is not expected to be approved for installation on commercial planes for several years. The TCAS system gives the pilot a miniature air traffic control system in the sky, showing aircraft within a 40-mile radius. It can only detect planes with transponders that emit radar signals. All but the smallest private planes have them. USAir officials said their 737 is the first commercial airplane to be equipped and certificated by the FAA with the TCAS unit. Northwest, United and Piedmont each equipped a plane with test versions of TCAS when the system was being evaluated by the FAA. Three companies manufacture TCAS systems that meet FAA specifications. The ones being put on USAir's fleet are made by Allied-Signal Aerospace's Bendix-King Air Transport Avionics Division. Other manufacturers are the Air Transport Systems Division of Honeywell Inc., and the Collins divisions of Rockwell International. The system was required as an added measure of safety for air travelers. Tom McSweeney, an FAA official who was on the demonstration flight, said the system would have the added benefit of making it easier for pilots to maintain proper separation from other aircraft during landings and giving them more information when they are in areas not covered by air traffic controllers. The system, however, is seen only as a backup to FAA controllers who monitor all flights and have responsibility for maintaining safe distances between aircraft, particularly those the pilots cannot see out of the cockpit window.

DOC.HEAD: AIDS Vaccine May Protect Healthy Cells From Virus
DOC.TEXT: A vaccine created by a pharmaceutical company appears to protect human immune cells from infection by the AIDS virus when the cells are in mice, but a Yale researcher cautions it may not work with people. The vaccine, called VaxSyn HIV-1, was developed by MicroGeneSys Inc. of West Haven. It has been able to defend human immune cells transplanted into specially bred mice, while mice injected with cells from unvaccinated people were vulnerable to the virus, officials at the company said Wednesday. The company said tests on people could begin soon. Dr. Anthony S. Fauci, director of the National Institutes of Health AIDS program, called the vaccine ``potentially a very important finding.'' The test is ``the first evidence of protective immunity in humans,'' he said. Francis Black, professor of epidemiology and microbiology at the Yale School of Medicine, called the experiment ``ingenious,'' saying it marks an important step toward a vaccine to prevent infection by the deadly virus. But he cautioned that it does not prove that the MicroGeneSys vaccine will work in people. ``In humans there would be other cells that doubtless play a role'' in the progress of AIDS, Black said. ``There are a lot of other differences between mice and men.'' The experiment was designed to test the vaccine on cells living in mice, to avoid the danger of infecting healthy people. The MicroGeneSys vaccine is composed of the outer protein coat of the AIDS virus. It is made by altering the genes of caterpillar cells to make the protein, which by itself is not dangerous or infectious. Franklin Volvovitz, president of MicroGeneSys, said healthy test subjects were first injected with the vaccine. A type of infection-fighting white blood cell then was taken from the people and transplanted into mice bred to lack a strong immune system. After the human immune cells, called peripheral blood leukocytes, grew in the mice, the rodents were exposed to the AIDS virus, Volvovitz explained. In one test, 11 of the 12 mice tested were protected against the virus, Volvovitz said. However, all the mice given white blood cells from volunteers not injected with the vaccine succumbed to the AIDS virus. The study, which was reported at a symposium on acquired immune deficiency syndrome in Colorado earlier this month, was performed at the Medical Biology Institute in La Jolla, Calif., a non-profit laboratory funded by the federal government. Black said many scientists consider an AIDS vaccine impossible because of the complex ways in which the virus and the human immune system work. ``I remain very optimistic that a vaccine will be developed,'' he said. ``I think they (MicroGeneSys) are fairly close to a clinical trial.'' The vaccine probably would be given to members of a population at high risk for AIDS, and then rates of the disease would be analyzed, Black said. The study would be complicated and expensive, because it would require participation of large numbers of people, he said. The vaccine is being tested both as a measure to prevent infection by the AIDS virus and as a treatment for those already infected.

DOC.HEAD: Officials Caution Deficit Could Worsen This Year
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration told Congress on Thursday that the U.S. trade deficit, after narrowing for the last two years, could worsen in 1990 and an administration official said Japan must do more to lower its huge trade surplus. Treasury Undersecretary David Mulford said Japan's closed markets pose ``important risks for the world economy'' and added that nations such as Japan need to protect the trading system from protectionist onslaughts. ``Clearly, Japan has not done its part,'' Mulford told a Senate Banking subcommittee reviewing a new administration report on the outlook for world trade in 1990. The report said any improvement in the trade deficit would be ``at very best modest'' and there was a distinct possibility the deficit could actually widen this year. The report, which the Treasury Department must prepare under the 1988 trade law, noted that the dollar has risen in value against the Japanese yen by almost 20 percent over the last year. A stronger dollar threatens to widen the trade deficit by making U.S. goods less competitive on overseas markets and allowing foreign producers to lower prices to American consumers. Sen. Alan Dixon, D-Ill., said that executives of the Caterpillar company had told him that ``all their efforts to improve their international competitiveness had been wiped out'' by the recent currency changes. ``If the yen keeps falling against the dollar, I don't see how our trade performance can be improved,'' Dixon said. Mulford said that the weakness of the yen was of a concern to the United States and its allies in the Group of Seven _ Japan, West Germany, Britain, France, Italy and Canada _ and would be a primary topic on the agenda when the group next meets in early May in Washington. However, Sen. Paul Sarbanes, D-Md., questioned whether the G-7 countries would be able to come up with any stronger coordinated effort to stabilize currency rates than the bland statement issued when the group met earlier this month in Paris. Mulford said that while exchange rates should be monitored, he believed it was more important mow for the United States to push ahead with its efforts to dismantle Japan's structural barriers to foreign products, including American goods. ``Simply depreciating the dollar against the yen is not going to do'' what is necessary to solve the U.S.-Japan trade deficit, he said. The Bush administration has been seeking to remove a variety of Japanese trade barriers. The broadest effort involves the Structural Impediments Initiative aimed at eliminating broad-based barriers to trade.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Release of U.S. Hostage Postponed, Bush `Disappointed'
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 15 grafs to ADD Bush `disappointed' by postponement, CORRECTS that kidnappers said they would free one of the three U.S. hostages within 48 hours, sted 24, statements warns of attack on carriers of Soviet Jews to Israel, quotes. Pickup 11th pvs, `Earlier today...
DOC.TEXT: Pro-Iranian kidnappers today indefinitely postponed the release of an American hostage because the United States failed to meet their demand to send a senior State Department official to Syria. President Bush said this afternoon in response to the news that the United States has ``been disappointed before'' by dashed hopes for the release of U.S. hostages in Lebanon and repeated he will not meet the demands of kidnappers. The announcement of the postponement came in an Arabic-language statement delivered by Islamic Jihad for the Liberation of Palestine to the independent Beirut newspaper an-Nahar and a Western news agency. The handwritten statement was accompanied by an instant picture of Robert Polhill, one of three U.S. educators held by the group since Jan. 24, 1987. The kidnappers had said Wednesday that they would freeing one of the three American educators within 48 hours, or by Friday evening. The other two are Jesse Turner and Alann Steen. The group had said that it was acting in response to requests from Iran and Syria, whose leaders have encouraged an end to the hostage crisis. The group implied that some sort of exchange was involved. Bush, in Key Largo, Fla., told a news conference, ``I would add that we are not talking to the hostage-holders.'' The Islamic Jihad for the Liberation of Palestine had demanded that John Kelly, U.S. assistant secretary of state for Near Eastern affairs, fly to Damascus ``to coordinate some final steps'' leading to the release. It did not specify what they expected of Kelly, the U.S. ambassador to Lebanon from 1983 to 1988. He was in Bonn, West Germany, on Wednesday. Secretary of State James A. Baker III had cautiously welcomed the reports but said Kelly had no plans to fly to the Middle East ``at the present time.'' ``As for the release of the American hostage, arrangements had been under way on a basis that they would be concluded and finalized. But Kelly's failure to respond has so far frustrated the release, which made us postpone this operation until the picture is clearerd,'' today's statement said. Although the Bush administration refused to send Kelly, it dispatched a hostage reception team to West Germany after hearing ``statements of imminent release'' of an American hostage, the White House said. The latest statement reiterated a threat the group made last month to attack jetliners, airlines and airports used to transport Soviet Jewish emigrants to Israel. ``The organization serves this final warning ... on all those participating in this matter, especially those countries offering transit facilities,'' the statement said. ``This is the last warning. All civilians should stay away from the airports, airlines and jetliners that will be the targets for operations mounted at times we deem adequate.'' Earlier today, Shiite militiamen clashed in west Beirut and the city's southern slums, prompting fears that that would delay the hostage release. Many of the 18 Western hostages in Lebanon, including eight Americans, are believed held in south Beirut. Police in Beirut said foot patrols of Syria's 12,500-strong force in the city's Moslem sector moved in to contain the fighting between the pro-Iranian Hezbollah and Syrian-backed Amal. ``You can't expect a hostage to be freed in such risky conditions,'' a police spokesman said, speaking on condition of anonymity. Also, Israeli warplanes attacked Palestinian guerrilla bases 10 miles south of Beirut, targeting tunnel bases manned by guerrillas of Capt. Ahmed Jibril's Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine-General Command. The kidnappers' statement on Wednesday was accompanied by an instant photograph of Turner _ the first photo of him alone since three months after his abduction. Steen and Polhill were taken with Turner from the campus of Beirut University College. Polhill, 55, lectured in accounting. Turner, 42, was a visiting mathematics and computer science professor. Steen, who will be 51 Sunday, taught journalism.

DOC.HEAD: Canned Turkey Products Recalled In Puerto Rico
DOC.TEXT: The Agriculture Department said Thursday a food company in Puerto Rico is voluntarily recalling three canned turkey products because food spoilage organisms had been found in one of the products. All of the suspected food was said to have been distributed to schools and other institutions in Puerto Rico. There was no estimate of the quantity of products distributed. The department said Federal Packing Co. Inc. of Carolina, P.R., ``also reports the isolation of the bacterium Clostridium botulinum in samples of its products tested by a private laboratory.'' According to USDA references, these organisms can cause botulism, a deadly form of food poisoning. The food spoilage organisms were detected when the department's Food Safety and Inspection Service tested some of the company's canned boned turkey in bouillon, officials said. No botulinum was detected by USDA, but the agency said it is continuing the tests. Both of the products were produced for the Puerto Rico Department of Education and were distributed to public and private schools, churches, charitable organizations and the Head Start program in Puerto Rico. The products ``are not officially distributed in U.S. locations outside of Puerto Rico,'' the announcement said. Officials said the products are packed in 50-ounce cans and are labeled ``Canned Boned Turkey in Bouillon,'' ``Canned Boned Turkey in Broth,'' or ``Canned Boned Turkey with Natural Juices Diced Fully Cooked.'' The establishment number P-6694 is located inside the inspection seal on the label, and the wording ``Packed for AJM Meat Packing Inc.'' appears on the bottom of the label. Ronald J. Prucha, associate administrator of the department's Food Safety and Inspection Service, said there have been ``reports of seven unconfirmed illnesses that may have been associated with consumption of the canned boned turkey in bouillon.'' Prucha said institutions that may have received the products should check their inventory, and if any are found should contact the distribution warehouse that supplied them. The products should not be eaten or tasted.

DOC.HEAD: Pentagon Plans to Pull 12,000 U.S. Forces From Pacific Rim
DOC.TEXT: The United States plans to withdraw more than 12,000 of its troops in Asia over the next three years and additional cuts are possible as the Soviet threat diminishes, administration officials said Thursday. Paul Wolfowitz, undersecretary of defense for policy, detailed the planned changes in U.S. forces as he presented a report required by Congress on military strategy in the Pacific. The report reiterated many of the proposals Defense Secretary Dick Cheney unveiled in February during his two-week visit to the Pacific rim. Under the administration plan, 10 percent of the 120,000 American forces based in Asia would be withdrawn _ some 7,000 military personnel of the 44,000 U.S. forces in Korea and 5,000 to 6,000 of the 50,000 in Japan. ``Since our forward deployments have been most commonly justified as a deterrent to Soviet expansionism, our presence in the region is now seen as less relevant in light of domestic changes with the Soviet Union and prospects for U.S.-Soviet arms control negotiations,'' the report said. It said further reductions could be considered in later years. However, the report stresses threats to U.S. economic and political interests in the Pacific remain despite the dramatic changes overseas. The communist government of North Korea is still pursuing reunification with South Korea and in other Southeast Asian nations U.S. interests are vulnerable to terrorism. ``Our deterrence posture and forward presence in East Asia have been successful, and it remains in our interest to maintain a forward deployed strategy, including a military presence on the Korean peninsula and elsewhere in East Asia and the Western Pacific,'' the report said. The United States will also push for Asian nations to share a larger portion of the financial burden for defense. In his meeting with Japanese officials in February, Cheney sought increases in the $2.4 billion annual support toward the $7 billion cost of the American deployment in Japan. ``It is appropriate to expect our prosperous Asian allies _ Japan and Korea _ to assume greater responsibility for their own defense and, by so doing, to contribute more directly to the stability of the region,'' the report said. Sen. Sam Nunn, D-Ga., chairman of the Armed Services panel, stressed the need for the U.S. allies to foot more of the defense bill and noted the strong congressional support for such action. ``I believe that almost everybody I know on Capitol Hill _ both political parties _ believes South Korea ought to contribute more to offset,'' Nunn said. Wolfowitz said South Korea has tripled its defense budget in recent years, allowing the United States to consider reductions.

DOC.HEAD: Milk Prices Dropping On The Farm, But Not Yet At Retail
DOC.TEXT: The farm price of milk has dropped sharply from the record highs of last winter, but consumers may have to wait a while longer to see much effect, an Agriculture Department report said Thursday. Analysts said there are ``conflicting indications of the supply-demand balance'' in the dairy markets. ``Milk production has resumed expansion, and falling international prices of non-fat dry milk have demolished opportunities for commercial exports,'' the report said. But domestic demand has been strong, both commercially and to rebuild depleted inventories. Milk prices at the farm probably will slip in the coming months, and ``the onset of seasonal increases may be delayed,'' the report said. Overall, the farm price of milk in 1990 may average 4 percent to 9 percent below last year's all-milk price of $13.51 per hundredweight. Consumer prices of dairy products as a group in early 1990 had risen more than 10 percent from a year earlier, greatly exceeding the overall increases in retail food and consumer prices. ``Retail dairy prices probably will trend down in coming months, although any signs of strength in wholesale prices will tend to lessen and delay retail price declines,'' the report said.

DOC.HEAD: Czechoslovakia Restores Diplomatic Relations with Vatican
DOC.TEXT: Czechoslovakia restored diplomatic relations with the Vatican on Thursday, sweeping away a remnant of 40 years of church-state hostility before a historic papal visit this weekend. Czechoslovakia joined a growing list of Eastern European countries forging ties with the Holy See in an expansion of the church's influence in the once Communist-dominated region. The Prague government interrupted diplomatic relations in March 1950 when it gave the papal envoy three days to leave the country, said the Vatican in a statement. The Vatican hailed the resumption of ties as bringing an end to the ``sad parenthesis of these last 40 years.'' Pope John Paul II's visit Saturday and Sunday to Czechoslovakia will be his first to a Warsaw Pact country other than his native Poland. ``The trip symbolizes ... everything that has happened in the countries of what is by now the ex-Communist world,'' said the Vatican newspaper L`Osservatore Romano. Under a succession of hard-line Communist regimes that ruled until Czechoslovakia's peaceful revolution last November, such a visit was unthinkable. As elsewhere in the Soviet bloc, organized religion in Czechoslovakia was rigidly controlled, believers were repressed and religious education was severely restricted. In his inauguration speech Dec. 29, President Vaclav Havel, who had been jailed by the Communist regime, asked the pope to visit Prague as a goodwill gesture to support the democratic changes sweeping Eastern Europe. Poland last year re-established diplomatic relations with the Vatican, followed by Hungary in February. A month ago, the Vatican and the Soviet Union established official ties for the first time since the Russian Revolution although they fall short of full diplomatic relations. The Vatican has also restored the leadership of the church in Romania and diplomatic ties with Bucharest are believed not far off. The announcement at the Vatican and in Prague said relations were being renewed on the level of a Czechoslovak Embassy and an apostolic nunciature. The envoys were not immediately named. The Vatican estimates that a little more than half of Czechoslovakia's 15.5 million people are Roman Catholics. On several occasions, John Paul had deplored the ``sad state'' of the church in Czechoslovakia, where up to 10 of the country's 13 dioceses were left without bishops. The church is led by 90-year-old Cardinal Frantisek Tomasek, who long struggled for church freedoms. Soon after the regime led by Milos Jakes was toppled, relations with Rome warmed. In recent months the Vatican has returned the church hierarchy to full strength. Millions of Catholics are expected to attend the papal events in Prague, the shrine city of Velehrad and Bratislava during the two-day visit, the first by a pope to Czechoslovakia. The trip will be the 46th foreign tour of John Paul's papacy. Trips by John Paul to Poland and Hungary are scheduled next year.

DOC.HEAD: Japanese Companies Announce Import Expansion
DOC.TEXT: Two major Japanese electronics firms said Thursday they will increase their purchases of foreign products to reduce trade friction with the United States. The government also adopted a new set of procedures for procurement of supercomputers by state-run agencies and universities, and said it would open talks with Washington on amorphous metals, another contentious trade issue. Sony Corp. and Matsushita Electric Industrial Co. said they will boost their purchases of foreign-made semiconductors from 14 percent and 13 percent respectively to 20 percent by next year. Matsushita sells under the National, Panasonic and Quasar brand names. ``We are making an earnest effort by setting the 20 percent target,'' Sony spokesman Koichi Izukura said. Sony will allow foreign chip makers to develop more semiconductors for future products starting at the product design stage, Izukura said. U.S. semiconductor makers have complained that they frequently are not given information by Japanese companies about future products that would allow them to design new computer chips for those products. Sony uses 2,000-2,500 types of new chips each year in its audio and video products, Izukura said. About 400 were designed by foreign companies in fiscal 1989, he said. In the current fiscal year, which began April 1, Sony plans to procure 500-600 types of chips from foreign chip makers that will be developed for new products, Izukura said. In 1986 the United States and Japan set a goal for the foreign share of the Japanese chip market to be 20 percent by July 1991. Foreign chips accounted for 12.9 percent of the market during the last three months of 1989. Meanwhile, Nissan Motor Co., Japan's second-largest automaker, said it will increase its chip imports to a level higher than its import target for fiscal 1992 of $740 million. Nissan said as a result of meetings with 26 U.S. parts suppliers this month, it would place orders for 53 items made by the suppliers. It did not identify the companies. In supercomputer trade, U.S. officials say Japan discriminates against foreign suppliers because purchasing procedures are unclear and Japanese makers are allowed to sell at sharply lower ``academic discounts.'' The new procedures include a ban on unfair academic discounts and shorten the period for procurement to 130 days from 180 days, an official in the Prime Minister's office said. The new process will be implemented May 1, said the official, who spoke on condition of anonymity. Japan's Foreign Ministry announced that Tokyo and Washington would begin talks aimed at finding a solution within 150 days to U.S. trade complaints involving amorphous metals. The metals are a high-technology product used mainly to improve the efficiency of electric power transformers.

DOC.HEAD: House Panel Hears Testimony on Addicted Mothers
DOC.TEXT: A former drug addict and alcoholic who blames her substance abuse for her daughter's retardation asked a House committee Thursday to help addicted pregnant women. The woman, identified only as Kathleen X, said she was 14 when she began using heroin and alcohol. Over the next 16 years, she had five children. Two are normal, two died in infancy and one is mentally retarded, diagnosed this year as suffering from fetal alcohol syndrome. ``We now recognize that fetal alcohol syndrome is one of the greatest causes of birth defects and mental retardation in the United States,'' Iris Smith, project director of the Georgia Addiction, Pregnancy and Parenting Program in Atlanta, told the House Select Committee on Children, Youth and Families. Infants born to alcoholic women are often premature and later display learning or behavioral disorders, growth retardation and deficits in memory or attention, Smith said. Kathleen X told the panel that she would promise her children she would stop using drugs, ``but I could never keep that promise.'' She said she stopped using drugs and alcohol six years ago when she entered a long-term treatment program. She's now regional director of community outreach and education for a drug treatment center in suburban Maryland. Committee Chairman George Miller, D-Calif., noted that Kathleen X is white and grew up in an affluent area. He said her story illustrated that the problem affects all socio-economic groups. Dr. Sheila B. Blume of South Oaks Hospital in Amityville, N.Y., said efforts must be made to identify addicted women before they give birth. ``Pregnancy is the best time to treat an alcoholic woman or a chemically dependent woman,'' she said. ``The incentive to have the healthiest possible infant is the best motivator.'' Kathleen X said she stopped using drugs when she was pregnant but continued to drink wine. ``Back then no one said there was anything wrong with that,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Bright & Brief
DOC.TEXT: Singer Willie Nelson isn't much of a golfer, but he's now got a winning stroke named after him: the ``Pedernales hole-in-one.'' Nelson owns the Pedernales Country Club west of Austin, a course known for its imaginative rules and a par rating that its owner says ``is anything I want it to be'' on any given day. Nelson has a 21 handicap, which means he would have to be credited 21 strokes to be evenly matched with a golfer capable of hitting par. On Wednesday, playing in the pro-am portion of the Legends of Golf tournament at the par-72 Barton Creek Country Club, Nelson was awarded two handicap strokes on the par-4 16th hole. Nelson chipped in his third shot, so it was scored as a net 1 _ and immediately dubbed a ``Pedernales'' hole-in-one. The ace helped the team finish in a tie for third in the pro-am with a score of 54. The team's professional was Chi Chi Rodriguez, who shot a 66, and the team's amateurs included Nelson, former University of Texas football coach Darrell Royal and country singer George Strait.

What do you do if you see two guys climbing toward your home wearing hardhats, welder's jackets and chainsaw-proof leggings, and carrying badminton rackets? If you're a great horned owl, you back off. That's what a pair of tree service men arrayed in that manner discovered as they climbed warily to an owls' nest to offer them up an orphan owl found on the ground. ``An owl has to be brought up where it can see other owls. Otherwise, it thinks it's a human and can never be released,'' said Sherri Smith, a volunteer, who found the new nest atop a 60-foot white oak in Scio Township. The adoptive father wasn't around and the mother flew away as Brad Burton, owner of an Ann Arbor tree service, and employee Bill Guy scaled the tree Tuesday afternoon to place the baby owl in its new home. A Canadian wildlife authority had warned that adult owls might attack humans venturing near the nest, so Burton and Guy brought along all the protective garb they could find, not to mention the badminton rackets. Twice the owls' own baby jumped from the nest and coasted to the ground, where it was put in a sack and hoisted back home. The second time, it stayed. And on Wednesday, Smith said, a telescope caught up with the mother and two babies: ``All three were preening their feathers and happy in the sun, so everything is fine.''

DOC.HEAD: Health Officials Hope Inquiry Resolves Coroner's Office Controversy
DOC.TEXT: City health officials hope an inquiry into the Denver coroner's office will end controversy that developed after lawyers questioned autopsy findings in the deaths of three children. ``We are going to try to do what we can as soon as possible so we can put to sleep the rumors and unanswered questions,'' said Vi Swenson, chairwoman of the board of the Denver Department of Health and Hospitals. ``I can't say we've drawn a conclusion. Certainly there are some questions that have to be answered, but I can't say there is something wrong in the coroner's office,'' Swenson said Wednesday. ``Certainly, there may be some things that people are not comfortable with.'' Mayor Federico Pena on Wednesday ordered the board of the Department of Health and Hospitals to investigate the office after attorneys and medical experts raised questions about the competence of Dr. Robert Deters of Loveland, who has been under contract to perform autopsies for Denver. In the past year, the coroner's office operated without a full-time pathologist, turning its work over to Deters, who performed 390 autopsies for Denver in 10 months. In addition, Deters has carried a full load of responsibilities as head of the pathology department at McKee Medical Center in Loveland. In that capacity, he has done 110 autopsies in the past 16 months. The National Association of Medical Examiners recommends that a coroner carry an annual caseload of 250. In the past month, prosecutors and defense attorneys, concerned about Deters' competence, have sought second opinions in three child-death cases: _A 16-month-old boy died Jan. 17 at a hospital, three days after he was admitted exhibiting what doctors said were symptoms of having been hit on the ear. The boyfriend of the child's mother was arrested for investigation of child-abuse charges, but released after Deters ruled the boy died of complications from an ear infection. The district attorney's office requested a second opinion. _A 2-year-old child died in August after falling in his home. Deters ruled there was no evidence of foul play and police closed an investigation of child-abuse allegations. The district attorney requested a second opinion. _A 2-month-old boy died Feb. 6, and his mother is accused of starving him to death. A public defender sought a second opinion after criticizing the coroner's office for withholding autopsy reports and failing to perform required tests. In addition, a defense attorney has challenged Deters' findings in the case of a 13-month-old Fort Collins girl who was fatally beaten in August 1988. The attorney claims Deters authorized the removal of the victim's organs before vital tests were done. At a news conference Wednesday, officials at the Denver coroner's office defended Deters, saying he provided competent, high-quality work during a crisis at the office. Deters, too, stood by his work. ``I worked hard. I put in some long hours ... I dedicated however much time was required to do the job thoroughly,'' he said. ``People have alleged shortcuts were taken. No shortcuts were taken. The job was done right.''

DOC.HEAD: Bush Says US `Does Not Knuckle Under to Demands' on Hostages
With AM-Hostages Bjt
DOC.TEXT: President Bush said Thursday he declined to send a senior State Department official to Syria as demanded by the holders of an American hostage because ``the United States does not knuckle under to demands.'' ``We have a perfectly capable, accredited diplomat on the scene in Syria,'' the president said. The Islamic Jihad for the Liberation of Palestine cited U.S. refusal to send John Kelly, assistant secretary of state for Middle Eastern affairs, as the reason for not releasing one of three hostages held by the group in Lebanon. The group had said it wanted Kelly ``to coordinate some final steps'' for the release. Speaking to reporters after his meeting with French President Francois Mitterrand, Bush said he had not heard of the Kelly connection to the kidnappers' refusal. ``We are not talking to the hostage holders,'' the president said. ``We do not meet demands. Our ambassador to Syria is back in Syria. We have been disappointed before, hopes raised only to have them dashed by excessive speculation,'' he said. Bush said he was grateful to Syria for trying to play a constructive role in the matter. A reporter said France had been more successful in gaining freedom for its hostages and asked Bush whether the two presidents had discussed that. Bush turned the question over to Mitterrand after saying the matter had been discussed by staff members. ``The freeing of the hostages in the early period in 1988 took place in somewhat different circumstances ... and under different conditions,'' the French president said. ``Each individual case of hostages is in fact a different and separate case.'' The kidnappers said on Wednesday they would free one of the three American educators they are holding within 24 hours, or by Friday evening. The three are Robert Polhill, Jesse Turner and Alann Steen, but the kidnappers did not say who was to be released. The group said at the time that it was acting in response to requests from Iran and Syria, whose leaders have encouraged an end to the hostage crisis. It did not specify what they expected of Kelly, the U.S. ambassador to Lebanon from 1983 to 1988. He was in Bonn, West Germany, on Wednesday. ``As for the release of the American hostage, arrangements had been under way on a basis that they would be concluded and finalized. But Kelly's failure to respond has so far frustrated the release, which made us postpone this operation until the picture is clearer,'' said a statement Thursday from the group.

DOC.HEAD: Medfly War Killing Beneficial Bugs, Gardeners Battling to Save Blossoms
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Bartje in 19th graf cq
DOC.TEXT: Ladybugs, honey bees and crickets are dropping like flies in Medfly-infested regions of Southern California soaked in pesticide, leaving gardeners to battle aphids thriving with their natural enemies gone. ``It's gross. It's sickening,'' said San Gabriel Valley homeowner Peggy Watson, whose orange trees are covered with aphids. Frustrated gardeners are making a bee line for pesticide shelves at nurseries and garden centers, where there has been a run on $4 tubes containing 1,000 ladybugs. ``We have people calling us up asking to reserve ladybugs,'' said Henrick Mar, manager of the San Gabriel Nursery. Pesticides sprayed by helicopters were intended to rid the region of the Mediterranean fruit fly. The Medfly, thought to enter the country in illegally imported fruit, threatens part of the state's $16 billion a year farm economy because it feeds on and lays eggs in more than 200 varieties of cash crops. Gov. George Deukmejian said Thursday there was no alternative to spraying. He said it would continue despite vocal protests and attempts by municipalities to stop what they view as a potential health menace. ``The Department of Agriculture is pursuing what is a time-tested method of eradicating the Medfly,'' Deukmejian told reporters. ``We cannot give up on this. We have to eradicate it.'' Deukmejian said if eradication efforts fail there will be higher food prices, quarantines on California fruit by foreign governments, loss of jobs and even placement of maggot-infested fruit on supermarket shelves. The blossom-devouring aphid has flourished because the pesticide malathion has killed off its predators _ ladybugs, lacewings and tiny wasps. They have been all but eliminated within the nearly 400 square miles of quarantine and spray zones. Wild honeybees, which pollinate fruit trees, also have fallen victim to malathion spraying. ``It's as if they drop dead in mid-flight,'' said Watson. Medfly spraying also has robbed spring of one of its traditional sounds: the chirping of crickets. Aphids, leaf-scales and whiteflies survive the sprayings because they live close to petals or beneath leaves, shielding them from the pesticide droplets. ``Malathion spraying causes an imbalance,'' said Lester Ehler, an entomologist at the University of California, Davis. He said seven or eight sprays over an urban area is enough to kill off beneficial insects. The aphid, enjoying a backyard garden feast without reprisal, leaves disfigured rosebuds, wilted orchids and mold-coated leaves. ``There are aphids on my violets, aphids covering my herbs. It's horrifying,'' said Marty Asolas, 42, of Bellflower. ``I have just decided not to plant anything else because I can't bear to see my flowers attacked.'' The aphid infestation was expected by state officials. ``We knew this was going to happen. But it is infinitely preferable to what the Medfly can do to the state,'' said Robert Dowell, senior economic entomologist for the state Department of Food and Agriculture. Aphids have become a hot topic among members of the Pacific Rose Society, said the organization's president Bartje Miller. But members also blame prime aphid breeding weather _ a dry winter followed by warm spring showers. ``It's a whole combination of factors. I think Mother Nature is just throwing us a curve,'' said Miller, who is also chairwoman of Wrigley Gardens in Pasadena. The aphids are ``the worse I've seen in the eight years I've been here,'' said Clair G. Martin III, curator of roses at the Huntington Library, Art Collections and Botanical Gardens in San Marino. It could take up to a year or longer after malathion spraying ends for gardens to become home again to beneficial insects. ``We don't know what the long term effects are on plant life,'' Ehler said. Entomologists advise gardeners to control aphids and other pests by hand-washing leaves with soap and water. Using more pesticide will only prolong the time it takes beneficial bugs to return and could burn leaves. Malathion spraying in Southern California began in force last summer and was recently ordered over a wide area of Riverside County that includes a commercial citrus grove.

DOC.HEAD: French Leader Proposes NATO Summit This Year
With AM-Bush Bjt
DOC.NOTE: EDs: UPDATES thruout with more Mitterand quotes and adds background; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: French President Francois Mitterrand on Thursday proposed to President George Bush that the 16 NATO allies hold a summit before year's end to discuss the changing face of Europe.
