Mitterrand, emerging from several hours of talks with Bush at a seaside resort, said Bush agreed with the idea. The summit would discuss the ``requirements of the new times head,'' Mitterrand said. But although both men stressed the importance of maintaining cohesion within NATO and maintaining U.S. troops in Europe, Mitterrand appeared to place more emphasis on European self-reliance. NATO must coordinate more closely ``with the other bodies within which the allies find themselves together in Europe,'' including the 12-nation European Economic Community and the 35-nation Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe, the French president said. ``And I would add a very important additional note on this, to prepare the Europeans for the idea of playing an increased role in working for their own defense,'' said Mitterand. ``And with that in mind, I suggested to President Bush, and he agreed, that we propose to our allies to hold a summit of the alliance before the end of the year,'' he said. Mitterand said Europeans should also speed up their economic and political union. He cited a joint letter issued earlier Thursday in Europe by France and West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl, saying the first concrete steps toward economic and political union in the EEC should be in place by Jan. 1, 1993. Mitterrand also said he had emphasized the importance of the CSCE, which takes in NATO and Warsaw Pact nations. ``We must always remember that the CSCE is, and has been in the past, the only place where all European countries can meet,'' he said. Asked whether he believed greater European self-reliance could split the United States from its European allies, Bush said, ``I don't see any danger'' of such division. He added his views of Europe's future security were ``very close'' to those of the French. Bush said he had stressed to Mitterrand the ``key role'' of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization in the fall of communist governments in Eastern Europe. ``The alliance must remain vigorous in this critical period of transition,'' he said. ``I told the president that the U.S. will retain militarily significant nuclear and conventional forces in Western Europe as long as our allies desire our presence as part of a common security effort,'' said Bush. ``And he indicated strong French support for the continued U.S. presence.''

DOC.HEAD: More Than Half of Toxic Pollutants Released Into the Air
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBs last 2 grafs with 4 grafs to CLARIFY that chemicals sent off-site not included in overall figures and why.
DOC.TEXT: The nation's factories released 4.6 billion pounds of toxic chemicals, including scores of carcinogens, in 1988, the Environmental Protection Agency reported Thursday. More than half of the pollutants went into the air, The pollution, emitted from 19,762 industrial plants nationwide, was 9 percent less than a year earlier, but the EPA said the decline may be a result of better record keeping. EPA officials cautioned that they are unable from the raw figures, the latest available, to assess the health risks to individuals. The data do not take into account levels of toxicity, release concentrations and actual exposure. Nevertheless, federal officials have been surprised at the high volume of releases of toxic chemicals in both 1987, when 5 billion pounds of pollution was reported, and 1988. The reporting requirement covers 332 toxic chemicals. ``The figures are absolutely shocking,'' declared Rep. Gerry Sikorksi, D-Minn., who along with several other members of Congress obtained a special computer run on the EPA figures and provided additional details about the releases. Among the chemicals routinely emitted from industrial sources were 77 carcinogens. The most widely released cancer-causing chemical _ 115 million pounds _ was dichloromethane, a chemical often used as an industrial solvent and paint stripper. Industry released a total of 281 million pounds of carcinogens, including chemicals such as arsenic, benzene and vinyl chloride. ``We've got to bring these pollution numbers down,'' EPA Administrator William Reilly said as he released the latest data. Clean-air legislation that already has passed the Senate and is being considered in the House would impose stringent controls on toxic industrial chemicals and require companies to use the best available technology to curb releases. Under current law, the EPA is required to deal with each chemical separately. In more than a decade, it has placed controls on only eight of the hundreds of toxic chemicals in use. Many of the chemicals, however, are subject to local and state regulation. The releases reported by industry, however, are legal and within federal standards, officials said. Chemical and allied industries accounted for about half of the total releases. Two states with a concentration of petrochemical plants _ Louisiana and Texas _ accounted for more than one-fourth of the pollution totals. The toxic pollution figures reflect data provided the EPA by 19,762 industrial plants nationwide. It is the second year such reports have been provided under a new citizen right-to-know law. The EPA announcement provided only general release statistics and no information on specific plants. But information released by Sikorski from data contained on EPA computer tapes showed that Amax Magnesium Co. of Rowley, Utah, had by far the highest volume of releases into the air _ nearly 110 million pounds. Amax was followed among the top five industrial air polluters in 1988 by Tennessee Eastman Co., Kingsport, Tenn., 40 million pounds; Avtex Fibers in Front Royal, Va., 34 million pounds; Triad Chemical, Donaldsonville, La., 27 million pounds, and Eastman Kodak Co., Rochester, N.Y., 21.6 million pounds. The Avtex Fibers plant in Virginia closed last November after a lengthy battle with the state over pollution issues. The states with the largest volume of toxic chemical releases overall were Louisiana, 716 million pounds; Texas, 596 million pounds; Ohio, 229 million pounds; Florida, 226 million pounds; Indiana, 213 million pounds, and Tennessee, 203 million pounds, according to the EPA. More than half of the toxic releases, 2.43 billion pounds, went into the air, while the remainder was disposed of in surface water, stored in landfills or injected into underground wells. More than half of the air pollutants were reported by the petrochemical, rubber, plastics and primary metals industries. Industrial plants released 360 million pounds of toxic chemicals into lakes, streams and rivers and disposed of 560 million pounds in on-site landfills. About 1.22 billion pounds of chemicals were injected deep into underground wells for storage. Another 570 million pounds of toxic chemicals were transferred to municipal wastewater treatment plants for processing and an additional 1.1 billion pounds of chemicals were turned over for treatment and disposal at special off-site facilities or storage sites, the EPA said. Neither the chemicals sent to the municipal plants nor those sent elsewhere for treatment and disposal were counted by the EPA in its overall release figure. Agency spokesman Sean McElheny said it is assumed most of those chemicals are treated and not released into the environment. However, the EPA has in the past criticized many municipal treatment facilities for not adequately ensuring that industrial wastes are kept from being released into surface waters. Neither the private or municipal treatment facilities subject to the toxic release reporting requirements.

DOC.HEAD: Cool In The East, Wet Elsewhere
DOC.TEXT: Temperatures fell to record lows Thursday in the East, and rain was scattered around the central section of the nation. Record lows were 38 at Allentown, Pa.; 28 at Atlantic City, N.J.; 31 at Baltimore; 31 at Bridgeport, Conn.; and 20 at Elkins, W.Va. Thursday's low for the Lower 48 states was 17 degrees at Concord, N.H. At midday, rain and thunderstorms extended from southwestern Oklahoma across south-central Texas and west-central Texas. Rain and thundershowers reached from northwestern Tennessee across western Kentucky, Illinois, northeastern Missouri, eastern Iowa and the southeastern half of Wisconsin. Showers were scattered over east-central Kansas and west-central Missouri, and from central Colorado across southwestern Nebraska. Elsewhere, rain extended along the northern Pacific Coast, and eastern Florida had rain and thundershowers. Temperatures around the nation at 3 p.m. EDT ranged from 43 at Gunnison, Colo., to 85 at McAllen, Texas, and Tampa, Fla.

DOC.HEAD: Mitterand Defends French Diplomatic Ties to Libya, Iran
With AM-Bush Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: French President Francois Mitterrand on Thursday defended his country's diplomatic ties to Libya and Iran, saying both countries have denied responsibility for hostage-taking. Mitterrand said France maintains relations with many regimes ``we do not like.'' At a news conference with President Bush, the French president said ``it's very difficult to draw the line'' in deciding when a country deserves to be ostracized. Both Iran and Libya ``have always said that they were not at the origin of the hostage-taking,'' said Mitterrand. The United States has drawn the line against relations with the two regimes, accusing both of sponsoring international terrorism including, in Iran's case, influence over the terrorists holding American hostages in Lebanon. ``As you know, we have a different situation in terms of relations with Iran and Libya,'' said Bush. But on a day when the Islamic Jihad said in Beirut it was reneging on its offer to release an American hostage, Bush said, ``let me just take this opportunity to repeat what I said when I first became president: goodwill begets goodwill. And I link that to the release of American hostages. ``We can't have normal relations when hostages are held,'' he said, adding that in Libya's case ``a verifiable renunciation of terror is terribly important ... if we are to have better relations there.'' The lawyerly Mitterrand said, ``It's always a very difficult question.'' He cited France's decision to maintain ties with Chile during ``the bloody dictatorship'' of Augusto Pinochet, which recently ended. He said the French embassy became ``a useful point of transit'' for those working in the Chilean resistance. ``I think it's probably a good idea to try to use those relations (with Iran and Libya) ... to try to help to get the release of the hostages,'' said Mitterrand. The French president drew criticism at home last week when he praised Libya for its role in securing the release of a French woman, her Belgian companion and their child who had been held hostage in Lebanon. Mitterrand said, ``most Western countries do business with these countries and often on a large scale.'' ``At any rate, what is clear is that any country that would be directly involved in hostage-taking or that would be a clear accomplice in hostage-taking should be set outside the pale of the civilized world community,'' Mitterrand said. On the Middle East, Mitterrand said it was ``unacceptable'' to place conditions on where Jewish refugees from the Soviet Union can settle. But he also cautioned Israel against further settlements on the West Bank, saying, ``it is not wise to multiply such settlements because they give rise to a climate of uncertainty'' that could undermine peace efforts.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Says `There Are Limits' to US Patience on Lithuania
DOC.NOTE: Eds: TOPS with 24 grafs to add detail, quotes and edit; picks up 17th graf pvs, bgng: On another ...
DOC.TEXT: President Bush said Thursday ``there are limits'' to U.S. patience for Soviet coercion of Lithuania but refused to say when or how he might respond. As Moscow imposed new pressure on the breakway Baltic republic by curbing oil and natural gas supplies, Bush said, ``I am greatly concerned by this escalation in terms of using energy to push the Lithuanians into line.'' Bush, asked the extent of his patience, said, ``Yes, there are limits and, having said that, I am convinced that Mr. Gorbachev knows there are limits.'' Bush made his comments at a news conference following a day of talks with French President Francois Mitterrand at a plush oceanside resort. With palm trees and sparkling waters as the backdrop for an outdoor news conference, the two leaders met for reporters for 78 minutes. The session was prolonged by translation of all the remarks into French. Bush appeared impatient at times, looking around, rubbing his chin and grimacing during lengthy statements by Mitterrand. On various subjects: _Bush, when asked about a report that Mideast extremists had postponed a plan to release an America hostage in Lebanon, said, ``We've been disappointed before, hopes raised only to have them dashed by excessive speculation.'' The Islamic Jihad for the Liberation of Palestine said the release of a hostage was postponed because of U.S. refusal to send John Kelly, assistant secretary of state for Middle Eastern affairs, to Syria to take part. ``The United States does not knuckle under to demands,'' said Bush when asked why he did not dispatch Kelly as demanded by the group. The president said he was grateful to Syria ``for trying to play a constructive role'' regarding the hostages. _Mitterrand, defending his country's ties with Libya and Iran, said he could not judge whether they were responsible for hostage-taking. Bush noted that the United States does not have ties with either country and said, ``We can't have normal relations when hostages are held.'' _Mitterrand said he had proposed a summit of the 16 NATO allies before the end of the year to discuss the changing face of Europe and that Bush had concurred in the idea. On Lithuania, Bush and Mitterrand joined in calling for dialogue to end the confrontation between Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and the leaders of the breakaway Baltic republic. Bush said he was ``deeply disturbed'' by Soviet threats to cut off natural resources from the Baltic republic. Lithuania said the cutoff had been put into action Thursday but Bush said the United States had ``not been able to confirm, oddly, the exact extent of a Soviet crackdown.'' ``There is a real need for a dialogue,'' said Mitterrand who noted that France, like the United States, has never accepted the incorporation of Lithuania into the Soviet Union. Bush said Secretary of State James A. Baker had discussed Lithuania on Wednesday with Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze. It was the second time in a week that Bush had met with a Western leader to discuss developments in Eastern Europe. He traveled to Bermuda to talk with British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher last Friday. Asked about a U.S. response to Soviet pressure against Lithuania, Bush said, ``I can't tell you when the U.S. might do something. But my reluctance stems from trying to keep open a dialogue and discussion that affects many, many countries. ``And I'm talking about arms control. I'm talking about solidifying the democracies in Eastern Europe,'' Bush said. He said he was confident that Gorbachev understood there were limits to what would be tolerated concerning Lithuania. ``I don't think there is any danger that there will be a misunderstanding on this point,'' said the president. ``None at all.'' Bush had earlier warned Moscow not to apply economic pressure against the Baltic state, saying the United States would react with ``appropriate responses.'' On another front Thursday, anticipation about a possible hostage release had been fueled when Syria sent word that one appeared to be imminent. Syria's message added weight to a similar report by the Islamic Jihad for the Liberation of Palestine, the radical group holding three Americans in Lebanon. The group's message was accompanied by a photograph of hostage Jesse Turner of Boise, Idaho. Bush has tried to entice the kidnappers to release Americans by pledging repeatedly that goodwill begets goodwill. White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater said Bush had dispatched a hostage reception team to West Germany to be on hand at the sprawling U.S. air base at Wiesbaden, likely the first stop for any hostage freed in the Middle East. As for the situation in Lithuania, Fitzwater said Bush was consulting with major allies about possible responses to Moscow's actions. In addition to the meeting with Mitterrand, Bush talked by telephone Wednesday with West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl. ``We will be in touch with all of the allies either directly or through diplomatic channels in the next few days,'' Fitzwater said. Asked if joint action was being considered, Fitzwater said, ``I wouldn't put it in that category. I think it's more a consultation about what individual countries might do, what their approach might be.'' He said the best guide to a U.S. response was Baker's statement about possible restrictions of ``bilateral commercial contacts'' with Moscow. Baker, testifying before Congress on Wednesday, indicated arms-control negotiations and U.S.-Soviet talks about regional conflicts would not be affected. Fitzwater said there was some uncertainty about what was happening in Lithuania, and ``we're still trying to get verification of the exact situation there.'' Bush's Florida visit marked the seventh time he has met with Mitterrand since becoming president. Bush greeted Mitterrand with a warm handshake as the French president stepped off a helicopter. Both leaders wore gray suits and ties for the arrival but quickly changed to casual attire for their talks. After Mitterrand's departure, Bush was spending the night here at the Ocean Reef Club before trips Friday to Republican fund-raisers in Birmingham, Ala., and Orlando, Fla. After that, he was heading back to the Florida Keys for a weekend of fishing in the Everglades off Islamorada, Fla. The White House portrayed his weekend as an environmental outing in honor of Earth Day.

DOC.HEAD: Gov't Wins Passage of Bill Making Hong Kong Residents Citizens
DOC.TEXT: The government won a surprisingly easy victory Thursday night in a crucial vote on a bill to give British passports and citizenship to an estimated 225,000 Hong Kong residents. The 650-seat House of Commons approved the measure by a vote of 313-216 despite rare opposition from both right-wingers in the governing Conservative Party opposed to increased immigration and from the socialist Labor Party, which called the bill elitist. The measure now goes to committee for possible amendments and then back to the House of Commons where political observers say its passage is virtually assured. It then must pass the unelected House of Lords. The government says it hopes the bill will become law by summer. The 97-vote margin of victory in the latest vote was far higher than political commentators predicted. Home Secretary David Waddington had argued that giving British citizenship to 50,000 key Hong Kong residents and their families would prevent a brain-drain and maintain confidence in the colony before it reverts to China in 1997. The vote on the British Nationality (Hong Kong) Bill was seen as one of the toughest tests for Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher since she took power nearly 11 years ago, because of the prospect of a Conservative revolt and Labor opposition. The opposition Labor Party told its members to vote against it on grounds that only Hong Kong's elite will be given passports. Smaller opposition parties were divided on the bill. An initial analysis of the vote showed 44 Conservatives voting against the government and one Labor member voting for the government. The number of Labor lawmakers voting against the government was not immediately available. The voting capped an acrimonious and noisy debate in the Commons. Under the bill, 50,000 Hong Kong residents in ``good jobs, earning good salaries'' would be selected on a point system from a wide variety of fields to receive British passports, Waddington said. ``First and foremost, this is not an immigration bill,'' he said. ``This is a nationality bill designed to anchor people to Hong Kong rather than to encourage them to come here.'' In an angry retort, Former Conservative Party Chairman Norman Tebbit called for the bill to be thrown out. He warned that it could lead to rising racial tension and accused the Thatcher government of reneging on election pledges against large-scale immigration. ``These pledges were made because these islands of ours are already overcrowded, and in the belief that great waves of immigration by people who do not share our culture, our language, our ways of social conduct, in many cases who owe no allegiance to our culture was, and is, a destablizing factor in society,'' he said. Labor's deputy leader Roy Hattersley objected to the bill saying, ``The only solution that meets the needs of all the people is to make major progress toward democracy in the colony.'' But Paddy Ashdown, leader of the centrist Liberal Democrats, asked whether Hattersley had not learned anything from the Chinese government crackdown on pro-democracy demonstrators in Beijing last spring. ``What (democracy) needs to be supported by is the right of those people to leave if they wish with a British passport and come to Britain.'' About 3.25 million Hong Kong Chinese now hold a special category of British passport that do not confer a right to residence in Britain.

DOC.HEAD: Klansman Testifies He Needs Mask To Protect Life, Family
DOC.TEXT: A Klansman who is challenging a state law banning public wearing of masks and hoods testified Thursday that he wore a mask during a one-man protest because he feared for his life. ``I could lose my job ... my family might be in danger, if people knew I was a Klansman,'' Shade Miller Jr. said during a hearing in Gwinnett County State Court. Miller said he was willing to challenge the 1951 law publicly because ``I felt it was my freedom of speech. I feel this is wrong.'' Representatives of black and Jewish advocacy groups testified that the anti-mask law has helped reduce Klan violence. ``The threat of the Klan is the threat of violence and terrorism. That's why (the mask) is offensive,'' said Charles Wittenstein, Southern counsel for the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith. Earl Shinhoster, Southeastern regional director for the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, said Georgians know the Klan wardrobe represents ``harassment, intimidation or carrying out acts of violence.'' After the testimony, State Court Judge Howard Cook said he will rule in about a month on Miller's legal challenge. Miller was arrested in February on a misdemeanor charge of wearing a mask and hood in downtown Lawrenceville. Miller, of Calhoun, asserted that a proper Ku Klux Klan uniform includes the hood. ``It's one thing. It's like a suit and tie,'' he said. Supporters of the law, including civil rights groups, say that without it the Klan would be free to anonymously terrorize blacks and other minorities. David Fuller, Gwinnett County's chief assistant solicitor, questioned Miller's assertion that he feared for his job, pointing out that Miller was unemployed at the time. Miller said his boss at his previous truck-driving job had warned him he would be in ``bad trouble'' if he joined the Klan. He testified he joined the Invisible Empire of the Knights of the Ku Klux Klan in July 1988. Miller's attorney, Michael Hauptman, also called as a witness Edward K. Fields, a former Klan organizer who said he believed the use of masks and hoods helped people overcome fears of joining the KKK. In his cross-examination of Wittenstein, Hauptman asked the B'nai B'rith representative if people would feel threatened by masked gay rights demonstrators. Wittenstein replied that gay people do not have the Klan's history of violence. Hauptman has argued that the law is too broad, covering people who would not be perceived as threats.

DOC.HEAD: WHO Chief Asks U.S. Travel Restrictions Dropped on AIDS Carriers
DOC.TEXT: The chief of the World Health Organization on Thursday hailed a new, eased U.S. visa policy for participants at a world AIDS conference in San Francisco, but again asked Washington to drop all travel restrictions on carriers of the AIDS virus. WHO Director General Hiroshi Nakajima also made plain his concern over U.S. reaction if next month's annual WHO assembly approves a PLO bid to have the ``State of Palestine'' join WHO as a member. Washington has threatened to cut off funds to any U.N. agency admitting the Palestine Liberation Organization as a full-fledged member, arguing that the self-declared state does not meet internationally accepted norms of statehood. The United States contributes $78 million, or 25 percent, to the 1990 regular WHO budget. Under a new visa policy announced last week, foreigners coming to attend certain professional conferences in the United States will be granted special 10-day visas without having to reveal whether they are infected with the HIV-virus that causes AIDS. Nakajima told a news conference that WHO, co-sponsor of the San Francisco conference in June, welcomes the new procedures. ``However,'' he added in a statement he read before a question-and-answer session, ``WHO views the situation as not completely satisfactory and strongly urges the United States to continue its efforts to drop all travel restrictions against HIV-infected persons.'' The U.S. policy was relaxed after several countries and organizations, including France and Switzerland, said they would boycott the San Francisco gathering. The European Parliament also asked scientists not to attend. Nakajima also cautioned on Thursday that he was sure the United States would cease its contributions to the WHO regular budget if next month's assembly accepts the PLO as a a ``state'' member. He said such a cutoff would force reduction of all important programs operated by WHO. More than 100 countries have recognized the ``State of Palestine'' since it was proclaimed by the PLO's legislative body in Tunis in 1988. Last year, the WHO assembly voted to defer a decision until 1990. Nakajima said it was his understanding that a decision by the U.S. Congress to stop payments to any U.N. agency granting full PLO membership would not apply to voluntary contributions, such as to the WHO Global Program on AIDS. That program, which has a 1990 budget of $78 million, is exclusively financed by grants. The United States, which leads the world in the number of AIDS cases, has pledged to contribute $25 million. Nakajima was pressed repeatedly to elaborate on his comments on the resignation of the American head of the program, Dr. Jonathan Mann. Mann told Nakajima in a letter last month he was not renewing his contract because of a ``great variance between our positions on a series of issues'' he considered critical for the global AIDS strategy. Nakajima reiterated there had been no differences on basic strategy questions. He declined to go into detail, saying entering ``into polemics would not be in the interest of the AIDS program.'' He said he personally had ``very good relations'' with Mann.

DOC.HEAD: Observatory Records Quake Measuring 6.1 Near Indonesia
DOC.TEXT: An earthquake measuring 6.1 on the Richter scale struck Thursday night in the Celebes Sea off central Indonesia, the Hong Kong Observatory reported. An initial reading of the quake showed the epicenter to be 944 miles south-southeast of Manila, the Philippines, the observatory said. No further details were available. A quake measuring 6 on the Richter scale can cause severe damage on land while a tremor of magnitude 7, 10 times higher in intensity, is capable of causing widespread heavy damage.

DOC.HEAD: Brian Hogben, Newspaper Executive, Dead After Long Illness
DOC.TEXT: Brian Hogben, a senior executive with Rupert Murdoch's News Limited media group, died Thursday after a long illness, the company announced. He was 64. Hogben, group general manager (editorial) of News Limited, also served on the company's board of directors. Ken Cowley, managing director of News Limited, said Friday that Hogben had been a journalist 47 years. He began his career as a intern on the Sydney Daily Mirror at age 17. He later became editor of that paper, as well as of the Sydney Daily Telegraph. ``He was a great newspaperman of the old school. He earned unrivaled respect,'' Cowley said. ``He will be sorely missed by everyone.'' Hogben is survived by his wife, Peg, daughters Terri and Lisa and sons Sean and Timothy. Funeral arrangements are pending.

DOC.HEAD: GOP Senators Want To Reduce Unions' Political Role
DOC.TEXT: Senate Republicans said on Thursday they would write their own campaign finance reform bill to reduce the ability of labor unions and other groups to spend money on political activities, including voter registration. Republicans, however, were divided on how far to go beyond Democrats in restricting how much money candidates can take from labor, corporate and trade association political action committees that rely on voluntary contributions. ``There was no resolution,'' Sen. John Danforth of Missouri said upon emerging from an hour-long meeting among more than half of the Senate's 45 Republicans in GOP Leader Bob Dole's office. In a bill scheduled to be brought to the Senate floor next week, Democrats would retain the current $5,000 limit a PAC can contribute to a candidate for each primary, runoff and general election but impose a ceiling on the total PAC contributions a candidate can receive. President Bush wants an outright abolition of PACs, which in recent elections have overwhelmingly favored incumbent lawmakers. Since Democrats hold majorities in both the Senate and House, they have enjoyed PAC largesse more than Republicans. ``We spent a lot of time talking about the PAC issue and how far to go,'' Kentucky Sen. Mitch McConnell, who will manage the Republican side of the debate, said of the meeting in Dole's office. ``We disagree on just a very few things, such as how far to go in bashing PACs.'' McConnell said Republicans are divided into three camps: _Those who want to go along with Bush and abolish PACs outright. _Those who would reduce the amount a PAC can contribute to a candidate for each primary, runoff and general election to $1,000. _And those who want to abolish labor and corporate PACs but only reduce to $1,000 the contribution that issue-oriented, unconnected PACs, such as those of the National Rife Association, environmental groups and both sides of the abortion debate. An overwhelming majority of the Republicans in the meeting opposed provisions in the Democratic bill that would basically impose spending ceilings of $400,000 on House candidates and $950,000 to $5.5 billion for Senate candidates, depending on the population of a state, McConnell said. However, he said Republicans endorsed the idea of so-called flexible ceilings that would place no limits on how much a candidate can raise from home-state residents but would cap contributions from out-of-state donors. ``I still believe that the president _ a former chairman of the Republican National Committee _ will veto a bill that has spending limits, in or out of state,'' said McConnell, one of the most vociferous opponents of ceilings. Republicans, he said, are united on abolishing the use of so-called ``soft'' unreported money by unions and other tax-exempt organizations for voter registration drives. Academic experts have estimated that unions spent up to $45 million of such money in the 1988 election _ almost all of it benefitting Democrats. And it was through a tax-exempt California voter registration project headed by the son of Senate Democratic Whip Alan Cranston, that Phoenix savings and loan operator Charles H. Keating Jr. gave $850,000 of the total $1.3 million contributed to five senators. ``If you're tax-exempt, you shouldn't be playing the political game,'' said Dole. ``If we're really concerned about cleaning up the campaign sewer money, then it's about time to spray the sewer stench with a big can of legislative Lysol.''

DOC.HEAD: Tear Gas Explodes During Religious Meeting, Injures Nine
DOC.TEXT: A tear-gas grenade exploded Thursday night outside a religious meeting in an ultra-Orthodox Jewish town, injuring at least nine people, witnesses and police said. An anonymous caller said a Jewish extremist organization carried out the attack in the Tel Aviv suburb of Bnei-Brak. Officials said the attack came in response to an Orthodox political party's support to the left-leaning Labor Party, which is trying to form Israel's next government. An Israel Television report showed the site surrounded by dozens of ultra-Orthodox Jews in traditional long black coats. Police vans and ambulances with wailing sirens were transporting the injured. The television said 11 people were injured by gas inhalation and one was hit in the head in the scuffle that followed the attack, but Bnei-Brak Mayor Moshe Irenstein reported only nine injured. The grenade exploded outside a hall where hundreds of religious Jews gathered for a special ceremony to celebrate the end of their studies of a portion of Talmud, the body of Jewish law and rabbinical commentaries. A police spokeswoman, Ahuva Ivri, said an anonymous caller told Israel army radio the attack was carried out by the Sicarites, a radical Jewish group believed responsible for a series of arson attacks and death threats against leftist and liberal Israelis advocating peace talks with Palestinians. The Sicarites, who take their name from a radical sect that assassinated opponents in Roman times, claimed responsibility for the April 1989 shooting outside Jerusalem's walled Old City that left one Arab dead and three wounded. The gathering in Bnei-Brak was organized by the ultra-Orthodox Agudat Israel Party, which supports the left-leaning Labor in its attempts to form Israel's next coalition government. Labor advocates territorial concessions in peace negotiations with the Arabs. The attack came shortly after a defecting Agudat Israel member, Abraham Verdiger, announced that he decided to return to his party and support Labor. ``It is possible'' that the attack came in response, said witness Eliezer Steizberg, an Agudat official. The defection of Verdiger and another party member last week prevented Labor from forming a new government in the 120-member parliament. Irenstein, the mayor, denounced the attack. ``We condemn it. Such a thing has never happened at a gathering devoted to Torah.'' Irenstein said threats will not deter his political party and their pledge to form a new government with Labor. ``Now, with God's help, we have to succeed.''

DOC.HEAD: EPA Rejects Environmentalists' Pesticide Petition
DOC.TEXT: The Environmental Protection Agency on Thursday rejected a petition from environmentalists asking that any pesticide that poses even a slight cancer risk be prohibited for use on processed foods. The EPA affirmed its intention not to use the ``zero-tolerance'' standard in cases where the cancer risk is considered negligible. Several suits are pending before various federal courts challenging the EPA position. Under a provision of the federal pesticide laws, a cancer-causing pesticide must be prohibited for use on processed food products if even the slightest residue levels are found. The ``zero tolerance'' standard is called the Delaney Clause after the congressman who pushed for its enactment. The EPA in 1988 concluded that because of modern techniques that can discern even exceedingly small amounts of pesticide residue, it would not invoke the Delaney Clause in cases where residue levels were ``negligible.'' That prompted several environmental groups, including the Natural Resources Defense Council, to file a petition challenging the EPA policy. The EPA said Thursday it was denying the petition and would continue to disregard the Delaney principle in cases where residue levels are negligible. Agency lawyers have argued that the government is not legally required to comply with the Delaney provision in all cases. At the same time, however, the EPA acknowleged for the first time that it would apply the Delaney priciple for so-called ``old'' pesticides _ those that have been approved and later found to cause cancer _ as long as the residue levels are more than negligible. Most pesticides found on processed foods are ``old'' pesticides so environmentalists characterized that EPA decision to apply the Delaney principle _ even to a limited extent _ as somewhat of a victory. ``If properly implemented, today's decision will lead to a far safer food supply,'' said Al Meyerhoff, an attorney for the NRDC.

DOC.HEAD: GAO: Military Doesn't Know What's Buried At U.S. Bases Or Cleanup Costs
DOC.TEXT: No one knows how much radioactive material is buried on U.S. military bases, Sen. John Glenn said Thursday as he released an investigative report with more questions than answers. ``None of the three services has a complete grip on what type and how much low-level radioactive waste it has generated,'' said Glenn, D-Ohio, who made public a report prepared at his request by the General Accounting Office. Glenn said he wanted the auditors to figure out how much it will cost the military to deal with its waste, but they didn't have enough information even to attempt an estimate. All they could say with certainty was that the cost of disposing of the waste is going to skyrocket. The Army has found that surcharges tacked onto the cost of disposing of its low-level radioactive waste over the next few years will be higher than the actual disposal cost and ``We can't even take a guess as to what the Navy and Air Force may have to pay because they don't have accurate records,'' Glenn said. Glenn's interest in the radioactive waste on military bases was triggered by a 1986 spill at Wright-Patterson Air Force Base near Dayton, Ohio, that cost the government more than $1 million to clean up. Unmarked drums of radioactive americium-241, which had been brought illegally onto the base, were accidentally opened, contaminating a building and exposing some workers. After that episode, the Navy and Air Force initiated surveys to discover how much and what kind of waste was stored at each installation. But the GAO report said those surveys weren't completed. Just under half of the installations returned their survey questionnaires, the report said. The Air Force is scheduled this year to begin excavating low-level radioactive waste buried in the early 1950s. After the Air Force stopped burying that waste it failed to provide instructions on maintaining the sites or record-keeping, the report said. ``As a result the Air Force is facing a cleanup situation of unknown proportions,'' he said. The Air Force referred a request for comment to Capt. Sig Adams, who did not return a telephone message. The GAO report said the facts in the report were discussed with officials in all three military branches and ``they generally agreed with the facts.'' Glenn said he's ``considering various legislative options,'' but he wants the Pentagon to get a fix on the problem and put a radioactive waste disposal program in place without having ``This points out the problem. It's up to them to do something,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Banks Report Tighter Lending Practices
DOC.TEXT: A majority of large banks responding to a survey said they had tightened their lending practices for real estate loans in the last six months, Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan said. Greenspan said the Federal Reserve, which regulates bank holding companies, had surveyed 60 of the country's largest banks in January to determine whether it was easier or harder for businesses to obtain credit. A ``large majority'' of the banks said they had become less willing to make construction and land development loans during the past six months, Greenspan said in written responses released Thursday by the Senate Banking Committee. Greenspan did not provide a specific percentage figure, but said that ``most'' banks responding to the survey also had tightened standards for making merger-related loans or loans to businesses with lower credit ratings. One-fifth of the banks said they were less willing to make general business loans, Greenspan said. The banks blamed the tighter credit policies primarily on the economy's weakness late last year, which made them scrutinize loan requests more carefully. Other factors cited by the banks were rising numbers of bad loans and closer scrutiny by banking regulators. Many small and medium-sized businesses have complained they are facing a severe credit crunch at present as financial institutions are forced to tighten credit practices under pressure from federal regulators who have become more strict in the wake of the giant savings and loan bailout. Greenspan's comments came in response to a question submitted by Sen. John F. Kerry, D-Mass., who said many businesses in his state were complaining about their inability to get credit. Greenspan said the Fed was aware that banks in New England and other areas of the country had tightened their lending standards. He said such a development could have an impact on overall economic activity in a region. But he said for the lending slowdown to pose serious threats to the health of the economy it would need to be more severe than what the Fed has detected and extend for a longer period of time. Greenspan said it was essential for banks to meet the financing needs of their communities but in a prudent manner. ``As recent experience has shown, there are substantial costs associated with both too much restraint and with too little,'' he said. ``We (federal regulators) are attempting to strike the proper balance.''

DOC.HEAD: Imelda's Spending Sprees Detailed in Documents
DOC.TEXT: When Imelda Marcos visited New York in 1983, she put $1 million toward a Michelangelo painting and spent millions more on jewelry, documents in evidence at her fraud trial show. During a visit a year later, she spent $55 at McDonald's. Other expenses included a $19,400 order of nightgowns, towels, tablecloths and bedsheets and a hotel bill at the Waldorf Astoria for $18,401. The purchases were logged in stenographer notebooks kept by Mrs. Marcos' personal secretary, Fe Roa Jimenez, during Mrs. Marcos' trips to the United States in the early 1980s. The notebooks, entered in evidence Tuesday, were found in the Philippine presidential palace in 1986 after Mrs. Marcos' husband, Ferdinand E. Marcos, was ousted as president and they fled to Hawaii. Mrs. Marcos, 60, is on trial on charges she and her late husband bought four New York properties and financed a lavish lifestyle between 1981 and 1983 with more than $160 million allegedly embezzled from their homeland's treasury. Many of Ms. Jimenez's handwritten entries were for jewelry purchases _ such as a $200,000 diamond bracelet and $360,000 for antique jewelry. The biggest single expenditure during the May 1983 trip was the $1 million payment toward the unidentified Michelangelo painting, leaving a $2.5 million balance. During a 1984 visit to New York, Mrs. Marcos spent $13,284 in a single day at Bloomingdale's department store, according to a ledger. Food expenses ranged from $55.95 for hamburgers and fish fillets at McDonald's to $305 for lunch at a Manhattan restaurant two days later. In testimony Thursday, a former Philippine banking official said the Marcoses worried about their country's diminished U.S. dollar reserves while they allegedly bought Manhattan real estate with embezzled government funds. Jaime Laya, who served as governor of the Philippine Central Bank from 1981 to 1984, testified that he discussed with President Marcos in September 1983 ways to obtain private loans to replenish the treasury because banks were reluctant to lend the country money. Marcos also was charged in the 1988 indictment along with his wife. He died last September in exile in Hawaii. Another witness, former Philippine National Bank official Oscar Carino, said that Jimenez asked him for as much as $500,000 in cash during each of Mrs. Marcos' trips to New York. Prosecutors have described the bank's New York office as Mrs. Marcos' ``own personal piggy bank.'' The notebooks revealed bits and pieces of Mrs. Marcos' social activities, including Broadway shows, and contained references to numerous celebrities such as singer Julio Iglesias, actor George Hamilton and industrialist Armand Hammer. One notation concerned a request by former Philippine Sen. Benigno Aquino Jr. to meet with Mrs. Marcos in New York on May 12, 1983. Aquino, a Marcos foe then living in exile in the United States, was murdered at the Manila airport when he returned home three months later. In his testimony Thursday, Laya said he attended a meeting at the Marcoses' official residence in Manila at which Mrs. Marcos asked prominent Filipino businessmen to use their contacts abroad to help the Philippines in its time of crisis. The meeting resulted in Marcos' decision to issue treasury bonds in U.S. dollar denominations that would be repaid with interest in two years, Laya said. When the treasury bonds did not immediately spur investments, Laya said he asked Marcos for help, and a few days later, three foreign banks bought bonds worth $75 million. The witness said $15 million came from Banque Paribas, a Swiss institution where prosecutors claim the Marcoses held secret accounts for funds allegedly stolen from their homeland's treasury. Laya, who testified with immunity for the prosecution, served on Marcos' cabinet as Minister of Education, Culture and Sports from 1984 until February 1986 when Marcos was ousted from power. In his position as the Central Bank's governor, Laya supervised the regulation of the country's money supply.

DOC.HEAD: Postponement of Hostage Release Saddens Relatives
With AM-Hostages, Bjt
DOC.TEXT:
Relatives of Americans held hostage in Lebanon reacted with weary sadness to the news Thursday that the release of one of the captives had been indefinitely postponed. ``I've had my hopes shattered so many times in the past three and a half years that I cannot say that it was unexpected,'' hostage Robert Polhill's mother, Ruth Polhill of Fishkill, N.Y., said in a telephone interview. ``Nothing has come on the dates they say it would be coming,'' she said. The Islamic Jihad for the Liberation of Palestine said Wednesday that it would release one of the three U.S. educators it has held since 1987. But on Thursday, the pro-Iranian group said in a statement that it was postponing the release because the United States refused to meet its demand that John Kelly, U.S. assistant secretary of state for Near Eastern affairs, fly to Damascus, Syria, to coordinate final arrangements.
The group holds Polhill, Jesse Turner, and Alann Steen, but didn't say which one it had planned to release. An instant photograph of Turner was released with Wednesday's communique; Thursday's announcement was accompanied by a photo of Polhill. ``Regardless of which of the men is going to be released, I will be happy,'' Mrs. Polhill said. ``But it looks like a long haul.'' ``We've very sad,'' Steen's mother-in-law, Dorothy Rose of Clark Lake, Mich., said in an interview with Detroit television station WDIV-TV. ``You have your hopes up any time something like this happens.'' ``It gives me a very bad letdown,'' Turner's mother, Estelle Ronneburg, said in a telephone interview in Boise, Idaho. ``I may not go as high and as low as I used to, but it's still hard. ... This seemed to be the time he was going to be released.'' Steen, Polhill and Turner were abducted from the Beirut University College campus on Jan. 24, 1987. Turner, 42, taught mathematics and computer science. Polhill, 55, of New York, was a lecturer in accounting. Steen, a journalism professor born in Arcata, Calif., and a former resident of Boston, turns 51 Sunday. Eight Americans are among the Western hostages held in Lebanon by pro-Iranian groups. The longest-held is 42-year-old Terry Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press, who was kidnapped March 16, 1985. Anderson's sister, Peggy Say, who has traveled and spoken widely to win freedom for her brother, on Thursday criticized the U.S. government's refusal to send Kelly to Syria. ``God knows I have heard from the White House, `We will go anywhere and we will talk to anybody.' And I am totally puzzled by the attitude of reluctance to move forward and get on with this,'' she said in an interview with CBS News. ``If they want John Kelly, send them John Kelly.'' ``I don't know the reasons for them not sending him,'' said Mrs. Ronneburg, who said the State Department contacted her Wednesday and Thursday before the release fell through. ``The reasons may be very good reasons but they haven't told me the reasons,'' she said. In a news conference in Key Largo, Fla., on Thursday, President Bush repeated that he will not meet the demands of kidnappers. ``The United States does not knuckle under to demands,'' Bush said when asked why he did not dispatch Kelly to Damascus.

DOC.HEAD: Contras Agree to Cease-fire, Demobilize; U.S. Official Mobbed
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 16 grafs to UPDATE with Ortega urging caution, meetings with U.S. official. Pick up 16th pvs, `Sandinista army...' ^By DORALISA PILARTE
DOC.TEXT: Nine years of civil war that took 30,000 lives appeared near an end Thursday when Contra guerrillas, leftist Sandinistas and the incoming government agreed to a truce and a deadline for the rebels to disarm. ``With this accord we conclude the peace process that started with the elections,'' said Antonio Lacayo, senior negotiator for President-elect Violeta Barrios de Chamorro, after the accords were read at a dawn news conference. However, President Daniel Ortega cautioned late Thursday that the war is not over ``as long as those accords are not fulfilled.'' He spoke after meeting with Bernard Aronson, assistant U.S. secretary of state of inter-American affairs. The accord sets a cease-fire that began at noon Thursday; the withdrawal of Sandinista military forces at least 12 miles from the borders of five security zones, to be completed by Saturday; and the immediate gathering of all Contra fighters within the zones. About 9,000 Contras fighters are in Nicaragua. An addendum said the Contras will start turning in their weapons on Wednesday afternoon, April 25, after Mrs. Chamorro takes office from President Daniel Ortega, with the Contra fighting force to be disbanded completely by June 10. Missions from the United Nations and the Organization of American States _ as well as Roman Catholic Cardinal Miguel Obando y Bravo _ were charged with supervising the cease-fire and demobilization. The accord, completed after 14 hours of negotiations, does not meet the Sandinista Front's demand that the Contras disband by April 25. But it also makes no mention of what had been a key Contra demand _ that the Sandinista People's Army be neutralized as a condition for the rebels to surrender their weapons. Mrs. Chamorro's United National Opposition alliance clearly gained the most from the agreement _ the opportunity to start its government in peace, instead of in the middle of civil war, bitter recriminations or anti-government strikes, as had been feared. After nine years of civil war that cost 30,000 people their lives in a country of 3 million, each side was suspicious of the other's motives and neither wanted to be the first to put down its weapons. The army is controlled by the Sandinista party, and the Contras insisted that they wouldn't disarm until they were sure Mrs. Chamorro had full control of the government and it was safe for them to return home. Under a protocol with Mrs. Chamorro's coalition, the Sandinistas agreed to depoliticize the army and reduce its size. In exchange, the incoming government promised to ``respect the integrity and professionalism'' of the army. Some Sandinistas appeared disappointed the accord did not call for the immediate disbanding of the Contras, and a mob of youths chanting anti-Contra slogans surrounded a car carrying Aronson hours after the agreement was signed. The U.S. Embassy vehicle was ringed as it left Managua's airport. The mob beat on the car's windows, but was startled by a loud bang like a firecracker and the vehicle was able to leave. Aronson later met with Ortega and Mrs. Chamorro for several hours each, but commented only after talking with Mrs. Chamorro, saying they had discussed ``economics, the transition, the peace process'' and President Bush's proposed $300 million aid package. Washington backed the Contras in their war but supported Mrs. Chamorro's call for their dissolution. Sandinista army Gen. Humberto Ortega, the defense minister and brother of the president, said he was satisfied with what he called a peace effort reached ``in a profound, serious way, with a great spirit of responsibility.'' ``Let it be clear that what has been signed here is something serious, something formal, and I think that we all have the good will to fulfill this signed document,'' said Oscar Sovalbarro, the Contras' senior negotiator. Lacayo, Gen. Ortega and Sovalbarro, along with Obando y Bravo, the archbishop of Managua, signed the main Contra agreement. A separate accord was reached between the Sandinista army and the Yatama Atlantic Front, the Miskito Indian rebel contingent fighting the Sandinistas in Nicaragua's Atlantic Coast region. The Yatama accord calls for a cease-fire covering the sparsely populated eastern half of Nicaragua to start at midnight Thursday. The rebel Indians have two separate security zones, and they are to disband by May 18. Gen. Ortega said ``technical and operational hurdles'' made it logistically impossible to meet an April 25 deadline for disbanding the Contras. Making the Contras disarm by inauguration day had become nearly an obsession with the Sandinistas, who were trounced in the Feb. 25 election. However, Gen. Ortega dismissed the failure to have the Contras disarm immediately. ``The delay is nothing if we compare it to the tragedy and suffering that we have had to endure during these years of war,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Silver Table Fountain Fetches Record-Breaking $1.98 Million
DOC.TEXT: A 17th-century Sicilian table fountain sold for $1.98 million Thursday, an auction record for a piece of silver, Christie's said. The decorative centerpiece, crafted in 1670 by Giuseppe d'Angelo of Messina, was bought by a London silver dealer identified as Armitage, said Doris Athineos, a spokeswoman for the auction house. The seller's identity was withheld, she said. The 22-inch-high, two-tiered centerpiece supported by four horses is based on Giovanni Montolorsoli's marble fountain of Orion. It was auctioned for $1,500 in 1947 from the estate of J.P. Morgan. The previous auction record for a piece of silver was believed to be a pair of candelabra that sold for $1.5 million in 1989 at Sotheby's, the spokeswoman said.

DOC.HEAD: Mexican President Warns U.S. on Abductions in Mexico
DOC.TEXT: President Carlos Salinas de Gortari on Thursday warned the United States against actions such as the alleged abduction of a Mexican doctor for trial in the murder of a U.S. drug agent Enrique Camarena. Salinas said his nation has joined the battle against drug trafficking in good faith, ``but we will not permit anybody, not drug traffickers nor their pursuers, to violate Mexican rights.'' Dr. Humberto Alvarez Machain, a suspect in the 1985 torture-slaying of Camarena, was arrested April 3 in El Paso, Texas. His U.S. lawyer, Robert Steinberg, said Alvarez was kidnapped at his office in Guadalajara the previous day. ``In the fight against drugs, the law is rendered useless by illegal actions, or by trying to measure justice with a ruler of one country in foreign territory,'' Salinas told an international conference on drug trafficking. Mexico has asked the United States to explain how Alvarez got to El Paso, and U.S. Attorney General Richard Thornburgh said an investigation is being conducted. Mexican Attorney General Enrique Alvarez del Castillo said Wednesday the incident might hinder U.S.-Mexico cooperation in the drug war. Thornburgh and his Mexican counterpart met privately Thursday and a U.S. Justice Department statement said without elaborating that the two nations would continue working together. The Los Angeles Times on Wednesday quoted unidentified Mexican sources as saying agents in the Drug Enforcement Administration's Los Angeles office arranged to kidnap Alvarez without the knowledge of their superiors in Washington. A senior Salinas administration official told The Associated Press that Mexican officials believe Alvarez was abducted by bounty hunters and that Mexican police were not involved. Alvarez, 42, is one of 19 Mexicans indicted by a U.S. grand jury in Los Angeles on charges of kidnapping, torturing and killing Camarena in 1985. He was arraigned earlier this month and pleaded innocent. In Mexico, two drug lords, Rafael Caro Quintero and Ernesto Fonseca, have been convicted and sentenced to long terms in the Camarena killing. Although Salinas mentioned neither the United States nor Alvarez by name in his speech to an international anti-drug conference at this coastal resort, his meaning was clear. ``The fight against drug trafficking can't be used as an excuse to violate the law in a country's own territory, and much less so in a foreign nation's territory,'' said Salinas. ``Mexico fights drug trafficking because it considers it a menace to the security of the state and a threat to the health of our families and our youth,'' Salinas told the conference, which drew representatives from 32 nations. The Alvarez arrest has drawn protests from Mexicans who cite it as an example of U.S. highhandedness. Opponents have tried to rally nationalist sentiment by saying Salinas is letting the United States take advantage of Mexico on trade, drugs and other issues. In his speech to the conference, Thornburgh made no mention of the Alvarez incident but praised the Salinas administration's commitment to the war on drugs. ``We have demonstrable proof of the Mexican authorities' resolve to deal with these problems. Mexico has brought to justice several of the world's most notorious drug kingpins. Mexico has become a leader in promoting international cooperation,'' Thornburgh said. In a written statement, Thornburgh said his office has begun a full investigation. ``Until I have received that report, it would be premature to comment,'' Thornburgh added in a brief interview with reporters. Asked how Alvarez appeared in the United States, a member of the American delegation said an answer would have to await the report to Thornburgh. ``All we know is that a plane arrived in El Paso, and the DEA met the plane,'' said the official.

DOC.HEAD: Pullen Challenges Primary Election Results, Seeks Reversal
DOC.TEXT: A leading abortion opponent in the state legislature filed suit Thursday to get a judge to reverse election results that showed her narrowly losing a primary to an abortion-rights supporter. The state Board of Elections certified April 9 that Rosemary Mulligan defeated state Rep. Penny Pullen in the March 20 GOP primary for the northwestern suburban district, by 7,431 votes to 7,400. Ms. Pullen, in her petition in Cook County Circuit Court, said a partial recount showed her winning. Ms. Mulligan claims a separate partial recount conducted by her campaign confirmed her victory. Ms. Pullen has gained national recogntion in the GOP for her conservatism on social issues. President Bush recently nominated her to the board of the Legal Services Corporation. Several national abortion-rights groups that had targeted Ms. Pullen helped fund Ms. Mulligan's campaign. A court hearing is scheduled April 30. If Ms. Pullen convinces a judge she should be the winner, the judge could order a full recount. Ms. Mulligan, a paralegal, contends Ms. Pullen's attempt to reverse the results are a ploy to scare off financial backing for her run against the Democratic primary winner in the Nov. 6 election.

DOC.HEAD: OSHA Issues $6.4 Million Fine Against Companies in Pasadena Explosion
DOC.TEXT: Federal officials Thursday proposed $6.4 million in fines against Phillips 66 Co. and a contractor in connection with a Texas chemical plant explosion that killed 23 workers and injured 124 last October. The proposed fines of $5.67 million against Phillips and $729,600 against Fish Engineering and Construction Inc. would be the second largest for a single inspection by the federal Occupational Health and Safety Administration. OSHA accused Phillips of 566 willful violations and nine serious violations at the Houston Chemical Complex in suburban Pasadena. The agency accused Fish Engineering, a maintenence contractor at the plant, of 181 willful violations, 12 serious violations and one of mismanaging records. A series of explosions Oct. 23 destroyed the section of the plant that makes polyethylene, which is used to make plastics. Twenty-three workers were killed and 124 were hurt. ``We conducted an extensive investigation of what caused this catastrophe,'' said Gilbert Saulter, OSHA's Southwest regional administrator. He said the agency determined that the explosion would not have occurred ``had Phillips provided a safe workplace'' by following OSHA and industry standards. Phillips and Fish Engineering have 15 days to contest the fines. ``At no time has Phillips ever compromised the safety of its employees,'' the company said in a statement. ``Based on preliminary information, we do plan to contest a number of the citations and we do take issue with OSHA characterizing any of the violations as willful acts.'' Phillips 66 is the chemical production and marketing arm of Phillips Petroleum Co. Fish Engineering said in a statement that it also would contest the fines. However, the statement said OSHA's investigation ``confirmed that the Houston contractor did not cause or contribute to the explosion ...'' Saulter said one of the major problems at the plant included the lack of a double-valve system as a failsafe on gas emissions. Phillips officials have said the explosion occurred after a seal on a polyethylene reactor ruptured, leaking highly flammable ethylene and isobutane gas from a pipeline. It was unclear what ignited the gas. Workers reported that only a few seconds elapsed between the time they spotted a cloud of gas, heard warning sirens and were rocked by explosions. Saulter said the deficiencies described as willful violations fell into three categories: failure to prevent the release of flammable vapors, failure to minimize or mitigate the consequences of a release, and failure to provide adequate fire protection. The serious violations include inadequate emergency exits and emergency planning, inaudible emergency alarm sire and deficiencies in hazard communications and respiratory protection programs. Phillips Petroleum President Glenn Cox said the company's investigation showed the explosion ``was the result of a departure from established routine procedures. ``We are thoroughly evaluating our procedures and training to determine how the possibility for error can be further minimized,'' Cox said in a statement issued from company headquarters in Bartlesville, Okla. Saulter said Phillips officials already have contacted OSHA about the reconstruction of the plant and possible modifications at the site, but declined to give specifics of the talks. He said Labor Secretary Elizabeth Dole is expected to give President Bush a report in the coming weeks about the accident, what should be done at the new plant and what changes might be needed at other plants across the country. The largest fine ever sought by OSHA was proposed last November, when the government said it was seeking $7.3 million from USX Corp. for 2,000 alleged safety violations at a steel plant near Pittsburgh and another on the Pennsylvania side of the Delaware River near Trenton, N.J. USX has contested the fine.

DOC.HEAD: West German Spy Scandal Widens with New Arrest
DOC.TEXT: Prosecutors said Thursday a senior diplomat was arrested as a spy, the fourth government employee seized this month and accused of providing secrets to East Germany's former Communist rulers. The 54-year-old suspect, indentified only by the initials H.B., spied for East German intelligence since 1961 and is believed to have passed on information while posted at embassies in Cairo, Tokyo, London and Vienna, said spokesman Rolf Hannich of the chief federal prosecutor's office in Karlsruhe. Hannich said the diplomat, whose rank was not revealed, was said to have furnished ``vast amounts of information'' to East Germany before being arrested Wednesday. Hannich said the Constitutional Protection Office, the nation's highest spy-fighting unit, helped uncover the diplomat's activities. West German newspapers said changes in East Germany have helped West Germany's counter-intelligence efforts. News media say West German spy-fighters have been receiving useful tips from former East German agents. A week earlier, Hannich announced the arrests of two other West German government employees suspected of spying for East Germany _ another Foreign Ministry employee and a high-ranking official for the federal border police. On April 5, the federal prosecutor's office announced the arrest of a 45-year-old man working for the West German NATO mission in Brussels. Spiegel magazine identified that suspect as Heinz-Helmuth Werner, a former West German soldier, and said he delivered a bonanza of classified information to the East Germans and the Soviet KGB. In Ankara, the capital of Turkey, the Turkish government on Thursday decided to recall 15 Turkish diplomats from West Germany, following allegations in the West German press they engaged in espionage. Turkey also asked West Germany to remove eight of its diplomats from Turkey.

DOC.HEAD: Developer of Practical Method For Freezing, Thawing Blood Dies
DOC.TEXT: Dr. Charles E. Huggins, who developed a method for freezing and thawing donated blood so it can be stored almost indefinitely, has died of cancer of the pancreas. He was 60. Huggins, who died Wednesday, was director of the Massachusetts General Hospital Blood Transfusion Service and taught at Harvard Medical School. He developed a technique for freezing blood donated to blood banks by adding glycerol, which acts like an organic antifreeze, to red blood cells that have been separated from other blood components. The cells can be thawed years later and the glycerol removed by a sugar compound, the hospital said. In 1963, Huggins developed a Cytoglomerator _ a machine that freezes the red blood cells and removes the glycerol. The machine was widely used until the 1980s, when it was replaced by automated equipment. Dr. J. Robert Buchanan, general director of Massachusetts General, said in a prepared statement that Huggins was ``one of the world's luminaries in blood banking.'' Huggins became director of the hospital's blood transfusion service in 1973. He was also an associate professor of surgery at Harvard Medical School. Born in Chicago, Huggins was the son of Dr. Charles B. Huggins, a Nobel Laureate cancer researcher. He received his bachelor's degree from the University of Chicago in 1947 and graduated from Harvard Medical School in 1952 at age 23. He was trained in surgery at Massachusetts General Hospital and later practiced there as a general surgeon. Huggins is survived by his father, his wife, Gareth W. Huggins, and five children.

DOC.HEAD: Hills Demands Japan Ease Barriers on U.S. Timber Products
DOC.TEXT: U.S. Trade Representative Carla Hills told the Japanese foreign minister on Thursday that Japan must lower trade barriers on U.S. timber products or face possible sanctions. She and Japan's Taro Nakayama discussed U.S.-Japanese trade issues at a breakfast meeting. The two are attending a three-day conference of nations and organizations which belong to GATT, the General Agreement on Tarriffs and Trade. ``There's still a lot to be done between now and April 30,'' the date Hills could call for retaliatory measures, Torie Clarke, a U.S. Trade Office spokeswoman said Hills told Nakayama. U.S. timber representatives estimate their industry could earn up to $3 billion more a year if Japan would revise building codes, reclassify lumber categories and lower taxes. Japan now imports only raw lumber. U.S. exporters want to sell Japan processed products, such as boards. The United States has been trying to untangle a related wood products dispute with Canada for about 10 years. ``A great amount of advancement has been made'' in U.S.-Japanese trade talks, Japanese Foreign Ministry spokesman Makoto Yamanaka told a news conference. ``What's needed at this point is the final touch.'' Another sticking point is Japan's practice of allowing stores to rent foreign recordings without paying royalties to record makers. Nakayama told Hills he hopes to introduce new regulations protecting foreign copyrights, Yamanaka said. Currently, records released in the United States with patents before 1978 can be legally rented in Japan. Arthur Dunkel, director of GATT, told The Associated Press he is happy to see bilateral negotiations between parties to the foreign trade treaty when the negotiations lead to lowering trade barriers such as taxes and permit requirements, the object of the 42-year-old international agreement. Canada, one of 96 signers of GATT, has hinted it would propose forming a world trade organization that would help promote GATT interests. Yamanaka said Japan has not discussed the proposal.

DOC.HEAD: Marla Maples: I Love Donald Trump
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Embargoed for use until 11 p.m. EDT
DOC.TEXT: Model Marla Maples, who was rumored to be the other woman in the split-up of Donald and Ivana Trump, admitted that she loves Trump during a televised interview aired Thursday. ``I do love him,'' Maples answered when asked whether she had a romance with the billionaire real estate developer in an interview with Diane Sawyer on ABC's ``Prime Time Live.'' ``I can't lie about it. Oh, I do,'' she added. The segment was taped Wednesday in a house in Atlantic City, N.J., where Trump recently opened the glitzy Taj Mahal casino. Asked if she talked with Trump about marriage, Maples replied, ``No. He's a friend. ... He has a family and that's No. 1 to him, I know.'' Was she the reason for the Trump split? ``Only the two of them know what really went wrong with their marriage. But I'm not the reason for that marriage having problems,'' she said, adding: ``As Donald has said himself, `People just grow apart.''' Maples would not discuss how she met Trump, nor would she talk about a reputed confrontation she had with Ivana Trump in Aspen, Colo., where the Trumps vacationed last year. Of Ivana Trump, Maples said: ``I feel like she's gone through a lot of pain. I can only imagine what it's like to have your whole world as you knew it sort of shaken and put out there for everyone to see.'' She called Mrs. Trump ``an absolutely beautiful woman.'' Maples said she speaks with Trump ``every once in awhile. He just wants to know how we're doing. I mean, he has a lot of sympathy for how we've been besieged by this.'' She was referring to her family. ``And I think he wants to see me come out looking OK. He's very sorry. I think he sees that I've been a victim in the press that all started from his, his personal life.'' Maples said Trump approved of her doing the interview. ``I made sure of that.'' She added: `` My family has been so besieged by the press, and I feel like it's time that I step out and I take the heat for a bit for what they've had to go through.''

DOC.HEAD: Former Panamanian President's Son Denies Threatening Bush
DOC.TEXT: The son of a former Panamanian president said Thursday that he was joking when he told a pawnbroker he had ``a bullet with Bush's name engraved on it.'' But the Secret Service took Otto Lakas at his word and he was being held without bail on a federal charge of threatening to kill the president. ``I was not serious. Not at all,'' Otto Lakas said in an jailhouse interview. ``I didn't do anything. I am very confused. All I know is that I am in jail.'' Lakas, a 21-year-old architecture student at Lubbock Christian University, was arrested Tuesday after a Secret Service investigation. Police said Lakas had no previous record. According to court documents from the Secret Service, Lakas tried to buy a .357 Colt revolver at the Exect Pawn Shop and told clerk Stacy Nichols, ``I have a .223-caliber rifle at home and a bullet with Bush's name engraved on it. ``Bush is coming to Lubbock and I will blow his ... head off.'' The White House has announced no plans for a Bush visit to Lubbock, although Bush is scheduled to visit Dallas, Houston and Austin in May. Federal agents say Lakas was upset over last December's U.S. invasion of Panama, which resulted in the arrest of Panama's leader, Gen. Manuel Noriega, on drug charges. ``The U.S. got a bad guy but a lot of good people were hurt,'' a Secret Service affidavit quoted Lakas as saying to Nichols, who twice refused to sell him a gun. Lakas' father, Demetrio B. Lakas, was figurehead president of Panama from 1972 to 1978, during the time Panama was ruled by Gen. Omar Torrijos. Noriega was a disciple of Torrijos and gained ascendancy in the military after the popular leader died in a 1981 plane crash. Lakas' brother, Basilio, on Wednesday told the Texas Tech student newspaper, The University Daily, that ``the whole thing is a misunderstanding, and there is no reason to blow it out of proportion.'' In the affidavit for a search warrant, the Secret Service said Lakas tried on April 2 to buy a Colt revolver at the pawnshop but was turned away by Nichols because he did not have a Texas driver's license or a state identification card. On April 4, Lakas went back to the same pawnshop, produced a Texas identification card and told Nichols he wanted to send the weapon to his father in Panama, according to the affidavit. When Nichols told Lakas that he could go to jail for making a threat against Bush, Lakas said, ``they will not mess with me'' because of his family connections in Panama, according to the Secret Service. Nichols told Lakas to think about buying the gun and return later. Lakas did not return, but called Nichols later to say he no longer wanted to buy the gun, court documents said. ``Most pawnbrokers would not have thought twice about taking $850 for the gun, which is what he offered to pay for it,'' Nichols said Thursday. ``But I said no. I was just doing my civic duty.'' Nichols said he waited two weeks to tell federal agents about it because he feared reprisals by Lakas. He notified authorities on Monday. The Secret Service said agents searched Lakas' house Tuesday and found a stun gun and a BB-gun.

DOC.HEAD: Teachers Strike Over After Deadlock Broken on School Financing
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 12 grafs to UPDATE with quotes from Bellmon, education association president, detail on bill, financing, compromise; picks up 10th graf, `Senate Appropriations ...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto KO4
DOC.TEXT: State lawmakers broke a deadlock Thursday on school financing that would raise teachers' salaries, ending a strike that idled classes for more than 300,000 students this week. As striking teachers crowded the halls of the Capitol and thousands more rallied outside, senators approved an emergency clause on a $230 million education reform and tax bill shortly before 6 p.m. The bill was sent to Gov. Henry Bellmon, who said he would sign the bill at an undetermined date. The emergency clause, which allows the bill to become law as soon as it is signed, had been a stumbling block to the package. The Senate failed last week to pass it, prompting the Oklahoma Education Association to call for a five-day teacher walkout. The bill calls for spending $68.1 million to raise minimum teacher salaries by $1,500 a year for four years. The bill would not increase the salaries of teachers above the minimums, but $212 million budgeted for schools could be used for teacher salaries and other items. Oklahoma teachers rank 48th in pay among the states, making an average of $22,000 a year. The national average is $29,648. In Oklahoma, the minimum beginning teacher's salary with a bachelor degree is $15,060. ``A new day is dawning for education in Oklahoma,'' Bellmon said after the vote. ``Oklahoma will no longer take a back seat among the states where education is concerned. From now on, others can look to Oklahoma for leadership in education.'' Union officials said the passage would end the walkout, which was in its fourth day Thursday. It was unclear if regular classes would held Friday. Teachers in districts already closed for the week planned to hold a ``thank you'' rally at the Capitol on Friday, said Nancy Jewell, spokeswoman for the Oklahoma Education Association. Thousands of teachers as well as some administrators, parents and students protested earlier Thursday over the legislative stalemate on a bill that calls for raising the state sales tax and increasing personal and corporate income taxes to pay for the education reforms. A half-cent increase in the 4-cent state sales tax increase would raise $104 million, as would a 10 percent increase in personal income taxes. An increase in the corporate tax from 5 percent to 6 percent would produce $22 million. A compromise that would give tax rebates to low-income families led to the passage of the emergency clause. As the vote on the clause was announced shortly before 6 p.m., a loud cheer broke out in the Senate gallery. The need to resolve the stalemate had taken on an added urgency after Senate President Pro Tempore Bob Cullison, a Democrat, said he might adjourn the special session Thursday, effectively killing the measure. Senate Appropriations Chairman Stratton Taylor, a Democrat, earlier brought cheers from protesting teachers when he told a rally of more than 10,000 that Democratic senators were meeting and might have a solution after a day of closed caucuses. The Oklahoma Education Association, which called for the walkout last week, said 145 school districts in the state were closed Thursday. Among those were Tulsa, Oklahoma City and Lawton, the three largest districts in the state with about 95,000 students. State education officials have said the walkout has affected about 60 percent, or 343,200, of the state's 572,000 students have been affected. The state has 606 school districts. Some schools have remained open throughout the week, while others have been closed the entire time. In some instances, parents and businessmen have made the trek to the Capitol while teachers have stayed in the classroom. The OEA represents 31,000 of the state's estimated 35,000 teachers. The Democratic majority apparently was not involved in any negotiations with Republicans, who voted against the education reform and tax bill earlier, causing the stalemate. Thursday's demonstrators, undaunted by rain and soggy grounds, staged the most boisterous rally of the week. Sen. Taylor touched off a round of chants that echoed through the Capitol area when he proposed a new motto: ``Never Last Again.'' ``I don't believe the people of Oklahoma want to be at the bottom of the heap in salaries _ or educational funding,'' said House Speaker Steve Lewis, who is the principal author of the education package.

DOC.HEAD: Prosecutors Will Not Seek Charges In Drowning Deaths
