DOC.TEXT: No criminal charges will be filed in the February drowning deaths of three teen-agers from a probation camp who fell into an icy lake and four men who tried to rescue them, prosecutors said. Mono County District Attorney Stan Eller said in a memo to the sheriff Tuesday that he felt there was insufficient evidence to prosecute the camp's operator, Camp O'Neal Inc., or any individual. Three juvenile offenders housed at Camp O'Neal fell through thin ice and drowned during an outing to frigid Convict Lake in the Sierra Nevada on Feb. 19. Two counselors and two other adults drowned trying to save them. Although the district attorney's investigation clears the camp operator of criminal wrongdoing, a civil complaint filed by the state Department of Social Services is still pending. The complaint alleges inadequate supervision leading to the drownings, sexual misconduct, overmedicating the juvenile offenders and not properly maintaining medical records. A hearing is scheduled for Aug. 16. The group home, licensed by the state to treat emotionally troubled youths, has been closed since the complaint was filed March 16. Camp O'Neal had been cited before the Convict Lake tragedy for several violations of state licensing standards, according to Department of Social Services spokeswoman Kathleen Norris. The camp's director, Bobbi Trott, has denied any wrongdoing in the drownings or other alleged incidents at the camp.

DOC.HEAD: Report: Lawyer Who Filed Club's Papers Is A Cop
DOC.TEXT: The lawyer who filed incorporation papers for the Bronx social club where 87 people died in a fire is a city police lieutenant who is now himself under investigation, according to a published report. Lt. Primo Flores was moonlighting as a lawyer when he listed the Happy Land club as a not-for-profit corporation in the 1988 papers, The New York Times reported in Thursday editions. Nothing suggests Flores knew the club would sell liquor illegally and operate in violation of city orders that it close because of building violations, the Times said. Police told the Times that the investigation is aimed at determining whether Flores adhered to departmental requirements to disclose his outside business activities and whether he had committed any wrongdoing in his work for the club. Flores' role in setting up the club has been under investigation by the Police Department's Internal Affairs Division since shortly after the March 25 fire, the Times said. The 48-year-old Flores, a policeman since 1967, works in the Police Department's Advocate office, which prosecutes departmental charges against police officers accused of breaking regulations. Flores did not return calls requesting comment, the Times said. A Cuban immigrant, Julio Gonzalez, has been charged with setting the deadly blaze after a dispute with his girlfriend, who worked at the club as a coat checker. The club had been operating in violation of vacate orders issued after city inspectors discovered there was no second exit, no fire alarms and inadequate sprinklers.

A federal bankruptcy judge appointed a trustee to take over Eastern Airlines, delighting striking union members with the knowledge that Frank Lorenzo no longer will pilot the company. ``Justice has finally been served by stopping the most renowned corporate pirate of the past decade,'' said Michael J. Flynn, president of a union local representing about 2,000 striking Machinists in Atlanta. Judge Burton R. Lifland late Wednesday granted the request of Eastern's unsecured creditors, who sought a trustee because of frustration over the carrier's mounting losses and its plans to cut payments to creditors. ``The flying public's interest must at all times be taken into account,'' Lifland told a packed courtroom. ``It's time to change the captain of Eastern's crew.'' The judge appointed as trustee Martin Shugrue, a pilot and airline executive who formerly worked for Lorenzo, chairman of Eastern parent Texas Air Corp.

Soaring health care costs could bankrupt the Medicare trust fund that pays for hospital care before the turn of the century, the fund's board of trustees says. In its annual report to Congress, the board said ``early corrective action is essential in order to avoid the need for later, potentially precipitous changes.'' The hospital insurance trust fund is financed with payroll taxes. While currently more than four covered workers support each beneficiary, that ratio will start slipping early in the next century. By the middle of the next century there will be just two covered workers supporting each beneficiary. ``Not only are the anticipated reserves and financing of the hospital insurance program inadequate to offset this demographic change, the trust fund is projected to become exhausted even before the major demographic shift begins to occur,'' said the report, released Wednesday.

Women who sought to have baby girls have been impregnated with female embryos selected from a test tube, scientists reported today. The results, obtained by way of a new embryo-screening procedure designed to prevent genetic diseases, are the first reported pregnancies using embryos tested to reveal gender, researchers said in the British journal Nature. Two of three pregnant women expect twins this summer, study co-author Alan Handyside said in a telephone interview. The third expects one child, he said. The laboratory test identified the sex of the microscopic embryos only three days after fertilization, he said.

A pornography-fighting Christian group is blanketing Congress with envelopes it says contain ``filthy'' pictures of homosexual acts from a taxpayer-funded art exhibit. Each envelope marked ``extremely offensive material enclosed'' holds explicit photographs and drawings from the ``David Wojnarowicz, Tongues of Flame'' show mounted with a $15,000 federal grant. The American Family Association hopes a good look at reproductions of 14 images displayed at the University Galleries at Illinois State University will convince lawmakers to kill funding for the National Endowment for the Arts. ``We're spending $175 million in this area that benefits primarily the rich and the perverted,'' the Rev. Donald Wildmon, founder and director of the Tupelo, Miss.-based association, said Wednesday.

DOC.NOTE: $Adv25
For Release PMs Wednesday April 25 and Thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Plan for Church TV Channel Meets Strong Opposition
DOC.TEXT: A government plan to give the Roman Catholic Church a television channel has created strong opposition in a nation where the church worked closely with a half-century dictatorship overthrown 16 years ago. Prime Minister Anibal Cavaco Silva's plan would provide the church not just a platform for religious opinions, but a full commercial franchise for one of two private channels that are to end a 26-year state monopoly on television. It has provoked heated debate of the church's place in a society that still retains considerable anti-clerical feeling from the revolution by leftist military officers on April 25, 1974. Conservative businessmen, among the center-right premier's staunchest supporters, have joined the left against the plan. Even the church is not happy. The Catholic Bishop's Conference also wants control of evening programming on one of the two state channels and extended air time on weekends. The debate has split Cavaco Silva's Social Democratic Party, which faces elections next year to preserve its parliamentry majority. ``I think it is immoral to grant a channel without a public tender,'' said Franciso Pinto Balsemao, once a Social Democratic premier and now a media executive. His company is a leading contender for one of the private channels. Leftists and liberals worry about the political impact of church television and recall the Roman Catholic hierarchy's close cooperation with the dictatorial regime founded by Antonio Oliveira Salazar. Salazar granted the church a radio station, Radio Renascenca, in 1936. The station's management is leading the church campaign for a television channel. When Cavaco Silva liberalized radio broadcasting last year, he restricted private stations to local transmission but left Renascenca as Portugal's only national station not under state control. ``Renascenca has very strong political views and they interfere a lot,'' Pinto Balsemao, the former prime minister, told The Associated Press. ``We cannot say it is an independent project.'' Since the 1974 revolution, the church has entered politics in unsuccessful efforts to stop leftist governments from liberalizing divorce laws and legalizing abortion. Church leaders organized a long and emotional campaign against abortion in the early 1980s, with the support of the Social Democrats and conservative parties. A parliamentary majority of Socialists and Communists legalized abortion in 1984. Moises Espirito Santo, a sociologist at Lisbon's New University specializing in religious affairs, said he doubted the church could enlist as much support for the television channel as it had against abortion. ``The church today has more political power than it had under Salazar ... but this lacks the emotion of the abortion issue,'' he said in an interview. More than 96 percent of Portuguese are Roman Catholic, but figures published recently in the newspaper O Jornal indicate only 27 percent attend Mass regularly. Strength of religious feeling varies widely. The report said about 65 percent of people in northern Minho province go to church regularly, but the number dips below 5 percent in the southern Alentejo, the rural stronghold of the Communist Party. Espirito Santo said much of Portugal's popular religious feeling, particularly in the countryside, is based on traditional beliefs and less influenced by teachings of the bishops in the cities. Efforts by clerics to sway votes may have helped thwart communist ambitions immediately after the revolution, but increased political awareness after 16 years of democracy means few people now follow their priest's political guidance, he said. ``The church no longer has any electoral weight,'' Espirito Santo declared. ``Its influence lies in the links the bishops have with politicians.'' Some Catholics wonder whether the church will compromise its moral standards by entering the materialistic world of TV advertising and competition with the racy Brazilian soap operas Portuguese viewers enjoy. ``What sort of commercial television can they have?'' Pinto Balsemao asked. ``What sort of advertising can they accept? Are they going to have `Dallas' and `Dynasty' and the Brazilian telenovelas (soap operas), which are full of sex and beautiful, almost-naked girls?''. Fernando Magalhaes Crespo, director of Radio Renascenca, said moral standards would be maintained. ``It will be a television with programs parents won't be ashamed to watch with their children,'' he told Balsemao's weekly newspaper Expresso. Magalhaes Crespo said `Dallas' and `Falcon Crest', Britain's Benny Hill and many of the Brazilian soaps were not likely to appear on the Catholic channel. Espirito Santo said the argument over telvision is the latest in a long line of disputes dating to the 19th century, when conflicts between clerical and secular political groups sometimes became bloody. Roman Catholicism was the state religion until 1910, when an anticlerical revolution overthrew the monarchy and founded the republic.

DOC.HEAD: Envoy Says Washington Has Gained Support at United Nations
DOC.TEXT: U.S. foreign policy is gaining support at the United Nations and there is less emphasis on linking foreign aid to how a recipient country votes, the American ambassador says. Some Arab envoys, however, expect the Bush administration and Congress to put pressure on recipients of American aid to rescind a General Assembly resolution adopted in 1975 that equates Zionism and racism. Ambassador Thomas R. Pickering, the U.S. permanent representative, told reporters recently the idea of linking U.S. foreign aid to supportive U.N. votes ``never rose to massive proportions, and the fact is that there is less focus now on scorecarding in aid than there was before. ``I don't think at this stage one can say this is completely a dead letter, but I don't see it rising to high prominence. ... I don't believe there is such overwhelming interest in it. ``I think we, in fact, should give assistance where we believe it is in our broad foreign policy interests to do so, all factors considered.'' The ambassador said nothing of the Zionism-racism resolution and Arab statements, made later, that some members of Congress wanted to penalize nations that did not follow the U.S. line. In Decemb is chairman. ``We have a list of who the aid recipients are and how the vote was, and do they understand their aid is in jeopardy?'' Moynihan said. ``I mean, enough is enough. ``The Soviet Union ... no longer rewards that behavior. Have they learned it and do they know that this country is angry about that because they have put peace in jeopardy in a place they had no business bothering in? ``What does it mean to Chile? What does it mean to Sri Lanka? Whose business is it in the Ivory Coast to cause instability in the Middle East?'' Moynihan called the document ``a low point'' in U.N. behavior and an attempt to politicize the General Assembly. Nearly 70 percent of political resolutions received unanimous support in the 44th General Assembly last year, according to the latest voting report. That compares with 64 percent in 1988, 60 percent in 1987 and 58 percent in 1986. It said other U.N. members voted with the United States 23.3 percent of the time on the 16 issues, which ranged from the invasion of Panama to the annual question of accepting Israel's credentials. When all General Assembly votes are examined, the figure declines to 16.9 percent. Some U.N. diplomats say voting the same way does not guarantee an identical point of view. They also suggest that, if more countries are voting with the United States, changes in U.S. policy may be the reason.

DOC.HEAD: An AP Photo Package
Assaulting the Male Tradition at Virginia Military Institute
LaserPhotos NY10-14 of April 18
DOC.TEXT: When dawn breaks over the Alleghany Mountains and shines dimly on Stonewall Jackson Barracks, cadets in gray and black uniforms march to the mess hall in a cadence unchanged by the passing of 150 years. Tradition is the lifeblood of Virginia Military Institute, a small public college defending its male-only admissions policy from a lawsuit by the federal government, what some graduates call the second War of Northern Aggression. The first skirmish in the sex-discrimination lawsuit will be May 4 in U.S. District Court in Roanoke. The U.S. Justice Department claims VMI's admissions policy is a chauvinistic anachronism that is unconstitutional and violates the Civil Rights Act. ``We believe the Justice Department is wrong and we intend to fight,'' said Maj. Gen. John Knapp, VMI superintendent. The vast majority of cadets and alumni believe admitting women to the corps would ruin the school's mission of producing citizen-soldiers. The academic training and the strict honor code would remain, they say, but the camaraderie achieved through living in close quarters and surviving a grueling physical and psychological freshman year would be changed forever. The 1,300 cadets all live in a three-story, fortress-like dormitory. The Spartan rooms have no telephones, posters, television sets, curtains or locks on the doors, and the standardized cots, shelves and desks are made of bare wood. The cadets awake to reveille at 6:55 a.m. and head to communal showers. Women, they say, just wouldn't fit in. ``How could a cadet bust into the room of a lady at any time and order her to do push-ups?'' asked Antonio Zang, a cadet from Fairfax. ``We're taught here to be gentlemen. How can you yell at a lady and still be a gentleman?'' The lawsuit was prompted by a letter from a northern Virginia teen-age girl who complained that she could not attend the school. VMI and The Citadel in Charleston, S.C., are the only state-supported military schools in the nation that refuse to admit women. The Justice Department is investigating The Citadel for a possible sex-discrimination case. Ironically, Virginia's first female attorney general, Mary Sue Terry, is defending VMI in the lawsuit, which also names as defendants Gov. Douglas Wilder, the nation's first black elected governor, and the state system of higher education.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Tues PMs, April 24

DOC.HEAD: Stars Go All-Out To Save the Earth
DOC.TEXT: It is a safe bet that on Sunday you're not going to see a star-studded special called ``Just Say No to Rain Forests.'' This is because Sunday is Earth Day. An army of ecology-minded celebrities will be on TV then, earnestly urging you to save the planet and to fight pollution, global warming and maybe even bad breath. As you may have noticed, though, Earth Day warmups already are under way. Today, for example, the scheduled guests on Geraldo Rivera's syndicated talk show include noted eco-celebs Olivia Newton-John and John Denver. Denver, a spokesman says, will sing his new song, ``Raven's Child,'' described as ``dedicated to saving the Earth.'' Tonight at 11:30 p.m. EDT, CBS has ``Save the Planet: A CBS-Hard Rock Cafe Special,'' in which Katey Sagal, Bobcat Goldthwait and assorted rock stars gather to joke, sing and ponder the environment. An advance tape of that show wasn't available for screening. Neither was one for ABC's two-hour eco-extravaganza, ``The Earth Day Special,'' which features more than 40 stars ranging from Jane Fonda to the Toxic Rappers. However, an ABC spokeswoman describes that show, airing Sunday at 9 p.m. EDT, as an ecological fable. In it, Bette Midler plays an abused Mother Earth who collapses in a town square during an Earth Day celebration. Midler chastizes Robin Williams, cast as an Everyman, for not taking better care of her. Then she's whisked to a hospital, where the staff includes the compassionate Dana Delany of ``China Beach.'' And so it will go, with song, comedy and vignettes all aimed at raising the viewers' consciousness about the environment and showing possible solutions for that which threatens the Earth. Cable TV also has a number of Earth Day-related shows afoot, among them the Discovery Channel's ``Amazonia,'' about the Brazilian rain forest. That airs tonight, when the baby boomer VH-1 channel also starts a series of programs on environmental issues that will continue through Sunday. The Arts & Entertainment Cable Network will have a one-hour Sunday special, ``Challenge of the Seas,'' with host-narrator Ted Danson. The show starts a 26-part weekly documentary series about the ocean. (Danson, of course, is a co-star of ``Cheers.'' It sure would be nice if some day an oceanographer got to host and narrate that show.) As you'd expect, Ted Turner's cable empire, perhaps the only TV giant with a vice president for environmental policy, also is noting Earth Day. It has four environmental specials scheduled Sunday, two of them reruns on his TNT network, and two new shows, a National Geographic special and a Cousteau Society special, to be shown by his TBS Superstation. And his Cable News Network ``World Report'' on Sunday will feature an ambitious two-hour collection of reports on environmental issues in more than 40 countries. The news divisions of ABC, NBC and CBS, which have given extensive coverage to environmental issues this week, will again be rife with Earth Day reports on Sunday, starting with their morning programs. Local stations will be active, too, although not on as large a scale as NBC affiliate KRON-TV in San Francisco. It has put together an Earth Day weekend network of 120 stations to carry two specials. The first is the taped one-hour ``Earth Day 1990: A User's Guide to Saving the Environment,'' hosted by Dennis Weaver. The second, fed live to participating East Coast stations at 11:30 p.m. EDT Sunday, is ``Earth Day Tonight,'' a half-hour wrapup of Earth Day doings around the nation. That show will be anchored by Linda Ellerbee. Unlike some reporters who may be cynics, she takes a benign view toward all those Hollywood ecological stars who'll be all over TV on Sunday. ``I suppose it's easy to make fun of the whole notion of the celebrities who are joining in,'' she says. ``But this is one of those situations where, I guess, as loud a noise as can be made is good. ... ``The best thing that can be said for them is that by making such a loud noise, they're helping create a climate where some things can be done.''

Elsewhere in television ... TOONS FIGHT DRUGS: It'll be hard for kids to miss ``Cartoon All-Stars To the Rescue'' on Saturday morning. The three networks, Fox stations, about 200 independent stations and some cable channels will show the don't-use-drugs show then. More than 20 cartoon characters, from Bugs Bunny to Garfield, are featured. The half-hour broadcast generally will start at 10:30 a.m. EDT.

DOC.HEAD: May 4, 1970: Taunting Students, Panicked Guardsmen, the Rattle of Riflefire
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhotos
DOC.TEXT: ... Soldiers are gunnin' us down, What if you knew her And found her dead on the ground? How can you run when you know? Four dead in Ohio ... _ From ``Ohio,'' Crosby, Stills and Nash, July 1970.

Dean Kahler hugged the grass of the practice football field. Bullets were ricocheting off the blacktop road no more than 40 feet away. ``Oh, my God! They're firing,'' he said to himself. Then a sudden sting, not much more than a pin prick at his back. It was the only pain he felt. He would never walk again. A bullet fired through Jeffrey Miller's mouth and skull slammed him to the ground. As his blood pooled along a concrete curb, a 14-year-old runaway knelt over him in anguish, her arms flung skyward, her face contorted in bewildered terror. A 13-second fusillade by National Guardsmen turned anti-war dissent into disaster on a May Monday 20 years ago at Kent State University. Four students were killed and nine others wounded, stunning a nation already fragmented by five years of a distant conflict. By April 1970, more than 100 young Americans and probably thousands of Vietnamese, north and south, were dying each week in distant jungles and rice paddies. But now the war had claimed victims at home, four kids on a blue-collar campus amid the pancake-flat farmfields of Ohio. (Even so, a Gallup poll taken for Newsweek within days of the shootings indicated that 58 percent of the public blamed the demonstrators and backed the Ohio guardsmen. The mourning parents received hate mail.) Almost three more years would pass before the United States ended its military role in Vietnam, although some families of the dead believe the Kent State killings hastened that end. ``I believe the war in Vietnam was brought to a quicker close because of it,'' said Florence Schroeder of Lorain, Ohio, whose 19-year-old son, William, died that day. ``That is our only reason to have ever filed the lawsuits, to make sure the event gets its proper historical significance.'' The significance of dead students on American soil was powerful. Dissent against U.S. involvement in Vietnam had built slowly since combat troops were sent in March 1965. But by 1970, campuses were in turmoil over the increasingly unpopular war. President Richard Nixon was seen as the villain and he returned the sentiment in kind. The president assailed the more vocal anti-war protesters as ``bums.'' His vice president, Spiro Agnew, suggested in April that universities deal with their protesters like Nazis: ``The next time a mob of students, waving their non-negotiable demands, starts pitching bricks and rocks at the student union _ just imagine they are wearing brown shirts or white sheets and act accordingly.'' Adding to the boiling tension was the fact that every young man's birthday was potentially a ticket to Vietnam. From 1969 to 1973, the military draft was a lottery based on birth dates. ``The black cloud of Vietnam and the draft were hanging over their heads,'' said Kahler, then a 20-year-old freshman and conscientious objector from Canton, Ohio. Thomas Lough was one of many professors who felt they didn't dare give a male student a failing grade. ``That would kill him,'' said Lough, who teaches sociology at Kent State. ``They'd be eligible for selective service if they were flunked out of school. Their lives were on the line.'' On April 30, student dissenters around the country listened in disbelief as Nixon announced on nationwide television the invasion of neutral Cambodia by U.S. troops bent on destroying communist border sanctuaries. Just the previous July, Nixon had begun a phased withdrawal, and tens of thousands of American men were already back home. Now Americans were fighting on a new front. Some students had lost brothers and childhood friends in the war. They didn't want to kill or to be killed. Protests broke out at one-third of the nation's 2,500 colleges. The day after Nixon's speech, perhaps 500 anti-war protesters rallied peacefully at noon on the Kent State commons, then planned to gather again Monday. But that night, the first warm evening of the year, a small crowd of students and townies spilled from a string of bars in downtown Kent. Early festiveness turned to angry shouts and anti-war slogans. A passing police cruiser dodged beer bottles. The crowd, by midnight swollen to 500 people, lit a bonfire in the street and began smashing shop windows. The mayor declared a civil emergency, imposed a curfew, closed the bars and summoned the National Guard. Thrown rocks slightly injured four or five officers. Police forced the students back onto campus with tear gas. The violence continued. On Saturday night, the campus ROTC building was burned down. Demonstrators threw rocks at firefighters and slashed their hoses. The arsonists were never identified or arrested. The National Guard arrived in the midst of the chaos. One convoy was stoned as it approached the campus. The guardsmen were already weary, pulled away from patrolling interstate highways during a truckers' strike. When they were called out again to patrol Monday morning, ``nobody had any sleep to amount to anything,'' recalled Sgt. Leon Smith of Beach City, Ohio. That same morning, Alan Canfora, a 21-year-old junior from Barberton, Ohio, left for the noon rally carrying a black flag, his banner of mourning for yet another Vietnam casualty. Even before the Cambodia invasion, more Americans were dying every day. The toll was grim: 335 killed in January, 385 in February, 442 in March. One of the April victims was Canfora's childhood friend. Canfora, upset at his friend's death and by the presence of the guardsmen on campus, joined 200 to 300 student protesters gathered at the commons. As other students left class for lunch, the crowd grew to as many as 2,000, many of them on the hill behind the main knot of demonstrators. Many of the dissenters talked angrily about the guardsmen, the curfew and the university's ban on rallies, announced the day before. They considered the last an attack on their rights to free speech and assembly. ``I felt so strongly against the war,'' Canfora said in an interview. ``I was willing to risk my own life and face those rifles. I chose the black flag because of the sad state of affairs on our campus and in our country.'' To enforce the ban on rallies, guardsmen drove past in a jeep, ordering students through a bullhorn to leave the commons. ``Pigs off campus!'' the students shouted. ``Sieg Heil!'' they chanted, mocking the Nazi salute. Students hurled stones at the jeep, and guardsmen retaliated with a burst of tear gas canisters. The students tossed them back. Within moments, however, the nearly 100 guardsmen had fixed their bayonets and loaded their weapons, mostly M-1 rifles. They advanced on the students, scattering them in retreat over the hill and down the other side onto the football field and parking lot.
DOC.NOTE: MORE
$Adv23
For Release Monday cycles, April 23, and Thereafter
DOC.HEAD: KENT: parking lot.
DOC.TEXT: As the students retreated, Allison Krause, a freshman honors student from Pittsburgh who had just turned 19, turned to her boyfriend and sobbed, ``Why are they doing this to us? Why don't they let us be?'' She cursed the soldiers and threw rocks. The guardsmen regrouped on the practice field, knelt and aimed their rifles at students in the parking lot. But other students had regrouped behind them. Realizing they were outflanked, the guardsmen rose and marched back up the hill to resume their original position on the commons. They were under bombardment from stones and obscenities, but the nearest students were at least 60 feet away. As the guardsmen neared the top of the hill, they suddenly turned, rifles at their shoulders. The gunfire stunned the students. Many began running. Others dropped to the ground. Some, thinking the guardsmen were firing blanks, stood their ground _ until they heard the bullets hitting around them. Joseph Lewis Jr., an 18-year-old freshman from Massillon, Ohio, and probably closest to the guardsmen, was shot as he made an obscene gesture. A guardsman later said he believed Lewis was advancing on him. Lewis was hit just below the waist and slammed to the ground. ``I felt like being hit in the stomach with a shovel,'' he said. ``I thought I was dying. I prayed.'' Another bullet hit his left leg. Canfora, about 75 yards away, was shot in the right wrist. ``I got behind a tree. That's what saved my life,'' he said. ``I'm convinced they were shooting at me intentionally. I could hear bullets hitting the tree. I could hear bullets zipping and cracking through the air and through the grass on both sides of the tree.'' Sixty-one shots were fired from at least 28 weapons. Allison Krause fell mortally wounded 100 yards away from the guardsmen, a bullet through her chest. The body of 20-year-old Jeff Miller of Plainview, N.Y., dropped 90 yards from the rifles. The FBI said Krause and Miller were initially at the front of the crowd taunting the guardsmen. Miller made some offensive gestures and Miss Krause shouted obscenities, the report said, but ``neither was in a position to pose even a remote danger to the National Guard at the time of the firing.'' Sandy Scheuer, 20, of Boardman, Ohio, and Schroeder were walking to class. Each was about 130 yards from the guardsmen. Schroeder was shot in the back after diving to the ground. Scheuer was shot through the neck. ``I was scared,'' said Sgt. Smith, who fired one shot into the air. ``I felt my life was in danger. I had a fellow coming at me with what looked like a brick in his hand. I had no intention of hurting anybody or killing anybody.'' What prompted the shootings remains a mystery. The FBI said it could only speculate. One theory is that a guardsman either fired in panic or shot intentionally at a student, and the other guardsmen fired at the sound of the first shot. The President's Commission on Campus Unrest said that although the actions of some students were violent, criminal, dangerous, reckless and irresponsible, ``the indiscriminate firing of rifles into a crowd of students and the deaths that followed were unnecessary, unwarranted and inexcusable.'' A Portage County special grand jury found that the guardsmen acted in self-defense and exonerated them of criminal charges. It indicted 25 students and faculty members including Canfora, Lewis and Lough, the professor. Those charges were dropped in December 1971. In March 1974, a federal grand jury in Cleveland indicted eight guardsmen on charges of violating the civil rights of the dead and wounded students. Midway through the trial, a judge dropped all charges for lack of evidence. The wounded students and the families of the dead settled a $40 million civil suit out of court in January 1979 for $675,000. But more important to them, they said, was a signed acknowledgment by the defendants, Gov. James A. Rhodes and 27 guardsmen, that the shootings should not have occurred and that the confrontation could have been resolved in other ways. After years of debate over an appropriate memorial, a granite plaza with four prominent upright slabs is being dedicated May 4 on a 2{-acre site adjacent to the parking lot where the students were killed. A bouquet of 58,175 gold daffodils already blooms around the memorial, one for each American man and woman killed in Vietnam. For Florence Schroeder, the daffodils are a living memorial more valuable than quarried granite. Her son, she explains, used to pick her wild flowers when he was a schoolboy. She says she will plant one more daffodil at the memorial. For him.

DOC.TEXT: Special Correspondent George Esper, the AP Northeast regional reporter, was AP bureau chief in Saigon from 1973 to April 1975 and roving correspondent in Ohio from September 1975 to November 1976.

DOC.HEAD: Generation Later, Witness to Kent State Shootings Returns
With BC-Kent State Anniversary
LaserPhoto CD3 of of April 17
DOC.TEXT: June Romeo is back at Kent State, a generation after witnessing National Guard bullets kill four students and wound nine more. The tears still come easily. ``It's funny,'' the 38-year-old nursing instructor and graduate student said. ``They said 13 seconds (of gunfire). When you stop to think: one, two, three, four ... If you count, that's a long time.'' Romeo, then an 18-year-old freshman from Westlake, Ohio, was about 20 steps from one of the wounded, Tom Grace. ``You don't believe it at first,'' she said. ``No one had ever shot a student protester before.'' The violence and its emotion-charged aftermath became too much for Romeo. She left campus the next year, upset by such scenes as a cafeteria confrontation between students joking about the shootings and others who were irate. ``It was not the right place for me,'' said Romeo, who tried selling insurance then enrolled at Baldwin-Wallace College, a small liberal arts school in Berea, near her hometown. ``I kept thinking, `I should go back,' but I never did,'' said Romeo, who keeps a candle from the first campus anniversary memorial May 4, 1971. Twenty years later, she has come back, as a graduate student and instructor in educational theory. ``The tragedy was very personal,'' said Romeo, whose undergraduate students occasionally note her resemblance to the young woman whose searing photographic image, arms raised high over a dying Kent State student, won a Pulitzer Prize. Romeo said she pushed the shootings out of her mind, along with other campus memories. She lost track of classmates and roommates. She collected _ but never read _ almost every book about the shootings and student unrest in 1970. ``I wanted things connected with it,'' she said of the books. Her husband has read the books, but the two don't talk about ``May 4.'' Romeo says the only person with whom she discussed Kent State in detail was a physician and former Navy officer who convinced her that the guardsmen would never have fired without a command. ``That more than anything else has bothered me. ... I can't conceive of a mind that would give an order like that,'' she said, pausing to catch her breath at the thought. Romeo's emotions were rekindled four years ago when James Rhodes, who as Ohio governor had ordered the National Guard onto the Kent State campus to restore order, was a patient at the Cleveland Clinic, where Romeo was a nurse. The soft-spoken Romeo said her loathing for Rhodes and his role in what happened was so strong that she took a day or two off while Rhodes was hospitalized. ``I kept thinking, `I want so much for him to feel some of the terror those people felt,''' she said. ``That really brought it back. I never had feelings like that about anyone. I really can't think of people I hate.'' Romeo returned to Kent State full-time last year. She credits her social activism for her return to campus and her efforts to deal with memories of the shootings. She runs a program in Cleveland's inner city that teaches youngsters to read and write as well as how to make reasoned decisions that will affect their lives. ``I need to help people become aware,'' she said. ``Aware of choices and consequences.'' Romeo believes that few among the couple thousand Kent State students protesting the war on May 4, 1970 were aware of the potential consequences. She teaches her students that ``you're going to have to decide for yourselves what battles are important to fight and what aren't worth your time and effort.'' When her students learn she was a student of the '70s, they are curious about the period. She tells them she favored ``weird clothes'' and wore her hair long and flowing. ``I even wore flowers in my hair,'' she tells them. ``They said, `Noooo.''' Romeo brushes aside the current campus brouhaha over whether the granite memorial to be dedicated on the 20th anniversary of the shootings is too little, too late. ``I don't care that much about the memorial,'' she said. ``I think the most fitting thing is to keep the whole thing alive. People 20 years down the line should really be questioning it. It should be studied _ like we study wars.''

For Release Monday Cycles, April 23, and Thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Survivors Recall Terror of U.S. Air Attacks
With BC-Kent State Anniversary
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhotos
DOC.TEXT: Twenty years later, the survivors, mostly poor peasants, still remember the terror of the American warplanes and the many who could not evade their fury. Hok Nhem says the planes killed four of her 10 children and destroyed her fine concrete house. Two youngsters died at play in a village street. Two older children were felled by strafing jets in the rice paddies. ``To this very day I don't know why the Americans bombed our village,'' said Choi Sandal. She recalls the afternoon when six jets swooped down and she sprinted home from the fields to try to save her grandparents but was held back by flames shooting as high as the coconut trees. For five years, in a brutal aerial bombardment kept secret from the American public, U.S. planes, often B-52 bombers, savaged the countryside around this remote town and other border areas of eastern Cambodia. In the spring of 1970, American soldiers came on foot. President Richard Nixon ordered the invasion to finally destroy border sanctuaries used by Vietnamese communists. ``To protect our men who are in Vietnam and to guarantee the continued success of our withdrawal and Vietnamization program, I have concluded that the time has come for action,'' Nixon announced on television April 30, 1970. A day earlier, American and South Vietnamese troops had begun Operation Total Victory. The invasion prompted anti-war demonstrations across the United States; at Kent State University in Ohio, four students were shot dead by National Guardsmen. In Cambodia, some historians say, the invasion was the catalyst for a chain reaction of national tragedies. Villagers here don't make such subtle linkages; they do say that since that time they have known only suffering. ``The pattern of Vietnam is being repeated,'' said an Associated Press dispatch from the front. ``The American troops are putting the torch to homes because they may be useful to the communists. Livestock is shot for the same reason.'' Some of the worst damage was inflicted on Snuol and Mimot. Described by the Americans as an enemy hub, Snuol was all but razed. When troops entered the once picturesque town they found the charred bodies of one girl, one woman and two men. Mimot was partly destroyed by air strikes after North Vietnamese in the town fired on U.S. helicopters. ``It is pretty well blown away,'' reported one American officer. Today, ox carts roll down the town's red dirt main street, past buildings still scarred by shrapnel. Long strips of two-story shop-houses were rebuilt only in the last several years, said Deputy District Chief Rin Saman. Rin Saman, who was in Mimot during the invasion, said the bombed sugar factory where he worked remains inoperative and much of the vast rubber plantation on the edge of town still lies in ruins. Only traces remain of what was a hospital for plantation workers. By the end of June 1970, the invasion force of 63,000, including 23,000 Americans, had returned to South Vietnam. According to the U.S. command, 339 Americans, 799 South Vietnamese and more than 11,000 communist soldiers were killed and vast amounts of communist supplies destroyed in the operation. But Cambodia would never heal. The invasion had created a new battle front, dragged all of Cambodia into the Indochinese conflict, and started years of national agony. The capital city of Phnom Penh, as well as the U.S.-backed government of Lon Nol, fell to the Khmer Rouge guerrillas April 17, 1975, two weeks before the fall of Saigon. What followed was the ghastly ultra-revolution of the victors. Mimot's inhabitants were driven into rural communes or forced into slave labor on the rubber plantation. Press Samoeur, deputy governor of Kompong Cham province, which surrounds Mimot, estimates 360,000 inhabitants of the province perished under the 1975-78 rule of Khmer Rouge leader Pol Pot. Some say craters from the B-52 bombings were used for mass graves. Nationwide estimates of deaths by execution, starvation and disease in the ``killing fields'' of Pol Pot range as high as 3 million, in a country that had 7.3 million inhabitants in 1975. ``It was harder to survive under Pol Pot than under American bombs,'' said Rin Saman. In 1978, the area was invaded again, this time by the Vietnamese who punched across the border on Christmas Day to oust the Khmer Rouge. Today the Khmer Rouge are one-third of an anti-government coalition supported by the United States. ``U.S. aggressors bombed schools, roads, bridges, hospitals, markets. They razed people's homes. They sprayed chemicals on the rubber plantations,'' Press Samoeur said in an interview. ``And until this day the U.S. government still has a distorted view of what is happening in Cambodia.'' Choi Sandal, now 38, is still haunted by the sight of her grandparents' charred remains in the still-smoldering village, where only one of 60 houses survived the aerial attack. The aging widow Hok Nhem posed for a photo before a house built on the ruins of the concrete one. Only one pillar remains of the old, atop which she has placed an aviary for doves. Other survivors joined them, talking openly with this reporter, the first American most had met in 20 years. A toothless old man was overheard suggesting the reporter might be there to assess damage for future U.S. reparations. But nobody openly mentioned this nor exhibited the slightest hostility. Instead, they clasped their hands together in the traditional prayer-like gesture of farewell _ and offered a glass of sweet coconut milk.

DOC.HEAD: Kent State Mementos: ``Flowers Are Better Than Bullets''
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Every spring, just as surely as the daffodils, sad memories bloom again. In the spring of 1970, in his last letter home from college, William Schroeder altered a few lines from a popular Neil Young song, ``I Am a Child,'' to tell his mother he loved her and savored weekends spent at home. ``I am a child, I last awhile, ``You can't perceive all the pleasure in my smile. ``You make the rules, you say what's fair, ``It's lots of fun to have you there ... '' Twenty springs have come and gone since May 4, 1970, when William Schroeder and three other students were gunned down by National Guardsmen at anti-war demonstrations on the Kent State University campus. But the annual arrival of spring cannot erase the pain felt for missing sons and daughters, for friends lost forever, for graduations unattended and anniversaries uncelebrated. ``Even after 20 years it still hurts,'' said Florence Schroeder, who lives in Lorain. ``They took him away, but they can't wipe out the memory.'' Schroeder's mother can still recite, her voice breaking, the words from the Neil Young song. But sometimes the memories are too painful for her and her husband, Louis. ``At the end of the trials,'' she said, ``we promised ourselves we'd never go that far down deep into our souls again. It hurts too much.'' Schroeder, 19, was shot in the back while lying on the ground. He took cover when the gunfire began as he walked to class after a meeting with his ROTC adviser. He was concerned that the military program paying his scholarship might be discontinued because demonstrators had burned down the ROTC building two days earlier. The Vietnam war tormented Schroeder, his mother said, because he knew he would end up there. ``Flowers and Bullets'' is the name of an album of remembrances put together for Allison Krause's parents by her college boyfriend. On her tombstone is the epitaph, ``Flowers are better than bullets, May 3, 1970.'' May 3, a Sunday, provided a sunny, peaceful respite from campus rumblings. As Allison, a freshman honors student from Pittsburgh who had just turned 19, and her boyfriend strolled the campus, they encountered a soldier with a lilac in his gun barrel. When his commanding officer ridiculed him and pulled the lilac from the rifle, Allison grabbed it before he could toss it down. As the officer walked away, Allison yelled after him. ``What's the matter with peace? Flowers are better than bullets.'' Her father, Arthur Krause, spent a decade seeking the justice he and the other ``Kent Families,'' as they came to call themselves, felt was due them. In the final court settlement of a $40 million civil suit in January 1979, the four families and nine wounded students received $675,000 to be divided among them. But more important to them, they said, was a signed statement of regret and acknowledgment from Ohio Gov. James A. Rhodes and 27 guardsmen that the shootings should not have occurred. Arthur Krause died of cancer in 1988. His widow, Doris, feels only rancor toward Kent State. She says she will never return under any official invitation, not even for dedication of a memorial that will mark the 20th anniversary of her daughter's slaying. ``I'll be bitter to the day I die,'' Mrs. Krause said. She recalls with anger how she learned of Allison's death only by calling the hospital after a reporter told her Allison had been wounded. ``Would you not expect to hear something from that university?'' she asked. ``Would you not expect to see an official at the hospital where you went to see your dead child to extend a hand, to tell you what happened? ``They've never done that. Their letter of sympathy was a check, a refund made out to Allison for spring tuition. She wasn't around to cash it.'' Jeff Miller left behind an anti-war poem he wrote when he was 16. `` ... A teen-ager from a small Ohio farm clutches his side in pain, ``and as he feels his life ebbing away, he too asks why _ ``why is he dying here, thousands of miles from home ... `` ... The War Without a Purpose marches on relentlessly, ``not stopping to mourn for its dead, ``content to wait for its end. ``But all the frightened parents who still have their sons ``fear that the end is not in sight.'' Four years later, he lay dying in a pool of blood, a bullet through his skull. It was his body that a 14-year-old runaway, Mary Ann Vecchio, knelt over in the famous photograph, her arms outstretched in anguish, her face filled with terror. His mother, Elaine Holstein of New York City, is still shaken by his poem. ``It's always struck me as strange and ironic that he refers to a teen-ager from a small Ohio farm,'' she said, ``never knowing that he himself would die four years later in a small Ohio farm town.'' Among the mementos Sarah and Martin Scheuer of Boardman, Ohio, have kept for 20 years is an anniversary card from their younger daughter, 20-year-old Sandra. Her note had urged them to dine at a Chinese restaurant and enjoy their 27th wedding anniversary that May 4: ``Honorable wish for happy anniversary to honorable couple who still have big yen for each other.'' But celebration turned to mourning. The card arrived the same day Sandy lay dead in a parking lot, felled by a bullet through her neck as she walked to a speech therapy class. ``How would you like to identify your child in a morgue?'' Mrs. Scheuer asked 20 years later.

DOC.HEAD: LORAIN: years later.
DOC.TEXT: Dean Kahler has only to look down to remember that day. A rifle bullet made him a paraplegic and put him in a wheelchair for life. ``I know why I'm sitting in it,'' Kahler said. ``I'll never really forget Kent State.'' Kahler, then a 20-year-old freshman from Canton, Ohio, had worked nearly a year in a steel mill to help pay for school. When rifle fire crackled over the shouts of his fellow students, he fell to the ground to take cover. He felt a sensation like a bee sting; it was a bullet ripping into his spinal cord. Kahler, a conscientious objector, was the most seriously injured of the nine persons wounded. He finished school seven years later then built a career in state government, working for the secretary of state and attorney general. He was elected an Athens County commissioner in 1984 and re-elected four years later. Kahler, divorced in 1984, married a counselor he met in a pub last August. He frequently drives the 340-mile round trip to Kent State for sports and alumni events. He is a guest lecturer for a regularly offered course that examines the Kent State shootings and their aftermath. ``Kent State is not something I carry around as a burden,'' he said. ``Just because I had one bad day at Kent doesn't mean the whole university should be condemned. ... To me what's more important is the county budget ... and my family and the rest of my life.'' But for Sarah and Martin Scheuer, much of their life died in a 13-second volley of gunfire. ``It ruined our lives,'' said Scheuer, now 79 and suffering from Parkinson's disease. As the seasons come and go, so do May 4 wedding anniversaries _ unmarked, uncelebrated. Nor can Mrs. Scheuer bear the fragrance of springtime lilacs. ``I'd like to bring them all inside. I love them all so much,'' Sandy told her mother when Mrs. Scheuer visited her apartment two days before she died. Those were the last words her mother ever heard her speak. ``I try not to look at them,'' said Mrs. Scheuer. ``It just makes me feel sad.''

DOC.HEAD: Investigation of Jesuit Killings Proceeds; Others Do Not
DOC.TEXT: President Alfredo Cristiani's government has brought charges against soldiers in the massacre of six Jesuit priests, but investigations of other alleged military atrocities seem to go nowhere. ``Unless the killings cause an uproar abroad, nothing gets done,'' said a judge who, for a time, was dealing with the case of seven young men slain Nov. 18. A witness said they were lined up against a wall and shot by soldiers. No witness or complainant came forward by the end of November and the judge referred the case to the next higher justice. ``Coming forward to testify would be a real risk,'' the judge said. ``The case will be `under investigation' until it is forgotten.'' The young men were killed in the poor Cuscatancingo neighborhood of San Salvador two days after troopers of the elite, U.S.-trained Atlacatl battalion massacred six Jesuit priests who taught at Central American University, their housekeeper and her daughter. Those killings shocked the world. The United States, which gives El Salvador more than $1 million a day in aid, put pressure on the Cristiani administration to identify and punish the people responsible. A colonel and three lieutenants have been charged, but critics say others were involved. Such charges are an exception in a country where members of the armed forces or military-backed death squads are believed to have murdered thousands of people they suspect of being leftists. Despite a wealth of evidence, no officer has been convicted of a crime involving politically motivated abuse of human rights in El Salvador. No officer had even been charged until March 1989, when a major was indicted for killings. He has not been tried. The attention given the Jesuit case is exceptional. The treatment of the Cuscatancingo case has become the norm in a decade of civil war. ``As long as our military men do not understand the meaning of the administration of justice and that they, too, are subject to (it), we will have no justice and no improvement in respect for human rights,'' said Maria Julia Hernandez, director of the Roman Catholic Church legal aid office. The Cuscatancingo killings were barely noticed during an offensive by leftist guerrillas that convulsed San Salvador and three other cities for two weeks. Attorney General Mauricio Colorado, who has dealt with dozens of foreign officials checking on the Jesuit investigation, said he had not even heard of the case. ``There were a hundred cases like that,'' of bodies found in the street, Colorado said when told of it. He suggested the victims were guerrillas or were killed in a cross fire. The seven bodies were found sprawled at the foot of a bloodstained wall, the only wall on the street pocked by bullets. Two victims still clutched social security cards in their hands in what the witness described as an effort to identify themselves as workmen. Colorado acknowledged that U.S. pressure has spurred some investigations, and said: ``Justice should work for everybody, not just for the Americans.'' In Cuscatancingo, two young men said they fled the scene as soldiers ordered the others into the street. One spoke to The Associated Press on condition of anonymity. He expressed fear that soldiers would kill him if he accused them openly. He and the others were sitting along a sidewalk Nov. 18 when an army patrol spotted them and ordered them into the main road, the young man said. Most of them reached for identity cards and obeyed the order, but the young man said he told his brother and a friend, all out of sight at the end of the line, that the three should run. His brother said he had nothing to worry about and went with the group, the young man said, but he and the friend ran up a side street. Five minutes later, they heard a volley of shots followed by single shots, ``coups de grace,'' and his brother and the others were dead, he told the AP. Family members reported the killings to a justice of the peace, who inspected the scene. The judge who first dealt with the case said only a formal complaint from the young man could activate an investigation, and ``I can only offer him security up to a certain point.'' He also said coming forward probably would not make much difference. ``We judges supposedly are the authority, and the police supposedly are the auxiliary organs, but the reality is very different,'' he said, on condition of anonymity. ``I would have to depend on the police, which are part of the armed forces, to investigate the armed forces. You see where that puts us.'' Proceso, the weekly publication of Central American University, published an article in February on the Cuscatancingo slayings. ``Three months after the two massacres, those materially responsible for the murder of the Jesuits have been arrested and charged,'' it said. ``The murderers of the seven young men in Cuscatancingo, on the other hand, remain unpunished. ``The contrast between the two cases is a example of how little the country's judicial system has been consolidated, notwithstanding the trumpeted advances the government has proclaimed with regard to the Jesuit case.''

DOC.HEAD: A Kinder, Gentler Commune After Guru's Death
DOC.TEXT: Buffeted by the recent death of its god and a drop in donations, the commune of the late free-love guru Osho Rajneesh is trying to save itself by going mainstream. Emphasis has shifted from mystical sex to meditation exercises. Primal screaming was banned after neighbors complained of the noise. Deals have been signed with prominent companies for distribution of video cassettes. ``We are mellowing,'' said Swami Tatahgat, an Indian board member of Rajneesh Foundation, the trust that controls the commune. ``Before, we used to wear our rebelliousness on our sleeves.'' It appears to be a kinder, gentler commune at Poona, a far cry from the days in Rajneeshpuram, Ore., when commune members poisoned each other for being ``negative.'' In those days, Rajneesh called himself Bhagwan, or God. No longer do disciples prance half-naked through the halls of the local five-star hotel, the Blue Diamond. The hotel recently welcomed them back, but only for meals. The lush 11-acre campus, with its miniature waterfalls, outdoor Japanese restaurant and high-tech workout rooms, seems more like a summer camp for adults than a focus for worldwide revolution in consciousness. All visitors are required to produce the results of an AIDS test no more than a month old. Westerners seen groping at one another's bodies on Poona's streets may get a talking to by other followers. Osho mediatation is taught at the Tata Management School, a Poona business college. The commune has a contract with CBS@India to distribute videotapes of Rajneesh's lectures, and another with Pocket Books to publish his writings.

Day breaks at the Osho International Commune. Disciples gather for a meditation session in Lao Tzu Hall, where the guru's ashes are housed in a small vault kept on his marble bed. Pattering into the house, they pass through a marble room furnished only with a plush dental chair. ``This is where Osho had his teeth fixed,'' Swami Subhuti, a commune spokesman, intones reverently. He used to be Peter Waight, a newspaper reporter in London. Inside the mausoleum, once Rajneesh's bedroom, disciples move close to the vault containing his ashes. ``Never born, never died,'' reads the epitaph on black marble. A stocky guard flicks a remote-control switch. Lights in an ornate glass chandelier dim. A chime rings and meditating begins.

Osho Rajneesh, the mesmerizing guru of quick-fix enlightenment, died Jan. 19. At the height of his popularity, the 58-year-old former teacher of Sanskrit amassed 500,000 followers, 87 Rolls Royces, diamond-studded watches and gowns fashioned from gold thread. Rajneesh started his movement in India in the late 1960s, preaching a blend of Eastern mysticism, free love and pop psychology. Among his 650 works are such titles as ``Take It Easy'' (Vols. I and II) and ``Ya-Hoo.'' He changed his name numerous times, adopting Bhagwan, Zorba the Buddha and finally, Osho, ``the one the heavens shower with flowers.'' In the early 1980s, Rajneesh moved his band of red-robed followers to a 64,229-acre ranch in the hills of central Oregon. Rancho Rajneesh disbanded after the master was kicked out of the United States in 1985 for immigration fraud, and the American movement degenerated into a miasma of poisonings and costly court cases. Ma Anand Sheela, Rajneesh's former chief aide, was sentenced to 4{ years in prison for arson, attempted murder and masterminding a food-poisoning outbreak that made 750 people sick. Other aides avoided prosecution by cooperating with police. Rajneesh advocated breaking with all social conventions through meditation, as he defined it. Through meditation, he said, his followers could destroy the family, the church and the state, structures he said were destroying humanity. He developed or synthesized several techniques, including one in which followers jump up and down, yelling ``Hoo, hoo, hoo!'' Unlike gurus who demanded that disciples reject worldly goods, Rajneesh encouraged his followers to revel in sensual pleasures, including sex, drugs and good food. ``Only by this way will you ever rise above them,'' he said in one of his famous discourses, which he peppered with bathroom humor and intriguing riddles. Those who succeeded in meditation, the guru said, would attain ``Buddhahood,'' or enlightenment; they would be able to live in the world unaffected by its changes. ``What Osho taught is that the next jump for humanity is not changing the shape of your nose or face, but changing the shape of your inner space,'' said Swami Amrito, a British doctor who was with Rajneesh when he died. Rajneesh returned to India in 1986 and problems followed the movement home. After his death, the Indian press speculated that Rajneesh was murdered or died of AIDS. His followers denied the claims and accused the United States of poisoning their god while he was in jail. Indian newspapers claimed Westerners were trying to seize control of the movement. The commune also rejected that claim. A mysterious team of 21 people, called the ``Inner Circle,'' runs the commune. An American, Swami Jayesh, and the British doctor, Swami Amrito, are believed to be in charge. Negative publicity has hurt donations, which routinely reached millions of dollars a year. Swami Tatahgat, the Indian board member, said the commune did not plan to expand its campus because ``we don't have the funds.'' Last year, the commune lost a court case and was forced to pay the Indian government $2 million in back taxes.

``Be there or be square,'' says a Californian with pigs riding surfboards on his shorts. The meeting of the White Robed Brotherhood is the centerpiece of meditation at the commune. Every evening, hundreds of followers don cotton robes and gather in the Gautama the Buddha Auditorium. Disciples pass a metal detector, then a duo of sniffing women whose job it is to detect those who are wearing perfume or haven't bathed. ``Osho doesn't like weird smells,'' says one olfactory guard. Like other followers, she speaks of Rajneesh in the present tense. His empty chair sits on a marble stage between two air conditioners set at 52 degrees Fahrenheit, his preferred temperature. A screen drops and a video of the master is shown. As the discourse ends, a young Frenchwoman whispers: ``He is still with us.''

DOC.HEAD: Doctors Take the Road Less Traveled By
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Fame came early for Drs. James Cimino and Michael Brescia. But they ditched life in the limelight for the quieter rewards of treating patients dying of cancer. They insist, repeatedly, that they're no heroes. ``We aren't saintly,'' said Cimino. ``Whatever people do, they do with the motivation of self-gratification.'' They praise co-workers at Calvary Hospital in the Bronx and speak with awe of the nuns who founded the hospital. ``We took a road,'' says Brescia. ``To the left, it looked shiny and gold. But to the right, it looked happier to us.'' They came to the crossroads 25 years ago, when as internists at the Veterans Administration hospital in the Bronx, they developed a procedure now widely used in kidney dialysis. Medical journals touted their achievement. Research opportunities rolled in. They were invited to speak at conventions. They were offered an entire Westchester County hospital, for a token $1, if they would turn it into a kidney center. Instead, they chose the day-to-day rewards at Calvary, the nation's only acute care hospital devoted exclusively to advanced cancer patients. ``We didn't go home if someone was suffering,'' said Brescia. ``We learned to live with tiny victories: The patient was able to eat today, or go to church, or sit in a chair, or play with her children. We're mature enough to accept that.'' Without that attitude, he conceded, a patient could ``put tremendous anxiety in you by looking at you and expecting what cannot be done: those pleading eyes, looking at you, telling you that you've failed.'' In 1961, Cimino, director of renal services at the VA hospital, began spending a few hours a week as an adviser at Calvary. Then Brescia, one of his residents, joined him. Gradually, it became their life's work. ``We felt this was a mission,'' said Brescia, who, like Cimino, is a father of six. ``We saw unbearable suffering of patients and families that we, as physicians, could relieve.'' ``It was an adventure,'' said Brescia. ``But I wasn't unhappy taking it. To me, it looked good and right.'' Cimino became medical director and Brescia his assistant. Under their leadership, Calvary won accreditation. The two capitalized on their fame to lure other doctors to Calvary. In 1980, they dropped their titles to become assistants to the medical director and senior attending physicians; mostly, they were ``just doctors,'' and the patients think that's just fine. ``I came from another hospital,'' said Vivian Dowling. ``This is heaven in comparison _ and I'm not just saying that because the doctor is here.'' ``I love Vivian; she's brave and courageous,'' said Brescia. ``When you work with patients like this, the things you thought were important _ you get home and somebody went through the garage door _ don't mean anything.'' Calvary, unlike a hospice, is a full-fledged hospital. It uses medical treatments to slow the spread of cancer, fight other ailments brought on by the disease, and alleviate pain. But the emphasis is on comfort, rather than cures. Miss Dowling, for instance, ``came here in terrible pain: not from the cancer, but from a hole in her back,'' said Brescia, 57. ``I cured the hole. Now, she's a whole person.'' Cimino and Brescia maintain that, even in an era of hospices and patient rights, the terminally ill often are shunted to the back wards of big hospitals and ignored by busy doctors. ``Some oncologists are not able to work here. They want to see the patients get well,'' said Cimino, 60. ``A place like this could be very defeating for persons with that attitude. That's why so many of these kind of places are led by religious groups.'' ``One of the worst things in this stage of life is to feel that you're not worthy of the attention of a professional,'' Cimino added. It's not uncommon for doctors at Calvary to telephone a patient on a holiday. New patients are presented with a rose. There is a free beauty parlor and barber. ``Even the security guards are told to be gentle. Everything is done with human dignity,'' said Brescia. ``It's equally important for the doctors to comfort the families,'' he said. ``The families have been through hell: They're devastated. Sometimes we sit them down with a cup of coffee. We're trying to undo all the spiritual and emotional neglect.'' Many patients, some of them lying on colorful gurneys, also attend Catholic, Protestant or Jewish services in the chapel or watch them on closed-circuit television in their rooms. The staff relies heavily on ``cancer care technicians,'' who work under the supervision of registered nurses to change tracheotomy tubes and surgical dressings, groom patients and ``give the most essential quality of care: kindness and love,'' said Cimino. ``It's the philosophy of non-abandonment. You keep your promises to the patients; you never let them feel isolated,'' he said. And along with the attention, said Brescia, ``We always leave a tiny bit of hope in the patient.''

DOC.HEAD: Scientists Coax Bamboo to Flower for First Time in Lab
DOC.TEXT: On a fall day in 1988, botanist Rajani Nadgauda burst into her boss's office and shouted: ``The bamboo is flowering.'' The scientist led her boss by the hand to the greenhouse where, in a beaker, a bamboo seedling had sprouted tiny pale flowers. Like all bamboo buds, they weren't very pretty. Limp, almost dry and close to colorless, the flowers exuded no fragrance. But to Mrs. Nadgauda and her boss, plant physiologist Anthony Mascarenhas, they were beautiful. Thus began a ground-breaking experiment on the ``high emperor of all the grasses.'' For almost two years, the ``bamboo team'' at India's National Chemical Laboratory used rigorous science, the potion-making of a brewmaster, and a good dose of superstition to coax successive groups of bamboo to flower. The results were published March 22 in the British magazine Nature. The implications of coaxing a bamboo to flower in a laboratory are immense. Bamboo is an important raw material for paper and in construction. Its shoots are a popular vegetable in Asia, and its leaves and branches are used as livestock feed. But understanding of the plant has been hampered by its bizarre life cycle. When first growing, bamboo spears shoot skyward at up to 1.6 inches per hour, soaring as tall as 130 feet. The grass flowers once every 30 years, and some stands take as long as 120 years. Most botanists die or retire by the time one generation of the tall grass dies and another flowers. But on that fall day two years ago a glimmer of hope appeared. If Mrs. Nadgauda and Mascarenhas could repeat the flowering, they might be able to unlock bamboo's secret. With seeds from the flowers, they could also crossbreed bamboo, another first. Success could aid the fight against deforestation ravaging much of Asia. It also could increase production of bamboo. Success might even help halt the extinction of China's giant panda, which relies on the capricious plant for food. Using highly nutritious ingredients, Mascarenhas' team took bamboo seedlings and tried to spark flowering. ``We invented a powerful brew,'' said Mascarenhas. ``We used coconut milk but we also added some secret things. We felt a little like witch doctors.'' The scientists showered their plant cultures with care. ``You have to give love to your cultures to make them grow,'' Mascarenhas said. ``Of course, we are scientists but we also know that nature moves in strange ways.'' Mrs. Nadgauda had the best luck with the cultures. The fiery-eyed 39-year-old is known in the laboratory as a woman who does not suffer fools or stubborn cultures gladly. ``If I look at the cultures angrily, they grow,'' she said. ``I treat them like my children. If they obey me, then I love them.'' Mrs. Nadgauda said she would often place beakers of bamboo seedlings on her desk and glare at them in the afternoon. The morning after one such scolding, Mrs. Nadgauda came to work to find her cultures had sprouted flowers. The experiment had succeeded. Within a few months, the ``bamboo team'' succeeded twice more, prompting two species of bamboo to flower. In an editorial attached to the Nature article, David Hanke, a professor of botany at Cambridge University, said the experiment ``opens up endless possibilities for the high emperor of all the grasses.'' Mascarenhas and Mrs. Nadgauda are more modest. ``We still have much work to do,'' said Mascarenhas. ``We are perfecting the brew.'' Bamboo comprises about 500 species scattered throughout the world. But it is in Asia where it reigns supreme, cutting a verdant swath through India's monsoon country, the valleys of China's Yunnan and Sichuan provinces, over the Korean peninsula and into Japan. In Hong Kong and Tokyo, bamboo scaffolding encases most construction sites. On China's farms, bamboo hay feeds water buffalo and pigs. Shoots of the young bamboo are stir-fried in Shanghai and pickled in Bombay. In Cambodia, Thailand and Vietnam, bamboo trunks lift farmers' houses from the flood-prone plains. In Bangladesh, where houses and humanity are constantly swept away by cyclones and floods, bamboo is split and woven into mats that serve as walls and roofs of hastily erected new dwellings. Mascarenhas hopes the ``bamboo team'' will soon be able to perfect the flowering experiment and begin selling the technology to other labs. ``Of course, we love the plants,'' he said, ``but we could also use the money.''

DOC.HEAD: Disputes Over Our Common Ancestors
DOC.TEXT: Did we all descend from Eve, an African woman whose offspring quite literally conquered the world? Though of course no one knows her name, some biologists and anthropologists believe that all humanity traces its roots to just one woman. This idea, known as the Eve hypothesis or the Garden of Eden theory, is intriguingly simple: Eve lived in sub-Saharan Africa 100,000 to 200,000 years ago. As the ancestors of modern humans, her children and grandchildren spread throughout Africa and eventually across the world, triggering the extinction of other primitive peoples. Or so some scientists believe. Others ridicule the idea. The theory, based on a comparison of the genes of people around the world, is one of the most hotly conteste controversies in the often-rancorous field of human origins. At a meeting earlier this year of the American Association for the Advancement of Science, both sides argued their cases with facts, speculation and sarcasm. Allan C. Wilson of the University of California at Berkeley, one of the architects of the Eve hypothesis, said the evidence is so strong that the ``argument is done, clinched, finished. It's over.'' Not quite, countered the other side. ``There are serious and obvious flaws in the Eve hypothesis,'' said Geoffrey G. Pope of the University of Illinois. Most everyone agrees that small-brained, humanlike creatures arose in Africa 1.5 million to 2 million years ago. They spread throughout Africa, Europe and Southeast Asia and flourished for hundreds of thousands of years. But what became of them? The theory favored by Pope and many fossil experts holds that those creatures, known as homo erectus, are the true ancestors of us all. If they are right, these early hominids parted company in Africa but went on to evolve in unison. Useful genetic changes that arose in small pockets of population slowly spread throughout the world as neighboring tribes mingled. After thousands of centuries, they became us _ modern humans who differ only in superficial racial features. However, Garden of Eden theorists believe those early settlers disappeared leaving no trace in humanity's genes. Instead, they say they have evidence that a new kind of people arose in Africa much more recently. Their kin also spread throughout the prehistoric world, somehow killing off or squeezing out the European Neanderthals and other descendants of the first wave out of Africa. The difference between the scenarios is so stark that there seems to be no middle ground, no room for compromise. ``There is no question on this issue,'' said Alan G. Thorne of the Australian National University, an Eve skeptic. ``One of us is absolutely wrong.'' The debate began about three years ago with the use of new scientific techniques to look for signs of the family tree inside the genes of modern humans. This intrusion of the glitzy tools of molecular biology have not always been accepted graciously by the traditional fossil hunters, who rely largely on meticulous measurements and comparisons of bone fragments to fathom human origins. David W. Frayer, a Neanderthal expert from the University of Kansas, said the quick acceptance of Eve reflects a preference for sensational catastrophe over mundane gradual change, as well as a ``willingness of some to accept without criticism, or even suspicion, the results of molecular biology.'' Molecular biology's role has been to decipher the genetic information inside mitochondria. These are structures within human cells that help produce energy. Mitochondria have their own genes, separate from the chromosomes that carry all the other blueprints for human beings. Ordinary genes are a mishmash contributed equally by mothers and fathers. Mitochondrial genes are passed along only by mothers. Therefore, each new generation gets an almost exact copy of the mitochondrial genes of their forebears. The only difference is the occasional variation caused by genetic mutations. These mutations are the key to reading mitochondrial genes as a clock. Biologists believe they know how quickly the mutations occur. By comparing the degree of mutation in the genes of people from different parts of the world, they believe they can trace the various lines back to the point at which they all converge: Eve. The latest study of this sort, conducted by Linda Vigilant at Berkeley, uses hair roots plucked from 199 people from Europe, Asia, New Guinea and seven ethnic groups in Africa. Analyzing the root genes, she calculates all the people descended from a common ancestor who lived in Africa 207,000 years ago. This female's descendants evolved into physically modern humans by 100,000 years ago. As neat as the idea seems, anthropologists attack it on several grounds. One is whether the mutations in mitochondrial genes occur like clockwork. The critics argue that the biologists are overly confident that they know the tempo at which the mitochondrial clock is ticking. Milford H. Wolpoff of the University of Michigan contends the clock's rhythm is hopelessly thrown off by the dead ends of all-boy families. Whenever a family produces no girls, the orderly accumulation of genetic mutations stops cold. No mitochondrial genes are passed to the next generation. ``If there is a clock,'' said Thorne, ``it needs new batteries.'' Other scientists point to the fossil record, the teeth and bits of bone that remain from the ancient beings. If the Eve theory is correct, the new wave of humans migrating out of Africa 1,000 centuries ago did not mate and mingle their genes with the ancient hominids that already lived in Europe and Asia. Instead, they replaced them completely. Some fossil experts believe they have found clear signs that traits of those ancient peoples have been passed down to modern humans. For instance, Pope argues that 1 million-year-old fossils from ancient Asia have the same cheekbones and wisdom teeth as modern Asians. This similarity in facial features ``indicates that the Eve hypothesis is completely untenable in Asia.'' Frayer also believes he can see echoes of Neanderthal skulls and teeth in later generations of Europeans. Allison S. Brooks of George Washington University questions Eve on behavioral grounds. She said that if modern humans overran Europe, replacing the dimwitted natives, there should also have been a cultural revolution. However, she finds no abrupt change showing dramatically more advanced stone tools or hunting techniques in Europe after the supposed arrival of Eve's offspring.
