DOC.HEAD: Back to Basics for Good Nutrition and Weight Loss
DOC.TEXT: Tufts University President Jean Mayer, one of the nation's best-known nutritionists, has taken much of the confusion out of eating well and losing weight. ``Dr. Jean Mayer's Diet & Nutrition Guide,'' written with Jeanne P. Goldberg, provides a compact and generally sensible path for children and adults, but is somewhat disorganized and fairly conservative. Mayer and Goldberg, a Tufts School of Nutrition professor, are widely known for their newspaper column ``Food for Thought,'' written in a question-and-answer format. The same device is used in the book, at the end of each chapter, which can make information hard to find. For example, yogurt is discussed both in the main section of a chapter that inclues adapting recipes to make them healthier and in the question-and-answer section at the end of the chapter. With the plethora of diet plans available and labels on food difficult to decipher, consumers need someone to cut a path through it all. And Mayer and Goldberg offer reasonable advice and clear explanations. Their book includes information on preventing food poisoning, eating well in restaurants, vitamins and minerals, food requirements at different ages and for those with various health problems or conditions, and how to lose weight sensibly. That Americans are doing a poor job of feeding themselves seems clear. ``You would probably think it outrageous if we suggested that our paleolithic ancestors crouching in their caves may have been routinely eating a better diet than do many Americans today,'' the authors say. It need not be the case, and beginning with a tour of the supermarket, the authors warn that shoppers' best nutritional interests are not always served by marketing professionals. Overall, Mayer and Goldberg recommend a low-fat diet consisting of foods either fresh or lightly processed, passing by many of the prepared foods that have come on the market in the five decades since the opening of the first supermarket, a King Kullen in New York. They warn about tricky food labels: An ounce of all sorts of cereals may have the same number of calories, but an ounce of corn flakes is about a cup, while an ounce of granola may be just one-quarter cup. Manufacturers are not required to use comparable serving sizes, and many foods have no nutrition labeling at all. But while the authors note that labels can be vague about the types of fats used, they do not point out that because manufacturers must list ingredients in descending order by weight, various kinds of sugar won't appear all together; shoppers should beware of how they add up. There is plenty of information in the book on what various terms on labels mean; how to get enough protein, even in a vegetarian diet, without eating too much fat; how to adjust favorite receipes. Weight-loss advice is simple and traditional: Eat fewer calories, generally by cutting fats and sugar, and exercise more. A month's worth of menus is included. Where government scientists or agencies clash with other groups, the book tends to be conservative. For example, on pesticides, it repeats old arguments about toxins that naturally occur in foods and concludes, ``But when you mesh all these factors together, and weigh the risks and benefits, a general outcry against pesticides is unwarranted.'' With almost half the restaurant dollars going to fast-food outlets, the appendix listing the calorie, salt and fat content of fast-food items from three chains is very useful. ``Dr. Jean Mayer's Diet and Nutrition Guide'' is being published in April by Pharos Books.

DOC.HEAD: Breast-Feeding May Not Protect Middle-Class Infants From Disease, Study Says
DOC.TEXT: Breast-feeding may not protect middle-class urban infants in developed countries from infectious disease as it does in the Third World, a new report says. The study found no effect on rates of upper or lower respiratory illness, an ear condition called otitis media, or an inflammation of the stomach and intestines called gastroenteritis. The study, done in Denmark, involved 500 infants whose health and feeding practices were tracked over their first year with monthly questionnaires. Previous studies have shown that breast feeding protects infants from infectious disease in the Third World. But researchers have reached conflicting conclusions about infants in developed countries, maybe because of how they did their studies, researchers said in the April issue of the journal Pediatrics. The American Academy of Pediatrics generally endorses breast-feeding for full-term infants, saying it provides nutritional, economic and psychological advantages as well as bolstering the infant's disease-fighting immune system. The authors of the new study said their results probably apply to middle-class populations in the United States but not to rural or poor urban populations. The researchers were from the Albert Einstein College of Medicine-Montefiore Medical Center in New York, the Yale University School of Medicine and the University of Copenhagen in Denmark.
DOC.HEAD: Ozone-Sparing Gases May Contribute to Greenhouse Effect, Study
DOC.TEXT: Says

Gases being studied as replacements for ozone-destroying chlorofluorocarbons would contribute to global warming, but less than chlorofluorocarbons do, a study says. Chlorofluorocarbons, called CFCs, are used in a variety of products, but researchers want to find replacements because CFCs destroy ozone in the upper atmosphere. The ozone shields Earth from solar rays that can cause skin cancer. The new study notes that CFCs also promote global warming through the greenhouse effect, because they can trap energy radiating from Earth. Most replacement gases can also absorb that energy, researchers said. But their potential contribution to global warming is only about one-tenth that of CFCs, chiefly because they break down more quickly in the atmosphere, researchers found. The work is reported in the April 5 issue of the British journal Nature by scientists at E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Co. of Wilmington, Del., and Atmospheric and Environmental Research Inc., of Cambridge, Mass. In an accompanying editorial, Keith Shine of the University of Reading in England said unrestrained emissions of the substitutes could lead to ``climatically significant concentrations during the next century.'' So it would be important to prevent unnecessary releases, he wrote.
DOC.HEAD: Diet Guide Gets Attention
DOC.TEXT: Twenty states have expressed interest in distributing Tennessee's nutrition guide for AIDS patients. ``Nutrition and HIV: Your Choice Makes a Difference'' is being prepared for its second printing. Twenty states have asked to see it and may distribute it, said a state nutrition specialist, Peggy Wickwire. The booklet is intended to give patients with acquired immune deficiency syndrome information on keeping up their energy and maintaining their weight. ``Traditional diets don't work for them,'' Ms. Wickwire said. ``They need the opposite of keep-slim diets.'' The guide also may be useful for people with other debilitating diseases such as cancer, she said. The booklet is the brainchild of Matt Nelson, who heads the state health department's AIDS Education and Social Work Service division. Diseases that commonly strike AIDS patients affect what and how much they can eat, Nelson said. ``You almost have to look at what disease you have and what medicines you're on, then figure out what foods are left for you to eat.'' The guide gives tips on dealing with chronic fatigue, drug side effects and food safety, Nelson said. ``AIDS patients can't fight off germs and bacteria found in raw or undercooked food,'' he said. The Tennessee Department of Health and Environment is making bookplates available to any state, city or group that wants to print copies. Information on obtaining the plates is available from Nelson at 615-741-7500.
DOC.NOTE: End advance for April 23

DOC.TEXT: The United States in February recorded its smallest trade deficit in more than six years, a $6.49 billion imbalance that reflected a sharp drop in oil imports, the government reported. The Bush administration, which is counting on strong export growth this year to boost a sluggish domestic economy, hailed the dramatic narrowing of the deficit. But some private economists cautioned that the improvement reported Wednesday could be short-lived, saying the big drop in oil imports was unlikely to be sustained and the dollar's strength was making U.S. goods less competitive overseas.

A federal bankruptcy judge appointed a special trustee to take over the running of Eastern Airlines, removing control from Frank Lorenzo, chairman of Eastern's parent Texas Air Corp. Judge Burton R. Lifland late Wednesday granted the request of Eastern's unsecured creditors, who had sought a trustee because of frustration over Eastern's mounting losses and plans to scale back payments to creditors sharply. ``The flying public's interest must at all times be taken into account,'' Lifland said, adding later, ``It's time to change the captain of Eastern's crew.''

House Democrats unveiled their own $1.2 trillion budget for next year, a plan that calls for $8 billion less in military spending than President Bush wants. The package shown Wednesday, which the House Budget Committee plans to vote on Thursday, also would increase spending by $6 billion on programs that include child care, NASA and aid to Central America, Eastern Europe and Africa. The proposal is the first detailed response by Democratic leaders to the 1991 fiscal year budget Bush requested in January.

Action by Moscow against Lithuania could doom commercial relations between the Soviet Union and the United States, Secretary of State James A. Baker III said. ``It's very difficult to see some of the commercial aspects of our relationship surviving the use of force or coercion'' against the independence-minded Baltic republic, Baker told the House Ways and Means Committee Wednesday at a hearing on East Bloc economic reform.

General Motors Corp. is speeding development of an electrically powered car because of consumer demands for a cleaner environment, chairman Roger B. Smith said. The nation's largest automaker intends to be the first to mass-market an electric vehicle, Smith said Wednesday in a speech to the National Press Club. He refused to say when or where the car would be built. GM unveiled a prototype vehicle, the Impact, in January.

U.S. Trade Representative Carla Hills said she will delay for five months making a decision on a petition to retaliate against Japan for allegedly barring an American-made high-technology product from its market. Hills said Wednesday the delay would give U.S. and Japanese negotiations time to see if the dispute involving amorphous metals can be settled without the need to resort to retaliatory sanctions. The complaint was filed by Allied Signal Inc.

AT&T Chairman Robert E. Allen defended his company against protesters who accused it of caving in to abortion foes and union members who said it pushed workers out of jobs to boost profits. Union workers picketed outside as Allen delivered an optimistic message to shareholders at American Telephone & Telegraph Co.'s annual meeting Wednesday. The workers accused AT&T of achieving profits by unnecessarily laying off 13,500 workers in 1988 and planning to discharge another 9,000 this year while raising some executives' pay by 35 percent. Before the meeting, AT&T reported first-quarter profits rose 12.5 percent to $668 million, or 62 cents a share, from $594 million, or 55 cents a share, a year earlier.

The government would be asked to spend $350 million over three years to develop a magnetic levitation system that would whisk passengers between major U.S. cities at 300 mph, under legislation introduced in Congress. The system, planned as a U.S. improvement on transportation concepts being developed in Germany and Japan, could eventually compete with railroads and airlines by running on elevated tracks alongside interstate highways, Rep. Robert J. Mrazek, D-N.Y., said Wednesday.

Two teams of researchers say they have produced genetically altered corn plants capable of passing on their newly acquired genes to the next generation, an advance that other scientists hailed on Wednesday as a breakthrough. The technique should allow scientists to develop new strains of disease-, insect- and herbicide-resistant corn much more quickly than they can using traditional cross-breeding techniques, the researchers said.

A sharp rise in interest rates helped push stock prices broadly lower Wednesday as Wall Street registered little enthusiasm over news of a much lower trade deficit. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials tumbled 32.89 points to 2,732.88. Bond prices plunged amid concerns about inflation and possible Japanese selling. The dollar fell against all major currencies. Crude oil futures prices settled below $17 a barrel for the first time in nearly 16 months; sugar futures surged; grains and soybeans were mixed; precious metals were mixed; and livestock and meat futures were mixed.

DOC.HEAD: Shearson Loses $915 Million; Merrill Earnings Up Slightly
DOC.TEXT: Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. paid for what analysts have termed the excesses of the 1980s in one $915 million shot in the first quarter. Merrill Lynch & Co. took its post-boom medicine earlier and showed a profit. The nation's top two brokerage firms reported quarterly earnings Wednesday that reflect continued problems in the securities industry, which still is looking to recover from the 1987 stock market crash. ``In both cases there was a slowdown in the investment banking sector, and that's true for most of the (brokerage) houses,'' said Samuel Liss, a securities industry analyst with Salomon Brothers Inc. ``It's a low revenue period.'' Shearson's $915 million loss _ the biggest quarterly loss in Wall Street history _ included a $630 million charge to pay for a restructuring that included about 2,000 layoffs and the elimination or reduction of several businesses. It also took a $157 million charge for an accounting change in the way it pays for development of computer software. The restructuring was implemented after parent American Express Co. moved to seize tighter control of the nation's No. 2 investment firm, which has struggled during a bad period on Wall Street following broad expansion in the 1980s. American Express plans to acquire all Shearson stock it does not own. Merrill Lynch, which reported a 16 percent profit rise, took a $470 million charge in the 1989 fourth quarter to pay for its restructuring. Those cost-cutting measures appeared to take hold in the first quarter despite a revenue drop. Merrill's fourth-quarter charge gave the firm its first annual loss since going public in 1971. Merrill plans to eliminate about 3,000 jobs by the end of 1990 and is divesting some product lines and businesses. Merrill, Shearson and other Wall Street firms have been struggling because of declines in stock market activity and key businesses such as stock and bond underwriting and takeovers since the 1987 stock market crash. The retrenchment is due in part to rapid expansion in the 1980s to capitalize on explosive growth in all segments of the securities business. As business lags, the major firms are forced to consolidate. ``We're saying that in these weak market conditions, firms that generate profits are doing pretty well,'' said Jeffrey Bowman, who follows the securities industry for Standard & Poor's Corp. Excluding its one-time charges, Shearson still lost $128 million for the quarter on its securities business. ``The first-quarter operating loss before the restructuring charge stems from a slowdown in overall business activity and other first-quarter 1990 events,'' Shearson said. The first quarter loss before the accounting change equaled $8.75 per share. That compared to a loss of $15 million, or 24 cents a share, in the same 1989 period. Revenue fell 15 percent to $2.6 billion from $3 billion. Shearson said it increased litigation reserves by $50 million; added $32 million to a loan-loss reserve primarily related to the portfolio of its Boston Co. subsidiary; and lost $34 million because of fluctuations in the junk bond market. Shearson said it had $54 million in income related to the settlement of litigation in connection with the suspension of tin trading by the London Metal Exchange in 1986. Merrill and Shearson reported lower investment banking revenue as business remained sluggish in stock and bond underwriting and merchant banking. Merrill's revenue fell 26.7 percent and Shearson's 25 percent. Brokerage commission revenue was up 4.2 percent at Merrill and down 5.3 percent at Shearson. At Shearson, revenue from market-making and principal transactions also fell sharply, attributed in part to volatility in the collapsed junk bond market. Shearson is selling its portfolio of junk bonds held for investment. Merrill made $41.3 million, or 34 cents a share, in the first quarter, compared with $35.5 million, or 29 cents per share, last year. Revenue declined to $2.66 billion from $2.79 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Merrill Lynch Sees Green in `Eco-Logical' Investment Trust
DOC.TEXT: Environmentally conscious investors have attacked some Wall Street funds for failing to back up claims of being earth-friendly. Merrill Lynch & Co. wanted to make sure it avoided such criticism. With Earth Day approaching, Merrill has formed an investment trust composed of what it calls ``environmentally responsible'' companies. Merrill even printed literature for the trust on recycled paper in green, biodegradable ink. But Merrill hired four outside environmental groups to help set up its ``Eco-Logical Trust 1990.'' The firm denies seeing the environmental movement as another fad from which it can make a buck, and independent environmentalists praised Merrill's handling of the issue. ``The environmentalists selected those stocks that were environmentally responsible,'' said Stanley Craig, national sales manager for Merrill's unit trusts. ``These are not only good companies but they are solid financially.'' The scheme by the nation's largest brokerage is the latest attempt since the Exxon Valdez oil tanker spill last year to capitalize on investor demand to make money while showing concern about the environment. Other ``socially responsible'' investment funds have existed since 1970. But in the rush to jump on the bandwagon, environmentalists have criticized several new funds for investing in companies involved in waste cleanup that nonetheless have pollution records Mother Nature wouldn't be proud of. ``It's not just investing in companies that are dealing with environmental cleanup. It's dealing with companies that are themselves environmentally responsible,'' said Carsten Henningsen, president of Progressive Securities Financial Services, a Portland, Ore., investment adviser. The Merrill trust is a fixed portfolio of 29 stocks. Merrill paid the environmental groups $35,000 to recommend 100 companies they considered ``environmentally responsible.'' Analysts from five big firms that will market the trust through their stockbrokers then selected the companies with the best financial records. Investors profit if the value of the stock portfolio rises. Merrill and the other brokerages make money from a 4 percent sales charge on investments. ``Units,'' or shares in the trust, will cost $10 each, with a minimum 100-unit buy. Merrill said it will donate 50 cents to the Washington-based Environmental Federation of America for every 100 units sold, up to the first $25 million invested in the trust. More money will be donated as the trust grows. ``This is the way we want companies to make money out of the environment _ by telling the truth about it,'' said Peter Camejo, president of Progressive Asset Management in Oakland, Calif., who helped set up the Merrill trust. Camejo alerted Merrill last year that some of the pollution control companies in a trust formed after the Alaska oil spill were polluters themselves. Merrill later offered to set up the new trust. The pollution trust sold out in six days last July, attracting about $125 million in investments. The new trust consists of 13 companies involved in pollution control or abatement, 10 natural gas companies, two utilities and four other companies with no direct environmental tie. Among the stocks are Apple Computer Inc., which recycles the bulk of its waste; WalMart Stores Inc., which has a ``green section'' in its stores for products that use recyclable materials or have other environmental benefits; and Nucor Corp., which makes steel out of scrap from cars and appliances. ``They've got some good companies in there,'' said Gordon Davidson, executive director of the Coalition for Environmentally Responsible Economies in Boston. ``The only thing, of course, is that there is no such thing as a perfect company,'' he said. ``All these companies need to work to improve their environmental performance.'' But some environmentalists said that even if the companies in Merrill's trust are pro-environment, investment vehicles are no substitute for broader changes in corporate policy. ``This is Wall Street's version of green marketing,'' said Greenpeace USA spokesman Peter Dykstra. ``Almost without exception we have found that green marketing is far more marketing than green.'' ``What may be a bigger gain is a new marketing tool for Merrill and a new opportunity to package itself as environmentally concerned when the vast majority of its business will still be conducted with blue-chip stocks in the auto industry or energy industry,'' he said. Merrill officials said the firm recycles paper, glass and other materials, and that while the trust prospectus was its first printed on recyclable paper, it plans to print more that way in the future.

DOC.HEAD: Harold Simmons Challenges Lockheed Proxy Vote in Lawsuit
DOC.TEXT: Texas billionaire Harold Simmons is going to court to challenge the legality of the proxy contest he lost last month for control of Lockheed Corp.'s board of directors. The federal suit, filed Wednesday on behalf of the Simmons-controlled N.L. Industries in Houston, asked the court to declare Simmons-backed nominees the winners or to set a new election. The suit accuses the incumbent board of directors of illegally engineering extra proxy votes through an employee stock ownership plan and playing a variety of dirty tricks to ensure that Simmons lost his fight. ``This action seeks to restore integrity to the recent election of Lockheed's Board of Directors and to ensure integrity in future elections,'' said the lawsuit, filed in U.S. District Court. Bob Meder, a Lockheed spokesman, said the company declined to comment because officials had not seen the lawsuit. Simmons lost a proxy fight for control of the aerospace company's board at the March 29 shareholder's meeting, but he won major concessions for big shareholders. Simmons contends that Calabassas-based Lockheed, the nation's sixth largest defense contractor, has been mismanaged under the leadership of Chairman Daniel Tellep. The Dallas investor's N.L. Industries owns 18.9 percent of Lockheed's common stock. He paid about $530 million for his shares and is sitting on a paper loss of about $100 million. Simmons was not available for comment on the lawsuit. A call to his home was not answered and his spokesman did not immediately return a phone message. The lawsuit accuses the company of starting the employee stock ownership plan as ``an llegal entrenchment device'' whose votes should have been disallowed in the election. If the plan's votes and a few so-far challenged proxies were thrown out, Simmons' nominees would have won the election, the suit contends. The employee stock plan represented a large portion of the support for the current board, whose 14 incumbents won with support ranging from 57.6 percent to 60.7 percent. The employee plan holds nearly 20 percent of Lockheed's stock. Simmons has said he was dissatisfied with the way the trustee for the employee stock ownership plan had voted a block of shares believed to number at least 500,000 of the some 12 million shares owned by the plan. Hours after the shareholders meeting, a spokesman for the stock plan said the trustee did not receive voting instructions on the large block, but still voted those shares for management. Simmons has said that in the absence of voting instructions, those shares should not have been voted for either side. The trustee, though, said it was his fiduciary responsibility to vote all of the plan's shares. Lockheed said holders of 82 percent of its stock, 52,685,00 shares of the 63,192,196 outstanding, had cast votes. The lawsuit also accuses the company of taking a number of last-minute steps to allegedly steal the election. These steps included moving the annual meeting up six weeks from its usual date to rob N.L. Industries of time to prepare, and sending out proxy materials that failed to mention the existence of a competing slate of directors, the suit alleges. The suit also complained that managers refused to help N.L. Industries approach Lockheed workers who would be voting to explain Simmons's side of the dispute. Separately, Simmons struck a conciliatory note in an April 16 letter to Tellep that was disclosed in a filing he made Wednesday with the Securities and Exchange Commission in Washington. ``I firmly believe that, notwithstanding litigation, we can work together productively to maximize share values for all Lockheed shareholders, and I look forward to doing so,'' the letter said. Simmons suggested in the letter that Tellep explore ``the feasibility of a $1 billion stock repurchase plan.'' He also suggested the sale of non-strategic or underperforming assets to raise about $1 billion. Lockheed spokesman Ron Meder declined to comment on the letter, saying only, ``Basically it's just a rehash of all the issues raised in the proxy contest.''

DOC.HEAD: Norton Loses Plea in Federal Court
DOC.TEXT: With a war looming at its shareholder meeting next week, Norton Co. won one battle, lost another and fired more ammunition to fight a takeover bid from Britain's BTR PLC. The flurry of events began Wednesday morning when Gov. Michael S. Dukakis signed a law that would prevent BTR from wresting immediate control over the Norton board. Hours later, the U.S. Court of Appeals turned down Norton's request to delay its April 26 shareholder meeting for two months to prepare its defenses. In the meantime, Norton filed a lawsuit alleging state law prevents BTR from exercising any voting power at the shareholder meeting. BTR called Norton's claim ``frivolous.'' The sense of urgency was summed up by Bernard Nussbaum, an attorney representing Norton, who told the Appeals Court: ``These people have turned the April 26th meeting into a referendum on the future of the company.'' Norton last month rejected a $1.6 billion, $75-a-share offer from BTR. But the British conglomerate threatened to remove Norton's board of directors through a proxy fight at the shareholder meeting. Part of Norton's strategy has been to stall BTR. Norton, a leading maker of abrasives, insists it needs extra time to plan its options, including seeking other investors to help fend off the bid. ``There's a whole world out there to explore,'' Nussbaum told the Appeals Court, adding that if the meeting is held next week, ``the reality is the board would lose.'' Nussbaum argued that under state law, a company not only must weigh shareholder interests but also its duties to its employees, customers, community and the regional economy. But Stuart Meiklejohn, representing BTR, said the company's bylaws require Norton to hold the meeting April 26 and prohibit changing the date. Meiklejohn said there is no evidence to suggest that Norton has had any success in exploring alternatives. Instead, he argued, Norton is simply trying to line up shareholders who would support the company's position. The Appeals Court sided with BTR, upholding a U.S. District Court ruling from last week. The Appeals Court said it agreed with the lower court's interpretation of the Norton bylaws, stating that the annual meeting must be held the fourth Thursday of April. Meanwhile, in its suit Norton said BTR had triggered a special mechanism in Massachusetts law because more than 20 percent of stockholders had tendered their shares. About 64 percent of the shares have been tendered for BTR. The suit contends that under the state law, those people who tendered their shares would not be able to vote for BTR. BTR responded that the suit ``shows just how desperate the Norton board is.'' ``We view today's legal maneuvering by Norton and its board as without merit and a frivolous waste of company assets,'' the company said. BTR representatives stressed that the company does not own the shares that have been tendered. But Norton insisted that the tendered shares signify ``beneficial ownership'' and are subject to the law. Norton asked that the issue be decided quickly in state court, since the issue strictly involves Massachusetts law. Norton's stall strategy got a boost early in the day when Dukakis signed the new law, which took effect immediately. Under the law, only one-third of the directors could be elected at one time, meaning BTR would have to wait at least a year to gain majority control. BTR has vowed to continue with its bid despite the law. ``This bill gives companies a well-deserved fighting chance against hostile raiders,'' Dukakis said in prepared remarks. He signed the law in Worcester, where Norton's headquarters are located, declaring ``we must do all we can to protect our best corporate citizens and their workers and families from having their livelihoods wiped out.'' John Nelson, the Norton chairman, told a cheering crowd of workers that the company ``will continue to fight to remain independent.''

DOC.HEAD: Unions Hail Trustee Decision as Chance to Rebuild
DOC.TEXT: Eastern Airline's unions praised a judge's decision to appoint a trustee to run the airline, saying it vindicated their position in the bitter 13-month battle against their ultimate foe, Frank Lorenzo. ``Justice has finally been served by stopping the most renowned corporate pirate of the past decade,'' said Michael J. Flynn, president of Local 1690, which represents about 2,000 striking Machinists in Atlanta. ``Ever since Frank Lorenzo took control of Eastern in 1986, we watched our airline dismantled and sold for the benefit of Texas Air,'' he said. ``The (union) has fought this injustice every step of the way in the courts, in the Congress and with public opinion. Finally, the truth has been seen by Eastern's creditors and shareholders, but most important, by Judge Lifland.'' U.S. Bankruptcy Judge Burton R. Lifland late Wednesday granted a request from Eastern's unsecured creditors to appoint a trustee to run the airline. The move took control from Lorenzo, who is chairman of Eastern's parent, Texas Air. The decision was particularly sweet for the unions, who have pushed for a trustee since Eastern filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection five days after a crippling strike began in March 1989. The unions contended that Lorenzo was slowly bleeding Eastern to death by shifting assets to Texas Air and Continental Airlines, Eastern's largely non-union sister carrier. ``We're elated,'' said striking Machinist Mike Richy in Miami. ``We can't believe it. It's been a year coming.'' In Atlanta, Machinists union leader Robert D. Taylor called the judge's ruling a ``sad'' victory because it took 13 months too long. Nevertheless, he said, ``The union will rise to the occasion . . . and rebuild this airline under new management.'' Dick Nellis, an Atlanta representative of Eastern's pilots union, sounded a similar note. He said he was ``overjoyed'' at the ruling but added, ``it is really very sad that it has taken so long for the system to recognize why the real Eastern employees left the property in the first place. ``Literally, there have been thousands of careers that have been shattered and billions of dollars of Eastern Airlines assets wasted,'' he said. ``It is just a sad thing to think we had to wait this long.'' A small group of Machinists who were gathered at the Local 1690 hall in Forest Park, Ga., hooted for joy when they learned of Lorenzo's ouster. They were more cautious about Martin Shugrue, the former Continental president who was appointed as trustee. ``I will hold my judgment on Mr. Shugrue until we investigate him,'' said Local 1690 vice president Tony Chapman. ``There is reason to be cautiously optimistic. We are looking forward to working with him any way possible.'' E.J. Breen, spokesman for the Air Line Pilot Association in Miami, said the appointment of Shugrue would give Eastern a new lease on life. ``We've always felt that a change in management was the first piece of the formula that would bring Eastern back to the successful airline that it has been in the past,'' he said. ``Now that that's been cleared, I really think that it means a future for Eastern Airlines. It never had a future for the last 4{ years that Frank Lorenzo was on the airline.''

DOC.HEAD: Corn Genetics Work Expands Range Of Engineered Edibles
DOC.TEXT: Genetically engineered food could become as common as corn by the end of this decade, say researchers whose recent breakthrough in the field already has expanded the range of products under development. Tomatoes that taste better and last longer will be among the first genetically altered edibles submitted this year for federal Food and Drug Administration approval, according to the company that grows them. If the FDA gives the green light to tomatoes, herbicide-resistant corn likely will be among the cornucopia of products that follow _ because corn has just joined the genetic age. Two teams of researchers say they have produced genetically altered corn plants capable of passing on their newly acquired traits to the next generation, a problem that had stymied scientists for years. The technique promises to produce new strains of disease-, insect- and herbicide-resistant corn that researchers contend will be better for livestock and people, and better for the environment. ``People have talked for a long time of the potential benefits of genetic engineering of corn, but until you could put a gene in, all that was hypothetical,'' said Thomas B. Rice, president of the seed division of DeKalb Genetics Corp. of DeKalb, Ill. ``Now we'll find out,'' Rice said. A team of DeKalb researchers announced their success with corn genetics Wednesday, two days after a group of Agriculture Department and Monsanto Co. scientists announced similar findings at the same conference in Keystone, Colo. Both groups used a ``gene gun'' to shoot microscopic gene-coated bullets into corn cells, which were then grown into mature plants. The adult plants were fertilized with pollen and produced a new generation of seedlings which were shown to have the same genetic traits that had been engineered into their parents. Genetic engineering of corn, the largest and most valuable U.S. farm crop, has long eluded researchers despite their success with soybeans, cotton, tobacco and tomatoes, said Michael Fromm, a molecular biologist at an Albany, Calif., research center operated by the Agriculture Department and University of California at Berkeley. Fromm, who headed the USDA-Monsanto research team, said the technique used successfully with those crops involved a bacteria that did not work well with corn and other grains. Researchers using the bacteria technique have developed products such as better-tasting, longer-lasting tomatoes and herbicide-resistant cottonseed. Calgene Inc., a Davis, Calif., company plans to apply this year for FDA approval of the tomato, said Dan Wagster, Calgene's chief financial officer. With the FDA's permission, Calgene expects to market the tomatoes beginning in 1993, Wagster said. But the FDA filing is likely to rekindle the debate over genetic engineering, which critics fear will lead to the careless release of new life forms with potentially disastrous consequences. Wagster said that ``what we expect with the application to the FDA is that the controversy gets resolved.'' The company hopes to document that its new tomato, now entering its third year of field trials ``is still a food that is still safe as well as an improved product.'' He said Calgene's genetically altered cottonseed is immune to an herbicide that is biodegradable and more concentrated than those currently in use, but farmers can't use it because it kills cotton plants as well as weeds. If the new cottonseed is approved, he said, cotton growers could switch to that herbicide, saving them money and causing less damage to the environment.

DOC.HEAD: Amtrak Strike Threat Averted, But Some Pickets Appear
DOC.TEXT: A potential nationwide strike by machinists against Amtrak was averted early today by an agreement to try to settle the dispute, a spokeswoman for Amtrak said. The strike had been called for 6 a.m., and pickets who apparently did not get word of the agreement appeared in some places, including South Station in Boston. But Sue Martin, Amtrak senior director of public affairs in Washington, said service was not affected. The dispute involved interpretation of an agreement between the national passenger railroad and the International Association of Machinists on union officers conducting union business on company time. Ms. Martin said the agreement was being interpreted inconsistently and that union leaders in some places ``essentially were spending all day on union business and getting paid by Amtrak.'' Amtrak issued guidelines to remedy the problem, she said, but union officials thought they were too narrow. Under the agreement reached early today, the guidelines will be put on hold while the two sides seek a resolution of their diferences, possibly through arbitration or court action. Ms. Martin said she thought lawyers for both sides would meet later today in Washington to make the agreement formal. Roy Wildman, a shop steward with Machinists' Local 318 in Boston, said Amtrak has made it virtually impossible for union officials to conduct any type of union business, including grievances, on Amtrak property on company time. He said union officials could not even use company time for work that would benefit Amtrak, such as arranging vacation times for union members. The machinists inspect, maintain and repair the railroad equipment, and by federal law, locomotives on the road must be inspected every 24 hours, Wildman said.

The stock market lost more ground today amid persistent worries over rising interest rates. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials dropped 5.40 to 2,727.48 in the first half hour of trading. Losers outnumbered gainers by nearly 2 to 1 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed issues, with 324 up, 621 down and 510 unchanged. Volume on the Big Board came to 21.66 million shares as of 10 a.m. on Wall Street. Analysts said sentiment among traders was dominated by a recent rise in interest rates and signs of stubborn inflationary pressures. Interest rates, up sharply Tuesday and Wednesday, climbed further in credit-market activity today. Prices of long-term government bonds dropped more than $5 for each $1,000 in face value, putting their yields in the 8.86 percent-8.92 percent range. Brokers also said investors were giving mixed reviews to corporate earnings reports for the first quarter. Digital Equipment rose 2{ to 82{. The company posted a big drop in quarterly profits, but many Wall Streeters had been expecting the news to be even worse. American Express, which reported a $619.80 million loss for the first quarter, slipped \ to 28|. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks dropped .36 to 186.57. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index was down .67 at 352.55. On Wednesday the Dow Jones industrial average tumbled 32.89 points to 2,732.88, giving back nearly all of its 36.04-point gain over the three previous sessions. Declining issues outnumbered advances by more than 2 to 1 on the NYSE, with 471 up, 1,052 down and 473 unchanged. Big Board volume totaled 147.13 million shares, against 127.99 million in the previous session.
The NASDAQ Composite Index at 11am was 430.77 down 0.75 from the previous day's close.

DOC.HEAD: Crop Futures Edge Lower on Lithuania Concerns
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures prices edged lower in early trading today on the Chicago Board of Trade amid fears that Moscow's reprisals against Lithuania could jeopardize U.S. grain sales to the Soviet Union. Reports that the Soviet Union had cut off oil shipments to the breakaway republic triggered speculation that the United States will back away from granting the Soviets most favored nation trade status. The designation would allow for freer trade between the superpowers. Forecasts for increasingly wet, warm weather in the Midwestern croplands prompted further selling this morning. Rain was expected in the region today and Friday, and the National Weather Service has predicted above-normal temperatures for the Midwest during the latter half of next week. Higher prices for soybean meal in Europe helped to limit losses in the soybean market. In early trading, wheat futures were } cent to 1{ cents lower with the contract for delivery in May at $3.63} a bushel; corn was { cent to 1 cent lower with May at $2.72} a bushel; oats were { cent to 1 cent lower with May at $1.56{ a bushel; soybeans were { cent lower to \ cent higher with May at $5.94\ a bushel. Cattle futures were mixed in early trading on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange while pork futures advanced, led by a surge in pork-belly prices amid bullish chart signals. Live cattle futures were .05 cent lower to .20 cent higher with April at 79.82 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .10 cent lower to .05 cent higher with April at 84 cents a pound; live hogs were unchanged to .35 cent higher with April at 56.90 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .68 cent to 1.58 cent higher with May at 60.90 cents a pound. Cattle futures were mixed on Wednesday while pork futures were mostly higher.

The stock market declined broadly today amid persistent worries over rising interest rates. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials dropped 5.18 to 2,727.70 by noontime on Wall Street. Losers outnumbered gainers by nearly 2 to 1 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed issues, with 441 up, 855 down and 527 unchanged. Brokers also said investors were giving mixed reviews to corporate earnings reports for the first quarter. Digital Equipment led the active list and rose 1[ to 81[. The company posted a big drop in quarterly profits, but many Wall Streeters had been expecting the news to be even worse. American Express, which reported a $619.80 million loss for the first quarter, dropped { to 28]. Other losers among the blue chips included International Business Machines, down ] at 109{; General Electric, down \ at 66\, and Philip Morris, down ] at 42\. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks fell .63 to 186.30. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index was down 1.85 at 351.37.
