DOC.HEAD: Allied-Lyons Sells 41 Embassy Hotels to Jarvis
DOC.TEXT: Allied-Lyons PLC, the British liquor and food company, said Thursday it was selling its Embassy Hotels chain to Jarvis Hotels Ltd. for $331 million. The sale of the chain, which operates 41 hotels in Britain, depends on Jarvis completing financing for the deal, Allied-Lyons said. Jarvis is a newly formed hotel group headed by former Hilton International Chairman and Chief Executive John Jarvis. Jarvis will pay for Embassy Hotels with cash and debt, Allied-Lyons said. Allied-Lyons said the sale was in line with its plans to develop its core operations, and that the proceeds would help reduce its debt. Late last year, Allied-Lyons paid $325 million for the U.S. doughnuts and coffee chain Dunkin Donuts Inc. and $894 million for the liquor division of Whitbread and Co. PLC, a British brewing group. Embassy reported a trading profit of $15.4 million on sales of $94 million in the year ended March 1989. Trading profit is profit before taxes and other items. Allied-Lyons posted a trading profit of $964 million on sales of $7 billion in the same period.

DOC.HEAD: Control Data Agrees To Sell Chip Division, Ticketron
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 11th graf, `On Tuesday ...,' to CORRECT that Ticketron deal closed in December, not Tuesday. SUBS 13th graf, `The buyers ...,' to conform.
DOC.TEXT: Control Data Corp. has reached a tentative deal to sell VTC Inc., its money-losing computer chip subsidiary, to Seattle Silicon of Bellevue, Wash. Under the proposed agreement, Seattle Silicon would buy the assets of VTC in order to form a new company that hasn't been named. Control Data would hold a 20 percent stake in the new company, which would be headed by Amaury Piedra, Seattle Silicon's president and chief executive officer. Terms of the proposed agreement, announced Wednesday, were not announced. The new company would continue to operate VTC's Bloomington plant and keep nearly all of VTC's 400 employees, said Ed Fernandez, vice president of marketing and sales for Seattle Silicon. Larry Jodsaas, president of VTC, will stay with Control Data in an undetermined position, said Control Data spokesman Frank Ryan. Expecting to sell VTC, Control Data took a $110 million charge against its earnings last year. Control Data lost $680.4 million last year, and has sold or closed several operations in an attempt to achieve a turnaround. ``VTC is certainly the last obstacle to remove in the restructuring of Control Data,'' said Nancy Foltz, a Control Data spokeswoman. ``It was the only remaining business that consistently lost money.'' Control Data does not provide financial information on VTC, which designs computer chips for the military and the disk drive data storage industry. Seattle Silicon is a private, 6-year-old chip maker that has not had its own manufacturing facility. It has been making chips through alliances with other companies. In December, Control Data reached agreement to sell its Ticketron division, which provides tickets to theaters, concerts and sports events through a computer network. Terms of the deal were not disclosed. The buyers were a group consisting of Centre Group L.P. of Landover, Md., Ogden Allied Services Corp. of New York, Wembley Group of London and Carlyle Group, a private investment bank based in Washington, D.C. Centre Group and Carlyle Group are co-general partners under the new ownership. Centre Group consists of the Washington Bullets, the Washington Capitals and their arena, Capital Centre.

DOC.HEAD: Perrier to Remove `Sparkling Water' Claim from its Bottles
Precede NEW YORK
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 6 grafs to UPDATE with company, FDA confirming report, add detail. Picks up 6th graf pvs, `Source Perrier...'. This also moved on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Perrier water will be back on the shelves soon, but it won't have the same sparkle _ at least not on the label. The Food and Drug Administration has ruled that the mineral water's claim to be ``naturally sparkling'' is false and ordered the American distributor to remove the phrase from bottles. ``The water comes out of the ground and the carbonation is added,'' Bob Crowell, compliance officer in the FDA's Boston district office, said today. Jane Lazgin, a spokeswoman for the Perrier Group of America Inc., in Greenwich, Conn., said the company believed its description was accurate but would obey the FDA. ``We certainly want to comply with the FDA request, even though in principle we do disagree with some of the language,'' Lazgin said today. She said the company wanted to return Perrier to supermarket shelves as soon as possible. Lazgin said bottles would return to the shelf next week, beginning in New York, Miami and Washington. All Perrier bottled after July 29 would bear the new label ordered by the FDA. Source Perrier S.A. of France began a worldwide recall of its water in February after trace amounts of the carcinogen benzene were discovered in some bottles. The uproar revealed that Source Perrier not only mechanically added gas to its water but that the gas contained numerous impurities that had to be removed. An unchanged filter containing some benzene from the gas apparently was responsible for the contamination.

DOC.HEAD: Official Says Trade Deficit Could Worsen
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Tops with 8 new grafs with committee testimony, picks up 5th graf pvs, While this forecast. A version slugged PM-Trade Outlook moved on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: A top Bush administration official said today that the U.S. trade deficit could worsen this year and warned that Japan's closed markets pose ``important risks for the world economy.'' Treasury Undersecretary David Mulford said that there is more at stake than reducing America's huge trade imbalance. He said growing protectionist threats could imperil world prosperity. ``If we are going to preserve the global trading system, we are going to have to insist that Japan and others who share the benefits do their part,'' Mulford said. ``Clearly, Japan has not done its part.'' Mulford's comments were part of the administration's continuing campaign to pressure Japan to open its markets further for foreign trade. Many have grown concerned that a big decline in the value of the yen in recent months threatens to worsen the $49 billion trade deficit between the two nations. A weaker yen would make Japanese products less expensive in this country while making American goods more costly in Japan. ``The depreciation of the yen and Japan's relatively closed markets are not sustainable over time as their continuation would pose important risks for the world economy,'' Mulford said in testimony before a Senate Banking subcommittee. Mulford said that any further improvement in America's broadest measure of trade, the current account, was likely to be ``very modest and the possibility of deterioration in the current account cannot be excluded.'' Mulford's comments echoed the outlook in a new adminisration assessemnt prepared by the Treasury Department which said further improvement in the trade balance this year would be ``modest at best.'' While this forecast is in line with the view of many private economists, it poses a threat to the optimistic economic assumptions underlying President Bush's 1991 budget. A widening of the trade deficit would worsen the slump in manufacturing as companies found it harder to sell their products overseas. Further weakness in manufacturing could seriously depress overall economic growth. The broadest measure of U.S. trade, the current account, posted a deficit of $105.9 billion in 1989. It had posted an all-time high of $143.7 billion in 1987. The current account measures both trade in merchandise and services, a category that primarily reflects investment flows between countries. So far this year, the merchandise portion of the trade deficit has been on a roller coaster, surging to $9.32 billion in January, only to drop to $6.49 billion in February as oil imports retreated from a record high set the month before. Many private economists look for America's oil dependence to deepen in coming months as domestic production slumps further. Another negative factor on the trade front is the recent strength of the U.S. dollar, especially against the Japanese yen. A stronger dollar makes U.S. goods less competitive on overseas markets and makes foreign imports cheaper for American consumers. The United States has often joined with other leading industrial countries in coordinated efforts to keep currency rates in line as a way at attacking trade imbalances. The Group of Seven nations _ the United States, Japan, West Germany, Britain, France, Canada and Italy _ last met in Paris earlier this month. They promised then to continue their coordination efforts but rejected petitions by Japanese officials for stronger action to bolster the sagging yen. In the trade assessment, the administration declared that ``the yen's weakness is a matter of concern, with undesirable consequences for the global adjustment process.'' Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady gave a similar view in congressional testimony but did not offer any specific actions the administration was willing to take. The U.S. trade deficit with Japan widened to $3.12 billion in February from $2.86 billion in January. The administration's trade report said the dramatic political changes occurring in Eastern Europe had the potential of easing global trade imbalances. The report said the unification of West and East Germany should help lower West Germany's large trade surpluses because the united country would have more demand for imported products. However, it said, the prime beneficiaries of this development were likely to be other countries in Europe, not the United States. On another point, the report said Taiwan and South Korea had made progress in liberalizing their currency exchange-rate policies but that both nations need to make further progress. The two countries had been cited in previous reports for manipulating their currencies in order to bolster their export sales, particularly with the United States, their primary foreign market.

DOC.HEAD: Emergency Meeting of Monitoring Committee Set for May 2
DOC.TEXT: OPEC will hold an emergency session of its ministerial monitoring committee on May 2 to examine how to stop the fall in crude oil prices, the organization's current president, Sadek Boussena, announced Thursday. The full OPEC conference scheduled for May 25 in Geneva could be postponed until June 26, a statement by Boussena, the Algerian oil minister, said. The statement did not disclose where the meeting would be held, but said all 13 member nations of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries would be represented. Normally, eight nations take part in the ministerial monitoring committee. The announcement of such a meeting follows a series of consultations between Boussena and OPEC partners about the drop in oil prices. Boussena said consultations would continue to try to identify ``practical temporary measures'' which could be put into place ``with little delay.'' The current OPEC reference price for crude oil is $18 a barrel. Production rates are fixed at 22 million barrels per day.

DOC.HEAD: Dayton Hudson to Buy Marshall Field's
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATEs with comments from Chicago news conference; minor editing throughout.
DOC.TEXT: Dayton Hudson Corp. today announced an agreement to buy the Marshall Field & Co. department store chain for about $1.04 billion from BAT Industries PLC, a British conglomerate. The purchase of the famous Chicago-based retailer is expected to be completed within two months. The deal will link two of the Midwest's most prominent retailers and will expand Minneapolis-based Dayton Hudson's presence in Chicago and several other regional cities. The definitive agreement with Batus Inc., BAT's U.S. subsidiary, must be approved by regulators. Dayton Hudson said it planned to keep all 24 Marshall Field's stores in Illinois, Ohio, Wisconsin and Texas open for business. ``This is a once in a lifetime opportunity to add another premier name to our department store division,'' said Kenneth A. Macke, Dayton Hudson's chairman and chief executive officer. Macke said at a news conference in Chicago that he anticipates ``no problems in financing the deal,'' and added junk bonds would not play a role. He said it was too early to say what part current Field's chairman Philip Miller would play in the chain's future. But Macke and Stephen Watson, president of Dayton Hudson, both praised the role Miller has had in Field's over the past five years. For his part, Miller, who with other managers had mounted a buyout offer of their own, said he was disappointed his group had lost. ``We thought we were looking like the front runner,'' said Miller. ``It's always a surprise when you lose.'' Marshall Field's, one of the country's best known department store groups, was put up for sale last year by BAT as part of a restructuring to defend itself against a hostile takeover bid by Sir James Goldsmith. BAT, a large conglomerate with interests ranging from tobacco to financial services and retailing, also is selling its Saks Fifth Avenue division. Dayton Hudson's department store division operates 37 stores known as either Dayton's or Hudson's in their respective markets in seven Midwestern states. ``Our department store division is among the most profitable in its industry and has produced 11 percent compound annual profit growth for the past 5 years. Its consistent performance over the last several years supports this acquisition,'' Macke said in a prepared statement. ``We are very excited about the synergy created by these powerful department store names _ Marshall Field's, Hudson's and Dayton's, each one dominant in its markets,'' he said. The newly acquired Marshall Field's will report to Marvin W. Goldstein, chairman and chief executive officer of the department store division. Dayton Hudson is in the process of building two replacement and three new department stores by 1992. The addition of the Field's stores will bring the total number of stores in the division to 64. Goldstein said the company expects that there will be consolidation of some functions but that those decisions will be made in the coming weeks. The acquisition will be financed with a combination of internally generated funds and a mix of debt instruments, the retailer said. Dayton Hudson does not plan an equity offering. The corporation recently reported record revenue and earnings for the last fiscal year, with revenue up 12 percent to $13.64 billion and income up 43 percent to $410 million. In 1989, Dayton Hudson's department store division's revenue was $1.8 billion and its operating profit was $179 million. The division has more than 22,000 employees. Dayton Hudson also owns the Target chain, one of the country's biggest discounters with 408 stores in 32 states, and Mervyn's, a moderate-priced department store company with 221 stores in 15 states.

DOC.HEAD: Digital's Quarterly Profit Plunges, Unisys Loses $3.2 Million
DOC.TEXT: Digital Equipment Corp., the nation's second-largest computer maker, reported a sharp drop in quarterly earnings Thursday, while No. 2 Unisys Corp. said it lost $3.2 million for the first quarter. Digital, which has been reducing its work force through a costly severance program, said the results were better than expected. For the quarter ended March 31, Digital earned $24.9 million, or 20 cents a share, compared with $256 million, or $2.05 per share, during the same period a year earlier. Earnings for the most recent quarter were $1.40 a share before a restructuring charge stemming from the severance plan, the company said. Digital's revenues for the period, which is the company's third fiscal quarter, totaled $3.26 billion, up 4 percent from $3.13 billion for the third quarter last year. For the first nine months of the fiscal year, Digital earned $331 million, or $2.65 a share, on sales of $9.58 billion, compared with earnings of $759 million, or $5.94 a share, on sales of $9.25 billion a year earlier. Digital has offered voluntary severance to 2,000 employees in recent months, with 700 accepting. This week, Digital announced another round of voluntary severance packages, for 1,800 workers in Puerto Rico. The cost of the employee-reduction program was $150 million in the most recent quarter, said Digital, which is based in Maynard, Mass. Digital said earlier that it was walking a fine line between recording a profit or a loss for the quarter. ``The numbers came in a lot better than expected,'' said Mark Steinkrauss, a Digital spokesman. Digital officials said there could be more restructuring, but they declined to be specific. The company, along with other computer makers, has been hurt by slow U.S. sales. But Steinkrauss said Digital's U.S. revenues were up 4 percent during the quarter, marking the first growth in a year. ``It's not quite as catastrophic a story as it might have been,'' said Terry Shannon, an analyst at International Data Corp. At Unisys, which is based in Blue Bell, Pa., the first-quarter loss came to 19 cents per common share, compared with a loss of $78.7 million, or 66 cents a share, in 1989's first quarter. Revenue totaled $2.31 billion, up from $2.2 billion a year ago. Operating income was $86 million in the first quarter, compared with an operating loss of $37 million a year earlier. ``Our priority in 1990 is to make our business operations profitable and to bring down the company's debt level,'' James A. Unruh, Unisys' president and chief executive officer, said in a statement. ``We made progress in both of these areas in the first quarter despite a mixed business environment.'' Unruh said international business was strong during the quarter, but ``our U.S. computer business, which has been sluggish for the past two years, remains weak and we are cautious about the business environment in general.'' He said he expects benefits from last year's restructuring to be seen in the second half of this year.

DOC.HEAD: Profit Falls 12 Percent in 1st Qtr
DOC.TEXT: Weyerhaeuser Co. said Thursday its earnings fell 12 percent in the first quarter, mostly because of lower prices and lower profit margins for most pulp and paper products. The wood products company reported earnings of $130.1 million, or 61 cents a share, compared with $148.1 million, or 70 cents a share, a year earlier. First-quarter sales slipped 1.7 percent to $2.28 billion from $2.32 billion. George H. Weyerhaeuser, chairman and chief executive, told the annual shareholders meeting that the weakness in pulp and paper products was only partially offset by better results in forest products and other areas. In timberlands and forest products operations, the company said prices for logs, lumber and plywood improved and its engineered fiber panels and building materials segments did significantly better. Weyerhaeuser's mortgage banking operation also returned to profitability and its savings and loan subsidiary showed a stronger quarterly performance.

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Tax Gap
DOC.TEXT: The Internal Revenue Service estimated Thursday that individuals had $48.3 billion of legal, taxable income in 1987 that they did not report on their tax returns. Here is what made up that total: _Earnings from one-owner businesses, 34 percent. _Income of informal suppliers or ``off-the-book'' merchants, who deal in cash, such as day-care providers, home-repair workers and roadside vendors, 16 percent. _Capital gains, 14 percent. _Farm, small-corporation and partnership income, 11 percent. _Pensions, state tax refunds, alimony and other miscellaneous income, 9 percent. _Interest and dividends, 7 percent. _Rents and royalties, 6 percent. _Wages and salaries, 3 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Nike Battles Government over Air Jordans
DOC.TEXT: Nike Inc. is embroiled in a million-dollar dispute with the U.S. Customs Service over how the company makes its Air Jordan shoes. Customs says the athletic shoe and apparel company must pay a 20 percent duty when it imports its shoes from Asia. Nike claims it owes only 6 percent. At issue are what is known in the industry as ``foxing-like bands'' that connect many makes of athletic shoe uppers to their soles. Nike says Air Jordans don't have the bands. The government says they do, and that makes the $120 shoes competitive with domestic manufacturers' styles with the bands. In a 10-page ruling sent Wednesday to U.S. Sen. Bob Packwood, the Customs Service reaffirmed a preliminary finding last year that the imitation-leather versions of Air Jordans have foxing-like bands. Nike says the extra duty has been adding $10 to $12 to a pair of Air Jordans' retail price since mid-1989, when the agency first ruled on the matter. The company has had to pay $8 million to $9 million so far on the 3.2 million pairs that have been imported thus far. ``What they've done is charge all that excess money to the U.S. consumer, and it's not protecting anything,'' said Carl Davis, Nike's corporate lawyer in Washington, D.C. Air Jordans are assembled with a ``foot frame'' method that attaches soles to uppers differently, he said. ``The game's not over yet,'' he added. ``The only decision we have made is that we'll continue to fight it.'' Davis said the next step would be an appeal to the U.S. Treasury Department, which oversees the Customs Service, or to the U.S. Court of International Trade.

Stock prices sagged today under the weight of persistent worries about rising interest rates. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials dropped 8.33 to 2,724.55 by 3 p.m. on Wall Street. Losers outnumbered gainers by about 5 to 3 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed issues, with 527 up, 902 down and 531 unchanged. Analysts said sentiment among traders was dominated by a recent rise in interest rates and signs of stubborn inflationary pressures. Interest rates, up sharply Tuesday and Wednesday, climbed further in credit-market activity today. Prices of long-term government bonds dropped about $5 for each $1,000 in face value, putting their yields in the 8.85 percent-8.91 percent range. Brokers also said investors were giving mixed reviews to corporate earnings reports for the first quarter. Digital Equipment rose 1~ to 81~ in active trading. The company posted a big drop in quarterly profits, but many Wall Streeters had been expecting the news to be even worse. American Express, which reported a $619.80 million loss for the first quarter, dropped 1 to 27~. Other losers among the blue chips included International Business Machines, down ] at 109{; Coca-Cola, down 1{ at 77}, and Philip Morris, down | at 42. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks fell .56 to 186.37. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index was down 2.07 at 351.15. Volume on the Big Board came to 122.37 million shares with an hour to go.

DOC.HEAD: Quarterly Net Income Inches Up 1 Percent
DOC.TEXT: BankAmerica Corp.'s first-quarter profit edged slightly higher while its per-share earnings dropped 11 percent and the company said Thursday the results reflected an absence of Brazilian cash interest payments and more outstanding stock. The San Francisco-based parent of Bank of America earned $278 million in the three months ended March 31. That was up 1 percent from $275 million in 1989's first quarter, when BankAmerica received $46 million in Brazilian interest payments, which increased net income in that period by $38 million. Earnings per share fell to $1.23 in this year's first quarter from $1.38 a year earlier. The number of common shares outstanding increased 12 percent over the year. ``First-quarter earnings demonstrate continuing success in managing the fundamental areas of our business, producing growth in the volumes of deposits and loan originations, as well as continuing strong credit performance,'' said Chairman A.W. Clausen. BankAmerica in January reported a 52 percent increase in its 1989 earnings, a $1.1 billion figure that represented the highest annual profit ever for the nation's second-largest bank holding concern. As of May 24, Clausen will step down from BankAmerica, the company he joined in 1949 and rose through the ranks to head. Replacing him will be Richard Rosenberg, BankAmerica's vice chairman. Bank of America has 850 California branches.

DOC.HEAD: Citing Shearson Shortfall, Reports $620 Million Loss
DOC.TEXT: American Express Co. reported Thursday it lost $620 million in the first quarter due to losses at its Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. brokerage subsidiary. The loss, which translates to $1.50 a share, compares with earnings of $251.9 million, or 59 cents a share in the same period a year earlier. American Express said its revenue for the quarter totaled $5.9 billion, up 1.4 precent from $5.87 billion in the first three months of 1989. On Wednesday, Shearson said it lost $915 million in the first three months of 1990, the biggest quarterly loss in Wall Street history. The loss included $787 million in charges against earnings and a $128 million operating loss. American Express, which currently holds about 61 percent of Shearson, said its share of the investment firm's operating loss was $96 million, but that it would recognize the entire $787 million in charges because of its plan to acquire all of the outstanding shares in Shearson it travelers checks operations, reported a 16 percent increase in income to $215 million. The IDS Financial Services division, a financial planning business, had a 21 percent increase in income to $44 million. And American Express Information Services Co. had a 27 percent gain in income to $22 million. But the company's American Express Bank, which generally operates outside of the United States, reported earnings of $30 million, down from $35 million a year earlier. Shearson's loss, which had been expected, was partly attributed to a $630 million charge against earnings to pay for a restructuring that included thousands of layoffs and the elimination or reduction of several businesses. The remaining $157 million charge was also attributed to an accounting change in the way Shearson pays for development of computer software.

DOC.HEAD: Late Rally Boosts Crop Futures
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures prices closed moderately higher Thursday on the Chicago Board of Trade, boosted by a late flurry of buying linked in part to delays in the South American soybean harvest. Rainy weather and sweeping economic reforms have slowed the movement of soybeans and soybean meal from Brazil, the world's second-largest soybean producer, analysts said. Some of Thursday's strength in soybean meal futures reflected buying of contracts by users looking to lock in purchase prices in case the South American shipping delays continue, said Joel Karlin, an analyst with Research Department Inc., a Chicago-based brokers' advisory service. The crop markets had opened mostly lower amid concerns that the Soviet Union's reprisals against Lithuania could jeopardize U.S. grain sales to Moscow. But those fears were overshadowed by the soybean rally and by ideas the Soviet Union is seeking to buy more U.S. corn, Karlin said. At the close, wheat futures prices were } cent to 3} cents higher with the contract for delivery in May at $3.69 a bushel; corn was 2} cents to 3} cents higher with May at $2.77{ a bushel; oats were unchanged to \ cent higher with May at $1.57{ a bushel; soybeans were 3{ cents to 6{ cents higher with May at $6.00{ a bushel.

DOC.HEAD: House Panel Approves $1.2 Trillion 1991 Budget Bearing Defense Cuts
DOC.NOTE: EDS: New thruout with House panel action. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: President Bush's plans for nearly $300 billion in defense spending next year came under attack today on Capitol Hill where House budget writers approved deep cuts and Sen. Sam Nunn called for reduction of U.S. forces in Europe. The House Budget Committee passed 21-14 a $1.24 trillion Democratic-written budget that slashed $8 billion from the president's plan for Pentagon spending. The full House is scheduled next week to debate the Democratic proposal to shift the Pentagon money to domestic programs. While the House panel was completing its work, Nunn, the Georgia Democrat who chairs the Senate Armed Services Committee, proposed force reductions in Europe well below the 225,000 baseline proposed by Bush. ``We should start planning on a residual force in Europe on the order of 75,000 to 100,000 troops within five years,'' Nunn said in a speech certain to create a furor within the military services. Nunn's speech coupled with the House committee action represented the fullest statement of budget priorities by Congress' majority Democrats since the Warsaw Pact disintegrated. ``The president's budget virtually ignored the opportunities presented by the dramatic changes taking place in the world,'' said committee Chairman Leon Panetta, D-Calif. ``This budget meets that challenge head-on.'' ``We have a chance to restore the traditional peacetime priorities of our nation at a time when we are faced with tremendous economic challenges at home and abroad,'' said Panetta. Republicans opposed the Democratic plan and insisted that no serious 1991 budget will be written until congressional leaders and the White House hold negotiations. ``We look on this as a Democratic exercise you need to pass through before we go to a summit'' to bargain over the budget, said the panel's ranking Republican, Rep. Bill Frenzel of Minnesota. ``That's fine with us.'' The plan contains $36 billion in deficit reduction and claims to reduce next year's budget gap to $63.5 billion. That would satisfy the Gramm-Rudman law's requirement for a 1991 shortfall of no more than $64 billion. Fiscal 1991 begins Oct. 1. It would spread $6 billion in spending increases among initiatives ranging from highway construction to anti-drug efforts and expanded child care. For its savings, the package relies on $11.5 billion in military cuts, $13.9 billion in new taxes _ the same amount Bush is seeking _ and $5.6 billion in user fees. It reduces the expected growth of Medicare and other benefit programs by $4.2 billion, and claims minor savings in several other areas. Its most controversial element is how defense would be treated in the first federal budget since the disintegration of the Warsaw Pact. Panetta's package would leave next year's military budget at $295 billion in outlays, which is about $1 billion less than is being spent this year and $11.5 billion less than what would be needed to stay even with inflation. The figure also is $8 billion below the amount Bush is seeking. More importantly for the long run, Democrats would also cut next year's military budget authority to $283 billion, some $18 billion below this year and $33 billion less than the amount needed to keep up with inflation. Budget authority is the amount of spending allowed by an agency over a number of years. The reduction is crucial because if enacted, it would signal the beginning of a long-range decline in Pentagon spending. The plan had originally called for $286 billion in defense budget authority, but liberals on the budget panel threatened not to support the package unless the figure was reduced. Over the next five years, defense savings would total $251 billion, a shrinkage of military spending of 25 percent from current projections. Democrats would disperse $106 billion to domestic programs and apply the remaining $145 billion to shrinking the budget gap. The defense figures were worked out in concert with House leaders, who now begin the job of selling them to fellow lawmakers. ``It's a good-sized down payment on greater savings to come,'' said Rep. Les Aspin, D-Wis., chairman of the House Armed Services Committee. But there is dissatisfaction on both sides of the aisle with the defense figures for several reasons. ``We look on it as a meltdown, not a build-down,'' Rep. Bill Frenzel of Minnesota, ranking Republican on the budget panel, said of the Democrats' treatment of the Pentagon. Rep. Ronald Dellums, D-Calif., a liberal, said the figures seemed ``totally inadequate'' because they did not cut deeply enough. A member of the House Appropriations defense subcommittee, Rep. Norman Dicks, D-Wash., complained that budget authority was treated too harshly, saying, ``It would be difficult for me to live with that low a number.'' Progress on the budget is going even more slowly in the Senate. Budget Committee Chairman James Sasser, D-Tenn., is uncertain whether he has enough votes to approve a spending plan, which he wants to include a $15 billion defense cut. The congressional budget document, which does not require the president's signature, is used as a blueprint for the government's fiscal plans. Actual spending and tax decisions are made in other bills later in the year.

DOC.HEAD: Crunch Time for Milken as Government Deadline Approaches
DOC.TEXT: As the government's promised date for a new indictment arrives, financier Michael Milken faces the biggest decision in his lengthy securities fraud case: to plead or not to plead. Attorneys for Milken and the government are involved in negotiations for a possible settlement in the criminal prosecution of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc.'s former high-yield bond chief, sources said Thursday. But it was unclear whether the talks would result in a plea bargain tossing aside a 98-count fraud and racketeering indictment of Milken or whether new charges would be levied by Friday, as the government has promised, and the case proceed to trial. Individuals close to the case said discussions included a possible guilty plea to more than one felony count and penalties in the range of $650 million. But they cautioned the talks did not imply Milken was near agreeing to a plea deal. ``How much can anybody take? It's a very stressful, annoying kind of day-to-day living,'' said one attorney with knowledge of the case. ``(Milken) has to decide whether his position is improved in cutting a deal now or by hanging tough.'' Assistant U.S. Attorney John K. Carroll told a federal judge last month that the government would submit an expanded indictment by the end of this week. Carroll declined to comment Thursday, as did a Milken spokesman. The original indictment of Milken, his brother, Lowell, and former Drexel trader Bruce Newberg amounted to the largest financial crime prosecution in U.S. history. It was handed up in March 1989. The indictment is based largely on information supplied by former stock speculator Ivan Boesky, who recently was released after completing two years of a three-year prison sentence. It is widely assumed that new charges would include allegations stemming from activity that did not involve Boesky, who was implicated in a broad insider trading network and could be an easy target for defense lawyers. By pleading guilty, Milken and the government would avoid a long, costly trial. Milken would avoid a possible jury conviction on dozens of criminal counts that would carry years in prison. The government would avoid the potential embarrassment of losing the most highly touted case in its four-year-long Wall Street fraud crackdown. But sentencing would rest with U.S. District Judge Kimba Wood, so it is impossible to negotiate specific prison time through a plea bargain. Legal observers said the government is unlikely to agree to a one-count plea with a maximum of five years in prison. A single racketeering count carries a maximum 20-year sentence, which also is considered unlikely. Boesky's three years is viewed as a base. ``I think there is a slow process by which a defendant who believes he is innocent is gradually convinced by his attorneys that settlement is the best and most realistic course,'' said John C. Coffee Jr., a securities law professor at Columbia University. Milken has pleaded innocent and has said through his attorney, Arthur Liman, that he intends to fight his case at trial. In addition to ending his ordeal, Milken may be willing to settle if he can cut a deal exonerating his brother, legal experts who have followed the case said. Civil charges also still must be resolved. Milken, 43, is credited with developing the $200 billion market in high-risk securities called junk bonds that were used widely in the 1980s to finance corporate growth and hostile takeovers. The decision by Milken _ a proud man who strongly believes he helped American finance _ on whether to plead guilty is made even more difficult because he is convinced of his innocence, friends say. ``He knows in his heart of hearts that he has total integrity,'' said Dick Riordan, a Los Angeles lawyer and friend of Milken's. ``Now to be told that he doesn't is a hard thing to swallow, very hard.'' Drexel settled fraud charges with the government and the Securities and Exchange Commission last year by agreeing to pay $650 million in penalties and plead guilty to six felonies. The Drexel fine is seen as a benchmark for a Milken plea. Drexel collapsed in February and is liquidating after its parent company filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy court protection.

DOC.HEAD: Promises to Help New Trustee of Eastern
With AM-Eastern-Trustee, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Frank Lorenzo, whose control of Eastern Airlines has been seized by a federal bankruptcy judge, pledged Thursday to help the court-appointed trustee assuming the helm. ``We're going to help in all reasonable ways that we can,'' Lorenzo said in an interview the day after U.S. Bankruptcy Judge Burton R. Lifland designated a trustee to run financially sagging Eastern. After a four-day hearing that ended late Wednesday, Lifland granted the request of Eastern's unsecured creditors to take control of the airline from Lorenzo, chairman of Eastern's parent Texas Air Corp. The creditors, who are owed around $980 million, were angered by Eastern's relentless losses and management's plans to slash debt repayments. Miami-based Eastern, which had fought the creditors' request in court, said Thursday it would not appeal Lifland's appointment of a trustee. The airline has been in bankruptcy reorganization since March 1989, when a strike by employees shut down its operations. While pledging to support the new trustee, airline executive Martin Shugrue, Lorenzo acknowledged that the change in leadership could prompt some Eastern managers to quit. ``It's very difficult to project the future,'' he said. ``There may well be people leaving...but we're just going to have to see.'' Several Eastern executives, including President Phil Bakes, testified in the course of the hearing that appointment of a trustee would cause employee departures, hurt business further and heighten the chance Eastern eventually would have to be liquidated. Lorenzo said the end of his stewardship of Eastern was a relief in some ways, since it will allow him to focus full attention on Continental Airlines, Eastern's non-union sister carrier. Shugrue, a former president of Houston-based Continental, resigned under pressure from Lorenzo. But Lorenzo said Thursday that the decision to let Shugrue go was made by Continental's board of directors. ``Marty is an able airline operator,'' Lorenzo said of Shugrue. ``And he's going to have our support.'' Continental will continue to cooperate with Eastern in joint marketing efforts and frequent flier programs, Lorenzo said.

DOC.BYLINE: Service Sector Helping Inflate Consumer Prices
DOC.TEXT: The cost of a Radisson hotel room in Knoxville, Tenn., has gone up by $5. The soup-and-salad bar tab at an Indianapolis Howard Johnson's restaurant jumped 29 percent. And the Peddie School in Heightstown, N.J., is hiking tuition and room and board $1,500 per student in the coming academic year. A slowing overall economy has helped curb some inflation. But price increases in the service sector _ spurred by higher wages, skyrocketing insurance costs and a shortage of workers _ are leaving no American wallet untouched. ``We're all paying a little more,'' said James F. Smith, a finance professor at the University of North Carolina. Recent government figures sent mixed signals about inflation. The price of finished goods slipped 0.2 percent in March, and further declines in food and energy prices should keep wholesale inflation below last year's rate. But consumer prices jumped an unexpected 0.5 percent last month _ the equivalent of an 8.5 percent annual inflation rate. Economists agree that the service sector accounts for the divergence. The cost of services are factored into consumer prices but are not a component of the government's producer price index. ``It seems that the majority of Americans are employed in the service sector, and that's why inflation seems to be bigger problem,'' said Marc Chandler, an analyst at MMS International in Chicago. Some parts of the service sector have dramatically improved their efficiency, especially banking, retailing and other businesses that have benefited from the information revolution, which lowered costs through automation, Smith said. But a shortage of workers in several regions of the country and the first increase in the minimum wage in nearly a decade are pumping wages higher. While only about 3 million Americans earn the minimum wage _ which increased April 1 to $3.80 an hour from $3.35 _ it sets a floor for other lower-paying jobs. And the cost of higher wages filter through the economy. ``We're like anybody else,'' said Tom Polski, a spokesman for the Radisson chain. ``If the cost of doing business goes up, it has to be passed on to customers.'' Timothy Kennedy said the higher minimum wage has added $90,000 to the $1 million-a-year payroll at the Radisson hotel he manages in Knoxville. Sixty percent of his employees earn the minimum wage. To compensate, Kennedy has boosted room rates by $5 a night, raising the basic single-occupancy rate to $65 a night. And because the other service businesses that feed his hotel are also hiking their prices because of higher costs, the price of a typical menu item at the hotel's restaurant rose by about $1. In areas where workers are in short supply, employers must pay even more to attract them. At McDonald's Corp., which boasts it is not a minimum wage employer, the average worker earns $4.80 an hour, a spokesman said. But many employees in the Boston area, where workers are in demand, earn as much as $7 an hour. Service sector inflation also is shown by other factors, like rising insurance premiums, which account for sharply higher total labor costs. ``The fastest growing component of the consumer price index is medical care, which rose more than 18 percent over the past 12 months,'' said Raymond Stone, of Stone and McCarthy Associates, a consulting firm in Princeton, N.J. At the Peddie School, headmaster Tom DeGray said the school is raising tuition and room and board from the current $14,000 a year to $15,500 this September to help meet mushrooming insurance costs as well as higher teachers' salaries. Teachers' salaries ``are moving up at about 8 percent a year, but insurance costs are going out of sight,'' DeGray said. This year the school will pay about $420,000 for medical insurance for its 150-member faculty and staff; just four years ago the school was paying $240,000 a year for greater benefits. Charles Galbraith, the school's business manager, said if insurance costs go up only 33 percent this year he'll be happy. The ability to pay competitive salaries and keep costs in line for customers require balancing skills that are becoming harder for businesspeople to master. ``Unless we continue to improve salary and benefits, we're not going to be able to keep the finest faculty and attract them,'' DeGray said. And it's no secret who's going to pay for those improvements.

DOC.HEAD: Southmark Earns Right to Sell Insurance Company
DOC.TEXT: Southmark Corp. has reached an agreement that will allow it to sell its insurance company and move closer toward reorganization. The agreement with its common and preferred shareholders to sell Integon Corp. should help the troubled company, which has operated under bankruptcy court supervision since last July, rebound from its financial woes. ``I think we got a real chance to get this thing out of bankruptcy,'' Southmark chairman Arthur Weiss said Wednesday. Southmark offered in January to give equity stockholders 11 percent of the restructured company. But earlier this month, the company reduced that offer to 5 percent. After further talks, Southmark agreed to give 11 percent of the reorganized company to equity shareholders and to give the committee a consulting role. The company's unsecured creditors settled their objections to Southmark's plan earlier this month. The plan would turn over control of the restructured company to its creditors, liquidate most assets and reorganize around its Houston-based thrift. The sale of Integon to Chicago-based Jupiter Industries Inc. and Head Insurance Investors is a complicated cash, stock and note transaction valued at about $189 million. However, Southmark would get $36 million in cash.

Stock prices fell for the second straight session today under the weight of persistent worries about rising interest rates. Analysts said sentiment among traders was dominated by a recent rise in interest rates and signs of stubborn inflationary pressures. Interest rates, up sharply Tuesday and Wednesday, climbed further in credit-market activity today. Prices of long-term government bonds showed spotty losses, putting their yields in the 8.84 percent-8.91 percent range. Brokers also said investors were giving mixed reviews to corporate earnings reports for the first quarter.
