DOC.HEAD: Perrier to Remove `Naturally Sparkling' Claim from its Bottles
DOC.TEXT: The federal government has told Perrier to remove the phrase ``naturally sparkling'' from bottles of the imported mineral water, and the U.S. distributor said Thursday it plans to comply. The Food and Drug Administration said Perrier's claim to be ``naturally sparkling'' is false because the water is not naturally carbonated as it comes out of the ground at a spring in Vergeze, France. The water from the spring is mixed with carbon dioxide from a gas reservoir beneath it and are combined in the factory after impurities in the gas are filtered out. ``The water comes out of the ground and the carbonation is added,'' Bob Crowell, compliance officer in the FDA's Boston district office, said Thursday. Perrier, which plans to reintroduce its product next week after a worldwide recall, said it will comply. Jane Lazgin, a spokeswoman for the Perrier Group of America Inc. in Greenwich, Conn., said the company will obey the FDA, although it believes its product is ``naturally sparkling.'' ``While we do not agree with the need for these changes and feel that our label has always adequately and accurately described our product, we have made these changes to comply with the FDA request and to act responsibly in quickly returning Perrier to our consumers,'' Perrier Group president Ronald V. Davis said in a statement. Lazgin said all Perrier bottled after July 29 would bear the new label, which will say, ``Natural mineral water.'' A side panel will also state: ``Since 1863, bottled only at Source Perrier, Vergeze, France. The carbonation used in Perrier is taken from a naturally occurring source found deep within the earth.'' Source Perrier SA of France began a worldwide recall in February after trace amounts of benzene were discovered in some bottles. Perrier said the water became contaminated because workers had failed to replace filters that remove impurities from the carbon dioxide gas. It said small amounts of elements such as benzene are found in all naturally occurring gases. Perrier said no one's health was ever at risk because of the benzene. But the incident revealed that Perrier, which touted its product as pure and natural, mechanically adds gas to the water and filters out impurities. The company has announced new testing and monitoring procedures to prevent future problems. Lazgin said bottles would return to the shelf April 26, beginning in New York, Miami and Washington. All bottles since the recall will bear the words, ``Nouvelle Production.'' She said surveys of Perrier customers conducted shortly after the recall indicated 84 percent would buy it again.

DOC.HEAD: Fall $1.25 Billion
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Interest rate figures reported by Donoghue's Money Fund Report are for week ended Tuesday. All other figures are for the week ended Wednesday.
DOC.TEXT: Assets of the nation's 508 money market mutual funds fell $1.25 billion in the latest week, the Investment Company Institute said Thursday. The decline, to $388.60 billion in the seven-day period ended Wednesday, followed a $685.5 million decrease in fund assets the previous week. The Washington-based mutual fund trade group originally had reported the previous week decline as $667.6 million but subsequently revised it. The institute said that in the latest week, assets of 240 general purpose funds fell $467.3 million to $133.05 billion, assets of 102 broker-dealer funds increased $237.3 million to $165.32 billion, and assets of 160 institutional funds fell $1.02 billion to $90.23 billion. The seven-day average yield on money market mutual funds in the week ended Tuesday remained unchanged at 7.69 percent, said Donoghue's Money Fund Report, a trade journal based in Holliston, Mass. The 30-day average yield remained unchanged at 7.68 percent, Donoghue's said. The average maturity of the portfolios held by money funds was 44 days, down from 45 days, Donoghue's said. The newsletter Bank Rate Monitor said its survey of 100 leading commercial banks, savings and loan associations and savings banks in the nation's 10 largest markets showed the effective annual yield available on money market accounts fell to 6.24 percent as of Wednesday from 6.25 percent a week earlier. The North Palm Beach, Fla.-based newsletter said the effective annual yield available on special savings accounts, called Super NOW accounts, was unchanged at 5.05 percent. Bank Rate Monitor said the effective annual yield was 7.91 percent on six-month certificates of deposit, unchanged from a week earlier. Yields were 8.03 percent on 1-year CDs, down from 8.04 percent; 8.06 percent on 2{-year CDs, down from 8.07 percent; and 8.11 percent on 5-year CDs, unchanged.

DOC.HEAD: Colgate-Palmolive Reports 21 Percent First-Quarter Earnings Gain
DOC.TEXT: Colgate-Palmolive Co. said Thursday its first-quarter earnings rose 21 percent as its revenue increased 8 percent. The consumer products company said it earned $81.2 million, or $1.16 a share, up from $67.2 million, or 98 cents a share, during the first three months of 1989. First-quarter revenue totaled $1.3 billion, up from $1.2 billion a year earlier. The company reported increases in its domestic and international businesses. Colgate-Palmolive said it had lower interest expenses, but this was offset by a higher tax rate.

DOC.HEAD: Bristol-Myers Squibb Profits Up 19.1 Percent in First Quarter
DOC.TEXT: Bristol-Myers Squibb Co. said Thursday its first-quarter earnings rose 19.1 percent as its sale picked up by 8.5 percent. The pharmaceutical company said it earned nearly $409.1 million, or 78 cents a share, up from $343.6 million, or 66 cents a share, a year earlier. Sales for the quarter increased to $2.46 billion from $2.26 million. Bristol-Myers Squibb was formed last year by the $11 billion stock-swap merger between Bristol-Myers Co. and Squibb Corp. The company reported gains in both its domestic and international businesses. Separately, Bristol-Myers Squibb said it had agreed to sell its Genetic Systems Corp. to Sanofi Inc. for an undisclosed amount. Genetic Systems develops and markets tests for infectious diseases, including a test for AIDS. Sanofi is owned by the French firm Societe Nationale Elf Aquitane.

DOC.HEAD: Union Leaders Seek Talks to End Strike
LaserPhoto MH5
DOC.TEXT: Eastern Airlines's striking Machinists, victorious in their quest to outlast company boss Frank Lorenzo, looked ahead Thursday to negotiating a back-to-work pact that could include deep concessions. ``There obviously is going to be tremendous sacrifices over the next year, maybe two years or more, to bring us back to normalcy ... but it's not going to be done in the interest of Frank Lorenzo,'' Eastern Machinist president Charles Bryan told about 100 strikers gathered at union headquarters near Miami International Airport. Lorenzo, chairman of Eastern's parent Texas Air Corp., was ousted from control of Eastern late Wednesday in Manhattan by U.S. Bankruptcy Judge Burton Lifland, who named former airline executive Martin Shugrue as special trustee of the Miami-based carrier. Appointment of a trustee had been a major goal for striking workers, who contend Lorenzo has funneled valuable Eastern assets to non-union sister carrier Continental Airlines. Lifland made the appointment after Eastern's unsecured creditors, who are owed $980 million, argued that present management was unable to bring the company out of its financial tailspin. Eastern officials said Thursday they will not appeal the appointment and lauded Lifland's indications that the airline can be reorganized rather than liquidated. Eastern spokesman Bob Hunter said the court's decision to release $80 million from Eastern's escrow account will keep the carrier in operation through mid-1990. ``It's still business as usual,'' said Hunter. But problems remain. Eastern lost $852.3 million last year, and creditors say the company has failed to regain the confidence of consumers and travel agents since the strike. Several top Eastern executives told the bankruptcy court that appointment of a trustee could hurt business further and cause employee departures. Furthermore, the company still must reach long-term contract agreements with its unions. Nevertheless, Shugrue issued a statement projecting optimism about Eastern's future. ``I want to reassure the community of travel agents and the flying public that Eastern is flying, that it is flying safely and reliably, and with an unparalleled level of service and enthusiasm,'' he said. The Machinists are seeking talks as soon as possible, but returning members to the hangars and runways could take some time, said union leaders. ``Our main goal now is getting back to work,'' said Frank Ortis, president of the Machinists' Miami local. ``But we will remain on strike until an agreement is reached. We've worked to hard to make any moves now that we'd regret later.'' Eastern's Machinists, pilots and flight attendants unions went on strike March 4, 1989, following lengthy, bitter contract negotiations. The strike forced the company to seek bankruptcy court protection from creditors five days later. Of the 9,000 Machinists who walked off the job, about 7,500 have indicated a desire to return to Eastern, said Ortis. About 2,500 workers could be brought back immediately following a strike settlement, he said. Flight attendants and pilots ended their strikes in November, but few have returned to Eastern because of limited openings. The company has shrunk its operations since the strike and hired replacement workers to fill many positions. Many of the strikers said they would accept some wage and benefit cuts in order to get back on the job. ``If it was up to me, I'd be back to work today,'' said Willie Washington, 47, who has worked as a part-time substitute teacher during the strike. ``The goal of this strike was to get rid of Lorenzo and go back to work. Well, we're almost finished.'' Inside union headquarters, many anti-Lorenzo relics remain: cartoons depicting him as a sinister union-buster and bumper stickers with a red stripe across Lorenzo's name. But a bulletin board once covered with newspaper clips o the strike was stripped clean. A sign on top read: ``After Lorenzo.'' ``We are not in a position now to say that everything's over. We have a long and a very complicated road ahead of us, but certainly this is a giant step _ an enormous step _ to get us to our goal of bringing Eastern Airlines back to pre-eminence in the airline industry,'' Bryan said. Bryan declined to make direct comments concerning Shugrue, but said Shugrue's experience in aviation was encouraging. Shugrue, a pilot, worked as a Pan Am Corp. executive before becoming president of Houston-based Continental. Shugrue left Continental under pressure from Lorenzo a month before the Eastern strike. Shugrue was a consultant to former major league baseball commissioner Peter Ueberroth in a union-supported effort to acquire Eastern last year.

DOC.HEAD: Oil Futures Prices Rebound Sharply
With AM-OPEC, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Crude oil futures prices staged a dramatic rebound Thursday, spiking higher following news that OPEC has called a special emergency session to review deteriorating oil prices. On the New York Mercantile Exchange, the contract for May delivery of West Texas Intermediate, the benchmark grade of U.S. crude oil, jumped $1.10 per 42-gallon barrel to settle at $18.06. On Wednesday the contract traded as low as $16.60 a barrel, its worst level since December 1988. Because the May contract expires Friday, it typically is more volatile. Other contract months showed smaller gains. June crude gained 78 cents a barrel while July rose 67 cents. Prices rallied immediately after word spread that a special session of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries' eight-member monitoring panel would meet on May 2 in Geneva. Traders scrambled to cover short positions, and volume was heavy throughout the session. The market ``is anticipating there will be cutbacks'' in OPEC overproduction, said Andrew Lebow, an analyst at E.D.&F. Man International Inc. Analysts estimated the 13-nation cartel was pumping more than 24 million barrels of crude a day, well over its ceiling of 22.1 million barrels a day for the first half of the year. Analysts say Kuwait and the United Arab Emirates have persistently exceeded their OPEC supply quotas and are believed to be producing most of the cartel's excess crude. Traders are hoping that OPEC members will agree to stop overproducing so that prices will stabilize. ``It always makes the market nervous when there's any sort of meeting coming up,'' said John O'Connell, senior energy analyst at Refco Inc. ``If (OPEC) called a meeting, they must be concerned.'' Refined petroleum products traded on the Merc also rose after finishing mixed on Wednsday. The contract for May delivery of unleaded gasoline jumped 2.23 cents to settle at 61.78 cents a gallon after losing 0.89 cent on Wednesday. Other contract months posted similar gains. Home-heating oil for May delivery dropped rose 0.11 cent to 52.80 a gallon after losing 1.51 cents on Wednesday. But other contract months showed far stronger gains. June heating oil surged 1.24 cents a gallon while July was up 1.45 cents. Meanwhile, natural gas for June delivery settled at $1.570 per million British thermal units, off from $1.583 on Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: Dayton Hudson To Buy Marshall Field's
DOC.TEXT: Minneapolis retailer Dayton Hudson Corp. on Thursday added a new jewel to its department store crown, announcing it has reached agreement to buy Marshall Field & Co. for about $1.04 billion. ``We view this as a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity,'' Dayton Hudson chairman Kenneth Macke said in announcing the agreement to purchase Field's from BAT Industries PLC, a British conglomerate. ``This is a great strategic fit for us.'' At a Chicago news conference, Macke said his company expects to complete the deal for Field's, which operates 24 stores in Illinois, Ohio, Wisconsin and Texas, within the next two months. He said Dayton Hudson had no immediate plans to close any Field's stores or make dramatic changes in Field's strategy, and reiterated a commitment to the ongoing renovation of Field's flagship store in Chicago's Loop. The acquisition will be financed with a combination of internally generated funds and a mix of debt instruments, the retailer said. Dayton Hudson does not plan an equity offering. ``We will have absolutely no problem financing the deal,'' said Macke, who added that junk bonds would play no role in the purchase. Thursday's announcement capped a buyout effort by a number of groups, including current Marshall Field chairman and chief executive officer Philip Miller and a Field's management team. Miller, who is widely credited with helping turn Field's around in the past five years, said he was disappointed by the news but was taking a wait-and-see attitude before announcing any plans. ``We don't have any indication as to what Dayton-Hudson's plans are,'' Miller said in a telephone interview. ``Until we understand that, we're encouraging all our people to keep their powder dry.'' Miller said he believed until Thursday that his group was the front runner in the bidding for Field's. ``It's always a surprise when you lose,'' he added. A BAT executive said there was nothing wrong with the Field's management bid, but Dayton Hudson's was better. ``The fact is that the Dayton Hudson bid was clearly superior in financial terms,'' said Arthur Martinez, a senior vice president of Batus Inc., BAT's U.S. subsidiary. ``Simply put, it was higher. In other dimensions, it was a simpler proposal for us to deal with.'' While saying it was too early to discuss management changes, Macke and Dayton Hudson President Stephen Watson said they planned to meet with Miller soon. ``Phil Miller and his team have done an extraordinary job ... of building this company,'' Watson said. Others said to be bidding for Field's were May Department Stores Co., based in St. Louis, and Dillard Department Stores Inc., based in Little Rock, Ark. Analyst Marcia Raley, of Dain Bosworth Inc. in Minneapolis, said the purchase would appear to be a good deal for Dayton Hudson. ``The fit is exceptionally good,'' she said. ``I think it's a very, very strong strategic bid for them,'' she said, adding the acquisition price appeared to fair. ``There's been a lot of distressed merchandise that has been on the market,'' she said. ``But Marshall Field is not a distressed operation _ it's a very high quality operation.'' Marshall Field's, one of the country's best known department store groups, was put up for sale last year by BAT as part of a restructuring to defend itself against a hostile takeover bid by Sir James Goldsmith. BAT, a large conglomerate with interests ranging from tobacco to financial services and retailing, also is selling its Saks Fifth Avenue division. Dayton Hudson's department store division operates 37 stores known as either Dayton's or Hudson's in their respective markets in seven Midwestern states. Dayton Hudson also owns the Target chain, one of the country's biggest discounters with 408 stores in 32 states, and Mervyn's, a moderate-price department store company with 221 stores in 15 states. In 1989, revenues for its department store division, which employs more than 22,000 people, were $1.8 billion, and its operating profit was $179 million.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with closing prices throughout.
DOC.TEXT: The stock market recorded its second straight loss Thursday, beset by persistent worries about rising interest rates. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials fell 20.94 to 2,711.94, extending its drop over the last two sessions to 53.83 points. Declining issues outnumbered advances by more than 9 to 5 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed stocks, with 511 up, 968 down and 521 unchanged. Volume on the floor of the Big Board came to 152.93 million shares, against 147.13 million in the previous session. Nationwide, consolidated volume in NYSE-listed issues, including trades in those stocks on regional exchanges and in the over-the-counter market, totaled 184.95 million shares. Analysts said sentiment among traders was dominated by a recent rise in interest rates and signs of stubborn inflationary pressures. Interest rates, up sharply Tuesday and Wednesday, climbed further in credit-market activity Thursday. Prices of long-term government bonds slipped about $2.50 for each $1,000 in face value, putting their yields in the 8.84 percent-8.91 percent range. Brokers also said investors were giving mixed reviews to corporate earnings reports for the first quarter. While a few companies have chalked up better-than-expected showings, analysts say the positive surprises haven't been consistent enough to bolster confidence in the market as a whole. In addition, observers say the latest rise in interest rates has clouded hopes for an improved profit performance later in the year. Digital Equipment rose 2[ to 82[ in active trading. The company posted a big drop in quarterly profits, but many Wall Streeters had been expecting the news to be even worse. American Express, which reported a $619.80 million loss for the first quarter, fell 1\ to 27|. Other losers among the blue chips included International Business Machines, down } at 109[; Philip Morris, down ~ at 41}; Coca-Cola, down 1~ at 77], and General Electric, down } at 65}. Comdisco tumbled 8{ to 18, suffering the day's biggest percentage setback, as the company projected a substantial decline in its quarterly profits. Reebok International lost 1{ to 17{ on the company's report of a quarterly earnings gain that fell short of estimates. Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, the most active Big Board issue, jumped 1 to 4\ on takeover rumors and speculation. As measured by Wilshire Associates' index of more than 5,000 actively traded stocks, the market lost $23.73 billion, or 0.73 percent, in value. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks dropped 1.36 to 185.57. Standard & Poor's industrial index fell 3.07 to 392.74, and S&P's 500-stock composite index was down 2.63 at 338.09. The NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market slumped 2.52 to 429.00. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index closed at 350.73, down 2.49.

DOC.HEAD: Georgia Gulf Shareholders Approve Recapitalization
DOC.TEXT: Georgia Gulf Corp. shareholders on Thursday approved a recapitalization of the company, a move management proposed three months ago to ward off a takeover bid by Texas investor Harold Simmons. The company did not release the vote totals, but said if financing is completed as expected the recapitalization will take effect April 27. Simmons, who owns about 10 percent of the chemical maker's stock, said earlier this month he was abandoning his $1.1 billion tender offer for Georgia Gulf and instead would support the proposed recapitalization. Under the approved plan, each holder of a share of Georgia Gulf stock will receive $30 in cash, one share of a new issue of common stock and $8.50 a share in notes. Stockholders also were given the option of trading their common stock at the rate of one share for 5.5 shares of new common stock. The original recapitalization plan called for $38 in cash but there was doubt expressed that the company could sell the necessary junk bonds to finance that offer. Analysts previously have had mixed reactions to the move, noting that it would put the company heavily in debt. Simmons, through his company NL Industries, is expected to realize about $15 million in profits from the recapitalization. Meanwhile Thursday, Georgia Gulf announced its first quarter earnings declined 33 percent from the same period in 1989. Net income for the quarter was $37.4 million or $1.52 a share, down from $55.4 million or $2.12 a share during the same three months last year. Net sales also fell to $251.6 million from $317.8 million. Jerry R. Satrum, Georgia Gulf's president and chief operating officer, said the decline was ``substantial,'' and said it was partly a result of having to compare earnings to record levels achieved a year ago. ``During 1989, and in particular the first two quarters of that year, business conditions were robust and pricing reflected spot shortages for most products we manufacture,'' Satrum said. ``Despite the fact that we were unable to maintain this momentum, we are pleased with the company's progress so far this year given the obvious slowdown in the general economy,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: SEC Eases Rules on Trading Privately Placed Securities
DOC.TEXT: The Securities and Exchange Commission made it easier Thursday for big institutional investors to trade privately in unregistered stocks and bonds, a move expected to help lower the cost of raising money for U.S. companies. The new rule helps cut costs partly by easing disclosure requirements for companies making so-called private placements. It also is seen as making the market for such securities more liquid by clearly defining who may buy and sell them. That eliminates an uncertainty that made them unattractive to large investors and forced many issuers to sell the securities at a discount. The rule change also is an attempt to woo foreign corporations _ previously put off by onerous U.S. disclosure requirements _ to raise capital here. The SEC requires companies offering stock to the public to register and make extensive disclosures about ownership, financing and other issues, to protect investors. But the SEC eased restrictions on trading of privately offered securities, which aren't required to register and aren't bound by U.S. disclosure regulations. Only large institutional investors like banks, pension funds and insurance companies that already hold $100 million in securities can qualify for the new private placement restrictions, with certain exceptions. The SEC, which has one vacancy, approved the measure 4-0. The rule, Rule 144a, set a high threshold for participating in the private placement market to screen out unsophisticated investors who are more in need of such disclosures provided by SEC regulation of public offerings. The SEC also approved rule changes that would make the National Association of Securities Dealers' PORTAL trading system the market place for such unregistered securities and would clarify regulations governing foreign transactions of unregistered securities. ``These rules will have a profound and beneficial effect upon the ability of issuers to raise capital in the context of today's global marketplace, and will enhance the competitiveness and efficiency of our domestic markets,'' said SEC Chairman Richard C. Breeden, who has been pushing to make the U.S. securities laws and markets more competitive with foreign markets. ``The result should be a lower cost of capital in our markets,'' Breeden said at the beginning of the three-hour meeting before a standing room only crowd of more than 200. Linda C. Quinn, head of the SEC's Corporation Finance Division, said the rule change would make it easier to sell privately placed, unregistered securities. ``It says that if you have a security that hasn't been registered and you want to resell it without any conditions, you can do it as long as you resell it to the right person and that's the ($100 million institutional investor) requirement,'' she said. ``Currently the law is unclear as to when you can resell it.'' Exceptions to the $100 million requirement are banks and savings and loans, which must have net worth of $25 million in addition to the $100 million securities holding; and registered broker-dealers that either own and manage $10 million in securities, or act as riskless principles for qualified institutional buyers. The rule changes will not affect small investors unless they have money in a big pension fund or mutual fund that invests in privately-offered securities. Breeden said that according to some reports, the market for privately placed securities has grown from $15.8 billion in 1980 to $170.4 billion last year. ``We hope this rule will have a beneficial effect even on people who don't buy securities at all,'' Breeden told reporters after the meeting. ``To the extent that we can reduce the cost of U.S. companies raising capital, that'll benefit the people who work for those companies, benefit the U.S. economy broadly by helping make us more competitive.''

DOC.HEAD: Oil Rebounds On OPEC News
DOC.TEXT: Oil futures prices rebounded strongly Thursday on the New York Mercantile Exchange on news that OPEC had called an emergency meeting to discuss the recent plunge in oil prices. On other commodity markets Thursday, grain and soybean futures rose; livestock and meat were mostly higher; and precious metals were mixed. Some energy analysts regarded the OPEC announcement as a ploy to keep prices from falling further in hopes that a seasonal rise in gasoline demand will sop up the crude oil surplus, eliminating the need for a cut in OPEC production quotas. ``Basically, this is a little bit of a stability conspiracy,'' said Peter Beutel, the head of energy trading for Elders Futures Inc. Nonetheless, West Texas Intermediate crude oil settled 16 cents to $1.10 higher with the contract for delivery in May up $1.10 at $18.06 a barrel; heating oil was .11 cent to 1.45 cents higher with May at 52.80 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was 1.35 cent to 2.23 cents higher with May at 61.78 cents a gallon. All 13 members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries will attend a May 2 special meeting of OPEC's price-monitoring committee, the cartel's acting president, Sadek Boussena, said Thursday. He said the meeting was called to discuss the recent drop in crude oil prices to 16-month lows, a decline that market analysts have blamed on OPEC overproduction during a period of weak seasonal demand. The OPEC members probably could firm up the oil market quickly by cutting their own production quotas but some analysts said the cartel is unlikely to do so. They said OPEC is more likely to hold out the possibility of quota cuts while it waits for the seasonal increase in gasoline production to eliminate the crude oil surplus. That increase has already begun, analysts said, citing Tuesday's American Petroleum Institute inventory survey, which showed only a slight rise in U.S. crude oil stocks and a dramatic increase in U.S. refinery activity. The 3.3 percent rise in refinery runs indicated most refiners have completed their springtime ``turnarounds,'' when they shut down to retool for more gasoline and less heating oil production. By June 25, the rescheduled date of OPEC's mid-year conference, the current crude oil glut may have been reduced to the point where OPEC no longer needs to consider cutting quotas, Beutel said. In the meantime, he said, OPEC members may continue to hint at quota cuts just to keep prices from falling. Tom Bentz, director of trading for United Energy Inc., agreed: ``It's basically a ploy to stabilize the market a little longer until they can make it to June.'' Grain and soybean futures rose moderately on the Chicago Board of Trade, boosted by a late flurry of buying linked in part to delays in the South American soybean harvest. Rainy weather and sweeping economic reforms have slowed the movement of soybeans and soybean meal from Brazil, the world's second-largest soybean producer, analysts said. Wheat futures settled } cent to 3} cents higher with May at $3.69 a bushel; corn was 2{ cents to 3} cents higher with May at $2.77 a bushel; oats were \ cent to { cent higher with May at $1.57} a bushel; soybeans were 3{ cents to 6{ cents higher with May at $6.00{ a bushel. Cattle futures ended mixed on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange while pork futures rose sharply, paced by limit gains in the pork belly market amid stronger cash markets and bullish chart signals. Live cattle were unchanged to .15 cent higher with April at 79.92 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .25 cent lower to .30 cent higher with April at 84.05 cents a pound; live hogs were .05 cent to .75 cent higher with April at 57.47 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .85 cent to the limit 2 cents higher with May at 61.42 cents a pound. On New York's Commodity Exchange, gold futures ended $1 to $1.20 higher with April at $377.30 a troy ounce; silver was unchanged to 0.3 cent lower with May at $5.078 a troy ounce.

DOC.HEAD: Bear Stearns Profits Fall In Quarter
DOC.TEXT: Bear Stearns & Co. said Thursday that profit in its third quarter fell 16 percent and revenue declined 5.8 percent in another indication of Wall Street's recession. The brokerage reported net income of $34.6 million, or 34 cents a share, for the three months ended March 30, compared with $41.1 million, or 39 cents a share, in the same period a year earlier. Revenue fell to $588 million in its third fiscal quarter from $624 million a year earlier. Bear Stearns' fiscal year does not correspond to the calendar year. ``We are very pleased with the results for the third quarter as we continue to be operating in a very difficult market environment,'' Bear Stearns Chairman and Chief Executive Alan C. Greenberg said in a statement. Firms across Wall Street still are having trouble rebounding from the 1987 stock market crash. Business in key areas such as stock and bond underwriting, investment banking and retail brokerage activity all are down. In addition, the first three months of 1990 have been worse than figures released by the firms appear because the comparable 1989 period was particularly weak. For the nine-month period, Bear Stearns said net income was $85.9 million, or 82 cents a share, down 32 percent from $125 million, or $1.16 a share, in the same year-ago period. Revenue for Bear Stearns' first three quarters was $1.75 billion, up slightly from $1.74 billion for the comparable period a year earlier.

DOC.HEAD: Money Supply Higher
DOC.TEXT: The two broadest measures of the nation's money supply rose in the week ended April 9, the Federal Reserve Board reported Thursday. The Fed said the measure known as M2 rose to a seasonally adjusted $3,275.8 billion from $3,269.3 billion the previous week. An even broader measure, M3, rose to a seasonally adjusted $4,076.5 billion from $4,063.7 billion. The narrowest measure of the money supply, M1, fell to a seasonally adjusted $805.6 billion from $808 billion. M1 includes cash in circulation, deposits in checking accounts and non-bank travelers checks. M2 is M1 plus accounts like savings deposits and money-market mutual funds. M3 is M2 plus less-liquid accounts, such as certificates of deposit in minimum denominations of $100,000. In judging its monetary policy, the Fed has indicated it is monitoring the value of the dollar, commodity prices and the difference between short- and long-term interest rates. It also has shifted its attention from M1 to the two broader money supply measures. The annual growth rate in M2 so far this year is 5.8 percent, which is within the Fed's target range of 3 percent to 7 percent. The annual growth rate in M3 is 3.0 percent, which is below the Fed's target range of 3.5 percent to 7.5 percent. The Fed has not set a target for M1 growth since early 1987. For the latest 13 weeks, M2 averaged $3,255.5 billion, a 6.3 percent seasonally adjusted annual rate of gain from the previous 13 weeks. M3 averaged $4,062.4 billion, up 3.1 percent, while M1 rose 4.8 percent to an average of $801.2 billion. In other reports: _The Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported commercial and industrial loans at major New York City banks fell $429 million. _The Federal Reserve said bank borrowings from the Federal Reserve System at the discount window, excluding extended credit, averaged $296 million a day in the week ended Wednesday, up from $116 million the previous week. _The Federal Reserve said net free reserves averaged $576 million in the two weeks ended Wednesday, down from the previous two-week period. _The Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis reported that the monetary base, the seasonally adjusted total of member bank reserves held at Federal Reserve banks and cash in bank vaults and in circulation, was $304.5 billion in the two-week period ended Wednesday, up from $302.1 billion two weeks earlier.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Mixed, Gold Up
DOC.TEXT: The dollar was mixed Thursday in domestic foreign exchange trading, losing ground against a revived Japanese yen but rising against most other major currencies. Gold prices moved higher. Analysts said rumors in the markets that the Japanese were about to push their interest rates higher _ placing the yen in a better position to compete with the dollar _ put pressure on the U.S. currency. Jack Barbanel, president of First Global Asset Management Inc., said the dollar has not performed as well as might have been expected in recent days, given an improvement in the U.S. trade deficit and an increase in market interest rates in the United States this week. Barbanel said exchange rates may be stabilizing, or foreign currencies may be enjoying a technical bounce after the dollar's recent rise. Overseas dealers said the yen's modest recovery after weeks of declines was a result of a range of events, notably a rebound on the Tokyo stock exchange and reported comments from U.S. Treasury officials that they viewed the dollar as too strong. The dollar closed in Tokyo at 157.75 yen, down 2.12 yen from the Wednesday close. Later in London, the dollar traded lower at 156.40 yen. In New York the dollar fell sharply to 157.25 yen from 158.125 late Wednesday. The British pound was quoted at $1.6448, up from $1.6347 late Wednesday. In New York the pound fetched $1.6450, up from $1.6400. Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Wednesday's prices, included: 1.6787 West German marks, up from 1.6720; 1.4847 Swiss francs, up from 1.4785; 5.6425 French francs, up from 5.6200; 1,233.50 Italian lire, up from 1,228.25; and 1.16225 Canadian dollars, up from 1.16135. Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Wednesday: 1.6755 West German marks, up from 1.6720; 1.4815 Swiss francs, down from 1.4876; 5.6325 French francs, up from 5.6315; 1.8820 Dutch guilders, down from 1.8855; 1,231.25 Italian lire, up from 1,230.50; 1.1618 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1640. Gold rose $1.20 a troy ounce on the Commodity Exchange in New York, closing at $377.20, and was later quoted at a bid $377 by Republic National Bank of New York, up 70 cents from late Wednesday. Gold traded in London late Thursday at $376.55 a troy ounce, up from $375.00 late Wednesday. In Zurich, gold fetched $376.25 vs. $375.50 late Wednesday. In Hong Kong, gold rose $1.93 to close at $377.80. Silver rose 0.2 cent on the Commodity Exchange, closing at $5.067 a troy ounce. Silver traded in London at $5.10 a troy ounce, down from $5.11 late Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: Dramatic Decision Stripped Texas Air Boss of Control Over Eastern
DOC.TEXT: Outside the windows of the federal bankruptcy courthouse, the fading sun reddened the sky over New York harbor. Inside, the sun was setting on Frank Lorenzo's reign over Eastern Airlines. David I. Shapiro, the court-appointed examiner for Eastern, had remained uncharacteristically quiet through most of the four-day hearing over a request by creditors to put an outside trustee in charge of the airline. Now, at around 7:20 p.m. Wednesday, all the witnesses had been heard and Shapiro let loose. ``The issue in this case is $1.2 billion in losses within a year,'' thundered Shapiro, a bear of a man known as a tough mediator. ``Can Mr. Lorenzo now be allowed to wipe out the creditors' interest? ... Can anyone blame the creditors for being outraged?'' The 100 or so people packed into the small courtroom of U.S. Bankruptcy Judge Burton R. Lifland hung on every word. Attorneys for Eastern's unions, which shut down the airline in March 1989, had been dreaming of such a moment for more than a year. From the outset, the unions had demanded that a special trustee be appointed to take control of Eastern from Lorenzo, chairman of Eastern's parent Texas Air Corp. But they had gained a powerful new ally in recent weeks. The committee of Eastern's unsecured creditors, exasperated by the airline's staggering losses and plans to slash debt payments, had asked Lifland to appoint a trustee. Attorneys for Eastern and Texas Air, their table littered with documents, pens and bottles of mineral water, had called a stream of witnesses to fight the creditors' motion. After Shapiro, lawyers for the creditors and for Eastern would be speaking. Then it would be Lifland's turn. The Staten Island ferry plied across the harbor as the red sky turned to indigo and lights flickered. It was 7:45. Shapiro homed in more closely on the man at the center of the courtroom drama, the man who insists he is an airline builder while labor calls him a union-buster. ``Mr. Lorenzo only starts negotiating at the very last minute,'' the Washington attorney said. ``He's just a tough guy to make a deal with.'' Lorenzo didn't hear Shapiro's closing statement. He had left the courthouse earlier after testifying as the final witness of the hearing. Indeed, Lorenzo seemed to be doing some negotiating from the witness box in his last few hours as Eastern's chief. He offered a new reorganization proposal that would give the unsecured creditors about 30 cents for every dollar owed, up from a previous offer of about 27{ cents that creditors had rejected. Lorenzo, the son of Spanish immigrants and the head of an airline empire, raised his right hand and was sworn in by the court reporter just before 6 p.m. He was questioned first by Robert Sisk, an attorney for Texas Air, who asked him about his history, his relationship with Eastern President Phil Bakes and the links between Eastern and its parent. Lorenzo, wearing a conservative navy suit, blue shirt and reddish tie, looked tired as he answered Sisk's questions. About 15 minutes into his testimony, he carefully poured a glass of water from the aluminum pitcher in the witness box. Ten minutes later, he arched his back and leaned his head back almost horizontally in his chair. Later, he stretched out his right arm and drummed his fingers on the wood of the box a few times. At around 6:40, he put his hands together in a prayer-like position tucked under his chin. ``We're pretty proud of our track record,'' he told the court, noting how he had successfully taken Eastern's sister Continental Airlines out of Chapter 11 bankruptcy. After a brief cross-examination by creditors' attorney Joel Zweibel and some pointed questions from Lifland, Lorenzo stepped down. After four days of agonizingly slow hearings, time started telescoping _ like the last bit of sand running through an hourglass. After a recess, it was time for Shapiro's statement, followed by summations by Zweibel and Bruce Zirinsky, the lead attorney for Eastern. The union lawyers remained silent. Interrupting the speakers from time to time, Lifland started giving increasingly strong indications that he might take the radical step of appointing a trustee. He referred to Lorenzo's ``wheel of power'' and the strong relationship between Texas Air and Eastern, lashing out at Zirinsky's attempts to demarcate the two. As the harbor sky turned from indigo to jet-black, Lifland declared one last recess, for an hour. When court reconvened, he said, he would render his opinion. As they ran out of the courthouse for a quick dinner, some skeptical union lawyers still weren't convinced that Lifland would opt for a trustee. They were afraid that Lorenzo, the consummate dealmaker, might still pull a last-minute agreement with the creditors out of his hat. ``It's this hour that makes me nervous,'' confided Bruce Simon, an attorney for the Air Line Pilots Association. The courtroom filled up again at around 9:15 as people waited for Lifland to emerge from his chambers with a written opinion in his hand. At around 10, Lifland appeared. ``The air conditioning must be off,'' he noted as he sat down at the bench. The chief judge of the U.S. Bankuptcy Court for the Southern District of New York started reading, citing a litany of legal cases. ``The flying public's interest must at all times be taken into account,'' he said. ``It's time to change the captain of Eastern's crew.'' Frank Lorenzo had been thrown out of the cockpit.

DOC.HEAD: Makers Recall Infant Pillows Involved in 19 Deaths
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts 1 graf of company comment after 2nd graf pvs; SUBS 2 grafs for 19th graf pvs, An unidentified ... Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Manufacturers on Thursday recalled more than 600,000 infant pillows and cushions linked to the suffocation deaths of 19 children. The government said parents should stop using any similar pillows. One firm whose pillows were involved with ``more than several deaths'' was resisting the recall and could face legal action, said an official with the Consumer Product Safety Commission. But a spokesman for the company, Comfort Products of Dallas, said that the firm's president would meet with CPSC officials Friday and that an agreement was expected. ``Today we are announcing that nine of the 10 firms that made these cushions have agreed to recall their products from the public,'' said Jacqueline Jones-Smith, chairwoman of the Consumer Product Safety Commission. ``Regardless of who made the product ... we urge consumers to please, please, please stop using it immediately,'' added David Schmeltzer, head of the CPSC's compliance division. He said the recall could eventually include nearly a million pillows. Nineteen children 3 months or younger have been ``found dead, lying stomach-down'' on the cushions since September 1987, said Jones-Smith. Three of the deaths occurred in January and February of this year. Ten deaths occurred last year. Using a doll, Schmeltzer demonstrated how the soft, pliable pillows conform to shape and could engulf a child placed faced down on them. Because infants often are unable to roll over by themselves, they can suffocate when placed in that position on the cushions. Sen. Alfonse D'Amato, R-N.Y., who has been critical of the commission, said, ``This action should have taken place months ago.'' D'Amato last month criticized the CPSC for having ``an entirely too casual attitude'' about taking legal action against the pillow manufacturers. The commission issued a warning March 6 urging parents to discontinue use of the pillows, but it did not move to ban the pillows because such actions can take longer than a voluntary recall, said spokesman Dan Rumelt. The commission said negotiations had included all makers of an estimated 950,000 pillows produced since 1985. The recall involves 627,825 small pillows or cushions filled with plastic foam beads marketed by six manufacturers who the commission said would begin their recalls on Thursday. Three additional producers have agreed ``in principle'' with the recall and details on their response would be made available in the next few days, the CPSC said. As for the company that has resisted the recall, Schmeltzer said, ``If agreement by that company is not reached shortly the staff will recommend to the commission appropriate legal action to try and rectify the situation.'' ``We believe there have been more than several deaths that have been involved with that company's product,'' he added. Schmeltzer said the firm has not notified its distributors but has stopped manufacturing its product. The CPSC said it was prohibited from identifying the company. However, private consumer advocate David Snow, who met this week with CPSC officials, said it was Comfort Products of Dallas. Patty Lifsey Lakstigala of San Diego, whose 2-month-old son Kailan was found lying face down on a ``Comfort Tote'' cushion on Feb. 24, also said she had learned the company would not be participating in the recall. The spokesman for Comfort Products, Jan Hamill, said from Dallas that the firm president, Margaret Alivizatos, was in Washington to meet with commission officials to ``discuss a plan to meet the commission's concerns about the Comfort Tote.'' The company, in a statement attributed to Alivizatos, said, ``We anticipate that our company and the commission will reach agreement on this plan promptly and tat it will be implemented as quickly as possible.'' Eight of the 19 reported deaths occurred in Texas. Of the other deaths, there were two each in Florida, Oklahoma and one each in Arkansas, California, Hawaii, Illinois, Missouri, North Carolina and Virginia. Two retailers, J.C. Penney Co., Inc. and the Army and Air Force Exchange Service, which sold one brand of the cushions worldwide at post and base exchanges, have joined the recall effort. However, the commission said none of the reported deaths involved cushions sold by those retailers. The recall includes: _467,000 ``Mothers Helper'' cushions made by Hollander Home Fashions in Newark, N.J. Hollander said last month it had recalled its cushions in January. _110,000 ``Gold Bug Support Sacks'' made by Gold, Inc. of Denver. _35,700 ``Cozy Cushions'' made by Pinky Baby Products of Houston. _12,000 ``Cozy Baby'' pillows manufactured by Cozy Baby Products of Mount Vernon, N.Y. _3,000 ``Baby Minder'' cushions made by The Fourth Little Pig of San Anselmo, Calif. _125 ``Baby Sak'' pillows made by Baby Sak of Pembroke Pines, Fla. Consumers should contact the manufacturers or retailers for details on how to return or exchange the pillows for a refund or other products, officials said. Additionally, the commission said consumers who know of deaths they suspect may be connected with infant pillows should call the CPSC hotline at 1-800-638-2772.

DOC.HEAD: OPEC Agrees to Hold Emergency Meeting to Halt Price Slide
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 5th graf pvs, `The May... to UPDATE with closing prices; PICKS UP 6th graf pvs, `The market...
DOC.TEXT: Crude oil futures rose sharply Thursday after OPEC ministers agreed to hold an emergency meeting on May 2 to try to brake the recent price slide that pushed crude to its lowest levels in 16 months. Prices rallied immediately after word spread that the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries had decided to call a special session of its eight-member monitoring panel. Sadek Boussena of Algeria, the cartel's acting president, said an urgent meeting was necessary ``given the persistence of the deterioration registered on the international oil market.'' ``This meeting will examine the measures needed to halt the constant degradation of the market and to raise prices so as to re-establish them at the level set by OPEC,'' Boussena said in a statement released by Algerian officials in London. The May contract for West Texas Intermediate, the benchmark U.S. crude, jumped $1.10 per 42-gallon barrel to settle at $18.06 on the New York Mercantile Exchnage. Other contracts also gained. ``The market has decided to take it very bullishly,'' Nick Antill, analyst at the London-based investment firm of County NatWest, said of OPEC's announcement. The crude had been trading in the range of $20 to $21 a barrel early in April. It plummeted nearly 90 cents in the two previous sessions, finishing at its lowest since December 1988. Prices have been pummeled on reports that OPEC was exceeding its own output limits at a time of seasonal declines in demand by oil consuming nations. The average price of seven crudes used as the cartel's reference plummeted to $15.38 a barrel last week, compared with $17.12 a barrel in the first week of April and well below OPEC's target price of $18 a barrel. Boussena, who is Algeria's mines minister, said all 13 OPEC members would attend the special session, although it technically was a meeting of the cartel's eight-member price monitoring committee. OPEC's mid-year conference, previously scheduled for May 25, has been postponed until June 25 to give time for the market to move to a ``better balance between supply and demand,'' he said. Analysts estimated the cartel was pumping more than 24 million barrels of crude a day, well over its ceiling of 22.1 million barrels a day for the first half of the year. Kuwait and the United Arab Emirates, which persistently have cheated on their OPEC supply quotas, have been blamed for producing most of the cartel's excess crude. On Tuesday, the oil ministers of Saudi Arabia, Kuwait and the United Arab Emirates met in Saudi Arabia and called on all members to abide by their production quotas. But the markets reacted skeptically to the ministers' statement and prices continued sliding. Antill said that if the emergency session had not been scheduled, ``things looked bleak.'' But now, he said, ``there's potential for some sort of upside'' movement of prices earlier than expected. Lucy Mullins, analyst at London's Barclays de Zoete Wedd, said the ministers' decision to call the meeting ``indicated they are very severely concerned'' about the fall in prices. She said it indicated that they intend ``to take positive moves to shore up oil prices.'' Analysts had been predicting prices would weaken in the April-June period when warmer temperatures reduce oil demand in the United States and other consuming nations. But they were surprised by the sudden plunge that began last week. Prices were expected to strengthen in June when demand for gasoline picks up at the start of the summer driving season.

DOC.HEAD: How Some Leading Companies Have Responded to Environmental Movement
With BC-Corporate Ecology
DOC.TEXT: Here is a list of some leading American corporations and examples of what they say they are doing as part of their sensitivity and commitment to the environment: AMANA: Has developed a companywide employee recycling program for newspapers, plastic jugs and motor oil. All proceeds from sales of recycled material will be donated to a non-profit environmental group. AMOCO CHEMICAL: Has reduced disposal of hazardous waste by 87 percent. ARCO CHEMICAL: Has promoted the antifreeze agent propylene glycol over the more toxic ethlyene glycol. DU PONT: Plans to reduce air emissions by 60 percent in three years and is developing alternatives to chlorofluorocarbons. Oil subsidiary Conoco has ordered two double-hulled tankers and plans to add more. EATON: Has promoted use of recycling and reduction of hazardous wastes in its manufacturing processes. GENERAL ELECTRIC: Is evaluating products based on their environmental impact and plans to invest $200 million in environmental projects this year. GENERAL MILLS: Has required use of recycled papers in all cereal boxboard and has banned use of heavy metals in printing inks. GENERAL MOTORS: Has announced intent to mass-produce an electric car. H.J. HEINZ: Has developed easy-recycling ketchup bottles and pledged not to buy tuna caught by fisherman who trapped dolphins. IBM: Has achieved 84 percent recycle rate for hazardous waste and reduced chlorofluorocarbon emissions by at least 25 percent. Plans to recycle 50 percent of solid waste by 992 and eliminate CFC emissions by 1993. JOHNSON & JOHNSON: Has announced expanded companywide recycling program that originates at the employee's desk and eliminated use of styrofoam cups in the workplace. KODAK: Plans to recycle disposable cameras and is spending more than $140 million to improve chemical storage and slash toxic emissions by 1995. MCDONALD'S: Has cut 1 million pounds of waste by shortening straws, and uses recycled paper for napkins and trays. Has pledged to use recycled products in at least 25 percent of annual expenditures on restaurant construction and equipment. MONSANTO: Has pledged to cut hazardous air emissions at plants worldwide by 90 percent by 1992 and will spend $600 million on environmental programs over the next two years. PACIFIC GAS & ELECTRIC: Has joined with environmental groups to joint projects including a $10 million study of energy efficiency. PROCTER & GAMBLE: Has reduced the size of packaging components and is experimenting with the recycling of disposable diapers. Is marketing detergents in recycled plastic. SCOTT PAPER: Has sponsored plastic-foam recycling in Washington and tree-planting campaigns. Plans to award high-school scholarships to students in Scott communities who plan to pursue environment-related studies. SHELL OIL: Has promoted sales of a new ``environmentally enhanced'' gasoline that it says cuts emissions. 3M: Has pioneered a companywide effort to reduce solid and hazardous waste and announced plans to reduce all hazardous emissions by 90 percent. UNION CARBIDE: Recycles or reuses half its hazardous solid wastes and plans to spend $310 million over four years on the environment and recycling ventures.
DOC.NOTE: End adv for Sunday April 22

DOC.HEAD: Profit Falls 53 Percent in First Quarter
DOC.TEXT: Union Carbide Corp. said Thursday its net income fell 53 percent in the first quarter because of weaker chemical prices and extreme cold at the end of the year that shut down some southern facilities. The chemicals and plastics company reported it earned $94 million, or 66 cents per share, in the quarter ending March 31, down from $201 million, or $1.44 a share, a year ago. The company had sales of $2.17 billion, down 3 percent from $2.24 billion in the first quarter of 1989. Union Carbide attributed the decline to weaker chemical volumes and prices, as well as shutdowns and maintenance because of the extreme cold that struck the nation late last year and early January. The cold affected Union Carbide's chemical plants in Texas City and Seadrift, Texas, and Taft, La., said company spokesman David N. Kernis. The company said the earnings do not include recently announced sales of chemical businesses by Union Carbide's chemical and plastics subsidiary. Union Carbide reported $1.28 billion in sales from its chemicals and plastics businesses, down 15 percent from the first quarter of 1989. Sales from its industrial gases division were up 32 percent, to $718 million. Sales from its carbon products unit fell 10 percent to $175 million.

DOC.HEAD: Moody's Puts Citicorp Ratings Under Review
DOC.TEXT: Moody's Investors Service on Thursday placed its ratings on Citicorp short-term and long-term debt under review for possible downgrade because of problems involving the bank's real estate and Third World loans. The credit rating agency also said it was reviewing some ratings of Citicorp subsidiaries including Citibank NA. Citicorp, the nation's largest banking company, on Tuesday reported that first-quarter earnings declined 56 percent predominantly because of problems associated with loans associated with a declining real estate market. The move by Moody's affects $31 billion in credit held by the parent company and $7 billion by subsidiaries. Moody's said the review will focus ``on the risks associated with Citicorp's high asset concentrations,'' particularly commercial real estate, highly leveraged transactions and Third World loans. Citicorp is the nation's largest lender for real estate. Some developers in regions of the country have been unable to repay loans to many banks because of a glut of new buildings that has caused prices to fall. ``The review also will include an assessment of Citicorp's capital adequacy when adjusted for these risks, as well as an evaluation of the outlook for the firm's core profitability,'' Moody's said in a statement. Citicorp in the first quarter charged off $135 million of commercial loans in developing countries, including $56 million of real estate loans, mostly in North America. Also, Citicorp charged off about $40 million of loans to finance corporate takeovers or other heavily indebted borrowers. In its statement, Moody's also said it would ``considser Citicorp's strengths, which include an attractive and profitable consumer franchise and significant diversity in its business.'' A credit downgrade could increase substantially the cost of borrowing for Citicorp and its subsidiaries.

DOC.HEAD: McDonald's Profit Up 12 Percent; Plans Switch To Low-Fat Dairy Foods
DOC.TEXT: Fast-food giant McDonald's Corp. on Thursday reported a 12 percent increase in its first-quarter profit and announced plans to switch from ice cream drinks and desserts to low-fat dairy foods and fruit sorbet. The company recently was criticized publicly by a Nebraska millionaire who placed national newspaper ads saying McDonald's foods are too fatty. McDonald's reported net income of $158.1 million, or 43 cents per share, for the three months ending March 31, compared with $141.7 million, or 38 cents per share, for the same period a year ago. First quarter revenue rose 11 percent to $1.5 billion from $1.4 billion, McDonald's said in a statement from its headquarters in the Chicago suburb of Oak Brook. Systemwide sales, including sales at franchised outlets as well as company-owned stores, climbed 9 percent to $4.3 billion from $3.9 billion. Chairman Michael Quinlan said in a statement the company's business remained strong despite intense competition and a slower U.S. economy. Responding personally for the first time to the recent attack on the fat content of McDonald's foods, Quinlan said McDonald's offers ``high-quality and wholesome food, which fits comfortably into a well-balanced diet.'' He said McDonald's would make the switch to low-fat milk shakes, low-fat frozen yogurt and orange sorbet ice by May 15. The chain already has added no-fat, no-cholesterol apple bran muffins and cereals to its breakfast menu, Quinlan said. ``The low-fat milk shakes contain significantly less fat than the current milk shakes, but retain the same great taste,'' Quinlan said. Earlier this month, Nebraska millionaire Phil Sokolof bought full-page ads in major U.S. newspapers saying McDonald's foods are too fatty. He called on the restaurant chain to cut the fat content of its hamburger meat by 10 percent. McDonald's first responded that it was experimenting with using vegetable shortening instead of lard for frying its french fries and hash browns. The company then went on the attack itself by sending letters to newspapers advising them that Sokolof's ad was inaccurate and warning them not to print it again. McDonald's spokesman Chuck Ebeling said Thursday McDonald's had been planning the switch to low-fat dairy products since last fall. He said the company chose to announce the change at this time to combat public perceptions that may have been created by Sokolof's campaign. Ebeling said McDonald's wanted ``to demonstrate the fact that, first of all, Sokolof is all wet in implying there's too much fat in McDonald's menu and in inferring we haven't been doing everything possible to enhance our menu in every way that's feasible with respect to nutrition and good health. ``Our menu is balanced and nutritious as it stands,'' Ebeling said. ``These things are just an enhancement to it.'' McDonald's also has taken steps recently to combat perceptions that its heavy use of plastic and polystyrene foam contributes greatly to pollution. McDonald's began a pilot program last year in 250 New England restaurants that promote recycling of polystyrene food containers and other plastics. Earlier this week, McDonald's announced plans to spend 25 percent of its $400 million-a-year construction budget on recycled materials. The company also plans to use recycled paper for carryout bags at 500 of its outlets.

DOC.HEAD: Profit Falls at Weyerhaueser, Champion in 1st Qtr
DOC.TEXT: Weyerhaeuser Co. said Thursday its earnings fell 12 percent in the first quarter, while another paper products, Champion International Corp., reported a 39 percent profit decline for the same period. Weyerhaeuser, based in Tacoma, Wash., reported it earned $130.1 million, or 61 cents a share, compared with $148.1 million, or 70 cents a share, a year earlier. First-quarter sales slipped 1.7 percent to $2.28 billion from $2.32 billion. George H. Weyerhaeuser, chairman and chief executive, told the annual shareholders meeting that the weakness in pulp and paper products was only partially offset by better results in forest products and other areas. Champion, based in Stamford, Conn., said a softer market for paper products led to its profit decline for the quarter. It reported net income of $70 million, or 67 cents per share, in the quarter ending March 31, compared to $114 million, ot $1.16 a share, a year ago. Revenue held steady at $1.3 billion. The company attributed the earnings decline to softer markets for some paper products, as well as outages while it expanded and improved several mills. Andrew C. Sigler, Champion's chairman and chief executive officer, called the earnings disappointing but said in a statement that business was ``reasonably good.'' ``We are right in the thick of our capital program to reduce costs and increase productivity,'' he said. ``We're paying for it now because of the many outages, but we're already seeing positive results. The full returns will come in over the course of the next several years.'' Net sales from Champion's paper operations were $1.02 billion, up slightly, while income was $149.6 million, down from $211.6 million in the first quarter of 1989. Champion said income from its packaging operations was even with last year, although results were down in other segments, including domestic printing and writing papers, publication-grade paper, pulp operations in the U.S. and Canada, and newsprint operations. Net sales for wood products were also down, from $273 million to $262 million. Income was down from $23 million to $20 million.

DOC.HEAD: Boston Hotel Workers Union Inspires Affordable Housing Law
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 6 grafs to move up first reference to Hotel and Restaurant Employees Local 26; picks up 7th graf, ``It's going ...
DOC.TEXT: A small group of mostly immigrant workers who speak 87 languages among them are responsible for federal legislation allowing labor unions to negotiate for affordable-housing assistance. The success by Hotel and Restaurant Employees Local 26 stemmed from the strength of its 5,000 members, hotel and food service workers who struggled to eke out a living in one of the country's most expensive cities, local president Domenic Bozzotto said Thursday. ``It shows that when people get together over social responsibility, you can build community,'' said Bozzotto. ``This is what America is all about. We've shown all the cynics that America's not dead. We're still in love with America. Our parents told us anything could be done here and we're not jaded yet.'' Union officials from New Jersey to California called the Local 26 offices Thursday to ask about the legislation President Bush signed into law Wednesday. It was the first significant change in the Taft-Hartley Act in 20 years and the first time a local union _ as opposed to an international union _ had effected a change, Bozzotto said. Taft-Hartley has been the nation's overriding labor relations law for 43 years. It includes anti-corruption provisions prohibiting management from making direct payments to unions except for certain purposes such as employee education, health care and retirement. The amendment adds housing to that list. It became necessary after Local 26 negotiated in 1988 an unprecedented agreement with nine Boston hotels requiring employers to place money in a housing trust fund that could be used to finance housing purchases and rentals. ``It's going to have a huge impact _ it's the new benefit of the '90s,'' said Bruce Marks, housing director for Local 26 as he fielded calls for information from unions and employers. The cost of the housing trust fund for employers for Local 26's members is $1.5 million during the three-year contract. In contrast, dental insurance in the contract will cost $2 million. Officials from the Teamsters union, United Auto Workers, the firefighters' union in Toledo, Ohio, the United Food and Commercial Workers in Michigan and the policemen and city workers' unions in New York City were among callers. New York City unions were particularly interested because most city workers are required to live in one of the five boroughs, known for their expensive housing. The housing assistance plan may someday be brought to the bargaining table, said Michael Musuraca of District 37 of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees. Some employers are amenable. Peter van Kleeck, president of Saunders Hotels Co. in Boston said he was first ``surprised'' at the demand but later became ``much more convinced.'' ``We agreed to it voluntarily,'' Carl Madda, director of labor relations for the Sheraton Corp., said in a brief statement. ``We were satisfied by the negotiation. We hope it works out.'' The legislative success is a story that began, according to union officials, with universal predictions of failure. ``They said, `You're nuts.' But we take our philosophy from the Reverend Jesse Jackson. Never surrender,'' said Bozzotto, a union official since 1981. Bozzotto, 50, said he is typical of union members he said pushed for the legislation. The son of an Italian immigrant who worked as a cook in a Boston hotel, Bozzotto began work at age 13 as a hotel dishwasher. He later moved up to busboy and waiter. He worked in hotels to pay his way through college. ``It's brutal work,'' said Bozzotto. ``People only see the front part of a hotel. If you're in the back, in the bowels of the kitchen or the laundry room working in all that heat or steam, it's hard, hard work.'' He said most members of Local 26 work two or three jobs to meet living costs. The average price of a single-family house in the Boston area is $190,000 and an average two-bedroom apartment runs about $800 a month.

DOC.HEAD: Knight-Ridder Posts Profit Increase, Affiliated Posts Profit in 1st Qtr
DOC.TEXT: Knight-Ridder Inc. posted a 25 percent increase in its first-quarter profit on Thursday, while Affiliated Publications Inc. said it had a profitable quarter in contrast to a loss in the same period a year ago. A third media company, Pulitzer Publishing Co., said its profit tumbled in the first three months of the year. Knight-Ridder, based in Miami, said it earned $25.8 million, or 50 cents per share, in the three months ended March 31 compared with $20.5 million, or 39 cents a share, a year earlier. First-quarter revenue rose 2.6 percent to $554.9 million from $540.7 million. ``The quarter's results were favorably impacted by significantly lower newsprint prices, lower interest costs, a cut in our losses in Detroit, good performances from our Business Information Services Division and various joint ventures and approximately 800,000 fewer shares outstanding,'' said senior vice president and chief financial officer Robert F. Singleton. The company's newspaper division posted lower earnings of $63.7 million, down from $64.6 million in the first quarter last year. Singleton said the calendar was partly to blame for lower earnings as rthere was one fewer Sunday than a year ago. The business information services division had an operating profit of $4.5 million, up 31.3 percent over last year's $3.4 million. Knight-Ridder's interests include 29 daily newspapers, business news and information services, news, graphics and photo services as well as cable television and newsprint manufacturing. Boston-based Affiliated Publications, which publishes The Boston Globe, said it earned $6.5 million, or 9 cents a share, in the three months ended April 1 in contrast to a loss of $9.9 million, or 14 cents a share, in the sasme period in 1989. Revenue edged up to $133.7 million from $131.0 million a year ago. The 1989 results reflected charges related to Affiliated's share of losses from its former investment in McCaw Cellular Communications Inc. of Kirkland, Wash. The stake has since been sold. Despite the improvement, the company said its results were adversely affected by softness in advertising volume at the Globe. Affiliated Publications is the parent company of the Globe Newspaper Co. and BPI Communications Inc., a leading publisher of specialty magazines, books and electronic data bases for the entertainment, arts and design markets. Pulitzer Publishing, based in St. Louis, Mo., blamed a 70 percent decline in its first-quarter earnings on lower results at the St. Louis Post-Dispatch and costs involved in the purchase of a New Orleans television station. The company reported earnings of $906,000, or 9 cents per share, on revenues of $95 million for the first quarter, compared with earnings of $3 million, or 29 cents per share, on revenues of $94 million a year ago. ``The Post-Dispatch is confronting the effects of expanded competition in a soft economy, as well as difficult labor negotiations,'' said Chairman Joseph Pulitzer Jr. The decreased earnings also reflect costs connected with the acquisition of WDSU-TV in New Orleans in December. Pulitzer's newspaper operations include two major metropolitan dailies, the Post-Dispatch and The Arizona Daily Star in Tucson, and newspapers and shoppers in the Chicago area, including the Southtown Economist, a suburban daily and Sunday newspaper. Pulitzer's broadcasting operations consist of seven network-affilitated television stations _ WYFF in Greenville, S.C.; WEAL in Lancaster, Pa.; WXII in Winston-Salem, N.C.; KOAT in Albuquerque, N.M.; KETV in Omaha, Neb.; WLKY in Louisville, Ky.; and WDSU in New Orleans. Pulitzer also owns radio stations KTAR-AM and KKLT-FM in Phoenix.

DOC.HEAD: Lockheed Says Simmons' Suit Is `Pure Harassment'
DOC.TEXT: Harold Simmons' lawsuit challenging the legality of the proxy war he lost for control of Lockheed Corp. is ``pure harassment'' and without merit, Lockheed Chairman Daniel Tellep said Thursday. The company also reported that first quarter profits rose 11 percent because of lower tax payments. Simmons' federal suit, filed Wednesday, asks either for a new election or that his nominees for Lockheed's board be declared the winners. It alleges Lockheed illegally engineered extra proxy votes through an employee stock ownership plan and played a variety of dirty tricks to defeat Simmons. ``The results of the election were clear and decisive,'' Tellep replied in a statement from Lockheed's headquarters in suburban Calabasas. ``We are extremely disappointed that Simmons has chosen to ignore the independently certified results despite losing the election by over a 20 percent margin.'' Tellep suggested again that Simmons was interested more in his own investment than the good of the company. ``We view this action by Simmons as nothing more than pure harassment,'' Tellep said. ``Simmons' action confirms our view that he is interested only in advancing his own agenda at the expense of other Lockheed shareholders.'' Lockheed and Simmons also revealed Thursday they each spent about twice as much as they originally estimated in fighting their five-week battle, which culminated at the aerospace company's annual meeting March 29. The incumbent board was retained by about a 3-2 margin. Lockheed spokesman Stephen Chaudet said the company spent $15 million to persuade shareholders to re-elect the board of directors. It originally estimated spending would total $8 million. Simmons, the Texas billionaire who owns about 19 percent of Lockheed's stock, spent more than $10 million compared with an initial $6 million estimate, said his chief strategist, J. Landis Martin. Martin said Simmons bought about a dozen ads in national newspapers and in smaller papers in areas where Lockheed does business. That was twice the number he had anticipated, he said. Simmons also spent far more than expected on mailings to Lockheed shareholders, particularly participants in the employee stock ownership plan, Martin said. Chaudet also attributed Lockheed's extra expenses mainly to the costs of newspaper advertisements and shareholder mailings. Separately, Lockheed said profits rose to $69 million, or $1.09 a share, in the first three months of the year from $62 million, or $1.04 a share, a year earlier. Sales rose 8 percent to $2.25 billion from $2.09 billion, an increase spread fairly evenly across the corporation, Tellep said. Program profits were unchanged at $114 million, but Lockheed spent $13 million less on income taxes than in the 1989 period, helping to boost net profits. Martin, Simmons' chief lieutenant and the head of N.L. Industries, through which Simmons bought his stake in Lockheed, declined to comment on the results. Simmons contends that Lockheed, the nation's sixth largest defense contractor, has been mismanaged under Tellep's leadership. His lawsuit contends the employee stock ownership plan, which also owns about 19 percent of Lockheed's stock, is ``an illegal entrenchment device'' set up by the board to put a large block of stock in friendly hands. If the plan's votes and a few so-far challened proxies were thrown out, Simmons' nominees would have won the election, the suit contends. It also says Lockheed moved up the annual meeting date by six weeks to rob Simmons of time to campaign, failed to mention Simmons' nominees in its proxy material, and denied Simmons a chance to present his case to members of the employee stock ownership plan.

DOC.HEAD: Filmed Entertainment Division Helps Push MCA Inc. Revenues to Record High
DOC.TEXT: MCA Inc. said its first quarter net income rose 16 percent and revenues jumped 30 percent because of strong gains at the company's filmed entertainment division. MCA Chairman Lew R. Wasserman said Thursday that net income rose to $31.6 million, or 42 cents a share, from $27.3 million, or 37 cents a share, in the first three months of 1989. Revenues rose to $912.9 million from $703.3 million. Bolstered by such box-office hits as ``Born on the Fourth of July'' and ``Back to the Future Part II,'' the filmed entertainment group reported record first quarter revenues of $548.8 million, compared with $396.7 million a year earlier. The division also was bolstered by the success of such home-video releases as ``Field of Dreams,'' ``Parenthood'' and ``Uncle Buck.'' MCA said the division's foreign television sales were down, though. Television revenues were $160.5 million, down from $169.4 million. Revenue from MCA's Universal Studios tour rose to $24.9 million from $23.9 million.
